fields.headline: Bench-bound Owen looking for lift-off
fields.trailText: On the basis of statistics Michael Owen should be first choice up front, but his chances of starting tonight look slim. Jon Brodkin has a word about club and country.
fields.body:
Cast your mind back three years to St-Etienne or two weeks to Rome. Consider also the Michael Owen goals that earned England draws against Brazil and France in between. The very thought of his being ignored by club or country might seem ridiculous.

Yet two months past his 21st birthday Owen finds himself guaranteed nothing. Neither at Anfield nor with England can he count on a place in the side. Forced to watch from the bench as Liverpool, led by Emile Heskey and Robbie Fowler, won the Worthington Cup on Sunday, he can expect more of the same against Spain tonight. Even more galling, Heskey and Fowler are blocking his path again.

On the basis of statistics he should be the first forward on Sven-Goran Eriksson's team-sheet. His strike rate of a goal every three games for England (from 24 caps) is matched in this squad only by Paul Scholes and is beaten by no one. Andy Cole and Kevin Phillips have yet to find the net for their country; Heskey has one goal from 11 internationals, Fowler three from 15.

With Eriksson having announced yesterday that he will play with split strikers, Owen's chances of starting look slim. He was relegated to the bench when Kevin Keegan played Teddy Sheringham behind Cole in France last September, coming on to equalise.

It is pace, direct running and instinctive finishing which mark Owen out, more than an ability to hold play up and work with his back to goal. But he feels he can adapt to whatever Eriksson requires.

"You have got to be ready for any system," he says. "He has said he prefers a back four and it could be fighting for one place or it could be fighting for two.

"I don't think many teams in the Premiership play with two out-and-out strikers. At Liverpool one of us has always got to drift off, so a striker could play in that position in behind as well."

As a fierce competitor who cannot sit still for more than half an hour and almost never watches a film all the way through, being stuck on the bench must be unbearable. With Gérard Houllier's rotation system, though, he is there regularly at Liverpool. In the squad 30 times this season, he has played all through only six games.

Three days after his match-winning brace in Rome he found himself back on the bench for Liverpool, and despite missing from the spot against Roma at Anfield he craved to be part of the shoot-out and all that went before in Cardiff.

"Football's like that," he says. "You're on top of the world one minute and not playing the next. Emile Heskey was the opposite way round: he never played in Rome and played in the final. Obviously I wanted to play on Sunday but I've played in some big games and missed some, and so has everyone else."

What he did not miss were the Worthington Cup celebrations: "At the hotel we had a buffet and a bit of a disco. It was the first thing most of us have won so it was a good night."

Owen feels he is coming back to his best after having his season interrupted by a freak head injury in October. Before that he had scored eight goals in 11 games, and the self-belief remains undented.

"If I'm fit and training every day," he says, "I've no doubt I will be in the Liverpool team and playing for England."

webTitle: Beckham leads team with United look

fields.headline: Beckham leads team with United look
fields.standfirst: New England will owe much to Old Trafford,  David Lacey  reports
fields.trailText: Seven Manchester United players could be in the starting line-up against Spain tonight, including captain David Beckham. David Lacey previews the curtain-raiser on Sven-Goran Eriksson's rein.
fields.body:
Tonight at Villa Park a bespectacled, soberly suited Swede with no known history of mental illness will begin his attempt to prove that the job of running the England football team is not best left to someone more in need of men in white coats than white shirts.

Sven-Goran Eriksson comes across as a coach of eminent good sense with no time for fanciful theories. For him, therefore, it is absolutely logical that for tonight's friendly against Spain David Beckham will keep the captain's armband he wore for the first time in Italy last November.

"I don't see any reason to change the captain," Eriksson said yesterday. "I hope he will keep the captaincy for a long time, but we've never looked at that. I think he can be a leader and I thought he did the job very well in Italy.

"I don't think that being captain is heavy work but it's important to have someone able to talk to the referee when it's necessary - and many times it is necessary."

Beckham, then, is Eriksson's first England captain largely because he was the man in possession when the Swede took over. And from the way Eriksson was talking yesterday it looks as if the Manchester United player will spend at least half of tonight's game in familiar company.

England's latest strip features a thin red line running down one side of the white shirt, designed to capture the spirit of St George. Yet Eriksson's initial starting line-up may well involve a much broader red reminder of the success of Sir Alex.

Ferguson, that is, at least six of whose players could kick off against Spain: Gary Neville and Wes Brown in defence, Beckham and Nicky Butt in midfield, and Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole up front. Should Paul Scholes recover from a stomach bug in time he could be a seventh, in which case United would equal Arsenal's 1935 record when seven of their players appeared against Italy in the notorious battle of Highbury.

"It would be ideal to have as many as possible from the same big club," Eriksson mused, "although so far I've only looked at the players as individuals." But if the coach feels that using a large part of Manchester United tonight will be more likely to help him formulate a team for the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania next month, that is what will happen.

Apart from naming Beckham captain the only information about his team Eriksson would divulge yesterday was that it would play in a 4-4-2 formation with one of the front pair playing off the other. "I think that playing two strikers up front doesn't work," he explained, "so maybe we'll play one up with one behind." Sheringham, Scholes and Robbie Fowler are each capable of the supporting role and clearly Eriksson has Emile Heskey earmarked as the main striker.

Eriksson has knocked around Europe for 25 years and knows a few international wrinkles at club level. A good result for England tonight, plus the performance to go with it, would quell the chauvinistic antipathy to the idea of a foreign coach.

The Football Association may see the next World Cup but one as the earliest that anyone can expect to see England re-emerge as a team capable of winning a major tournament but Eriksson will be judged by tomorrow's headlines, not those of 2006.

The size of the task facing him should not be underestimated. He is the fifth England coach in the 12 years that have elapsed since Bobby Robson's side reached the semi-finals of the 1990 World Cup.

Subsequently England have flopped under Graham Taylor, revived briefly under Terry Venables, found a short salvation under Glenn Hoddle and fallen apart under Kevin Keegan. Or to put it another way they have gone from Turnip to Tel-boy to trial by Drewery to tears before bedtime.

The least Eriksson deserves is a period of calm while he takes stock of his resources under match conditions. "I will be very, very happy if I know my best team after tomorrow's match," he said, "but football has never been that easy. I just hope I know more about England tomorrow night than I did three days ago."

Beating a Spain team rich in experience and technique would not be bad for starters. But if Eriksson's first England team turns out to be an uneasy hybrid and flops accordingly he will surely be in for an early bout of critical Swede-bashing.

Possible teams

England (first half, 4-4-2): Seaman; G Neville, Brown, Campbell, Powell; Beckham, Butt, Scholes, Barmby; Sheringham, Andy Cole.

England (second half): James; P Neville, Ferdinand, Campbell, Ashley Cole; Beckham, Carragher, Lampard, Barmby; Heskey, Fowler.

Spain (4-3-2-1): Casillas; Pablo, Paco, Abelardo, Sergi; Guardiola, Helguera, Luis Enrique; Mendieta, Raul; Urzaiz.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The Guardian graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: Here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.
fields.body:
Here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

As usual, we take a look at the best graduate jobs offered by Jobs Unlimited - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies.

For all you newly signed up graduates, one thing to watch out for with this email is the URL links included. All of them work but may be too long for your email format. If they do not work when you click on them, try cutting and pasting the whole URL (weird codes and numbers included) into your internet browser.

If you spent most of last Saturday in bed, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 24 February). Hilary Freeman asked the hitherto unasked question: are overweight graduates being overlooked in the work place? The obese not only find it hard to get that first job, but also progress less quickly.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,442194,00.html?bnr=grad.email

It also examined whether graduate schemes that send you on a whirlwind tour are a good introduction to the business or a one-way ticket to a state of confusion; and last week's 60 Seconds looked at the police.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,442198,00.html?bnr=grad.email

NEXT WEEK'S RISE looks at the issue of ethical careers. We've got ethical investments and foreign policies, why not ethical careers? We also look at the latest trends in CVs and discuss how to deal with a friend being promoted over your head.

This week's RISE GOLD gives some advice on how to get that job that's got your name on it. If at first you don't succeed ... apply, apply again.
http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3894896,00.html?bnr=grad.email

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP.
Don't be like St Andrews graduate Michelle Simmonds - only the third person to depart from Who Wants to be a Millionaire? without winning a penny. Start reading a paper every day - interviewers are going to want to see a passable general knowledge - it's not too late.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS
If you are a web-meister extraordinaire, the BBC has the job for you. Its news and sport online technical team is seeking a number of experienced and TRAINEE web producers and software developers to join a growing team.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888105190,00.html?bnr=grad.email

If maths and crops are your thing, the Institute of Arable Crops Research has a job that suits that unlikely combo. If you know what Stochastic dynamic models and computer modelling are, the job's probably already yours.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888105104,00.html?bnr=grad.email

If you have always wanted to get involved in the Organic movement and have an environmental degree, Sheepdrove Organic Farm is looking for a farm biodiversity officer - it's even got its own barn owls.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888104845,00.html?bnr=grad.email

If you are a graduate in teaching or media studies who suddenly yearns for summers off again, Syndenham Hill School in South London wants to put you through its grad training programme - you might have to do a bit of teaching.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888104637,00.html?bnr=grad.email

Property information firm IPD is looking for graduates to produce reports into the financial performance of property investments. You'll have a First and experience of quantitative analysis -let's hope they're paying big bucks.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888104114,00.html?bnr=grad.email

If you've always wanted to work in children's publishing and for a company with a great name, look no further. Tucker Slingsby is looking for a publishing assistant - it'll be worth it just to answer the phone.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888104079,00.html?bnr=grad.email

English heritage has a wicked part-time job for a researcher to be based in London's trendy Clerkenwell. It's only 18 hours per week but you'll be researching the area's rich architectural heritage. £25K pro-rata.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888104047,00.html?bnr=grad.email

If you've always thought you were destined to get your hands on some serious gems, www.cooldiamonds.com is looking for a young graduate to help expand its internet diamonds business in Hatton Garden - must have an intimate knowledge of HTML.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888103870,00.html?bnr=grad.email

And finally, FTSE big-boy Euromoney Institutional Investor is looking for grad trainee journalists. Candidates should, apparently, have a genuine interest in journalism, a strong academic record and an inquisitive nature. Well you would, wouldn't you
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,8888103851,00.html?bnr=grad.email

webTitle: Owen, Cole and Powell start for England

fields.headline: Owen, Cole and Powell start for England
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has chosen a strike force of Andy Cole and Michael Owen and handed Chris Powell his England debut for tonight's friendly against Spain.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has chosen a strike force of Andy Cole and Michael Owen and handed Chris Powell his England debut for tonight's friendly against Spain.

Elsewhere the side is much as expected: David James get the nod over David Seaman in goal, while Sol Campbell and Rio Ferdinand will be the centre-back pairing in defence.

In midfield, Nicky Butt, alongside his Manchester United team-mates David Beckham and Paul Scholes, gets his chance to impress in the absence of Steven Gerrard while Nicky Barmby will play on the left.

Full team: David James (Aston Villa); Phil Neville (Manchester United), Sol Campbell (Tottenham Hotspur), Rio Ferdinand (Leeds United), Chris Powell (Charlton Athletic); Nicky Barmby (Liverpool), Nicky Butt (Manchester United), Paul Scholes (Manchester United) David Beckham (captain), (Manchester United); Andy Cole (Manchester United), Michael Owen (Liverpool)

webTitle: Politically motivated complaints make standards system a farce, says Clarke

fields.headline: Politically motivated complaints make standards system a farce, says Clarke
fields.trailText: The former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, launched a bitter attack yesterday on aspects of            parliament's regulatory system, saying it fed "cynicism and apathy" and would drive good people            out of public life.
fields.body:
The former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, launched a bitter attack yesterday on aspects of parliament's regulatory system, saying it fed "cynicism and apathy" and would drive good people out of public life.

The MP, giving evidence to the Commons standards and privileges committee , said some of the complaints against MPs were "obviously ridiculous and politically motivated" and led journalists to write up stories in a "snide and suggestive fashion".

Only "the more shameless crooks" would become MPs if it continued, he warned.

"At least half" of all complaints made to the standards and privileges committee since 1997 had been petty or malicious, Mr Clarke said. The list read like a Who's Who of British politics, proving they were made to attract damaging publicity, he told the committee.

The former minister singled out in the "absurd" category complaints about William Hague's free use of a private gym John Prescott's use of a subsidised flat and the fees for John Major's and Ken Livingstone's lucrative speaking engagements.

He also strongly defended the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, from accusations of advocating policies to benefit his paid consultancy with a US oil company.

He said no MP or journalist believed that his consultancy with oil company Kerr McGee, "which did not own a single petrol station" benefited from Tory policies advocating cuts in petrol prices.

The committee is examining tighter rules forcing MPs to declare fees and contracts for outside speaking engagements and insisting that employment contracts are deposited in parliament revealing exactly how much money they receive.

Mr Clarke, who opposes this, told the committee: "MPs are entitled to the same level of privacy that other citizens are entitled to expect in their activities outside parliament."

He added: "We do appear to be racing towards the American position, whereby individual tax returns and health records are made freely available to the public."

Later Sir Nicholas Lyell, the attorney general in Mr Major's government, called for one aspect of the rules to be tightened up - a proposal to exempt declarations of hospitality from regional quangos and the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland governments.

He also strongly defended the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, from accusations of advocating policies to benefit his paid consultancy with a US oil company. He said no MP or journalist believed that his consultancy with oil company Kerr McGee, "which did not own a single petrol station" benefited from Tory policies advocating cuts in petrol prices. The committee is examining tighter rules forcing MPs to declare fees and contracts for outside speaking engagements and insisting that employment contracts are deposited in parliament revealing exactly how much money they receive. Mr Clarke, who opposes this, told the committee: "MPs are entitled to the same level of privacy that other citizens are entitled to expect in their activities outside parliament." He added: "We do appear to be racing towards the American position, whereby individual tax returns and health records are made freely available to the public." Later Sir Nicholas Lyell, the attorney general in Mr Major's government, called for one aspect of the rules to be tightened up - a proposal to exempt declarations of hospitality from regional quangos and the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland governments.

webTitle: Milburn plans to cut death rate of poor

fields.headline: Milburn plans to cut death rate of poor
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today signal a historic shift in NHS policy when he announces a 10-year plan to reduce infant mortality and premature adult deaths in the poorest parts of England.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today signal a historic shift in NHS policy when he announces a 10-year plan to reduce infant mortality and premature adult deaths in the poorest parts of England.

In a speech that is meant to unveil the "big idea" for Labour's general election manifesto on health, he will announce the first government targets to reduce the most flagrant examples of health inequalities that are blighting the lives of the poor.

Unlike previous targets for reducing NHS waiting lists and increasing the input of re sources flowing into the service, the new targets will focus on health outcomes.

The first will be to save the lives of at least 3,000 children a year by bringing infant mortality rates in the poorest areas closer to the national average.

The second will be to reduce the gap in life expectancy that causes people in the poorest areas to die about seven years earlier than their contemporaries in more prosperous areas. Similar targets are expected in the manifestos for Scotland and Wales.

"For too long the health debate in this country has been focused on the state of the nation's health service and not on the state of the nation's health," Mr Milburn will say in a speech in London to the Long Term Medical Conditions Alliance, a group of patients' organisations.

"The progress we have made in our first term allows us to set a new ambition for the second term. It is to undertake the biggest assault our country has ever seen in health disadvantage - to start to break the link between poverty and ill health ... to improve the health of the poorest fastest."

The drive against infant mortality was triggered by government figures showing six children in every thousand died before their first birthday in poor areas, compared with a national average of 5.5. Mr Milburn will pledge to reduce the gap by at least 10% by 2010.

He will set a similar target to reduce inequalities in the adult death rate. Figures from the office of national statistics show life expectancy for men in England ranged from 70.1 to 78.4 years and for women from 76.8 to 83.5 years.

Mr Milburn will say it is unacceptable that a boy from the most disadvantaged social group will live nine years less than a boy from the most disadvantaged. A boy born in Manchester can expect to die seven years earlier than a boy from Oxfordshire.

Policies to close the inequality gap would initially be directed at health authorities where the problem is greatest.

These areas will get a larger share of the growth in the NHS budget. Policies will include extension of the Sure Start programme to help pregnant women and their partners, better health education in schools and an intensive drive to cut smoking and reduce coronary heart disease. There will be a new health poverty index to measure health inequalities more accurately.

As a first step, Mr Milburn will today start to provide 80,000 children aged four to six with free fruit during every school day. It was being billed by the Department of Health last night as the biggest health promotion initiative in schools since the start of free school milk in 1948.

webTitle: Comment: Blair's new map goes nowhere

fields.headline: This is Blair's new road map, but it leads nowhere
fields.standfirst:
He calls it his 'Third Way, Phase Two'. It is vague and useless
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Blair calls it his 'Third Way, Phase Two'. It is vague and useless
fields.body:
A plethora of plans pours from the government - crime, schools, transport, health - a manifesto unfolding week by week. But what's the big idea, the glue? Ideology was never Tony Blair's thing. Indeed his lack of it was his chief USP - a new-minted man with a third way that was progressive, pragmatic and free floating. Now, as he tries to catch this butterfly and pin it down on the page in an article in this month's Prospect, it flaps away, evading his grasp altogether.

The essay caused not a ripple in this country but it was spread across the front page of La Repubblica in Italy. Les Echos in France has reprinted it, Die Zeit in Germany follows. Latin America and parts of Asia are espousing third way political language too. Hardly surprising since it is the perfect vehicle in which troubled traditional socialist parties can drive away from a failing past into a more inclusive centre-left future. It is the ideal political portmanteau for our times - flexible, agile, chameleon. (Astonishingly, the Washington Post reports that even George Bush was toying with using it himself.)

But for a Labour party that has already made the long march centrewards, the third way is now utterly redundant. Worse, it muddies the waters, hides its light under a bushel. What Tony Blair calls his "Third Way, Phase Two" is a useless road map for present policy and an even vaguer guide to future intent. Inside the Downing Street thinkery they say they are searching for a "narrative", the missing red thread to guide them through this thicket of policy. That is only half true. Sometimes they want a narrative but sometimes they prefer muddy water. As soon as a policy threatens to define them, they rush out a counter-policy to confuse. The third way is an escape from self-definition - a butterfly always on the wing.

No wonder every politician everywhere reaches for it: the third way temptingly offers the best of all possible worlds. It means never having to choose, all the old lions and lambs happily snuggling down together. Successful business goes hand in hand with caring social objectives, dynamic markets embrace strong social communities. With felicitously crafted language, all goals can become mutually dependent, never competing. So the values of Europe, " fairness, solidarity" can combine with "the economic dynamism traditionally associated with the US". (No mention of the stark choice these societies make in tax rates, with concomitant very different results). Toughness on crime never works without tackling its causes, he says - punishment and pity side by side. (No contradiction between tabloid-pleasing and what works.) Decentralising power can cohabit with uniform standards. (No tug-of-war between local choice and national benchmark.) Reversing national decline and improving productivity can be done with green sustainable development. Yes, the third way offers all this, with no awkward choices.

Those who shuddered a bit on hearing a Labour prime minister declare on television, in Camp David casual wear, that he and Dubya had many "shared values", might rightly wonder what they are. Oil, guns, missiles, electric chairs . . . Even allowing for realpolitik, straddling the Atlantic will get harder if obedient bombing of Iraq against the rest of world opinion is the price of a relationship greatly less special since Clinton's departure. Europe will tug harder in the other direction: Blair assurances may be blown apart over NMD.

Curiously, the government does not always live up to third way flexibility. Mark this extract from the Blair text: The third way "does not (his italics) stand for rigid forms of state ownership or provision. It is pragmatic as to whether public or private means are the best delivery mechanism". Robert Kiley, the New Yorker at the end of his tether bargaining with the Treasury over control of London Underground, finds an ideological obduracy that makes Mrs Thatcher look pliable. Now even the Tories have abandoned tube privatisation, yet this PPP is still being imposed relentlessly, a long-term political disaster saster. (Financial risk is not really transferred to the private sector - but blame for every late train will be transferred to the Treasury.) Not pragmatism but dogmatism.

Next week Tony Blair makes a key environment speech: it will be visionary stuff. But there will be just one substantial matter - a genuine test as a battle is fought out behind the scenes. He will announce new money for renewable energy - currently Britain will not meet its target 10% energy from renewable sources by 2010. Wind power is now almost at a competitive price - but it needs the same kick-start other countries give it.

D enmark has stolen ahead in wind machine exports. Solar power is further from competitive price, but will be a winning technology. While Germany and Japan offer big solar subsidies, the US commissions a million subsidised solar roofs, but Britain is doing virtually nothing. It is like ignoring the early stages of the micro-chip. The Treasury is offering token sums for wind, nothing for solar - short-sighted and wrong-headed. Given the Blair essay's praise for new technology, if there is less than £500m for both technologies, his words will be empty: even that will not hit the 2010 target. In the end, there are always choices.

Does it matter if this government has no better self-definition than third way evasions? It does well enough on the big issues - the economy, poverty, gradually improving public services. The election is already won. So why yearn for sharp edges? Because hazy feel-good language does not announce which way Labour will jump when the going gets tough. As yet untested, how will Labour respond when a threatening Conservative opposition eventually rears its head? In an economic downturn, we need to know what comes first - business and taxpayers or preserving the public sector? So far, buttering up business has meant choosing no legislation on work/life balance to ease the gross over-work burden on families. Yesterday it meant announcing no enforcement of equal pay for women. With the Treasury over-flowing, the long-term need for higher taxes is obscured, but there is a choice between low tax and high public service.

This feeble third way language is too weak a light on the leader's helmet to shine the way. Odd that a government radical enough to promise an end to child poverty, unemployment and third world debt should so lack a resonant philosophy to encapsulate its own best qualities. It deserves a bolder legend. Bolder language might even stiffen its own nerve, as well as inspiring stronger allegiance. It is not easy to govern a modern fissiparous, pluralist and diverse society where each individual has multiple roles and contradictory interests. But that is all the more reason to plant a flag or two to rally round. It may not be cynicism but lack of tribal passion that is killing politics.

webTitle: Impatient Nick Brown unmoved by critics

fields.headline: Impatient Brown unmoved by critics
fields.standfirst:
Dismay at Tory stance key to reluctance to debate crisis

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who is leading the battle against the nationwide outbreak of foot and mouth disease, found himself fighting on a second front yesterday as senior Conservatives attacked his handling of the crisis.
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who is leading the battle against the nationwide outbreak of foot and mouth disease, found himself fighting on a second front yesterday as senior Conservatives attacked his handling of the crisis.

Some MPs found Mr Brown's tone during Monday's Commons statement unsympathetic to the farmers' plight. Although many Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs were supportive, some Tories were angry at Mr Brown's apparent reluctance to embrace the Opposition's decision to stage a three-hour debate on the foot and mouth crisis today. Mr Brown told MPs that such a debate was a waste of ministerial and official resources at a critical time. He restated his position on his return from briefing EU colleagues in Brussels yesterday.

"It's not debates in parliament that control the disease, it's hard veterinary work on the ground. We should all be working together to exterminate the disease. I deplore people turning this into a party political issue," he said.

Labour MPs admitted yesterday that Mr Brown had got this a bit wrong. "He should have said 'I'll give the house regular statements instead'," conceded one colleague. "He sounded tetchy, but he must be tired and under pressure," said another.

What most MPs seem to have forgotten is the history that lies behind the tiff. When the Phillips report on the great BSE disaster - home-grown, unlike the almost-certainly imported foot and mouth outbreak - was published last October, some Labour MPs were cross that the agriculture minister refrained from putting the party political boot in on culpable Tory ministers and their policies.

That did not incline the Tory agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo to soft pedal last week, though he pulled back in the Commons on Monday, adopting what Brown called "a welcome change of tone".

It came too late to placate officials at the Ministry of Agriculture. "Yeo was very critical of ministers, vetinerary staff and officials. It's a bit disheartening and Nick's fed up with it," explained one ally. Such is the ill-will that Mr Brown has not felt able to call in Mr Yeo, an amiable lightweight on the Tory left, to brief him. Mr Brown can point to support from fellow EU farm ministers, not always a charitable lot where Britain is concerned. Several have contrasted their own states' dithering over the slaughter of potentially-at-risk herds with Whitehall's steely determination to act fast and firmly.

Asked if he had been criticised by any of them, Mr Brown yesterday told reporters: "Absolutely not. All expressed their sympathy both in public and private. There is nothing but goodwill to Britain in our plight."

Mr Brown, 50, a former advertising executive with Procter and Gamble in Newcastle, his adopted city, came to agriculture in 1998 after being moved sideways from chief whip.

"My local NFU like him because he's pragmatic and level-headed. He doesn't pretend to be an expert," a young Essex MP said yesterday.

"Welsh farmers like him because he talks straight, tells them what he knows and what he doesn't. There's no spin," said a Welsh veteran.

webTitle: Deafening silence as countryside dies a slow death

fields.headline: Deafening silence as countryside dies a slow death
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: In Poe's story The Masque of the Red Death, the countryside is gripped by a terrible plague. Inside the castle, a magnificent ball continues, the aristocrats feasting, drinking and dancing, oblivious to the mayhem which is about to bring their doom upon them.
fields.body:
In Poe's story The Masque of the Red Death, the countryside is gripped by a terrible plague. Inside the castle, a magnificent ball continues, the aristocrats feasting, drinking and dancing, oblivious to the mayhem which is about to bring their doom upon them.

So it was rather like the Commons yesterday. To be fair, no one was swilling champagne or filling their dance card. They just didn't have time to discuss foot and mouth. It might as well not have been happening; it didn't impinge. The routine of parliament continued like a stately gavotte.

As Paul Tyler, the Lib Dem MP for north Cornwall put it, farmers in his constituency couldn't believe what was happening. "Nobody can claim that the Commons is doing its duty," he said. He'd told a farmer that MPs were to spend the first part of the day merely chewing over the timing of the hunting bill. The farmer had replied: "But my representatives are surely more concerned with what is really going on in the countryside."

(When MPs quote their constituents, even Cornish farmers, they always speak in this stilted oratorical manner. But I feel sure the sentiment was accurately expressed.)

The whole event did have a weird, disjointed, unreal air. Mike O'Brien, the minister in charge of getting the anti- hunting bill through the house, was appalled by the suggestion that Scottish MPs should not be allowed to vote, since the Scottish parliament can make up its own mind on this issue.

"A ridiculous suggestion!" he stormed. "May I remind you that the powers of the Welsh and Scottish parliaments are subordinate to this parliament and their powers depend on this parliament!" As chopped logic goes, Delia would have been proud of that. ("I like to chop a generous handful of logic and a few sprigs of parsley in the Magimix ...")

It turned out that parts of the bill had been drafted by an anti-hunting organisation called Deadline 2000. This body had generously agreed to exclude deer stalking from the bill. Nicholas Soames was disgusted, but then he often is. Mr Soames does disgust as vividly as the late Kenneth Williams did camp. He asked the Speaker: "In your long and distinguished experience in this house," he boomed, ironically I suppose, "can you ever recall the government sub-contracting the writing of a bill to something called ..." (pause for majestic expression of contempt) "Deadbeat 2000?"

The Speaker replied and I couldn't make out a word he said. But I'm sure it was full of robust common sense.

Sir Patrick Cormack was just as appalled at the decision to guillotine the debate. "We have had the long parliament and the short parliament," he announced. "This is the supine parliament! It is ..." - and I can only do justice to Sir Patrick's superlative diction by quoting him phonetically - "the dee-nigh-grated par-lee-ah-ment!"

They moved on to debate the fallen stock service, by which hunts haul dead animals away from farms to feed to their hounds. This saves both farmers and huntsmen a lot of money. Some Labour MPs seemed to feel that the hunts should keep this service even after hunting is banned.

Mr Soames was even more appalled, if that were possible. Did they imagine that hunts would continue to pay for their packs, their staff, their kennel-maids and everything else, purely in order to relieve farmers of this task? Were they mad? (I paraphrase, but not much.)

The debate proceeded on its slow, pre-destined course. Outside the palace we could discern the screams of the dying, but then again, it might just have been the wind in the trees.

He'd told a farmer that MPs were to spend the first part of the day merely chewing over the timing of the hunting bill. The farmer had replied: "But my representatives are surely more concerned with what is really going on in the countryside." (When MPs quote their constituents, even Cornish farmers, they always speak in this stilted oratorical manner. But I feel sure the sentiment was accurately expressed.) The whole event did have a weird, disjointed, unreal air. Mike O'Brien, the minister in charge of getting the anti- hunting bill through the house, was appalled by the suggestion that Scottish MPs should not be allowed to vote, since the Scottish parliament can make up its own mind on this issue. "A ridiculous suggestion!" he stormed. "May I remind you that the powers of the Welsh and Scottish parliaments are subordinate to this parliament and their powers depend on this parliament!" As chopped logic goes, Delia would have been proud of that. ("I like to chop a generous handful of logic and a few sprigs of parsley in the Magimix ...") It turned out that parts of the bill had been drafted by an anti-hunting organisation called Deadline 2000. This body had generously agreed to exclude deer stalking from the bill. Nicholas Soames was disgusted, but then he often is. Mr Soames does disgust as vividly as the late Kenneth Williams did camp. He asked the Speaker: "In your long and distinguished experience in this house," he boomed, ironically I suppose, "can you ever recall the government sub-contracting the writing of a bill to something called ..." (pause for majestic expression of contempt) "Deadbeat 2000?" The Speaker replied and I couldn't make out a word he said. But I'm sure it was full of robust common sense. Sir Patrick Cormack was just as appalled at the decision to guillotine the debate. "We have had the long parliament and the short parliament," he announced. "This is the supine parliament! It is ..." - and I can only do justice to Sir Patrick's superlative diction by quoting him phonetically - "the dee-nigh-grated par-lee-ah-ment!" They moved on to debate the fallen stock service, by which hunts haul dead animals away from farms to feed to their hounds. This saves both farmers and huntsmen a lot of money. Some Labour MPs seemed to feel that the hunts should keep this service even after hunting is banned. Mr Soames was even more appalled, if that were possible. Did they imagine that hunts would continue to pay for their packs, their staff, their kennel-maids and everything else, purely in order to relieve farmers of this task? Were they mad? (I paraphrase, but not much.) The debate proceeded on its slow, pre-destined course. Outside the palace we could discern the screams of the dying, but then again, it might just have been the wind in the trees.

webTitle: This is Blair's new road map, but it leads nowhere

fields.headline: This is Blair's new road map, but it leads nowhere
fields.standfirst: He calls it his 'Third Way, Phase Two'. It is vague and useless
fields.trailText: February 28: Blair calls it his 'Third Way, Phase Two'. Polly Toynbee is not impressed.
fields.body:
A plethora of plans pours from the government - crime, schools, transport, health - a manifesto unfolding week by week. But what's the big idea, the glue? Ideology was never Tony Blair's thing. Indeed his lack of it was his chief USP - a new-minted man with a third way that was progressive, pragmatic and free floating. Now, as he tries to catch this butterfly and pin it down on the page in an article in this month's Prospect, it flaps away, evading his grasp altogether.

The essay caused not a ripple in this country but it was spread across the front page of La Repubblica in Italy. Les Echos in France has reprinted it, Die Zeit in Germany follows. Latin America and parts of Asia are espousing third way political language too. Hardly surprising since it is the perfect vehicle in which troubled traditional socialist parties can drive away from a failing past into a more inclusive centre-left future. It is the ideal political portmanteau for our times - flexible, agile, chameleon. (Astonishingly, the Washington Post reports that even George Bush was toying with using it himself.)

But for a Labour party that has already made the long march centrewards, the third way is now utterly redundant. Worse, it muddies the waters, hides its light under a bushel. What Tony Blair calls his "Third Way, Phase Two" is a useless road map for present policy and an even vaguer guide to future intent. Inside the Downing Street thinkery they say they are searching for a "narrative", the missing red thread to guide them through this thicket of policy. That is only half true. Sometimes they want a narrative but sometimes they prefer muddy water. As soon as a policy threatens to define them, they rush out a counter-policy to confuse. The third way is an escape from self-definition - a butterfly always on the wing.

No wonder every politician everywhere reaches for it: the third way temptingly offers the best of all possible worlds. It means never having to choose, all the old lions and lambs happily snuggling down together. Successful business goes hand in hand with caring social objectives, dynamic markets embrace strong social communities. With felicitously crafted language, all goals can become mutually dependent, never competing. So the values of Europe, " fairness, solidarity" can combine with "the economic dynamism traditionally associated with the US". (No mention of the stark choice these societies make in tax rates, with concomitant very different results). Toughness on crime never works without tackling its causes, he says - punishment and pity side by side. (No contradiction between tabloid-pleasing and what works.) Decentralising power can cohabit with uniform standards. (No tug-of-war between local choice and national benchmark.) Reversing national decline and improving productivity can be done with green sustainable development. Yes, the third way offers all this, with no awkward choices.

Those who shuddered a bit on hearing a Labour prime minister declare on television, in Camp David casual wear, that he and Dubya had many "shared values", might rightly wonder what they are. Oil, guns, missiles, electric chairs . . . Even allowing for realpolitik, straddling the Atlantic will get harder if obedient bombing of Iraq against the rest of world opinion is the price of a relationship greatly less special since Clinton's departure. Europe will tug harder in the other direction: Blair assurances may be blown apart over NMD.

Curiously, the government does not always live up to third way flexibility. Mark this extract from the Blair text: The third way "does not (his italics) stand for rigid forms of state ownership or provision. It is pragmatic as to whether public or private means are the best delivery mechanism". Robert Kiley, the New Yorker at the end of his tether bargaining with the Treasury over control of London Underground, finds an ideological obduracy that makes Mrs Thatcher look pliable. Now even the Tories have abandoned tube privatisation, yet this PPP is still being imposed relentlessly, a long-term political disaster saster. (Financial risk is not really transferred to the private sector - but blame for every late train will be transferred to the Treasury.) Not pragmatism but dogmatism.

Next week Tony Blair makes a key environment speech: it will be visionary stuff. But there will be just one substantial matter - a genuine test as a battle is fought out behind the scenes. He will announce new money for renewable energy - currently Britain will not meet its target 10% energy from renewable sources by 2010. Wind power is now almost at a competitive price - but it needs the same kick-start other countries give it.

D enmark has stolen ahead in wind machine exports. Solar power is further from competitive price, but will be a winning technology. While Germany and Japan offer big solar subsidies, the US commissions a million subsidised solar roofs, but Britain is doing virtually nothing. It is like ignoring the early stages of the micro-chip. The Treasury is offering token sums for wind, nothing for solar - short-sighted and wrong-headed. Given the Blair essay's praise for new technology, if there is less than £500m for both technologies, his words will be empty: even that will not hit the 2010 target. In the end, there are always choices.

Does it matter if this government has no better self-definition than third way evasions? It does well enough on the big issues - the economy, poverty, gradually improving public services. The election is already won. So why yearn for sharp edges? Because hazy feel-good language does not announce which way Labour will jump when the going gets tough. As yet untested, how will Labour respond when a threatening Conservative opposition eventually rears its head? In an economic downturn, we need to know what comes first - business and taxpayers or preserving the public sector? So far, buttering up business has meant choosing no legislation on work/life balance to ease the gross over-work burden on families. Yesterday it meant announcing no enforcement of equal pay for women. With the Treasury over-flowing, the long-term need for higher taxes is obscured, but there is a choice between low tax and high public service.

This feeble third way language is too weak a light on the leader's helmet to shine the way. Odd that a government radical enough to promise an end to child poverty, unemployment and third world debt should so lack a resonant philosophy to encapsulate its own best qualities. It deserves a bolder legend. Bolder language might even stiffen its own nerve, as well as inspiring stronger allegiance. It is not easy to govern a modern fissiparous, pluralist and diverse society where each individual has multiple roles and contradictory interests. But that is all the more reason to plant a flag or two to rally round. It may not be cynicism but lack of tribal passion that is killing politics.

webTitle: PM aide to fight safe seat

fields.headline: PM aide to fight safe seat
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: One of Tony Blair's most long-standing and youthful aides, James Purnell, has been selected for a safe Labour seat.
fields.body:
One of Tony Blair's most long-standing and youthful aides, James Purnell, has been selected for a safe Labour seat.

Mr Purnell, 31 on Friday, has been selected for the safe seat of Stalybridge and Hyde, in Greater Manchester, in an open selection. He worked for Mr Blair in opposition, before joining the BBC as a strategic adviser and then joining the No 10 policy unit.

London-born Mr Purnell's ability to win a safe Labour seat against strong local competition will be a relief to Mr Blair, who in the past has been accused of imposing Blairite candidates against the wishes of local constituencies.

There has been speculation that the prime minister wants to impose a string of talented candidates at the last minute, but Millbank believes Downing Street has learnt its lessons from previous efforts to control nominations from the centre.

Mr Purnell won on the first ballot. He succeeds Tom Pendry, the former shadow sports minister, in a seat Labour has held since 1945.

Hilary Benn, a former employment department special adviser, won Leeds Central in a byelection, and Jon Cruddas, Downing Street's former trade union liaison officer, was selected for the safe seat of Dagenham, in Essex.

In selections to come, Tom Watson, an engineering union official, is expected to win the nomination for West Bromwich East. Kevin Jones, a GMB official, is a strong runner for Durham North.

fields.headline: Hague backtracks on tube sell-off
fields.trailText: William Hague will abandon Conservative plans to  privatise the London Underground today, intensifying  speculation that Michael Portillo is strengthening his  grip on party policy - and pushing towards the centre  ground.
fields.body:
William Hague will abandon Conservative plans to privatise the London Underground today, intensifying speculation that Michael Portillo is strengthening his grip on party policy - and pushing towards the centre ground.

The announcement, leaked last night, prompted the Tory right to claim that Mr Hague is increasingly a prisoner of his shadow chancellor who is busily courting what remains of the party's leftwing at Westminster with a view to a post-election leadership contest.

Faced with the deepening unpopularity of privatisation in the wake of Railtrack's problems, the Tories have decided to give their support to the alternative being proposed by Bob Kiley, the transport commissioner appointed by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone.

The latest Tory u-turn comes as Tony Blair struggles to get Mr Kiley the overall manage ment control he seeks within the broad framework of John Prescott's public/private partnership for revitalising the long-neglected underground.

Mr Kiley, an American whose smooth-talking popularity the Tories acknowledge, could be asked to chair a management board on which the three private firms running the underground will sit. "We've got to give this man a fair wind," one Hague aide said last night.

Within the Conservatives, the responsibility for junking the privatisation plan originally drawn up by John Redwood lies with the shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, and his transport spokesman, Bernard Jenkin - though Mr Portillo and Mr Hague have endorsed it.

The Redwood plan would have created park-and-ride schemes, competing underground lines, user-friendly stations and - in theory - given £750m back to the Treasury. Hague advisers said last night that "events have moved on" and that practical politics dictate that Mr Kiley deserves a chance.

Mr Redwood, former Welsh secretary and a failed Tory leadership candidate, thinks it is disastrous that some colleagues continue to speculate about Mr Hague's future so close to a spring election, when 56% of voters are said to be dissatisfied with his performance as party leader. "It's stupid and deeply disloyal," one Redwood supporter said.

Talk about a post-election leadership contest infuriates the Portillo camp, which says it is powerless to prevent people claiming to be "friends of Michael" spreading stories which they say are damaging both to him and to the authority of Mr Hague, already battered by polls which show him trailing up to 20% behind Labour under Tony Blair.

"There are no outriders licensed to speak for Michael," advisers said last night. The finger of suspicion is largely directed at a wider group of supporters. But Mr Portillo's decision to address the Mainstream group of Tory moderates at next weekend's spring conference in Harrogate has also contributed to the speculation about his intentions.

Moderate MPs have been making friendlier noises about Mr Portillo since he embraced a socially inclusive agenda. That, too, has offended the right.

Ann Widdecombe is not seen as whispering against "William" and believes he will survive if he can win 40 seats and get the Conservatives back above 200 MPs. But some MPs say Iain Duncan Smith and David Davis, both on the right, are quietly positioning themselves in case Mr Hague is voted out by MPs.

Tory jitters about their party's likely fate in an election were enhanced last night by private Liberal Democrat polling among 1,200 voters in key seats. The results are said to show that 66% think Mr Hague would say anything to get elected. His personal ratings are reported to be low among voters in terms of qualities of leadership and honesty.

fields.standfirst: From Simon
fields.trailText: Don't listen to that Sam geezer. His brain's obviously been addled by one too many Tooheys. Has he not sat for an entire day until his arse goes numb staring at the rain trickling down the windows of his hostel? Has he not been blown from pillar to post around the streets of Wellington by the hurricane gales? Has he not marvelled at the complete lack of anything to do that doesn't involve getting cold, wet and/or injured?
fields.body:
Milly,

Don't listen to that Sam geezer. His brain's obviously been addled by one too many Tooheys. Has he not sat for an entire day until his arse goes numb staring at the rain trickling down the windows of his hostel? Has he not been blown from pillar to post around the streets of Wellington by the hurricane gales? Has he not marvelled at the complete lack of anything to do that doesn't involve getting cold, wet and/or injured?

If you're still determined to go (and I'm sure they'll let you change your ticket even at this late stage) just make sure you pop into Woolies first and pick up a large supply of books.

And some mittens.

Have fun with your mum.

Simon

webTitle: In brief: Spielberg cameos for Cruise, Cruz and Crowe

fields.headline: Spielberg cameos for Cruise, Cruz and Crowe
fields.standfirst: Plus: Lee Evans joins bumpy comedy; Aardman in the race with The Tortoise and the Hare; Wes Craven takes on Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
fields.trailText: Plus: Lee Evans joins bumpy comedy; Aardman in the race with The Tortoise and the Hare; Wes Craven takes on Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
fields.body:
LATE UPDATE

 Eagle-eyed film fans will be able to spot a small cameo appearance by Steven Spielberg in the forthcoming Tom Cruise film, Vanilla Sky. Spielberg was apparently visiting Cruise on the set of the film in New York when the film's director Cameron Crowe asked him if he would sit in on a scene. The Oscar-winning director agreed and can be observed in the background of a restaurant scene involving Cruise and his Spanish co-star Penelope Cruz.

 British comedian Lee Evans is rumoured to be joining Bill Murray and John Cusack in the black comedy Bump And Run. The £30m movie focuses on a casino host who inherits an American football team from his father. The 35-year-old former stand-up won praise for his performance in the 1995 film Funny Bones and has also won parts in The Fifth Element and There's Something About Mary.

 The Aardman animation team behind hit movie Chicken Run have let slip some details about their next project, The Tortoise And The Hare. Although at least two years away from being released, Peter Lord and Nick Park have described the film as being: "A sort of Spinal Tap meets Aesop's Fables!" Michael Caine and comedian Paul Whitehouse are rumoured to be providing some of the voices for the film, which Lord describes as: "A modern take on the tale with a documentary element to it."

 Nightmare On Elm Street director Wes Craven has agreed to direct a new film version of Dr Jekyll And Mr Hyde, according to reports this afternoon. Craven will apparently update the classic horror story and turn it into more of a thriller, giving it a completely different title.

webTitle: Where will future farmers come from?

fields.headline: Where will future farmers come from?
fields.trailText: Who'd be a farmer? Anyone who doesn't want to farm, apparently. Agricultural training in Britain's colleges and universities has attracted fewer applicants than last year and those who are going don't want to grow food - they want to grow horses or golf courses.
fields.body:
Who'd be a farmer? Anyone who doesn't want to farm, apparently. Agricultural training in Britain's colleges and universities has attracted fewer applicants than last year and those who are going don't want to grow food - they want to grow horses or golf courses.

Last week's outbreak of foot and mouth disease is only the latest in a long line of disasters that have afflicted British agriculture, sending the industry into crisis. Universities and colleges training people to earn their living off the land have felt the effects. Applications for degree level courses remained stable this year but there are concerns about the quality of applicants. Numbers in agricultural training as a whole are down from last year.

"In 1998-9 there were 103,487 students on land based courses in the UK, we expect that number to be lower for last year. The industry is in crisis, prices are depressed," said Richard Winterton director of development services at Lantra, the private charity set up by the Department for Education and Employment to monitor and co-ordinate the agricultural training.

That sort of picture might miss the point, according to Howard Petch, the secretary of the National Association of Principal Agricultural Education Officers who represent over sixty educational organisations, including universities like Bath, Bristol, Cambridge and Leeds.

"The numbers applying for some sub-areas are down, but some are up. Agricultural training is no longer just about farming, it includes amenity, landscape, equestrian, environment, pet care, floristry or leisure. In a lot of these areas, numbers are up. One even might have concerns about whether the industry can absorb the numbers coming in," said Petch.

And there's the rub: raising horses, looking after pets or raising flowers may be popular courses with students, but according to Lantra, they are not necessarily what the industry most needs. Their top priorities are farm management skills and relevant scientific, environmental and technological knowledge.

webTitle: New test may boost state school pupils at university

fields.headline: New test may boost state school pupils at university
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: American-style aptitude tests could help universities to identify more bright students from poor-performing schools, a government adviser said yesterday.
fields.body:
American-style aptitude tests could help universities to identify more bright students from poor-performing schools, a government adviser said yesterday.

Up to 1,300 students in 70 British secondary schools took a short version of the US scholastic aptitude tests, known as SATs, last year, involving short verbal reasoning and maths tests, in a study commissioned by millionaire philanthropist Peter Lampl, an adviser to the Higher Education Funding Council for England.

In the study, carried out by the National Foundation for Educational Research, 30 students from state schools scored more than 1,200 in the tests - a level considered sufficient for entry to American ivy league universities, where the test is almost universal.

But only one achieved 3 As at A-level, the entry requirement for Oxbridge. Throughout the study, SATs scores "were only modestly associated" with A-level grades.

Mr Lampl said the results could mean that the test could complement A-levels and broaden university intake without lowering standards.

webTitle: Staff to send pupils home in workload row

fields.headline: Staff to send pupils home in workload row
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: As many as half a million youngsters face being sent home from school on reduced timetables from next week, after teachers voted overwhelmingly in favour of industrial action over staff shortages.
fields.body:
As many as half a million youngsters face being sent home from school on reduced timetables from next week, after teachers voted overwhelmingly in favour of industrial action over staff shortages.

The results of the first ballots were announced yesterday among members of the two biggest teaching unions, the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, employed in state schools in Greater London and Doncaster.

In the first wave of action, which could take place once employers have been given seven days' notice, they will introduce "part-time schooling" by refusing to cover for unfilled, permanent posts and staff absences of longer than three days.

The disruption will be the first to hit classrooms in England since the mid-1980s, when teachers took action over extra workload triggered by the Sats tests. It is bad news for Labour so close to the expected election.

Ministers said the action would be "counter-productive", damaging children's education, while headteachers agreed the impact would be "devastating".

Announcing the results, the union leaders forecast that one in three schools where ballots have been held could be forced to send children home because there was no one to teach them. That could involve about 1,000 of the estimated 3,000 primary and secondary schools where ballots have been held - up to around 500,000 youngsters.

The action is now set to spread to other parts of England, with further ballots in Manchester, Reading, Portsmouth, Southampton, Leicester, Middlesbrough, Nottingham and Kent.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, said: "Teachers in London and Doncaster have declared enough is enough; They rightly see no reason why they should paper over the cracks."

In the first ballots, held in schools in London and Doncaster, 93% of the participants voted for action but the turnout was just 30% in Greater London and 41% in Doncaster.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, warned: "Industrial action will not solve the recruitment problem. All it will do is make the task of raising standards and engaging children's commitments that much harder. If they are out of school they are not learning and if they are not learning the challenge for teachers becomes greater and the pressure increases.

"This therefore will be entirely counterproductive. What we need is positive ideas to build on the emerging success of the recruitment policy so that we can attract teachers back into the profession now as well as new recruits from September."

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "The impact will be devastating. Schools will be forced to send children home because there will be no teachers willing to cover and the chances of getting supply teachers are already past praying for."

webTitle: Comment: No religion in our schools

fields.headline: Bad faith
fields.standfirst:
The government has no business promoting religion in our schools, and deserves to be sued by parents

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: New Labour in power
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The government has no business promoting religion in our schools, and deserves to be sued by parents.
fields.body:
Is the government aware of the implications of its own legislation? This is not as naive a question as it sounds. For if education ministers find themselves short of bedtime reading in the next week or so, they might be well advised to acquire a copy of the Labour government's Human Rights Act, which came into force in October last year. I would recommend, specifically, that they study article 9, which guarantees freedom of thought, conscience and religion. And, when they have read it, the first paragraph may give them nightmares.

The point is that, if we all have the right in law to these freedoms, it opens up the prospect of a legal challenge to the government's plan to expand the number of church secondary schools. These schools would, presumably, incorporate Anglican, Catholic or Muslim beliefs into the everyday running of the school, and require children - and their parents - to observe the rituals and customs of that faith. They might well, as some primary schools already do, require regular attendance at Christian services (or a mosque or a synagogue), as a condition of getting into the school.

For parents who do not have religious beliefs, this poses a dilemma. If the only decent state secondary school in your area happens to be single-faith, do you pretend to convictions you don't have - and quite possibly find offensive - or jeopardise your children's education? I already have friends who are thinking seriously about starting to attend mass, even though they loathed their own Catholic upbringing, in order to get their children into a primary school with good results. This is particularly disturbing for mothers who are aware of the impact of the Vatican's entrenched misogyny on their own lives, and reluctant to expose their daughters to it.

This is, in effect, a form of discrimination against secular parents and their families. What makes it even more astonishing, at the beginning of the 21st century, is that it is being proposed by the state. The government has no business promoting religion, and what it does not seem to have realised, when it signalled its intention to expand the number of single-faith schools earlier this month, is that parents now have recourse to the courts if they wish to avoid making either of these unacceptable choices.

The first paragraph of article 9 reads in full: "everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; this right includes freedom to change his religion or belief and freedom, either alone or in community with others and in public or private, to manifest his religion or belief, in worship, teaching, practice and observance". It is abundantly clear that a child sent to a church school, where he or she is compelled to subscribe to a single faith as a condition of being there, is being denied the rights conferred by the Human Rights Act.

This is not an argument that aspects of religion should not be taught in schools; unlike religious bigots, who despise atheists like myself - I have the letters to prove it - I am happy for it to be there, as an optional subject and taught in the context of cultural studies. That is what living in a plural society means: giving people, and that includes children, a choice about what they believe in. It does not mean, as happened to the children of some friends of mine in an Oxfordshire village, being sent home from school with instructions to write a letter to God.

What I object to is children being indoctrinated in a single faith, at taxpayers' expense, and their parents forced to go along with it. This is no longer, as I have pointed out before, a Christian country, given that less than a million people, out of a population of 60m, attend Anglican services on Sundays. Even if it were, it is wrong in principle for state-funded schools to promote one religion over another, and to neglect other systems of thought, including humanism and atheism.

I recognised this myself as a teenager, with comical results. Pointing out that I was not compelled by law to attend the parts of morning assembly that involved Christian worship, I declared that I would not in future take part in it. This caused consternation, though not because I was the first child in my state school in Hertfordshire to exercise this right. The others were girls from other religions, Catholics or observant Jews; what the school had not previously encountered was a conscientious objector who just wanted to read Jackie.

What will happen to the next generation of 14-year-olds, packed off to Tony Blair's church secondary schools against their will? It is quite possible that some of them will decide that they don't want to attend mass or the local mosque; will the single-faith schools proposed in the green paper allow them to exercise freedom of conscience?

It is fortunate that, in a society increasingly aware of the importance of universal human rights, an act now exists to protect them. The irony, that it is the creation of this peculiarly narrow-minded government, is almost too delicious to contemplate.

fields.headline: Government cash for redundancy-hit area
fields.trailText: The government has thrown parts of the north-west a lifeline worth more than £600,000 in a bid to help the troubled region recover from the effects of a wave of industrial redundancies.
fields.body:
The government has thrown parts of the north-west a lifeline worth more than £600,000 in a bid to help the troubled region recover from the effects of a wave of industrial redundancies.

Nearly half a million pounds will go to help re-skill workers and create new business opportunities in Cumbria, which claims to have suffered from more than 1,200 lay-offs in the past six months.

The Wirral is to receive £140,000 to help local communities deal with the fallout from more than 400 redundancies recently announced by shipbuilder Cammel Laird. The bid was put together by the local training and enterprise council.

The funding, from the government's rapid response fund, is usually earmarked for areas that have suffered from one major industrial closure, such as that of steel giant Corus's Llanwern plant.

But the government has made an exception for Cumbria in recognition of the impact that a stream of redundancies from more than six companies are having on the county's economy.

Cumbria council leader Stewart Young said: "This news will act as a major boost to those areas in west Cumbria and Carlisle that are dealing with the recent spate of job losses It's terrible when someone loses their job through redundancy. Being able to offer practical help to get people retrained and supported through the difficult time as they come to terms with what has happened is essential."

The county put forward its bid in partnership with local employment agencies. The partnership will now have to find training and development agencies on which to spend the cash.

webTitle: Chatroom 'grooming' of children could be made illegal

fields.headline: Chatroom 'grooming' of children could be made illegal
fields.trailText: New laws to make the "grooming" of children by paedophiles through internet chatrooms illegal are being considered by the government, Tony Blair announced today.
fields.body:
New laws to make the "grooming" of children by paedophiles through internet chatrooms illegal are being considered by the government, Tony Blair announced today.

The surprise move comes after new evidence from Liberal Democrat MP Paul Burstow that as many as one in five children using online chatrooms has been approached by paedophiles.

The prime minister made the pledge in the Commons during question time - and just hours after the home secretary, Jack Straw, had a meeting to discuss the issue earlier today.

A spokesman for the home office confirmed: "It is one of a range of issues we are actively considering.

"Whether or not the current criminal laws are strong enough to prosecute for online soliciting is something we need to consider, as well as whether this could take the form of an amendment to an existing act or an entirely new bill."

Mr Blair was prompted to address the problems of youngsters being preyed on in Internet chatrooms after Mr Burstow  who is MP for Sutton and Cheam - called for the law to be changed to make "online grooming" a criminal offence.

Mr Burstow said last year a 12-year-old in his constituency had been approached through a teenage Internet chatroom by a paedophile.

"He groomed her online to entice her to an offline meeting for sexual purposes," said Mr Burstow. "As many as one in five children who use internet chatrooms are approached by paedophiles in this way."

Such a law has the backing of internet crusader and TV personality Carol Vorderman and the internet watch foundation.

However, a Whitehall insider said: "Pragmatically, there is not enough time this side of an election for this to happen  even if it got the go-ahead."

fields.headline: Labour vows to fight poverty
fields.trailText: Labour has pledged to put a war on poverty and poor health at the heart of its election manifesto.
fields.body:
Labour has pledged to put a war on poverty and poor health at the heart of its election manifesto.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today said Labour would concentrate on breaking the "vicious circle" of poverty and poor health and cutting the number of child deaths caused by poverty, should it win a second term.

Gaps in life expectancy between the most disadvantaged groups in society and the average person will be reduced by 10% by 2010, Mr Milburn added. The government also wants to cut the number of poverty-related child deaths by 10% over the same period.

In what is seen as a significant policy shift away from focusing on waiting list figures and short-term problems to long-term outcomes and life expectancy, the health secretary announced plans for a national health poverty index.

To be published from next year, the league table will rank areas according to how badly they are affected by the problems of poverty - including premature deaths and infant mortality.

Areas highlighted by the index as poverty blackspots will get more cash to help close the health inequality gap. Mr Milburn told a Royal College of Physicians conference today: "Health care in this country tends to focus on acute problems at the expense of managing and preventing chronic illness.

"For too long the health debate in this country has been focused on the state of the nation's health service and not the state of the nation's health.

"The biggest health improvement our country can make is to tackle unfairness."

He drew comparisons between poor health and poor education - saying both blighted too many communities and held too many people back.

"The vicious cycle of ill health, unemployment and poverty is mutually reinforcing," Mr Milburn added. "It costs the individual. It costs the health service. It costs the taxpayer. It must now be broken.

"The progress we have made in our first term allows us to set a new ambition for any second term. To now undertake the biggest assault our country has ever seen on health disadvantage."

At the moment, a boy born into the most disadvantaged group of society has a life expectancy of nine years less than one from the most affluent sector.

A girl born into the poorest section of society will on average live five years less than one in the most affluent group.

And death rates for children under one are more than three times higher in some of the worst-off areas in the country compared with the healthiest places.

From 2003, funding allocations for health authorities will reflect the health inequality gaps in different parts of the country, with those in the most disadvantaged areas given more money to tackle problems such as premature deaths and poor cancer survival rates.

The new health poverty index will take into account cancer survival rates, premature deaths and other statistics to show the differences between health authorities.

Mr Milburn said that the gap between the fifth of health authorities with the lowest life expectancy and the national average would be reduced by 10% over the next 10 years.

fields.headline: 'How could a vehicle get on to the railway?'
fields.standfirst:
Immediate reaction to the Selby train crash

Special report: Selby train disaster
fields.trailText: The Selby train crash in quotes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair, prime minister
"All our thoughts are with the dead and injured and their families and friends at this very difficult time. This is a quite horrendous accident which has shaken the whole country.

"As always, the emergency services have responded with great professionalism and I would like to thank them and all the people in the local community who continue to help in such awful circumstances."

John Prescott, deputy prime minister
"This is a dreadful accident at Selby. Our immediate concern is for the passengers who have died and others who have suffered so tragically."

Nick Brown, agriculture minister and MP for Newcastle East and Wallsend
"This will undoubtedly involve my friends and neighbours from Newcastle ? I am thinking of them."

Christopher Garnett, chief executive of GNER
"This is devastating. It is ghastly. We have people injured and people killed and our thoughts are with them and their families.

"I understand that a car came down the embankment and caused our train to derail. The train stayed upright, as it is designed to do. But the major problem happened when it came into contact with the freight train.

"The question has to be asked: How is it possible for a vehicle to come off the motorway and on to the railway?

"I have never seen anything like this before and I pray to God I never see anything like it again."

A Railtrack spokeswoman
"This seems to have been a tragic accident which has had appalling consequences. The passenger train travelled for about half a mile after the impact with the Land Rover and the rescue operation is now going on. Nigel Metcalfe, spokesman for Tees, East and North Yorkshire ambulance aervice

webTitle: 'People were screaming and covered with blood'

fields.headline: 'People were screaming and covered with blood'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: A drama student on board the Intercity train involved in today's crash told how passengers screamed as the impact happened.
fields.body:
A drama student on board the Intercity train involved in today's crash told how passengers screamed as the impact happened.

Janine Edwards, 22, of York, was travelling from the city to London for a drama college interview when the accident occurred.

She said: "It was still dark and at first I thought there was snow on the track. But it felt thicker than that, like grit.

"I was told later by a railway worker on the train that we were already derailed at this point.

"The train wasn't that busy because it was so early in the morning but there were about eight or 10 people in my carriage.

"I heard screaming and shouting and the lights went out. I held on to the table in front on me and then there was a huge impact.

"My carriage was on its side. I was lucky, I was still in my seat, clinging to the table.

"But one lady, who was travelling with her daughter, had been flung into the air and was lying in the next corridor. Her leg was trapped.

"The man opposite me was streaming with blood. The window next to him was smashed and the frame had come out and hit him.

"His wife sitting next to him was covered in his blood. She stayed really calm and found a towel to try to stem his bleeding.

"I think two people managed to scramble out of the carriage but I don't know how. Both ends were crushed.

"The smash happened at about 6.15am. I was unscathed, and I telephoned my dad.

"I told him it smelt of diesel and he urged me to get out. But I couldn't and thought it was safer inside.

"People were all phoning the police and ambulance but they seemed to take forever to get to us. We had to wait 45 minutes before they turned up.

"I was shaken and it was still dark and very cold.

"The daughter of the lady who was trapped was very upset. Her mum didn't know what was happening and didn't know who she was or where she was. I was cuddling her."
