webTitle: A disaster not of their making

fields.headline: A disaster not of their making
fields.standfirst:
While today's crash could not come at a worse time for the rail industry, writes Observer transport business editor Joanna Walters, for once it is blameless.
Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: While today's crash could not come at a worse time for the rail industry, writes Observer transport business editor Joanna Walters, for once it is blameless.
fields.byline: Joanna Walters, transport business editor, The Observer
fields.body:
Today's train crash could not have come at a worse time for an industry that is already in deep crisis in the aftermath of last October's Hatfield derailment.

While that incident cast doubt over the whole structure and management of the privatised railway with its fragmentation and profit motives, the central question in this latest accident is how a Land Rover managed to come off a motorway bridge and land on a mainline railway - into the path of two trains that had no time to stop.

The Highways Agency is responsible for the rules governing the strength, positioning, inspection and maintenance of road barriers and it is here that the spotlight must fall initially as members of the British Transport Police and her Majesty's Railway Inspectorate begin their investigations.

In the absence of solid information at this stage about why the Land Rover plunged off the road (after reportedly suffering a tyre blow-out) there is talk of a 'freak accident'. But there are usually important factors involved in any disaster of this kind that emerge during investigation and bring much wider issues into play.

Questions will have to be asked about the condition of the road surface and the roadside barriers on the bridge at the time of the accident, and about the strength of barriers on roads that take large volumes of traffic above other highways or railway lines.

It will also be necessary to test the driver of the Land Rover to see if he had any alcohol or drugs in his blood and to establish the speed and manner of his driving as well as the condition of his vehicle.

These are exactly the sort of investigations that would be carried out on a train, its driver and the track and signalling conditions at a crash site if the accident had only involved the railways.

It is especially worrying that a vehicle with the relatively small size of a Land Rover could plunge off the road and cause this disaster. With an estimated total weight for the Land Rover and the load it was towing of less than five tonnes, it begs the question of how vulnerable our road barriers are when articulated freight lorries typically weigh 38 tonnes. And it further brings into question the Government's intentions to raise the truck weight limit to 44 tonnes.

So is the beleaguered rail industry completely out of the blame frame on this one? The answer at this stage is probably. There will be searching questions about the condition and design of the wagons and carriages of each train as there always rightly are in such accidents, but rail experts are already pointing out that, despite the scenes of carnage, the passenger train stood up remarkably well to the impact of a near head-on crash at such high speed.

The Class 66 wagons on the Freightliner coal train are newly delivered from Polish manufacturers; the Mark Four coaches on the GNER passenger train are about 10 years old, and designed especially for the electrification of the East Coast Main Line. They were assembled at the old Metro Cammell works in Birmingham and are exactly the same class of coaches that were involved in GNER's derailment at Hatfield.

Experts are still studying the design of the buffet car after it was sliced by the lineside power pylon at Hatfield, which led to the four passenger deaths.

But in the case of today's crash, it is unlikely that GNER will be criticised. Both trains had cab radios connecting them directly to the nearest signalling centres, but there was simply no time for either driver to get a message across that would have shut down the system and prevented the collision.

It appears that the freight and passenger trains collided as little as 400 metres from the spot where the GNER train ploughed into the Land Rover. An intercity train travelling at the maximum of 125mph, as it is believed this one was, needs a mile to stop.

It is another bleak day for the rail industry. Even if it is completely acquitted in the ensuing investigation, the very occurrence of the fourth fatal crash in just three and a half years is a disastrous public relations blow for an industry on its knees after the horrific Southall, Ladbroke Grove and Hatfield crashes. This will further shake passenger confidence in train safety simply by association. In the current climate, where the public is calling for infrastructure-owner Railtrack to be renationalised, there will be a further outcry.

But the worst thing for people to do would be to lose faith in rail and jump into their cars. Whenever there is a train crash, the panicking public is always reminded that almost 3,500 people die on Britain's road every year - that's almost 10 every day - and that the railways are incredibly safe.

This message usually sounds rather hollow. First because people hand over control of their welfare to the train companies when they buy their tickets and climb aboard, second because the Southall, Ladbroke Grove and Hatfield crashes were entirely preventable and occurred because of varying degrees of industry complacency, incompetence and neglect.

It appears that today's crash and tragic fatalities could not have been prevented by any actions of the rail industry. Any further plunge in passenger confidence would be an overreaction.

fields.headline: 13 dead in train crash
fields.standfirst:
· 125mph passenger service hits freight train
· 70 injured
· Prescott visits scene of disaster
· Emergency hotline: 020-7834 7777

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Thirteen people have been confirmed dead today in a train crash that saw a high-speed passenger service smash into a car and a freight train in North Yorkshire.
fields.body:
Thirteen people have been confirmed dead today in a train crash that saw a high-speed passenger service smash into a car and a freight train in North Yorkshire.

Ian Griffiths, an inspector with British Transport Police, said that there were 40 walking wounded and 30 people with moderate injuries who had been cut from the wreckage of a GNER passenger train that had been travelling from Newcastle to London. An NHS spokesman said that 56 people have been taken to hospital.

After hours of work to free trapped passengers, the North Yorkshire ambulance service said it believes no one is left alive on board the derailed GNER train.

Divisional Officer Brian Bell, of the North Yorkshire fire service, said: "We have carried out four sweeps of the carriages and believe there is nobody alive left on board. There was an earlier report of a voice being heard in a buffet car. We have used listening devices and thermal imaging equipment in that area, but there has been no sign of life."

He said the death toll of 13 could rise once heavy lifting equipment was used to move the carriages.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, arrived on the scene and expressed sympathies for the families of the victims. He called for an interim report from the health and safety executive into the cause of the crash, and said he will make a statement to the House of Commons at 7pm tonight.

"Once I receive the interim report in the next few days, I will again make a statement to the House," he added.

The crash happened on the East Coast main line, near Selby, North Yorkshire, after the 4.45am Newcastle to London train smashed into a Land Rover car that had slid off an M62 motorway bridge.

A spokesman for Railtrack said it was believed the Land Rover, which was pulling a trailer, had suffered a blow out on the M62 and careered down an embankment before coming to rest on the rail line.

The driver, a 36-year-old man from Lincolnshire who escaped the crash unharmed, left the vehicle and rang 999 to warn that a car was blocking the track. This afternoon he was being interviewed by officers at Goole police station, East Yorkshire.

The driver of the passenger train, which had been travelling at 125mph, had reportedly spotted the vehicle on the track but was unable to stop in time. The impact knocked the train off the rails, but it continued to travel upright until it was hit by the freight train which was travelling at 75mph in the opposite direction.

A spokesman said the freight train driver spotted the danger but could not prevent the collision. All nine carriages of the passenger train were derailed.

The driver of the GNER train was seriously injured, British Transport Police said.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, and the Queen have both said their thoughts are with the relatives of those killed in the crash.

At Commons question time, Mr Blair described the accident as a "terrible tragedy" and promised the "fullest possible inquiry" into how it happened.

He told a hushed House: "Our thoughts and prayers are with the families, friends and relatives of those who died or were injured."

A Railtrack spokeswoman described the crash scene as "absolute devastation". She said: "Carriages have been overturned, they have gone down the embankment and into the field near the track."

The sound of desperate knocking was heard from within the twisted carnage, firefighters said. Rescue workers heard the sound of abandoned mobile phones ringing as friends and relatives tried to contact the victims.

The passenger train had left Newcastle and had stopped at Durham, Darlington, Northallerton and York.

The front three carriages appeared to have been smashed from the rest of the GNER train. The first carriage was almost vertical, lying back on the second one, while a third ended up in a field next to the track, which was surrounded by debris from the collision.

The freight train was carrying 1500 tonnes of coal and slid into the back garden of a house, crushing a caravan.

Crash survivor Laurie Gunson, of York, spoke of his experience from Pontefract general infirmary, where he was being treated for injuries.

He said: "I was travelling from York to London on business and was at the counter of the buffet car when the crash happened.

"The carriage roof was torn off and I was flung down the length of the corridor and found myself on the floor together with a fellow lady passenger. We talked to keep our spirits up".

The health and safety executive has begun a full investigation into the accident.

webTitle: Commons unites to pay tribute to Selby

fields.headline: Commons unites to pay tribute to Selby
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and William Hague abandoned their usual guerrilla warfare at prime minister's questions this afternoon as a mark of respect for the victims of the Selby rail crash.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and William Hague abandoned their usual guerrilla warfare at prime minister's questions this afternoon as a mark of respect for the victims of the Selby rail crash.

In what could be one of the last question time sessions before the general election, Mr Hague immediately signalled that the day's tragic events ? in addition to the foot and mouth outbreak - meant that this was not the time for political pointscoring.

He said: "Everyone will understand if the usual robustness of our exchanges is somewhat suspended today."

Prime minister Blair described the crash as a "terrible tragedy" and added "our thoughts and prayers are with the families, friends and relatives of those who died or were injured."

Mr Blair, Mr Hague and Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, were united in praising the emergency services and sending their thoughts to the families of the crash victims.

The prime minister promised the "fullest possible enquiry" into the accident and announced that the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, would make a full statement to the House when he returned from the crash site.

Labour MP John Grogan ? whose Selby constituency includes the crash site ? asked the prime minister: "As well as expressing our hopes for the speedy recovery of the many injured in the terrible rail accident this morning, will you also acknowledge the role of the villagers in Great Heck, who were amongst the first on the scene?"

In the "murk and the gloom" of the early morning, villagers had provided what assistance they could, he said.

Speculating about the cause of the accident, Mr Blair said: "It's too early yet to be absolutely certain, although it appears to be the Land Rover and trailer having slipped off the motorway and down onto the track.

"The villagers have behaved in an extraordinary, neighbourly, exemplary way and it is remarkable how, in Britain, local communities in times of crisis like this pull together and do the very best for other people."

fields.headline: Rail expert questions bridge safety
fields.trailText: A rail expert has said the highways agency may be to blame for today's fatal rail crash, saying checks should be made on the strength of motorway bridge barriers that should have prevented the disaster.
fields.body:
A rail expert has said the highways agency may be to blame for today's fatal rail crash, saying checks should be made on the strength of motorway bridge barriers that should have prevented the disaster.

"If a vehicle as comparatively small as a Land Rover managed to plunge through a barrier, it does suggest that barriers are not strong enough," said Nigel Harris, editor of Rail magazine.

Today's crash is believed to have happened after a Land Rover pulling a trailer plunged from the M62 and into the path of an oncoming GNER passenger train. The derailed GNER train then crashed into a freight train travelling in the opposite direction.

Mr Harris added: "These bridges are the responsibility of the highways agency and they should make checks."

fields.headline: Swans, Cockerels, and Dodos
fields.trailText: DEATH TO ALL GINGERS!
fields.body:
DEATH TO ALL GINGERS!

In the eyes of some Chris Evans may be yesterday's man, but he still has an insatiable appetite for publicity. Sorry, we meant enviable track record in business. Just ask anybody who watched the last three series of Think 'Funeral' It's Friday, or ever listened to anything on Virgin Radio (if you look hard enough you'll find someone). But Evans isn't simply content with being a broadcasting genius, the four-eyed gingernut is also a big big football fan. And to prove it, he's going to buy a club.

"I have received a telephone call from somebody called Danny Murphy," said Neil McClure, chairman of Swansea City today, inadvertently explaining what the receding Liverpool midfielder has been up to recently. "Mr Murphy is a representative of Chris Evans and he said Chris was interested in Swansea City. He said, however, that he was currently looking at a First Division club and if that deal fell through he would be taking a closer look at Swansea City."

What a gent he is. The First Division club in question is thought to be QPR, which is far closer to Evans's trendy West London home - taking less than five minutes' journey by Ferrari. But the mighty Rs may still prove too expensive for such a die-hard supporter as Mr Evans and, Swansea will come in at a far more reasonable price tag. But whether anyone has explained to Billie Piper that Swansea is a struggling Second Division side and not a sanctuary for pretty birdies however, it remains to be seen.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ENIC KNACK

There was a bright new dawn at White Hart Lane today. Of course, at the time most Spurs fans were trying to work out how to turn the knob while their head was in the oven, but the Fiver was there and we saw it. Yes, the shiny happy people of ENIC took charge at Tottingham today, and instantly set about ushering in a new era of hope, positivity and flowing football. By backing George Graham to the hilt.

"At the moment we have a manager who has lost only one of the last nine games, and who has led us into the quarter-finals of the FA Cup", said David Buchler, Spurs' new executive vice-chairman. "That isn't bad and I think we have got to give him credit for that." Buchler will take charge of the day-to-day running of Spurs while ENIC search for a new chairman with "suitable weight and City calibre" (might we suggest Eddie Large - boom boom!).

Mr Buchler is also a 49-year-old chartered accountant, rampant spending fans, and is described as having "more than 30 years' experience in business development and strategy for Kroll, the world's leading risk mitigation company". So when Buchler talks about how "it is a case of looking at a club which has money and finding out how to spend it properly in order to achieve the success you want", you know he means it. Sweet dreams Spurs fans, but please take the grill pan out first.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I will feel very proud and happy. I am also going to learn the words to the National Anthem. It's not too difficult is it?

Svennis, who still hasn't named his team(s) at the time of going to send, gets ready for his big bow. As for the anthem, it ain't that easy. 45 years in and the Fiver still hasn't got it down.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ROBBO IS GO!

Throughout the summer of 2000, wherever Bryan Robbo went, the Fiver followed. All those trips to Europe on the EasyJet! All those embarrassing meetings with a certain female Sky Sports reporter! Oh, those were happy times! But while the Fiver was living da vida loco, Robbo was returning back to Middlesbrough without - Alen Boksic apart - the world-class players he needed to make Boro the Premiership challengers we all know they can be (when we've downed five bottles of cough syrup).

But the city the Fiver spent the most time in last summer was Barcelona ("Barcelona amamos a sus señoras!") following Robbo's increasingly exasperated efforts to sign Dani, which - like Boro's season, alas - was a miserable failure. Of course now El Tel's "helping out", things are different. Hapless Boro are no longer chasing an Irish Eurovision Song Contest winner, or an Israeli one for that matter, but a half-decent Barcelona striker. And Dani might well be heading to the Riverside for just £7m - not the £12m Robbo was quoted in those hazy, crazy days of last summer.

"There may be activity before the transfer deadline but not just for the sake of it," insisted "first team coach" Tel this afternoon. "We have to feel it is going to improve us otherwise there is no point." But while El Tel is remaining coy, Robbo is showing no such restraint. According to reports he's already headed for the continent, armed with just a large stash of cash and the bargaining skills of chairman Steve Gibson. Let's hope they have more luck this time around eh!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Atalanta have dismissed reports that Sir Alex Ferguson is interested in signing Cristiano Doni for £3.5m. "We haven't had any offer from Manchester United for Doni," the club told planetfootball.com. "The story is not true."

Chelsea are hoping to bring Marcello Salas and Pablo Negro to Stamford Bridge this summer, according to reports.

Bradford goalkeeper Matt Clarke is likely to join Bolton on-loan until the end of the season.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Stan Cullis, former England captain and Woverhampton Wanderers manager, has died at the age of 85. Cullis played 12 times at centre half for his country in a career cut short by the second world war, captaining England against Romania in their final international before war broke out. He went on to manage Wolverhampton, guiding them to three league titles during the 1950s.

The League Managers Association has refuted claims that Bruce Rioch resigned as Wigan manager. "Having spoken with Bruce Rioch over press reports that he has resigned as manager at Wigan, we are able to categorically state that this is not true," a LMA statement said.

Fulham have been given the go-ahead to build a 30,000 capacity all-seater stadium on their Craven Cottage site. The project, which will cost £70m, was given the green light by Hammersmith and Fulham council's planning committee last night and the club hope it will be ready for the 2003-04 season.

The Republic of Ireland's friendly against Denmark has been called off due frozen terraces at Lansdowne Road. However Northern Ireland's game against Norway will go ahead.

Danny Cadamarteri has pleaded not guilty to a charge of assault occasioning actual bodily harm in court today. Joeline Joel, 24, suffered a broken cheekbone in the alleged incident last October. Cadamarteri will stand trial at Liverpool crown court on September 3.

Arsenal defender Matthew Upson has expressed his frustration at not playing more regularly for the first team. "I am not even getting a sniff at Arsenal," he admitted. "How long can I go on waiting? Not long."

A court case involving George Weah was postponed today after the former world player of the year failed to show up at a Lisbon court. Jorge Costa claims Weah head-butted him after a Champions League match between FC Porto and AC Milan in 1996. Weah admitted the assault during a UEFA investigation, which earned him a six-match ban, but said Costa provoked him with a series of dangerous fouls and racist insults during the game.

Brentford have announced plans to ground-share with non-League Woking during the 2002-3 season while they seek a permanent new home following their expected departure from Griffin Park.

Junior Lewis is expected to complete a permanent transfer to Leicester by the end of the week. Manager Andy Hessenthaler said: "Nothing has been finalised yet, he has still to put pen to paper, but it will happen."

Reading have signed Arsenal midfielder James Harper for an unspecified six-figure sum.

Luton chairman Mike Watson-Challis has confirmed his club have bought 55 acres of land near Junction 10 of the M1 to build a new stadium.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - England v Spain (10.45pm) "Hallo Mr TV and Radio. It's Barry, your next-door neighbour."

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.10am) "Yes, I know we haven't spoken for six years and that I occasionally allow my dogs to defecate on your prize leeks."

Sky Sports 1: Futbol mundial (6.30pm, 10.30pm, 2am) "But the thing is, because I object to giving Rupert Murdoch any money (for ideological reasons I'd prefer not to go into), I don't have any Sky and I was wondering if I could watch the game round yours."

Live international football Rep of Ireland v Denmark (7pm) "I know there's a big screen at the local, but I'm barred."

Sly Sports 2: Live international football - England v Spain (7pm, repeated 12am on SS1) "I attacked landlord with a mace when he wouldn't let me watch the football"

Sky Sports 3: The last word with Jimmy Hill (6.30pm, 11pm) "Thanks very much, that's very kind of you."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) "Can of Super Tennents?"

fields.headline: Statement from GNER
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: GNER confirms that its 0445 Newcastle to London Kings Cross service was involved in a collision today at 0612 at Great Heck on the east coast main line between York and Doncaster.     The southbound 225 electric train is believed to have struck a car and trailer which had left the road above the railway line.
fields.body:
GNER confirms that its 0445 Newcastle to London Kings Cross service was involved in a collision today at 0612 at Great Heck on the east coast main line between York and Doncaster. The southbound 225 electric train is believed to have struck a car and trailer which had left the road above the railway line.

The train remained upright until travelling through a set of points and subsequently colliding with a freight train travelling in the opposite direction.

The location is close to the point where the M62 motorway crosses over the railway line. After leaving Newcastle, the train called at Durham, at 0457, Darlington at 0515, Northallerton 0531, and York at 0559.

Fifty reservations had been made for travel on the train. It is estimated that there may have been up to 100 passengers on board the train at the time of the collision. All nine coaches of the GNER train are reported to have been derailed by the collision. GNER is running services between London and Leeds. A train shuttle service is running between York and Newcastle. Bad weather has curtailed services between Newcastle and Berwick which have been replaced a road coach service. Trains are running between Berwick and Edinburgh.

Passengers are recommended not to travel today unless absolutely necessary.

fields.headline: The carnage at Great Heck
fields.standfirst:
Northern editor Martin Wainwright reports from the scene of the Selby train crash, where 13 people died

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Northern editor Martin Wainwright reports from the scene of the Selby train crash, where 13 people died
fields.body:
Grey with strain and misery, Christopher Garnett of Great North Eastern Railways voiced the general disbelief at Great Heck this morning about the tragedy which left one of his flagship expresses mangled and strewn across the field behind him.

"Three things go wrong at once," he said, as the first of 13 bodies was gently eased from a horrific pyramid formed by two carriages upended at 125mph and left teetering over a third.

"First a car leaves the motorway and flies down the embankment onto our track. Then a passenger train hits it. Then a goods train comes the other way and hits both. It's terrible, it's terrible. Unbelievable."

The result has turned the north Yorkshire hamlet near Selby into what one villager describes as a "war zone" - a phrase exactly suited to the view from the crooked, redbrick bridge which takes Heck and Pollington Lane over the East Coast mainline.

Small holder Dean Puddephat's garden at Station Cottages has vanished beneath the broken-backed engine of the goods train, whose leading wagon has crushed his neighbour's lock-up garage and sliced his caravan in half leaving a black coal-dust smear.

Stabilised by 1700 tonnes of coal, unloaded only yesterday at Immingham docks and bound for Ferrybridge power station, the rest of the 14 wagons are still on the tracks. But their shear immovable bulk swatted the London express from Newcastle and York down a 15-foot embankment and across the nearby Northern straw company's paddock.

The 30 walking wounded and 14 more serious casualties were helped out - and in some cases cut free and taken to helicopters within an hour and a half of the crash at 6.15am, but a final search for survivors ended only shortly before John Prescott's arrival at midday.

"We've swept the whole train four times with thermal imaging equipment and sound detectors," said assistant divisional officer Graham Buckle of north Yorkshire fire service, as his team made a final attempt to check out reports of a weak voice from the dangerous void beneath the train's upended buffet car.

Cautiously cutting a hole in the crumpled metal the firefighters lowered a colleague down a ladder. But he was soon back up with nothing to report. Meanwhile as so often with terrible disasters, the surroundings could hardly be more placid. Winter pansies are still advertised for 25p at Bridgeside Nurseries within yards of the wrecked train and now a temporary base for dozens of police cars.

And the next job for Mr Puddephat's neighbour, not bothering to hide his tears, was to set about getting back the hammer he had used to smash carriage windows after running from his bedroom and the ladder which had helped stunned passengers to safety.

fields.headline: Religious bias 'on increase'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Hostility, abuse and discrimination towards Muslims and Hindus is increasing, a report commissioned by the Home Office revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Hostility, abuse and discrimination towards Muslims and Hindus is increasing, a report commissioned by the Home Office revealed yesterday.

They experience unfair treatment in every aspect of education, employment, housing, law and order and local government services, the study by the University of Derby showed.

Organisations representing the religions said hostility and violence remained "very real" concerns. The study, Religious Discrimination in England and Wales, found that most Muslim and Hindu respondents said hostility, verbal abuse, and unfair media coverage had become more frequent in recent years.

Muslim organisations reported more unfair treatment than other religious groups. Pagans and people from new religious movements also complained of open hostility and discrimination, and of being labelled child abusers and cults.

The report suggested some changes in the law might be needed to send the "right message" about discrimination.

"The idea of legislation of some kind received most support from Muslim organisations and interviewees from ethnic minorities."

Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister, said: "The findings reveal that there is a consensus among all faiths that there is ignorance and lack of respect for religion and religious identity."

He said the research would be used to take practical steps to tackle religious discrimination.

fields.headline: Ralph Nader regrets rien
fields.standfirst: The Democrats' whipping-boy, far from going to ground after his supposed wrecking of Al Gore's election chances, has been defending his corner in the American media, says Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: The Democrats' whipping-boy, far from going to ground after his supposed wrecking of Al Gore's election chances, has been defending his corner in the American media, says Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
The news this week that Al Gore would not have picked up enough uncounted votes in Miami-Dade to have beaten George Bush after all last November refocuses attention on the minutiae of the election.

So it is helpful to see that the man cast as "the spoiler" who wrecked Gore's chances of entering the White House has been talking about his role in the election and what he has been doing since.

Ralph Nader popped up last week in a Q&A session in the New York Times which introduced him by saying that: "He has been banished to the outskirts of the political arena and treated with open disdain... Hillary Clinton, who said 'that's not a bad idea' when the publisher and editor Harold Evans joked that he wanted to kill the Green party candidate, has ignored 16 phone calls asking for an apology, says Mr Nader."

But just in case anyone was really expecting the 67-year-old consumer advocate who took just under 4% of the votes as the Green party candidate to apologise for running at all they can stop holding their breath. "Any regrets?" he was asked. "Yeah, I didn't get more votes."

As for the suggestion that he had somehow gone to ground after the election amid suggestions that his 97,000 votes in Florida robbed Gore of victory, Nader points out that he has given nine press conferences and been making statements about the California power crisis and consumer protection on the internet but not many people have been bothering to report the fact.

He adds that Pat Buchanan, the Reform Party candidate, cost Bush the states of New Mexico, Iowa, Wisconsin and Oregon - "and the Republicans didn't whine the way the Democrats did as if they were entitled to the votes."

He gets a chance to say his piece in the special election edition of Brill's Content, the media magazine, and he is sanguine about the way the mainstream press in America covered his campaign: "The national press's insistence on focusing its attention on the horse race between the two major-party candidates creates a Catch-22 for any third party candidate who wants to inject any previously ignored issues into the campaign dialogue.

"Without coverage, you can't make headway in the polls. And a poor showing in the polls in turn distances the media from the campaign."

Nader draws the disheartening conclusion: "No democracy worth its salt should rely so pervasively on the commercial media. And no seriously pro-democracy campaign will ever get an even break, or adequate coverage from that media."

And to the Minneapolis Star Tribune, when asked about reports that progressive Democrats had "vowed never to work with him again" he replied: "The door's been closed for years. They just put the sign out."

The real test for Nader and the Greens comes now with plans to launch 900 campus Green parties by the end of the year at a time when student activism is on the up in the United States. He hopes that the party will be able to run candidates in 2002 in local state and national elections. In the meantime, it seems that he could save some money for the campaigns ahead by not making that 17th call to Hillary.

webTitle: Coke and GM carry Olympic Torch

fields.headline: Coke and GM carry Olympic Torch
fields.trailText: 5pm: Coca-Cola and General Motors are to sponsor the Olympic Torch at the Winter 2002 games, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola and General Motors are to sponsor the Olympic Torch run for the Winter 2002 Games and will ask the American public to choose the torchbearers.

Coke and GM brand Chevrolet will today begin the search for people to carry the Olympic flame on its 65-day journey through the US to Salt Lake City.

The public will be asked to nominate as torchbearers people who have inspired their community or overcome adversity.

Coke retailers, Chevrolet's 4,300 dealerships, the companies' websites and community organisations will stock nomination forms. People must write 50 to 100 words describing why their nominee deserves to win.

The torchbearers will be randomly selected from all eligible entries received by May 7 2001 and winners will be announced in August and September.

More than 11,500 people will carry the torch for approximately 13,500 miles.

US cyclist and three-time Olympian Lance Armstrong is Coca-Cola's Olympic Torch relay team leader and spokesperson.

He will feature in promotional point-of-sale material, television, print radio and online advertising associated with Coca-Cola's sponsorship of the Salt Lake 2002 Olympic Torch relay.

fields.headline: New marketing tool set to hit UK
fields.trailText:
4pm: US firm Digital:Convergence is to bring revolutionary new marketing technology to Europe, reports Julia Day.
www.digitalconvergence.com
fields.body:
While reading a newspaper on the bus, an advert for a new car takes your fancy. Pulling out a pen-sized scanner, you scan a barcode on the page.

Back at home, you plug the scanner into your computer and, hey presto, you are whisked to an internet page offering you a test drive.

Far from this scenario being an advertiser's space-age dream, this technology is about to arrive in the UK.

US company Digital:Convergence is launching the CueCat scanner in Europe with an international unit headed by Classic FM founder Stuart Graber.

The company's investors include Coca-Cola and global advertising agency network Young & Rubicam.

Some of the agency's clients are already using the technology in their adverts.

The Dallas and New York-based management team includes former Time Warner, AT&T, GE, ING Barings and Disney executives.

President and chief operating officer Michael Garin was global head of media communications investment bankers ING Barings for 11 years.

Media Group president Scott Carlin worked for Warner Brothers Domestic Television Group for 19 years on shows including Friends and ER.

But the technology is not limited to advertising - it is being used by media owners within editorial content.

US business magazine Forbes launched the CueCat scanners in August last year with a free covermounted scanner and millions have been given away through computer retailer Radioshack.

The Dallas Morning News and sports magazine Parade are using the technology within editorial and selling it as an option to their advertisers.

Cuecat aims to take customers directly to information they are seeking, negating the need for lengthy web surfing.

It could be used to scan supermarket products to access recipes or discount promotions, for example.

PR network Burson-Marsteller's London office has been appointed to support the European launch. The network already works for Digital:Convergence in the US.

The agency will be introducing the technology to the publishing, advertising, marketing, IT, retail and media industries in the UK.

fields.headline: Kew Gardens to revamp image
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Kew Gardens is seeking to capitalise on the popularity of recent exhibitions with an image revamp, writes Julia Day.
Feb 26: V&A seeks new image
fields.body:
Blooming with the success of its recent orchid festival and its African sculpture exhibition, Kew Gardens is seeking to capitalise on that popularity with an image revamp.

The Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew is on the hunt for new heads of marketing and PR.

A new marketing strategy will be implemented to modernise the gardens, which were founded in 1759 by the widow of Frederick, Prince of Wales.

Kew is seen as offering the same thing all year round - beautiful gardens - and the new strategy will see events launched throughout the year.

A spokeswoman compared it to a museum or art gallery mounting and promoting changing exhibitions.

Activities will be staged to attract different types of visitors - some appealing to couples and some aimed at families.

Already garden bosses run themed areas for families such as the snow garden inside the Princess of Wales glass house.

Kew's exhibition of the lifesize African sculptures in the grounds proved a major draw last year.

Some events will be annual in an attempt to emulate the success of must-do dates in the horticultural diary such as the Chelsea Flower Show.

But the spokeswoman pointed out that balancing the old and the new would be a difficult task.

"It is about becoming commercial," she said. "But we don't want to turn Kew in to a Disney theme park.

"Look at the Victoria and Albert museum, it has been accused of being stuffy and is looking for a new press chief and branding consultants to help change that," she added.

In May, a Japan 2001 exhibition will tie in with Japanese events at other London locations such as the Hayward Gallery and Hyde Park.

Kew will use tube advertising for the first time in years to promote the event.

Related story

webTitle: Nutella takes legal action against Gnutella

fields.headline: Nutella takes legal action against Gnutella
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Gnutella, the file distribution system, has finally incurred the wrath of Nutella, the homophonous chocolate spread.
fields.body:
Gnutella, the file distribution system, has finally incurred the wrath of Nutella, the homophonous chocolate spread.

The makers of the spread, Ferrero, obtained an interim injunction last month in Cologne, ordering Lars Gollnow, owner of www.gnutella.de, to cease and desist from using his domain name. The site is currently closed.

Gollnow signed the letter "immediately and without argument", said Ulrika Steiner, a legal spokesman at Ferrero's Frankfurt office.

Because the Gnutella system is decentralised - a downloadable, peer-to-peer system allowing users to distribute files - there is no danger of its imminent closure. Steiner could not confirm or deny whether Ferrero planned to take any action against Gnutella outside Germany.

Thousands of users are thought to have signed up to the Gnutella service since Napster, the file swapping service for MP3s, lost its US case against the Recording Industry Association of America.

Steiner confessed her office only became aware of www.gnutella.de shortly before then, after reading about Gnutella in a German newspaper.

She said Ferrero acted to protect its trademark rights, and in the light of reports of a police investigation into illegal content being exchanged by Gnutella users.

But she denied it had forced www.gnutella.de to close. "There wasn't any content before we filed for the interim injunction," she said.

Gnutella's connection with the Nutella name does not appear to be accidental. FAQs on Gnutella-hosting websites say its title is a compound of GNU, a Unix software suite, and the name of the chocolate spread.

fields.headline: Nickelodeon slams BBC proposals
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: The children's broadcaster claims the BBC's plans duplicate existing digital TV services, reports Jason Deans.
8.30am: Mori blasts consultation process
fields.body:
Nickelodeon UK has slammed the BBC's claim that it will be the key to the government's blueprint for digital television.

In a submission to the government today, Nickelodeon mounted a fierce challenge to the corporation's declaration that its two proposed children's digital TV services would help drive take-up of the technology.

The children's pay-TV broadcaster put its case in a submission to the government on the new BBC services.

"Homes with children have already led the way in adopting multichannel television and do not represent the digital 'resisters' the government and BBC want to target," the Nickelodeon submission stated.

"Nickelodeon and Nick Jr, along with other commercial children's channels, have established demand for multichannel television and are key players in expanding the market.

"There is no evidence new BBC children's services will drive digital take-up," it said.

The BBC is seeking the permission of culture secretary Chris Smith to launch a pre-school service and an offering aimed at six to 13-year-olds.

Today is the last day for submissions to Mr Smith on the proposals.

"The BBC has provided the secretary of state with a flimsy account of its planned children's services that do not in any way guarantee distinctiveness or value to the public," said Nickelodeon UK general manager Paul Lindley.

"All we know for sure is the proposed services would have a highly detrimental impact on innovation and investment by commercial players."

Nickelodeon's submission points out that there are already 14 digital children's channels and a further nine services offering significant blocks of children's output, covering all age groups and programming genres.

"The BBC's proposed children's services duplicate what is already provided in the market and are not truly distinctive," the document stated.

Nickelodeon also argued that the launch of the free-to-air BBC services will hit its own plans to increase investment in original UK production by £30m over the next three years.

"These investment plans are based on assumptions of a level playing field and access to archive material from the BBC at market rates," the submission said.

"The uncertainty over free-to-air BBC entry into the market - and the refusal by the BBC to sell its library to secondary channels - makes this commitment uncertain."

The Nickelodeon submission urged Mr Smith to "consider in detail the costs involved in the new BBC services as proposed in terms of economic investment, creative risk-taking and innovation, and choice and plurality, and not merely the perceived benefits of two new BBC children's channels".

Mr Lindley added: "Nickelodeon recommends the services should not be approved and the BBC should continue to provide benchmark children's programming on BBC1 and BBC1, and pursue its commercial aims in partnership with the commercial sector."

He was one of a group of senior pay-TV executives who met Mr Smith last week.

They expressed concern at the perceived shortcomings of the government approval process for the BBC digital services.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...a mobile phone

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: a mobile phone
fields.trailText: a mobile phone
fields.body: Take note all you plutocrats who rate social success by the size of your mobile phone bill. Now you may just have to go one better to prove your worth. Gordon Gekko had nothing on this gold- and diamond-encrusted telephone hand set lovingly crafted by de Grisogono. For £18,500 you can punch out your digits on a little Ericsson number with ruby and white diamond hearts surrounded by black diamonds (on display at the company's London showroom), and individually commissioned pieces can cost £65,000. The stones featured here are 8.65, 1.6 and 3.4 carats respectively, with a pavé set, which means that the gold setting is gently teased over the edge of the stones to hold them in place. Just transfer the Sim card from your regular mobile and you're off. The com pany assures me that all phones are compatible with major networks, so you won't be saddled with any pricey cancellation fees, which is just as well. A model of ghetto chic, just the job for Puffy when calling his lawyer. Sadly, the price doesn't include any free talk-time.

webTitle: A scheme to get children in care to read

fields.headline: Transports of delight
fields.standfirst: A scheme to encourage children in care to read is changing lives, finds  Julie Wheelwright
fields.trailText: A scheme to encourage children in care to read is changing lives, finds Julie Wheelwright
fields.body:
Peter bounds into the sitting room, curls himself into Grant Loveall's arms and soon they are gently teasing each other. Peter, 10, clutches a copy of Seriously Cool Puffin Stories and reels off his favourites. When he mentions The Hundred Mile an Hour Dog, the banter with Grant, the manager at the children's home where Peter lives, revs up again. "Yeah, that's like the dog round here, someone sees it in the rubbish and it speeds off: hundred mile an hour," says Grant, his hand shooting out in imitation.

"I like the one best with the Demon Headmaster," says Peter.

"I'm not that clever," he insists, "but I do like reading: Harry Potter books, Roald Dahl and some others."

Peter lives in a children's home in St Helen's, Merseyside, that is involved in a pilot scheme to encourage children in care to read. According to a report published this week, it has achieved astonishing results. Forty homes in five local authority pilot schemes have received packages of 50 brand new books from the Right to Read Project. The scheme is organised by the Paul Hamlyn Foundation, the National Literacy Association and the Who Cares? Trust, which campaigns for the rights of children in care. With donations from leading children's publishers (of books that range from classics to mass-market favourites such as Star Wars and Sabrina), Right to Read has built up libraries, organised "achievement days" for young readers and a roadshow with popular children's authors.

The scheme is already paying off as the report reveals that reading with a carer has actually improved the children's reading skills, cemented relationships with their carers and given the children a much-needed boost at school.

At a home for girls just down the hill in St Helen's, Angela, aged 15, recently received the top mark for her English exam. "I only had to talk for six minutes," she says proudly, "but I could have talked for six hours."

Her bedroom is crammed with books and reading is now among her favourite activities. "It helps you develop a good imagination and a good imagination sets you free," she explains. Lorraine Edwards, the home's unit manager, says the change in Angela since she discovered the pleasure of reading is profound: "When she first arrived two years ago, she didn't read at all. Since she's discovered the Star Wars books, she has sat her reading exam and she never would have had the confidence to do that before."

Now Angela plans to become a nursery nurse and to pass her passion for books on to other children.

The library of well-kept books in a corner of the living room at the home marks a radical change in attitude. "The library means a lot," says Edwards, "because it's not about reading just being to do with school - the girls are actually reading for fun."

Many children who arrive at the home have never been read a bedtime story, visited a library or had a book of their own. Consequently, the educational achievements of children in care are dismal, with 70% of children leaving with no qualifications and only 4% gaining five or more GCSEs. The NLA's goal is for 99% of these children to leave school with adequate literacy for daily life.

Edwards says that the home's annual book budget is usually just £25, which buys a few reference books but leaves little for fiction. The greatest constraint is financial: a Right to Read questionnaire circulated to the pilot schemes found that the most frequently cited reason for not having books in a home was lack of funds. Charlie Griffiths, NLA director, says that books have been seen as a luxury instead of a necessity: "One of the things we're saying in the report is that funding books has got to be ongoing. It's not enough to give a home 50 books and say, that's it. It's got to be down to the local authority to find the money to fund books."

If the people in charge of drawing up budgets were to compare the book budgets for children in care with the amount spent on their own children, they might think differently, Griffiths observes. "Reading a book together is a shared magical experience. And if you've got a caring adult giving you that time, that is something which makes a child feel valued. It's important for reading and for feeling confident and valued."

All children's names have been changed. For information, email the Who Cares? Trust at mailbox@thewhocarestrust.org.uk; the National Literacy Association at nla@argonet.co.uk.

Peter lives in a children's home in St Helen's, Merseyside, that is involved in a pilot scheme to encourage children in care to read. According to a report published this week, it has achieved astonishing results. Forty homes in five local authority pilot schemes have received packages of 50 brand new books from the Right to Read Project. The scheme is organised by the Paul Hamlyn Foundation, the National Literacy Association and the Who Cares? Trust, which campaigns for the rights of children in care. With donations from leading children's publishers (of books that range from classics to mass-market favourites such as Star Wars and Sabrina), Right to Read has built up libraries, organised "achievement days" for young readers and a roadshow with popular children's authors. The scheme is already paying off as the report reveals that reading with a carer has actually improved the children's reading skills, cemented relationships with their carers and given the children a much-needed boost at school. At a home for girls just down the hill in St Helen's, Angela, aged 15, recently received the top mark for her English exam. "I only had to talk for six minutes," she says proudly, "but I could have talked for six hours." Her bedroom is crammed with books and reading is now among her favourite activities. "It helps you develop a good imagination and a good imagination sets you free," she explains. Lorraine Edwards, the home's unit manager, says the change in Angela since she discovered the pleasure of reading is profound: "When she first arrived two years ago, she didn't read at all. Since she's discovered the Star Wars books, she has sat her reading exam and she never would have had the confidence to do that before." Now Angela plans to become a nursery nurse and to pass her passion for books on to other children. The library of well-kept books in a corner of the living room at the home marks a radical change in attitude. "The library means a lot," says Edwards, "because it's not about reading just being to do with school - the girls are actually reading for fun." Many children who arrive at the home have never been read a bedtime story, visited a library or had a book of their own. Consequently, the educational achievements of children in care are dismal, with 70% of children leaving with no qualifications and only 4% gaining five or more GCSEs. The NLA's goal is for 99% of these children to leave school with adequate literacy for daily life. Edwards says that the home's annual book budget is usually just £25, which buys a few reference books but leaves little for fiction. The greatest constraint is financial: a Right to Read questionnaire circulated to the pilot schemes found that the most frequently cited reason for not having books in a home was lack of funds. Charlie Griffiths, NLA director, says that books have been seen as a luxury instead of a necessity: "One of the things we're saying in the report is that funding books has got to be ongoing. It's not enough to give a home 50 books and say, that's it. It's got to be down to the local authority to find the money to fund books." If the people in charge of drawing up budgets were to compare the book budgets for children in care with the amount spent on their own children, they might think differently, Griffiths observes. "Reading a book together is a shared magical experience. And if you've got a caring adult giving you that time, that is something which makes a child feel valued. It's important for reading and for feeling confident and valued." All children's names have been changed. For information, email the Who Cares? Trust at mailbox@thewhocarestrust.org.uk; the National Literacy Association at nla@argonet.co.uk.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: The new chief of defence staff says kids need a clip round the ear. Is he right?
fields.trailText: The question: The new chief of defence staff says kids need a clip round the ear. Is he right?
fields.body:
Spokesman, Friends of the Family

The idea of a "clip round the ear" leaves me cold. It suggests that the child should be the subject of casual violence. Children ought to be treated with care and respect. Any discipline, be it verbal encouragement or physical punishment, must always be given in the child's best interests and not out of selfishness or frustration. Phrases such as "a clip round the ear" will help the extremists who want to criminalise all smacking. They will tear loving families apart simply because the parents use physical correction to teach their children right from wrong.
Peter Newell
Verdict: Yes

Coordinator, Epoch, anti-corporal punishment body

With his claims that a lack of physical punishment and general disciplining of children is creating a lazy, unfit and disobedient generation, Admiral Sir Michael Boyce yearns to return us all to his crude world, where might is right and respect is synonymous with fear. It is sad that such blinkered, dangerous views still gain attention. Promoting violent responses to young people will lead us down a spiral of violence breeding violence. Globally, the trend is more positive, with a long overdue recognition that hitting children is a fundamental breach of their rights.
Ferris Lindsay
Verdict: No

Education writer and parent

You should be able to discipline a child without violence. Good discipline depends on clear boundaries. It's no use expecting children to understand the rules by osmosis. We have to set the boundaries and they have to understand why. There has been a lot of talk about respect and what that means; it has different meanings in different contexts. The respect you give your teacher isn't necessarily the respect you would give your friends on the street. Teachers who achieve good discipline and don't have to spend hour after hour on behavioural control know this.
Stella Dadzie
Verdict: No

Headteacher, Christian Fellowship school, Liverpool

Parents of pupils at our school want us to have the right to smack children if they misbehave. We took a case to the European court on the issue and won, but now have to convince the UK government and are considering a judicial review at the high court. I would never advocate any sort of hitting around the head because it can be dangerous, but I do believe in loving discipline. I don't think people know how to instil moral guidelines into young people any more. When all the restraints are removed, we get into the kind of social experiment that has gone really wrong.
Philip Williamson
Verdict: Yes

General secretary, NAS/UWT teachers' union

Society has gradually disintegrated and there are no effective sanctions left. Parents have abdicated their responsibilities towards their children and it is teachers who are left holding the baby. Sensible families bring their children up to have some values, but ever-increasing numbers of children are growing up in dysfunctional families and there is no way of bringing them into line. They say violence breeds violence but I think a little dose of discipline administered early to a child can act like a vaccination and set them on the right path. Children need firm correction early on if they misbehave.
Mary Crowley
Verdict: Yes

Chief executive, Parenting Education and Support Forum

It is not surprising that a military man would think violence the best solution. The alternative to controlling by fear is to encourage self-discipline. But it can only grow out of self-respect. Children can have problems respecting themselves if the adults they care about do not respect them. We seem to forget as we grow up that children feel exactly the same as adults; they know less about the world, but they feel pain, humiliation and the withdrawal of affection at least as sharply. Teaching children to respect their elders is best done by example. They learn from being hit that might is right.
Nigel de Gruchy
Verdict: No

webTitle: Home truths about Old Macdonald's farm

fields.headline: Home truths about Old Macdonald's farm
fields.standfirst:
Cute moo-cows and burning beef pyres - Judy Rumbold on a clash of two worlds

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Cute moo-cows and burning beef pyres - Judy Rumbold on a clash of two worlds
fields.body:
All of a sudden, your five-year-old's usual line of intimate questioning seems like a picnic by comparison. Go right ahead and ask me where babies come from. Feel free to request a full and frank explanation of the intricacies of the menstrual cycle. Quiz me on willies/front bottoms/bowel function in a loud voice in a public place if you wish - anything at all - but please God, don't ask about the mountains of burning cows.

Faced with the gut-churning photo-reportage of the foot-and- mouth outbreak over the past few days, even the most creative parent will be struggling to explain to a curious child why anyone in their right mind would want to build an enormous fire and summarily incinerate Daisy, Ermintrude and their friends. Garden waste, yes. Old boxes, certainly. But cute moo-cows? Has the world gone mad?

You can understand the confusion. Children are brought up with the unshakeable belief that farm animals live charmed, Dappledown-style existences where nothing horrible ever happens. To then confront them with the reality - that Old Macdonald had a farm, certainly, but that he also had a shotgun, a freezer full of animal parts and a contract with the local abattoir - is to cloud somewhat the rosy picture.

To be hit with the realisation that pigs, cows and sheep are not only slaughtered for their meat but sometimes contract illnesses of a sort that can't be cured with a couple of capfuls of Calpol is, to a child, shocking indeed. Where will it all end? If livestock is being torched, what hope is there for the mute, inanimate minority? Is Bagpuss safe? How long before Kipper the Dog meets a similar fate? Is it only a matter of time before Rupert Bear, Sooty and the cast of Sesame Street end up on a smouldering pyre of singed acrylic?

If some of the blame for children's entirely blinkered view of nature's brutality stops at the door of Beatrix Potter (red, small, carved into the side of a tree trunk) and all the other authors, film animators and illustrators who thought it would be a good idea to put hedgehogs in skirts and bestow upon small rodents the ability to emote and make major life decisions, a far greater responsibility lies with parents.

The illusion that life in the wild is as benign as a Disney storyboard is, after all, a deception in which we all collude and which begins in the crib with the first animal with which most babies come into contact - a cuddly teddy-bear. Fact: there are bears out there that will rip your head off. There are bears that will strike you dead with a single swipe of a paw. There are bears that will maul you to a pulp and crush the last living breath out of you. But - sorry, kids! - cuddly bears simply don't exist.

A few more home truths. Chicken Licken may come over as a smart, urbane operator in the book of the same name, but he will surely cop for it in the end, suffering the indignity of being throttled, decapitated and eventually repackaged as part of a quartet of skinless breasts on a shelf at Asda. Likewise, as far as children are concerned, the Three Little Pigs come across as a trio of wily, articulate individuals with promising careers in the building trade. Wrong. I'll bet that the embers were barely cold beneath the Big Bad Wolf's cauldron before the Pigs were being whisked off to have their throats slit, their guts pulled out, and some of their less appealing body parts chopped and minced with bread and rusk before being forced into lengths of intestine and sold as sausages.

A little too vivid? Well, that's country life for you. The fact that it is not all gambolling lambs, babbling brooks and cheery-faced farmers may come as a rude awakening to otherwise sophisticated urban adults keen to preserve the fantasy for a time when they can afford a second home in Norfolk. Perhaps more surprising still will be the realisation that the children they have worked so hard to protect from the realities of death and mortality might actually welcome a brush with the truth.

Mine did. Indeed, they have witnessed more atrocities during a year in Suffolk than they saw the entire time they were living in one of the most crime-ravaged areas of London. Here, life is a thrilling, non-stop X-rated action movie of casual murder and mass destruction. Decapitated rats, fox-damaged rabbits, smashed badgers, gored lambs and horribly maimed pheasants litter the fields and roadsides. Everywhere you look, it seems, there are animals either running for their lives, mauling the living daylights out of each other or engaged in some sort of mortal combat. It is, in other words, child heaven. It's like Robot Wars with fur. Like Gladiators with cloven hooves and heavy plumage. Add to that the petrified foxes being chased by hounds, the huntsmen with their guns, angry farmers driving their tractors like madmen and snarling about BSE, GM crops and now foot-and-mouth, and the countryside is far from tranquil. On the contrary, it currently resembles an embattled war zone, riddled with disease, shunned by frightened townies and generally declared a no-go zone.

It is more than a year since we moved to the country, but the mortality issue was sorted in a matter of months.

The food chain question took a little longer. It was when the children witnessed a local man pulling up outside the village butcher with a dead deer in the boot of his car that the penny finally dropped. If they now have a more balanced view of country ways - here, they really do murder most fowl; battery hens are not, after all, rechargeable; and gruff men doing unspeakable things to animals in sheds is just the way things are - they have seen enough carnage and heard a sufficient number of horror stories to have become extremely apprehensive meat-eaters.

The fact that Bernard Matthews - that emperor of extrusion, that right royal reconstituter - is virtually a neighbour has not helped matters. (Turkey dinosaurs are an abomination for which he deserves to be shot. Or, at the very least, exposed to a full-on case of foot-and-mouth.) As to his and other sinister-sounding modern farming methods, I shall continue to answer my children's inquiries frankly - charred cows included - as and when they arise. Some questions, of course, are easier to answer than others. "Where do sausages come from?" asked my five-year-old son, recently. "Pigs," I replied. "Yes," he said, a little impatiently, "but where do the pigs get them from?"

webTitle: Waiting for two little strangers to arrive

fields.headline: Tales of the unexpected
fields.standfirst: Waiting for two little strangers to arrive - whoever they might turn out to be
fields.trailText: Waiting for two little strangers to arrive - whoever they might turn out to be
fields.body:
I met a woman this week who discovered she was having twins a week before they were born. Her children are now young adults but she still remembers the shock of being told her family would be more instant than she had thought.

Just 25 years ago, only one in five twin pregnancies was diagnosed before birth. Now they are all picked up on ultrasound. There are no surprises, no shocks. Our children emerge after we have already had long conversations with them, introducing ourselves as mummy or daddy. They have probably had a name for months. All we have to do is clothe them.

For me, nothing is unexpected. I was only a few weeks pregnant when an early scan revealed I was going to be a mother of two. With infertility treatment, your chances of twins are far higher than normal, and the consultant is on the lookout for a double implantation. Within a few weeks more, tests revealed the embryos' sex. During subsequent scans, one was identified as a prolific thumb-sucker and another as having inherited my short legs. They have even been videoed in my womb - their fidgety forms like a flickering home movie - to monitor the pumping of their heart muscles. Last week, their birth weights were estimated by ultrasound.

Does this excess of information make my relationship with my unborn different from that of another expectant mother? Do I have the enviable opportunity to get to know my children-to-be better?

My seven-year-old has enrolled in the bonding-before-birth school of thought. Scan after scan, she insisted I ask the consultant to print out a picture and bring it home. She was determined to take one into her class to show friends. I wouldn't let her. I tried to explain that she has, as yet, no brother and sister, just a smudged scan print of what might be. But she has given them names and watched my body expand. As far as she is concerned, she is already "big sis".

Technology has tricked us into thinking we have a family before it arrives. Expectant mothers of twins are particularly encouraged to find meaning by tuning into the contents of their swelling bellies. We are advised to look for differences between our embryos to "help them with their ego boundaries". We are supposed to notice if one is more active than the other, jumps more readily to the sound of its mother's than its father's voice, is more interested in Bach than Bob Marley, and assume different personalities.

The bible of multiple birth books, Elizabeth Noble's Having Twins, declares: "Many mothers notice exactly the same traits in their babies after birth as they displayed within the uterus." One parent is quoted as saying: "In the uterus Betsy preferred the left side. All I felt was a flutter from time to time. She is a flighty child, unlike her sister Barbara, who thudded hard and continuously and is a more solid person."

To suggest, because one of my babies is more fluttery in my womb, it will be more flighty in life is the runt end of biological determinism. It's like, "it must be a boy because he kicks as if signed up for Tottenham Hotspur". In fact, we know hardly anything about these foetuses beyond some medical facts.

In a few weeks' time, two babies will return to my home, near strangers, and only then will we get to know each other. I will not know my two children until I have given birth to them, lived with them, heard them, washed them, been enthralled and infuriated by them. There may well be shocks along the way, far more startling than discovering there were two. Despite all my scans, my tests, my diagnoses, there can still be tales of the unexpected.

Leahwild@cswebmail.com

fields.headline: A book to remember
fields.standfirst: Which were the books you loved most as a child, the special ones you want your own children to read? In the middle of bedtime reading week and with world book day tomorrow, we asked seven best-selling children's authors to nominate
fields.trailText: Which were the books you loved most as a child, the special ones you want your own children to read? In the middle of bedtime reading week and with world book day tomorrow, we asked seven best-selling children's authors to nominate
fields.body:
Gillian Cross
The Secret Garden by Frances Hodgson Burnett

The best books have a way of getting inside you and changing the way you think and feel and see. The Secret Garden, by Frances Hodgson Burnett, is like that for me. As a child, I read it more times than I can remember and it has coloured my whole view of the world.

It is a book that has everything. A mysterious crying voice. A boy who tames animals. A lovely, hidden garden and a heroine who is loveable even while she is a selfish, bad-tempered victim - and who becomes even more loveable as she develops into a healthy, confident girl.

As a child, I loved reading about Misselthwaite Manor, with its 100 rooms full of secret and lovely things. I envied Mary's solitary exploration of it and longed to find a house like that myself. I never have, but once, when I was a child, on holiday in the Isle of Wight, I struggled through undergrowth into a secret, walled garden with a fig tree in the middle.

Every spring I remember The Secret Garden when I see the new green shoots. To this day, I see spring through Mary Lennox's eyes, as a combination of promise and challenge. All my life - because of Mary - I have known that everyone needs love and work and hope. And all my life, I have believed that, given those, we can escape from the things that stunt and restrict us and grow into the people we were meant to be. Thank you, Frances Hodgson Burnett.

Gillian Cross is author of the Demon Headmaster series. Her next novel, Calling a Dead Man (Oxford, £6.99), will be published in October.

Quentin Blake
Chicks' Own Annual 1937

Perhaps the most significant book of my childhood was what may have been the first: on my fourth birthday in December 1936, my mother and father gave me a copy of Chicks' Own Annual for 1937. Chicks' Own was one of those weekly children's comics (price 2d, every Tuesday) with some stories in strip-cartoon form and other simple stories of a page each, a formula reflected in the annual. Two-syllable words were divided by a hyphen for easier reading.

The hero was Rupert, a little yellow chick. He had a red beak; his friend was to the same design but black with a yellow beak. There was a curious convention about the beaks: normal beaks seen in profile, they be came a nose and a mouth seen head on. The chicks were child-sized, and went to a school where their friends were other animals such as Teethy-y Croc-o-dile and Stri-pey Ti-ger, who were not much bigger than they were.

The interesting thing to me, in retrospect, is that I am sure that I was aware already that some of the drawings were better than others. Many were flat and anaemic, but those for the Rupert stories had satisfyingly substantial forms; the wheels on Rupert's train really looked as though they would go round, and the bowl of pudding they found in the pirates' cave really looked worth eating. Looking again at these drawings in more recent years I see that they were signed A White and that they were probably influenced, consciously or unconsciously, by Benjamin Rabier, the early 20th-century artist best known for the goose Gedeon, and some of whose books are still in print. When, about a year ago, I was invited to take part, with a handful of French illustrators, in an exhibition called Les Fils Spirituels de Benjamin Rabier, I had assumed that Spiritual Sons was just a convenient label for some artists who liked drawing animals. And no doubt it was: by turning again the pages of Chicks' Own Annual (which I still have), I came to realise that there was, after all, an element of truth in the description.

Quentin Blake's Tell Me A Picture (National Gallery, £9.95) mixes old and modern pictures with his own drawings in a book which parallels the exhibition at the National Gallery until June 17.

Malorie Blackman
The Silver Chair by CS Lewis

Books can change your life. I know, because that's what my favourite book - The Silver Chair by CS Lewis - did for me. Do you know that feeling when you learn something new and you're instantly aware of its truth for you at that moment and for the rest of your life? That's how I felt when I read chapter 12 of this book.

Prince Rilian, Puddleglum, Eustace and Jill are confronted by the Wicked Queen as she tries to seduce them with sweet words and drugged fire into believing that her world is the only real world - that there is no sun, no Narnia, no Aslan.

It was Puddleglum's words after he had destroyed the drugged fire that spoke to me. If there's no sun and no country and no Aslan, he'll still go on believing in them, because it's better than the alternative. I realise now that that chapter gave me the courage to believe in myself. When others tried to tell me that I couldn't do, shouldn't think, had no right to feel, somewhere deep down, I'd remember that chapter and I'd know that with God's help and belief in myself, I could do anything. I could even become a writer.

Malorie Blackman's latest book is Noughts & Crosses (Doubleday, £10.99).

Dick King-Smith
The Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling

As a child, I liked best to read stories about animals. Beatrix Potter's little beasts were probably the first to catch my eye, Winnie the Pooh and the riverside folk of The Wind in the Willows following. Then I came upon Kipling's The Jungle Book. I was fascinated by all the stories in it, but principally by the one called "Tiger! Tiger!" I thought then that the telling of the death of Shere Khan was the most wonderful piece of descriptive writing, and I think I would hold to that view today.

I could imagine the scene as vividly as though I were Mowgli on the back of Rama, the great herd bull, at the head of the narrow dry ravine of the Waingunga river. The wolves have split the buffalo herd in two, Gray Brother holding the cows at the foot of the ravine, Akela with the bulls at the head, awaiting Mowgli's order to drive them down to where the full-fed tiger is lying. The walls of the ravine are straight. There is no escape for the lame tiger, and Rama "tripped, stumbled, and went on again over something soft, and, with the bulls at his heels, crashed full into the other herd.

"Shere Khan needed no more trampling. He was dead, and the kites were coming for him already.

"'Brother, that was a dog's death,' said Mowgli."

Kevin Crossley-Holland
The Wool-pack by Cynthia Harnett

I'm going for Cynthia Harnett's Carnegie medal-winning The Woolpack, published in 1951, because it is the first book I bought for myself. It cost 10/- of my Christmas money, as my endpaper note of December 28 1953 records rather ruefully.

The author's knowledge of late 15th-century life and the Cotswold wooltrade is lightly worn but wonderfully convincing. She abides by Jill Paton Walsh's useful maxim that the historical novelist may employ the "not known to be true" but not the "known not to be true". Further, she has very little truck with the olde-tyme speeche: her dialogue is largely simple and clean, if now slightly dated.

Harnett likes human beings, warts and all; she is, above all, at home with childhood, its frankness and playfulness and exuberance and vulnerability. And she sees it, like the past, as another country. In 1953, aged 12, all I knew was that it was thrilling to read a story about smuggling and skulduggery. First and foremost, Harnett knew how to tell a story.

Kevin Crossley-Holland's novel The Seeing Stone (Orion, £10.99) was shortlisted for the 2000 Whitbread Children's Book of the Year.

Francesca Simon
Half Magic by Edward Eager

I was nine or 10 when I discovered Edward Eager's fantastic books about a group of children's magic adventures. Half Magic was the first. Katharine, Jane, Mark and Martha pick up a coin on the way to the library. They think it's an ordinary nickel, but gradually discover, after a series of mishaps, that it's a magic coin.

The catch is that it only grants half your wish. So when the youngest, Martha, is sick of being bossed around by her siblings, she wishes she wasn't there. Half of her remains, the other flits about wrecking ghostly havoc. The books enthralled me. The children were unlike the usual story-book children: they fought and argued; their widowed mother had big money troubles; they were bookish and imaginative. If magic could happen to an ordinary family, it could happen to anyone. Even to me.

Francesca Simon's latest book, Horrid Henry and the Mummy's Curse (£3.99, Dolphin), is a World Book Day Super Reads promotion

Michael Rosen
A White Sail Gleams by Valentin Katayev

My mother found obscure and absorbing books to read to me, such as Miskito Boy and Raff the Jungle Bird, alongside Beatrix Potter and Norse myths. The Tailor of Gloucester and The Binding of Fenrir were favourites. Later on, my father did holiday-time readings of Great Expectations (which I loved) and Little Dorrit (which I didn't). None of this fits the stereotype of Communist Party members, does it?

Talking of which, the book that most drew me into its imaginative space was Russian. A White Sail Gleams was written by Valentin Katayev in 1936. It's an intriguing mix of realism and expressionism, telling the story of two boys caught up in the 1905 revolution. Petya is middle-class, Gavrik a street-kid, both faced with the dilemma of what to do with a sailor on the run from the Battleship Potemkin mutiny - the revolt, pogroms and repression going on around them.

The dialogue is full of edge and humour, the tone of the scenes switches beautifully from tension to melancholy and the relationship between the two boys is full of anxiety and niggle.

Michael Rosen teaches children's literature at the University of North London and presents Word of Mouth on BBC Radio 4. His most recent book is Even More Nonsense (£10.99, Hodder). For more information about World Book Day events, visit www.worldbookday.com
