webTitle: Essex authorities' model for health and social services link

fields.headline: Forward together
fields.standfirst: Essex authorities' model for health and social services link
fields.trailText: Essex authorities' model for health and social services link
fields.body:
As concern over accountability of the government's proposed care trusts continues, with the health and social care bill entering the Lords this week, the east London authority of Barking and Dagenham has come up with a novel approach to avert social services being hijacked by the NHS.

The council's director of social services, Julia Ross, has been made chief executive of Barking and Dagenham's new primary care trust (PCT). The move means that Ross will in effect be managing a combined health and social care operation when the PCT gets underway in April 2001.

Barking and Havering health authority claims the joint appointment will lead to a much closer relationship between health services and the council, leading to better and improved services for residents in the seventh most deprived borough in London. The new model will see social services being delivered in new settings, such as GP surgeries, and will enable health visitors, nurses and social workers to work alongside each other.

Ross says: "My job is to pull both health and social care together to maximise scarce resources. You really can't have the two being run separately, especially in an area like Barking and Dagenham with high levels of ill heath and poverty. It makes no sense.

"Having one body managing both will make it much easier to provide a complete care package for someone. It will really make a difference. We'll be able to drive through all the improvements people want to see simply by working together more closely to a common purpose. It's easier to focus on people's needs rather than service boundaries.

"Obsession with structures is counter to the person. We should organise services around what people need. We are trying to create a more integrated and seamless service for the punter."

The PCT will pool its £87m budget, 600 staff - including nurses, therapists and dentists, plus 75 local doctors - with social services' £60m budget and 1,200 staff. In time, it will be responsible for joint planning, provision and purchasing of all health and social care services.

Ross admits that social services colleagues had been worried about establishment of the new trust, which is accountable to the health authority, fearing that social services would be sucked into health authority control. But she says the dual accountability and joint governance arrangements achieved by her appointment have overcome such fears.

The model will be evaluated against a number of targets. "Our two primary targets are to ensure service users think and feel they are getting a better service, and to ensure staff think it is a better way to provide the service," she says.

Ross, who has experience both of nursing and social work, joined Barking and Dagenham council as interim director of social services in November 1998 after the authority was put on special measures. She was appointed permanent director in June 1999. Her appointment to the PCT follows that of local councillor, Ray Parkin, as chair.

Parkin, who expounded the virtues of joint working during his eight years as leader of the council's health and environment committee, says: "People couldn't give a fig who they get the service from as long as it's good.

"The current service within the NHS is not flexible enough to meet our health needs because we are lumped together with the affluent area of Havering, so our ill health was hidden. The PCT gives us this flexibility."

Parkin hopes there wil be scope for more integration across social services, education, housing and the environment.

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, welcomes the Barking and Dagenham initiative.

"It is an interesting way of approaching partnerships," she says. "Different models work in different localities. It's up to local people to work out what works best for them. There is a lot to be gained from close working between local authorities and social services.

"The Barking and Dagenham arrangement clearly is about an equal partnership with the chief executive accountable to democratically elected councillors through the social services committee."

By contrast, Gibb points out that the government's proposed community trusts could simply become NHS bodies, accountable only to the secretary of state, unless their governance arrangements are made clear in primary legislation.

fields.headline: Evans may buy Swansea City
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Chris Evans has approached Swansea City about buying the struggling football club.
fields.body:
Multimillionaire media tycoon Chris Evans has approached Swansea City about buying the struggling football club.

Swansea chairman Neil McClure has confirmed that an agent acting for Mr Evans had contacted the second division club about a possible sale.

"I have received a telephone call from Danny Murphy, who is a representative of Chris Evans, saying Chris was interested in Swansea City," said Mr McClure.

"He said, however, that he was currently looking at a first division club and if that deal fell through he would be taking a closer look at Swansea City."

The struggling south Wales club was last month put up for sale by its owners, windscreen replacement company Ninth Floor, last month.

The move followed rising criticism from fans who claimed too little cash was being spent to attract the talent necessary to ensure success.

Mr Evans, 35, is known to have been interested in buying first division strugglers QPR, but Swansea City would represent a far cheaper option.

He made £75m when he sold his Ginger Media Group, which includes Virgin Radio and the Ginger TV production company, to SMG in January 2000

A spokesman for Mr Evans was unavailable for comment.

Related story

fields.headline: eToys files for bankruptcy
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The battered e-commerce sector yesterday claimed its biggest casualty yet when eToys - a US company once valued in excess of £12bn - filed for bankruptcy. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
The battered e-commerce sector yesterday claimed its biggest casualty yet when eToys - a US company once valued in excess of £12bn - filed for bankruptcy, declaring its shares "worthless".

The online toyseller said that it had no choice after failing to find a buyer. It said its stated debt figure of $274m (£190m) was likely to become "substantially higher" when the full amount of monies owing was finally calculated.

Shares in eToys were suspended, having last traded at just nine cents each and valuing the firm at £14m. At their height in 1999 the shares changed hands for $80 each.

"The climate we faced remained extremely harsh and a buyer did not emerge," eToys spokesman Ken Ross said.

The website will be closed on March 8, cash will run out on March 31 and all employees will be fired by April 6, the company added.

The collapse of eToys comes less than two years after it was being hailed as a business pioneer that stood to change the way people shopped for their toys forever.

Founded in 1998, it raised $50m in venture capital funding as a private company and a further $166m when it floated on the Nasdaq stock market in 1999.

Initial customer service was deemed to be poor and it struggled to fulfil orders during its first Christmas season. However, analysts and investors maintained it would emerge as a winner even if the dot.com bubble burst. Competitors like Toys R Us said they believed the "first mover" advantage of building a big internet presence would make it hard to compete with.

Executives invested heavily in rectifying the fulfilment problems, building state of the art warehouses and computer systems.

In December eToys said it was likely to run out of cash by March if it did not receive "additional, substantial capital infusion". Strong sales of $131m last Christmas suggested eToys might have turned the corner but it appears that the extra money it spent simply tipped it over the edge.

Analysts said it should have sold at least $200m worth of goods during the festive season to stay afloat.

Three days into the new year eToys said it would shut down its UK operation with the loss of 74 jobs. At one stage the operation, which had a turnover of £1.6m in its first six months, employed 100 people.

The announcement was made on the company's website with an image of children's favourite Bob the Builder asking "Can we fix it?" and a reply saying "No we can't".

Established toy retailers such as Toys R Us, Wal-Mart, Kmart and Target have been the biggest thorn in eToys side. A partnership between Toys R Us and online retailer Amazon.com was another blow.

UK e-commerce firms have not been immune from difficulties. Debt laden e-tailer LetsBuyIt.com was recently forced to refinance, while Boo.com and Clickmango.com folded.

Initial customer service was deemed to be poor and it struggled to fulfil orders during its first Christmas season. However, analysts and investors maintained it would emerge as a winner even if the dot.com bubble burst. Competitors like Toys R Us said they believed the "first mover" advantage of building a big internet presence would make it hard to compete with. Executives invested heavily in rectifying the fulfilment problems, building state of the art warehouses and computer systems. In December eToys said it was likely to run out of cash by March if it did not receive "additional, substantial capital infusion". Strong sales of $131m last Christmas suggested eToys might have turned the corner but it appears that the extra money it spent simply tipped it over the edge. Analysts said it should have sold at least $200m worth of goods during the festive season to stay afloat. Three days into the new year eToys said it would shut down its UK operation with the loss of 74 jobs. At one stage the operation, which had a turnover of £1.6m in its first six months, employed 100 people. The announcement was made on the company's website with an image of children's favourite Bob the Builder asking "Can we fix it?" and a reply saying "No we can't". Established toy retailers such as Toys R Us, Wal-Mart, Kmart and Target have been the biggest thorn in eToys side. A partnership between Toys R Us and online retailer Amazon.com was another blow. UK e-commerce firms have not been immune from difficulties. Debt laden e-tailer LetsBuyIt.com was recently forced to refinance, while Boo.com and Clickmango.com folded.

fields.headline: Canine cull divides Bucharest
fields.standfirst: Finding a solution for the Romanian capital's longstanding stray dog problem is proving contentious, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Finding a solution for the Romanian capital's longstanding stray dog problem is proving contentious, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
Driving south out of Bucharest about two years ago there was an almighty thump on the side of the Dacia. Looking back I was shocked to see a sandy-coloured pile lying motionless in the middle of the road, and I asked my friend to stop the car. "It's only a dog," he said, "plenty of others like him around."

We drove on, I, stunned into silence, he unable to see why I was upset. The Bucharesters react to their overpopulation of dogs in completely different ways. One friend told me she always fed the cluster of mongrels who gathered outside her apartment block every evening for a session of twilight barking and which also proved to be decent watchdogs.

Her journalist husband had befriended one who bemusedly hopped on the tram with him every morning, and hopped off when he arrived at his workplace, skipping round the back of the newspaper building for a daily rendezvous with his canine companions.

And speak to the thousands of street children and they'll often tell you the dogs are their best friends. But now Bucharest's strays - there are estimated to be around 100,000 of them and a further 200,000 in the rest of Romania - are for the chop.

In a culling programme which begins tomorrow, dog catchers are being employed to round them up and place them in kennels. Owners will be given ten days to make a claim, and sign a form admitting responsibility. Those that are not claimed will be given lethal injections, and probably, sent to soap factories.

Animal rights groups are up in arms. The problem, they say, has existed for years, but only now are city authorities acting, and in the most monstrous way.

Brigitte Bardot has become the Romanian government's most outspoken critic. The French film goddess has made several visits to the city, to fight, she says, for the rights of the dogs and the street children. "In my eyes," she said on a recent visit, "Bucharest is a symbol of courage and generosity. I don't want it to become a symbol of death and shame."

The sudden actions by authorities have been triggered by prime minister Adrian Natase's fear that the dogs are damaging Romania's reputation abroad. He has admitted being particularly embarrassed by an article in last month's La Libération newspaper which talked of the city's streets heaving with rabid dogs.

But the decision to cull them is not only to do with Romania's reputation. According to the anti-rabies centre in Bucharest, over 20,000 people were last year bitten by strays - some of them rabid - and had to be treated in hospital.

But many Bucharesters say the dogs are only a part of the problem. In most parts of the capital the rubbish can stack up on the streets for days before it is picked up.

Once, sitting at the window of my hotel on Piati Rossetti, I saw a pack of dogs huddling round open sacks in the street sniffing for food. A group of street children who lived in a nearby sewer saw the dogs' presence as a signal that there might be something to eat and gathered round. Then it probably didn't take the rats long to find their way.

Mr Natase is not the first to plan the dogs' demise. Previous governments have had similar ideas, but have failed twice to realise them. One plan was to hunt them down and administer poisonous injections. But animal rights organisers got wind of the plan and published video recordings of the "dog murders", bringing it to an end.

The second idea was slicker, but far too expensive: to sterilise the dogs so that they would gradually die out. The current plan, say officials, is the cheapest and most effective.

"It will take at least two years," says Liviu Harbuz, the prime minister's dog-culling adviser. "The average age of the stray dog population is now about three years and their life expectancy is around six years, so within three years we might expect significant results."

But however much the dogs clutter the city, a growing number of citizens are against the quick-fix scheme which is due to cost the cash-strapped city around £1.1m. Last month a few hundred staged a protest outside Bucharest' s town hall.

Those gathered explained why they were so strongly against the mass extermination. "These dogs have been around since the 70s," said an elderly man, "ever since the communists ordered the large-scale demolition of houses and we were forced to move into tiny flats and abandon our dogs."

Hence there's a certain nostalgia and sense of mass ownership attached to the dogs' presence. They, like the hundreds of street children (largely the products of attempts to create a huge workforce) are painful legacies of the reign of communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who will live to haunt his country for years to come.

On a visit a couple of years ago, Bardot had pledged to take home a stray and a street child - the two most poignant symbols, she said to much scorn, of Romania's desperate state. But in the end she plumped for two of the scraggy dogs after the authorities rumbled her plan.

webTitle: Dome's hamster goes for £3,000, the body zone louse for rather less

fields.headline: Dome's hamster goes for £3,000, the body zone louse for rather less
fields.standfirst:
Souvenir hunters of the bizarre descend on Greenwich as everything from giant brains to inflatable greenhouses go under the hammer

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Everyone wanted the giant hamster and cheese. But not everyone was prepared to part with thousands of pounds for it - which is why, in the end, the oversized piece of junk which came to symbolise the auction of the Millennium Dome's contents went to the owner of a Kent visitor attraction.
fields.body:
Everyone wanted the giant hamster and cheese. But not everyone was prepared to part with thousands of pounds for it - which is why, in the end, the oversized piece of junk which came to symbolise the auction of the Millennium Dome's contents went to the owner of a Kent visitor attraction.

The £3,000 that 40-year-old Brent Pollard paid to take the fibreglass rodent home to Paddock Wood was by no means the only preposterous price paid yesterday as around 600 bidders descended on Greenwich to pick flesh - almost literally, in the case of the body zone - from the skeleton of the great white elephant. "I started out bidding at £250," Mr Pollard explained, eyeing his new companion warily. "But I suppose I just got carried away. I'm really rather surprised that there's so much interest in this piece. Mind you, I'd be happy to spend £100,000 over the four days if it's worth it."

The serious money will be made today and over the next two days, as thousands of laptops, lighting rigs and pieces of catering equipment are sold off, but yesterday's auction was a festival of pointlessness to rival the Millennium Experience itself.

In a futuristic blue-and-silver auditorium a few hundred metres from the dome, auctioneer John Judson gamely trotted out the usual cliches - "a rather special item coming up now," and "a very unusual piece, this". But that kind of patter was never going to work, because everything on sale - from the giant brains to the imitation tree trunks to the snowman costumes to the inflatable greenhouses to the "angel-winged interactive pods" - was fundamentally unusual, and the prices some were prepared to pay for them even more so.

"I never went to the dome because I thought it was an abhorrent waste of public money, but this is different," said Benedict Davies, a 32-year-old product developer, who had his eye on several scraps of fake human tissue encased in plastic which he reckoned might look attractive sunken into the floor of his living room. "It's a souvenir of a national disaster. It's a very British thing to do, isn't it?"

It was somewhere around the time that a single floor tile from the money zone went for £120 ("I hope you enjoy it, sir," said the auctioneer, mystified) that I realised I certainly wasn't going to get a major piece of the body - the heart, say, or the eye - for a more reasonable £100. In fact, I was going to be lucky to get a seed head parade costume, as exuberantly modelled in the auction room by an outgoing member of dome staff, or, for that matter, a "recycled seagull built from kitchen utensils".

At one point in the often chaotic bidding process I was sure I had bagged one of the sought-after body zone mannequins, but given the resemblance it later turned out to bear to some kind of sex toy, it was a relief to discover that I hadn't, and thus wouldn't be forced to cart it back on the Jubilee line during the rush hour. Another mannequin, a depressed-looking man in an England shirt, his head in his hands, was bought by a sadistic Scot. Eventually, arms flailing, it was almost by accident that I bought my first piece of 21st century history: 10 hamster cages, inconveniently bolted together, at £25 the lot.

Back in the cavernous, stripped down dome itself, where the lots were being held and Christmas decorations still adorned the walls, the remaining handful of dome employees watched forlornly as punters came to dismantle their workplace. "Psychologically, I suppose it's healthy," said 43-year-old Chris Aygin with dismay as she kept guard over four mannequins in surgical dress which would later sell for £320. "We've come to the funeral, we're burying the body, and we're grieving."

Around them, buyers struggled to rationalise the motives behind their acquisitions. "It's just a bit of fun," said Anne Creasey, who had travelled down from Ludlow in Shropshire for the day with her farmer husband Chris, and would be returning with a giant's sink and draining board, a comically huge iron bed and a mysterious 12ft balustrade. "Maybe we can put it in the children's playroom or something. I don't know. It's just a bit of fun," she said again, perhaps a little too insistently.

Gavin Pretor-Pinney, the 32-year-old co-founder of The Idler magazine, had snapped up the body's enormous eye - complete with sinisterly glistening cornea - for £500, but didn't seem wholly reconciled to the fact. "I'm not entirely sure what I've done," he said. "I mean, I haven't got enough room for it in my flat. It was a really stupid idea, actually." Then his face brightened. "But it could be one for Damien Hirst, couldn't it? I've just bought a Damien Hirst for £500!"

The pubic louse wasn't nearly so much of a bargain as the eye, but at £100 it was affordable. In fact, nobody seemed very clear whether the foot-long piece of jelly-like plastic with metal attachments really was a pubic louse, or just a skin mite: in the catalogue it was identified only as "a parasite". In a former incarnation, it used to scuttle up and down the body, but it is not clear whether its mechanical parts will ever function quite as they once did. Several similar ones went to an antiques dealer from Epsom, who said he would use them to scare his wife and children.

"It's a bit sad, really," said Geoff, the dome worker who came to help me extract the louse from its storage box. "I used to work with this guy."

What they paid

 Giant hamster and cheese £3,000.

 "Time cogs" engraved crystal dish £1,700.

 Piaggio Vespa scooter, (incomplete) £1,250.

 Mannequin wearing England soccer shirt, head in hands £900.

 A brain, from the body zone £700.

 Heart from the body zone £1,500.

 "Time machine" brass-faced clock and two Blackadder paintings £650

 The eye from the body zone £500.

 Front half of a flower power Mini ("no tax or MoT") £450.

 A snowman costume, hat and scarf £180.

 A spotted glass floor tile £120.

 10 hamster cages £25.

 "Theo" millennium show costume £20.

 Oversized metal chair £15.

Prices exclude 10% buyers' premium and 17.5% VAT.

fields.headline: Driver 'complicit in immigrant deaths'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A Dutch lorry driver played an active part in a people smuggling operation which saw 58 Chinese immigrants suffocate in the back of a lorry bound for Britain, a court heard today.
fields.body:
A Dutch lorry driver played an active part in a people smuggling operation which saw 58 Chinese immigrants suffocate in the back of a lorry bound for Britain, a court heard today.

Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, Holland, is charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and four counts of conspiracy to smuggle people into Britain.

Female interpreter Ying Guo, 29, of Rivenhall Gardens, south Woodford, Essex, is jointly charged with Wacker on another count of conspiracy to smuggle immigrants into Britain. Both deny all charges.

The 54 men and four women suffocated as they tried to enter Britain illegally in the back of a truck laden with tomatoes on June 18 last year.

Shocked customs and excise officers discovered the bodies - and two male survivors - in a sealed lorry container at Dover's eastern docks.

A jury at Maidstone crown court today heard how Mr Wacker and Ms Guo had both been involved to different degrees in a worldwide people-smuggling network.

Victor Temple QC, prosecuting, said that it was important to understand the background of where the immigrants came from. "Life in China can be very hard, work is often difficult to obtain and wages low," he said.

"Some choose to settle in continental Europe, others come to Britain. Many come without papers, crossing the channel in ways so as not to come the attention of the immigration authorities.

He said a people smuggling organisation called the Snakeheads charged up to £20,000 per person.

"If discovered, such people will often put forward false claims for asylum as political refugees."

Mr Temple said that in June last year, 60 Chinese immigrants were waiting in two safe houses in Rotterdam, having travelled across Europe from their homeland.

He said Wacker did not fall into the role of the driver who was recruited at the last minute for a one-off fee.

"The crown says he was more deeply involved. He concerned himself in executing the transport side of the operation that led, in turn, to his driving the 60 Chinese immigrants onto a P&O ferry during a hot summer evening.

"The luckless and unfortunate Chinese were obliged to sit or squat in an airtight container with little or no opportunity to move and only a little water to quench their thirst."

fields.headline: Anger at huge 'fire sale' of unused bargains
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: While yesterday's auction at the dome may have been a mecca for souvenir hunters hoping to pick up a novelty item or two, the serious business will begin today when millions of pounds worth of catering and office equipment go under the hammer.
fields.body:
While yesterday's auction at the dome may have been a mecca for souvenir hunters hoping to pick up a novelty item or two, the serious business will begin today when millions of pounds worth of catering and office equipment go under the hammer.

With no reserve prices and a policy that everything must go, items with a retail price of several thousand pounds are likely to be sold for a fraction of their true value, leading to accusations that the Greenwich attraction is being asset stripped by a government keen to wash its hands of the disastrous project. Pierre-Yves Gerbau, the former dome boss who wants to turn the site back into a visitor attraction, has already accused the government of "sabotaging" his bid through the sell-off and yesterday the Tories likened the auction to a "fire sale".

Bargain hunters from as far afield as Italy and Germany inspecting the lots yesterday were amazed to find apparently unused computers and other electrical goods included in the auction of more than 3,000 lots of catering and 5,000 lots of broadcast, sound and lighting equipment.

Among the items on offer are 198 "plasma" flat screen televisions - 12 of them unused - which retail for several thousand pounds each; 57 laptop computers and 459 PCs. Top of the range kitchen equipment, from industrial size dishwashers to combination ovens, will also go under the hammer.

Peter Ainsworth, shadow culture secretary, said that like everything else to do with the dome the sale was being bungled. "It is all very well getting £3,000 for a giant hamster, but most of the value is in office equipment that may well go for a song. It looks like a fire sale and that hardly represents good value for the public purse."

The money raised at the four-day auction will go to the dome organisers, the New Millennium Experience Company, to pay off any outstanding bills before it goes into "solvent liquidation" this summer.

Any surplus money will go back to the millennium commission which authorised an extra £179mof national lottery money for the failing NMEC last year.

One seasoned auction buyer said he was shocked at the goods that were up for sale: "I'm not somebody with a particular social conscience, but it has made me quite angry to see all this stuff being sold off when the taxpayers have paid for it."

Pierre-Yves Gerbau, the former dome boss who wants to turn the site back into a visitor attraction, has already accused the government of "sabotaging" his bid through the sell-off and yesterday the Tories likened the auction to a "fire sale". Bargain hunters from as far afield as Italy and Germany inspecting the lots yesterday were amazed to find apparently unused computers and other electrical goods included in the auction of more than 3,000 lots of catering and 5,000 lots of broadcast, sound and lighting equipment. Among the items on offer are 198 "plasma" flat screen televisions - 12 of them unused - which retail for several thousand pounds each; 57 laptop computers and 459 PCs. Top of the range kitchen equipment, from industrial size dishwashers to combination ovens, will also go under the hammer. Peter Ainsworth, shadow culture secretary, said that like everything else to do with the dome the sale was being bungled. "It is all very well getting £3,000 for a giant hamster, but most of the value is in office equipment that may well go for a song. It looks like a fire sale and that hardly represents good value for the public purse." The money raised at the four-day auction will go to the dome organisers, the New Millennium Experience Company, to pay off any outstanding bills before it goes into "solvent liquidation" this summer. Any surplus money will go back to the millennium commission which authorised an extra £179mof national lottery money for the failing NMEC last year. One seasoned auction buyer said he was shocked at the goods that were up for sale: "I'm not somebody with a particular social conscience, but it has made me quite angry to see all this stuff being sold off when the taxpayers have paid for it."

fields.headline: How Dynamo defied the Nazis
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: THE BRAVEST FOOTBALLERS EVER?
fields.body:
THE BRAVEST FOOTBALLERS EVER?

"I once read that in a cup final during the great famine of the 1930's, there were three Ukrainian brothers on a Kiev team that beat the team from Moscow sponsored by the secret police," says Ian Walmsley. "Unfortunately, Stalin is reputed to have ordered the game to be replayed for political reasons; and the brothers warned not to win again. As an act of defiance on behalf of the starving Ukrainian people the Kiev team won the replay and the brothers disappeared into the Gulag. Is this true, or just a myth? If it's true, they must be the bravest footballers ever. "

It seems that the events you describe didn't quite happen, Ian, but something very similar did. In 1942 Stalin did send a set of footballing brothers to the gulag - but they played for Spartak Moscow, not Dynamo Kiev. That same year, however, most of Dynamo's team were executed by the Nazis after refusing to throw a series of "friendly" matches.

We'll get the Spartak story out of the way first: Nikolai, Andrey, Petr and Alexander Starostin, the popular brothers who led Spartak to the USSR championship in 1937 and 1938 were illegally arrested as "public enemies" in 1942 by Stalin and dumped in the gulag. They were only released thirty years later. Alexander - the man who founded Spartak in 1922 - returned to the club become "club leader" until his death in 1996.

Meanwhile, when Kiev was occupied in 1941, members of the Dynamo team found work in Kiev Bakery No. 1 and started to play football in an empty lot. The Germans offered them the opportunity to train in the Zenith Stadium and suggested a friendly with a team picked from the German army.

The Ukrainians accepted the offer, named their team Start and the match took place on June 12, 1942. The Germans, in good physical condition, scored the first goal. But by half-time Start had edged 2-1 ahead, much to the anger of a German officer from the Commandant's box who stormed into the team's dressing room and ordered them "not to play so keenly" - threatening to shoot them if they did not obey.

But Start ignored the warning and surged into a 4-1 lead. At that point the German Commandant of Kiev, Major-General Eberhardt, and his staff left, and the referee ended the game early. On July 17 the Germans fielded a stronger team still lost 6-0. Further Dynamo victories against the Hungarian team MSG Wal (5-1 and 3-2) followed.

The German administration was outraged that they decided to teach the Ukrainians a lesson. And so the "ever victorious" German Flakelf team was invited. But this German team also lost to Dynamo and not a word about it appeared in the newspapers.

The Ukrainian team were given three days to think about their position and on August 9th there was a "friendly" rematch. In spite of the warnings Dynamo again defeated the German team - for the last time. Most of the Ukrainian team members were arrested and executed in Babyn Yar, but they are not forgotten. There is a monument to them in Kiev and their heroism is said to have inspired the film Escape to Victory.

For more information see the Spartak Moscow official homepage click here and the Ukrainian Fraternal Association click here.

TRICKY TEASER

"Arsenal cannot do it unless Arsene Wenger leaves. Man Utd have done it more than any other British club. Liverpool have done it once but not in the usual way. Everton, Oldham and Charlton have all done it once but Wimbledon will NEVER do it unless Crystal Palace go bankrupt. What is it?" asks Marcus Pretlove.

"The answer is they've all hosted Rugby league matches," reckons Rob Jordan. "Arsene Wenger has said "no" to a proposed move of the Silk-Cut Challenge cup final from Wembley to Highbury.

"There have been loads of Rugby League games held at Old Trafford. And in the recent Rugby League World Cup, Anfield staged a friendly games for the Australian team to get some practice in (so a non-competitive game and hence not in the usual way).

"Everton and Oldham have staged Rugby League games and the London Broncos used to ground share the Valley with Charlton. Meanwhile Wimbledon wanted to ground share with the London Broncos, but it's not their ground, and Crystal Palace said no."

PROVE A TOKYO BAR OWNER WRONG!

"The owner of our local bar here in Tokyo, states that Sweden, Holland, Belgium, France and Portugal are the only European sides, outside of the British Isles, to ever field a black player in a full international. We think that he is talking out of his arse, can someone please help us out, so that we can shut him up?" says Nigel Drake.

Of course. Just tell him that Vicente Engonga played for Spain during 2000 - that should do the trick.

LITTLE BROTHERS TRYING TO MAKE IT BIG: PART 2

"At the moment in Italy, Christian Vieri's little brother Massimiliano and Roberto Baggio's little bro' Eddy are playing together for Serie B side Ancona. Are there any other younger brothers of big name players attempting to do likewise? asked Martin Casey.

Last week we mentioned Youssouf Hadji (younger brother of Coventry's Mustapha) and Egutu Oliseh (same of Borussia Dortmund's Sunday). But as Paul Crankshaw points out there are big name brothers playing closer to home. "Rhodri Giggs and Chris Brown, brothers of Ryan and Wes, play for Bangor City - they were recently joined by Clayton Blackmore," he says.

Can you help?

"Me and my friends got talking about this without resolution, what is the most popular colour for a teams shirt in all four divisions?" asks Stephen M.

"Can someone tell me who has played for the most professional clubs during a season or career?" asks Derek Tomkin.

"Has there ever been a player who, after being sold by his club, came back to score against them in an FA cup final?" asks Lee Cafferkey.

"Having watched the recent penalty shoot out in FA Cup replay between Wimbledon and Wycombe, does anybody know what the highest score in a penalty shoot out is and who the teams were?" asks Richard Beeby.

"Apparently on June 25th 1975, in a match between Chile and Uruguay there were nineteen players sent off (ten Chileans and nine Uruguayans). What was the rumpus that caused the ref such a problem?" asks Kevin Jones.

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Cadamarteri denies breaking woman's cheekbone
fields.trailText: Everton footballer Danny Cadamarteri has denied assaulting a woman in Liverpool city centre.
fields.body:
Everton footballer Danny Cadamarteri has denied assaulting a woman in Liverpool city centre.

Cadamarteri, 21, of Walton Cross Cottage, Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire, pleaded not guilty to a charge of assault occasioning actual bodily harm.

Joeline Joel, 24, suffered a broken cheekbone in the alleged incident, which happened in the early hours of October 1 last year in Hardman Street.

He will stand trial at Liverpool Crown Court on September 3 in a case that is expected to last five days.

The striker, dressed in a black top and trousers, spoke only to confirm his name and address. He was remanded on conditional bail until September 3.

fields.headline: Coke set to dump 'Enjoy' slogan
fields.trailText: 12pm: Coca-Cola is planning to ditch its 'Enjoy' advertising slogan, according to reports in the US, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is planning to ditch its "Enjoy" advertising slogan after little more than a year, according to reports in the US.

The decision follows a major shake-up of Coca-Cola's advertising arrangements following the appointment of a new chief executive, Douglas Daft, a year ago.

"Enjoy" was the successor to the long-running "Always Coca-Cola" campaign and has been in use for just over a year.

Possible replacements are thought to include "Life tastes good" and "The Magic Within".

The new direction is thought to be the brainchild of Interpublic.

Coca-Cola hired the marketing giant last year to help develop its global communications strategy.

Mr Daft wants to develop a more consistent image for Coca-Cola.

The company spends an estimated £690m a year on marketing its flagship brand.

fields.headline: Internet incubator axes staff
fields.trailText: 2pm: Internet incubator Brainspark has axed nine staff and revamped its management board, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet incubator Brainspark has axed nine staff and revamped its management board following a "disappointing" year.

The drastic move comes after an eight-month funding drought.

It failed to raise funding for its fledgling new media businesses last summer and today announced a radical restructuring to keep the company afloat.

"A year ago, we were not expecting the market to be so negative towards the technology sector," said David Hart, director of marketing at Brainspark.

"We could carry on as we are, but that would not be sensible and that is not what or shareholders want. We have to be realistic."

Internet incubators build web companies and then recoup their investment through a sale or stock market flotation.

However, the change in attitude towards technology firms has seen markets and potential buyers lock up their wallets.

This trend was underlined by today's inaugural full-year results for Brainspark, which reported a £14.5m loss and saw the value of its businesses tumble from £30m to £24m.

"If you looked at the sector as a whole, we are doing better than average," added Mr Hart.

"I think the market is saying we are not happy with the technology sector and the jury is still out on incubators. We cannot always produce consistent growth."

In a bid to turn around Brainspark's fortunes, the company has shown the door to chief operating officer Alwyn Welch and chief financial officer Mark Harford, and seven other staff at its London offices.

Don Caldwell, chief executive of key Brainspark shareholder Cross Atlantic Capital Partners, will become chairman.

Mr Hart remained bullish about the prospects for Brainspark's properties, which include the Smile-on internet service for dentists and the Traderserve share dealing business.

"We accept that the process of selling might take longer than we first stated, but it does not mean the end of our business if it takes longer for our companies to go for a trade sale or flotation," he said.

Brainspark has £9.8m in the bank, and intends to clip its monthly cash burn from £0.5m to £0.2m.

webTitle: Must film music always come a poor second?

fields.headline: Ears wide open
fields.standfirst: Must film music always come a poor second to the images?   John Tavener, Werner Herzog and even Claudia Schiffer have been working to redress the balance.
fields.trailText: Must film music always come a poor second to the images? John Tavener, Werner Herzog and even Claudia Schiffer have been working to redress the balance.
fields.body:
Film music has spent a long time trying to live down its bad name. Aaron Copland once likened it to "a small lamp that you place beneath the screen to warm it". Until recently the worst thing you could say about a new, supposedly classical work was that it sounded like film music. As film has matured as a medium, however, film music has gradually gained acceptance as more than a lightweight sonic accompaniment, and the relationship between the two art forms is now being re-examined.

Traditionally a score has not been written as an independent work; its logic - its forms, rhythms and textures - is dictated by the requirements of the film. To this end, mainstream cinema has developed a musical language for a range of dramatic scenarios, which has fast descended into a set of film-making cliches: accentuated brass and heavy percussion for car chases, strings or piano for romance, west coast jazz for seduction and so on.

But film and music can come together in an atmosphere of more balanced artistic cooperation. This is the premise behind a project called Sound on Film - four collaborations commissioned by the BBC between leading film-makers and musicians: Hal Hartley with Louis Andriessen, Nicolas Roeg with Portishead's Adrian Utley, the Brothers Quay with Karlheinz Stockhausen, and Werner Herzog with John Tavener. All are to be premiered live this week at the Barbican as part of the Only Connect season.

"We wanted to find a way of presenting new music that would have a different relationship with film - music that isn't soundtrack music," explains executive producer Rodney Wilson. "We wanted to get music and images in a different dialogue."

In contrast to commercial films, where music is generally used as a navigational device to reinforce storytelling, the images of both Hal Hartley and the Brothers Quay were created in response to the specially composed music of Andriessen and Stockhausen respectively.

Hartley's film The New Math(s) is a martial arts-style spatial ballet playfully centred around ideas of maths, time and space in a classroom. "I started listening to Andriessen's music," Hartley says, "and I let my immediate impressions give me ideas. In his work I felt a strong awareness of the mathematics of music, but it was countered with this real sense of fun."

Similarly, the Quays' response to Stockhausen, In Absentia, revealed an almost uncanny personal connection between them and the composer. The film magnifies the disturbing, surreal world of a woman in an asylum as she painstakingly writes a letter to her husband. But it was only after Stockhausen saw the film that he explained to the Quays that his own mother had been committed to an asylum by the Nazis.

"When I made the music I had no images," Stockhausen says, "but the Brothers Quay have a quality of spiritual life or art that exactly corresponds to what I'm trying to realise in music."

Herzog and Tavener, meanwhile, initially met to discuss the director's idea of a film based on pilgrims, and Tavener played some rough ideas to Herzog on the piano. Herzog told Tavener: "I can hear what you're playing working with my images." But while Herzog went to a Catholic shrine in Mexico to film profoundly emotional images of religious devotion, Tavener went off to write in Greece - the two working in tandem but without actual collaboration.

Both were content with the result, however. "I wanted to make a film about human pathos and Tavener composed a piece of music that is very deep and very good," Herzog says. "I haven't heard anything of that calibre for at least a decade."

Of the four films, Nicolas Roeg and Adrian Utley's Sound involved perhaps the closest collaboration. The film is a multi-layered visual and sonic collage featuring Claudia Schiffer in a meditation on celebrity, memory and sound itself. The process began with Roeg explaining his overall concept to Utley, sending him poems and pictures by way of illustration. He then made his film while Utley set about creating a score, but at the final dubbing stage the pair decided to rearrange the sound entirely. "I made 70 minutes of music for a 15-minute film," Utley says, "and in the end we just chopped it all into tiny bits. The music is not literal to the picture and anyway I think it's better to come at it from an obtuse angle because the more it doesn't fit the picture, the more it says something."

The relationship between film and music is at the heart of the Only Connect season. Based around creative collaborations, it will include live performances by Ennio Morricone and Ornette Coleman, as well as Howard Shore conducting his own score to a projection of David Cronenberg's The Naked Lunch. Asian Dub Foundation will improvise to a screening of Mathieu Kassovitz's film La Haine.

This last project looks at music and film from yet another angle, that of a freestyle, live accompaniment to the film's existing soundtrack in response to the images on screen - an approach closest in origin to the lone piano of silent cinema's earliest accompaniments. "To me everything is about expression," says Asian Dub Foundation's Chandrasonic. "I don't think you can really draw a line between the two. I see the film as another instrument and the music as a visual tool - there is no barrier between them. Music and film are just automatically intertwined."  Sound on Film is premiered live at the Barbican, London EC2, on Thursday. The Only Connect season continues until April 9. Box office for all events: 020-7638 8891. John Barry - A Sixties Theme, by Eddi Fiegel, is published by Constable, price £16.99.

fields.headline: Viewers flock to BBC regional news
fields.trailText: 1.30pm TV overnights: Viewers chose the BBC's regional bulletins for updates on the foot and mouth crisis, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
At times of national crisis, the nation invariably turns to the BBC and yesterday viewers flocked to the regional news in their droves.

More than 8m viewers tuned in to BBC1's 6.30pm regional bulletins around the country to find out the latest news on foot and mouth disease in their area.

The combined audience for BBC1's 30-minute early evening regional news yesterday was the highest since the fuel crisis last autumn.

It was also 1m up on Monday, which is usually the most-watched bulletin of the week as people tune in after the weekend break.

The regional news had 8.1m viewers - a 36% share of viewing at that time - according to unofficial overnights.

It beat the ITV Evening News, which had 6.7m viewers from 6.30pm.

From 6pm, the ITV regional news magazines pulled in 5.8m and a 28% share.

Elsewhere last night, the gossip surrounding Robbie Williams and Geri Halliwell helped the Brit Awards pull in more than 8m viewers on ITV.

The two-hour pop extravaganza beat BBC1 drama opposition Holby City and In Deep from 8pm.

The Brit Awards gained 8.4m viewers and a 33% audience share.

Hospital drama Holby City ran the ITV show close, notching up 8m pairs of eyeballs; while undercover cop show In Deep managed 6.9m.

Earlier in the evening, EastEnders pulled in a stonking 15.6m audience - three in five viewers watching TV at the time - between 7.30pm and 8pm.

The eve of Mel's and Steve's wedding proved a big draw.

BBC1's Ten o'Clock News won the battle of the 10pm bulletins, with 6.6m viewers to News at Ten's 5.4m.

On Channel 5, a repeat of the Patrick Swayze movie Road House did good business from 10pm.

The action film pulled in 2.4m viewers and an 18% share.

Earlier on in the evening, Channel 5 carried live coverage of a France v Germany football friendly from Paris between 7.30pm and 10pm.

webTitle: New cases as foot and mouth hits Europe

fields.headline: New cases as foot and mouth hits Europe
fields.trailText: Four more cases of foot and mouth disease in Britain were confirmed today as the first signs of the virus were detected in continental Europe.
fields.body:
Four more cases of foot and mouth disease in Britain were confirmed today as the first signs of the virus were detected in continental Europe.

Twenty-two UK farms are now known to be infected. Two farms at Powys, one in Hereford, and another in Lancashire joined a growing number of sites infected with the disease.

There are also fears that the disease may have crossed to Northern Ireland, after a farm in Meigh, in South Armagh, that had recieved livestock from a Carlisle market was sealed off.

The disease has an incubation period of 14 days so more outbreaks are expected.

"It's changing all the time," said chief veterinary officer Jim Scudamore. "There will be others coming in as we get results."

The government has extended the overall ban on moving livestock until March 16 but promised a plan to allow farmers to move disease-free animals under strict conditions.

In Germany, vets have discovered that animals among 1,500 sheep imported from Britain are infected with antibodies for the disease.

The environment minister for the state of North Rhine Westphalia described the finding - made on a farm near Düsseldorf - as an alarm signal for Germany

Earlier the EU extended the ban on Britain's meat and dairy exports until March 9.

EU health commissioner David Byrne praised "very strict" government action to contain the outbreak, saying all that could be done was being done.

Agriculture minister Nick Brown said today that the government would be drawing £152m from an EU agricultural fund to compensate beef, dairy and sheep farmers.

Farming campaigners, meanwhile, blamed the government for the crisis. Farmers for Action said it had been campaigning to stop the import of meat and meat products from around the world since last year, amid fears that they could cause an outbreak of disease.

Almost 7,000 animals have either been or are about to be slaughtered, including 1,800 cattle, 1,600 pigs and 3,500 sheep.

webTitle: Analysis: foot and mouth hits France

fields.headline: 'We are in the front line'
fields.standfirst:
Although gearing up to cope with the threat of foot and mouth, the French are not yet outright angry with the UK, says Stuart Jeffries in Paris

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Although gearing up to cope with the threat of foot and mouth, the French are not yet outright angry with the UK, says Stuart Jeffries in Paris.
fields.body:
The French are calling the British outbreak of foot and mouth disease "la fièvre anglaise" [the English fever].

While they are not yet as angry with the United Kingdom about exporting its agricultural problems as they were over the BSE crisis last year, there is a great deal of alarm here about the risks of contamination of French livestock and food from infected British exports.

"We are very worried," said a spokesman for the French food safety agency, la Direction Générale de l'Alimentation. "If the disease takes hold on the continent, we are in the front line."

The French agriculture minister Jean Glavany ordered the destruction yesterday of 20,000 sheep exported to France from Britain since last February. Last night 980 sheep raised in Britain were destroyed at an abattoir in Sarcelles.

Some 1064 French sheep known to have come into contact with British animals contaminated with foot and mouth disease are to be destroyed, and another 30,000 French sheep remain under veterinary surveillance.

Mr Glavany said he was acting quickly in the name of "the principle of maximum protection" and added: "As a preventative measure, all sheep whose origin cannot be certified will be killed and destroyed."

Mr Glavany is still in the process of trying to work out a satisfactory compensation deal for 40,000 French beef farmers thrown into difficulty by BSE, a disease widely thought here to have been exported from Britain to France thanks to unscrupulous animal feed suppliers and inadequate governmental controls.

French sales of beef plummeted by nearly 50% late last year as the country lost its confidence in faux filets, Chateaubriands, steak tartares, tournedos and all its other traditional beef delicacies.

While neither the French media nor the country's politicians have condemned Britain for yet again risking France's food, there is a great deal of bemusement here over Britain's latest calamity.

"Hunting, rugby, elections - the foot and mouth disease has overwhelmed everything" runs a headline in this morning's Libération newspaper. So far the only French analysis of the causes of the disease has been to suggest that British farming had become too intensive for livestock to resist infection.

webTitle: Website blocks access in plea for extra funds

fields.headline: Website blocks access in plea for extra funds
fields.trailText: 6pm: A Cornish surfers' website has stopped providing its most popular service - its surf reports - until its users stump up the cash and support it needs to escape extinction.
fields.body:
A Cornish surfers' website has stopped providing its most popular service - its surf reports - until its users stump up the cash and support it needs to escape extinction.

Surfingcornwall said it is "running out of money. Fast." An attempt to raise advertising revenue and sponsorship for the website failed, as did a message to users asking for support. Without investment, the site will shut down on March 6.

Mark Picken, who manages and designs the site, has emailed users to say that if they don't offer cash or practical help, they will have to "waste time and money driving from beach to beach trying to find the best surf".

"We have taken drastic action," he said. "We are not letting anyone see the daily surf report unless they give us the support we want."

The website's plight illustrates the difficulty of keeping an internet venture alive in the current climate.

Mr Picken said surfingcornwall only needs about £5,000 to keep the present service alive for another six months. But he would like to secure a good deal more funding, using his site to promote tourism in Cornwall and to help local businesses.

But as a niche site with only 15,000 page impressions a month, he has found that advertisers are not interested.

"The advertisers we've approached are looking at sites that get 2m impressions a month," he said. "We've tried Red Bull, as they're into surfing, and BT's Genie, as it uses a surfing logo. We've also tried the big surf companies, like Rip Curl and Aloha."

Mr Picken will make a last minute effort to save the site by appealing for EU funds from the South West Investment Group. He has also considered a subscription charge.

webTitle: Care trusts could mark the beginning of the end for NHS

fields.headline: Care trusts could mark the beginning of the end for NHS
fields.standfirst: We may eventually see a 'national' health service where much of the care provided comes from the private sector and where care is not universally free, says Fiona Campbell of the Democratic Health Network
fields.trailText: We may eventually see a 'national' health service where much of the care provided comes from the private sector and where care is not universally free, says Fiona Campbell of the Democratic Health Network.
fields.body:
The abolition of community health councils proposed in the health and social care bill received an enormous amount of media attention. A well organised campaign to save genuinely independent local patient advocacy seems to have paid off, with the government accepting an amendment setting up new "patient councils" in health localities. But another, probably even more significant, provision in the bill has been largely overlooked.

A completely new form of health body, the "care trust", threatens to undermine some of the basic founding principles of the National Health Service, not to mention local councils' central role in developing social services.

When the NHS plan was published last summer, it contained a preface signed by various luminaries in the health and social care field. This preface claimed to set out the NHS's "core principles". The first of these was that the: "NHS will provide a universal service for all based on clinical need, not ability to pay."

A few commentators noted at the time that this principle was worded so as to avoid reference to health services "free at the point of delivery" and that this commitment, which is generally held to be a founding principle of the NHS, was missing from the document. We are now beginning to see why. The setting up of care trusts will mean that, for the first time ever, some NHS bodies will be charging directly for care.

According to the health and social care bill, care trusts will be NHS bodies, created from existing primary care trusts or other NHS trusts, to provide primary and community health care as well as social care. That is, they will take over the social services role of their local authority and will also take over local authorities' ability to charge for social care.

Care trusts can be set up on a voluntary basis, with the agreement of the local authority and health partners. They can also be created by order of the secretary of state for health, where he or she deems that social services provision in a certain area is inadequate. The consent of those parties directly involved is not required in such cases. In the case of such "directed" trusts, the secretary of state may require local authorities to pass over both the recurrent costs and the capital assets necessary for care trusts to carry out the social care aspects of their work.

Although the rhetoric of partnership is used to describe the setting up of care trusts, it is clear from the bill that they will be health bodies - in fact, they will be created simply by renaming primary care trusts or other NHS trusts, such as community trusts. Although ministers, during the passage of the bill, have said that there will be local authority representation on the governing bodies of care trusts, there is no stipulation in the bill as to what form this representation will take.

Nevertheless, there is widespread expectation that local authorities will be willing to delegate their social services functions and their social services budgets to such bodies. It was suggested during the debates on the bill that this impetus would come from directors of social services, who see their vastly over-stretched budgets being subsidised from the vast NHS reserves. But if anyone really holds this view, it may be a very short-sighted one.

The care trust provisions obviously raise particular urgent questions of accountability for local authorities. But they have also given rise to much wider questions about the financial operation of the NHS.

It has been suggested that, because they can levy charges for personal care, care trusts will have clear financial incentives to shift intermediate care into non-NHS settings. As professor Allyson Pollock has pointed out, the likely result is that intermediate care will "follow the same trajectory as long term care in the 1980s".

Local authorities know only too well the pressures to privatise elderly persons' homes because of the availability of residential care allowance to those living in non-local authority homes. During the 1980s and 1990s, such pressure fuelled the expansion of private nursing and residential care.

As Ms Pollock points out, the main difference between then and now is that "the expansion of the private residential and domiciliary intermediate care market will be funded mainly out of user charges, not social security".

There will be additional pressures on care trusts to commission intermediate care wherever they can find it, because it is seen as a way of relieving so-called bed blocking in hospitals.

The Democratic Health Network has already expressed its profound concern that the transfer of social care to health bodies will mean that social care is seen as a way of moving elderly and disabled people out of the acute care sector, perceiving them as passive recipients of care and not holistically as participating active citizens. But there is little doubt that pressures further up the acute care system will make the model of commissioning "intermediate" care from private providers an attractive one for care trusts.

The NHS plan stated another "core principle" thus: "Public funds for healthcare will be devoted solely to NHS patients."

This too caused some raised eyebrows. Why not just say that the NHS will use its resources to care for NHS patients only? Now we can see that the wording of the "core principle" allows for NHS monies to go directly to private sector care providers, who, because they are providing "social" and "personal" care, rather than "nursing" or "medical" care, will in many cases be able to keep their costs down by passing them on to those they care for.

In 10 years' time or even less, we may see a "national" health service where much of the care provided comes from the private sector and where care is not universally free at the point of delivery. Will the ability of care trusts to charge for services create a more general precedent for NHS trusts generally? Are care trusts the beginning of the end of the NHS as Nye Bevan conceived it?

 The Democratic Health Network is an independent research organisation promoting partnership between local government and the health services to improve public health

fields.headline: Online sports site is a hit
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Sports news website Teamtalk has revealed successful third quarter results, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Sports news website Teamtalk has bucked the depressing trend in online services with a set of results that pleased the City.

The £39m left in the bank from the company's float last year prompted a welcome cheer among analysts not usually positive about dot.coms, despite a cash burn of £1m per month.

Teamtalk is one of the most popular sports websites with almost 2m users.

Today, for example, it indulges the most ardent of fans interests with detailed news, chat and even betting on everything from England's football showdown with Spain to the latest developments on horse racing and the foot and mouth disease.

It has expanded into Sweden and Germany and has shored up its position in sectors other than football, including horseracing and motor racing.

However, the current ban on racing from the foot and mouth disease may impact growth in the next quarter, if it continues into the next few months.

"I am very pleased with these results," said chairman and chief executive Bill Wilson.

Turnover is in line with expectations while cash reserves are stronger than anticipated and our moves into new sports and countries are ahead of plan.

"Our progress to date, together with our strong cash position, will enable us to continue our development plans and to deliver shareholder value."

Nine-month turnover reached £7.5m on pre-tax losses of £4.1m. Pre-tax losses for the third quarter reached £2.4m, more than half of the previous two quarters.

fields.headline: Cows in flames
fields.standfirst:
In town and country, an air of paranoia is deepening as the farm epidemic spreads

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: In town and country, an air of paranoia is deepening as the farm epidemic spreads.
fields.body:
The flames turning the night sky orange, the stench of burning flesh - no wonder the talk in the countryside is of apocalypse. "We are on the threshold of Armageddon," warns the National Farmers Union man in Devon, girding himself for another night of slaughter, another bonfire of the carcasses.

It is, to be sure, a medieval image, those piles of animal corpses being put to the flame - the pictures in the papers looking more like tapestries than photographs. And the panic is real. Farmers, already reeling after BSE and falling food prices, fear this could be the final blow. The Samaritans are on standby.

The rest of the nation stands back, heeding the warnings to keep its distance. To urban folk, this whole scene looks like one of those 1950s sci-fi tales - Quatermass or Day of the Triffids. Sealed-off farms, a deadly virus, government warnings to stay away: all that's needed now is for the army to move in. But townies have two other reactions to the foot and mouth epidemic sweeping Britain - reactions which could be as decisive for the farmers' fate as the virus itself. Neither will bring much comfort.

The first is confusion. Amid all the talk of European export bans, cancelled rugby matches and delayed general elections, plenty of people are still stuck on rather more basic questions. Like: what the hell is it? And: how might it affect me?

I've heard people shouting at the radio and TV, demanding answers to those questions. BSE they could understand: they knew cows went mad, visibly stumbling and slobbering in TV footage played over and over again, and that humans could contract a terrifying and lethal version of the disease.

Foot and mouth sounds so much simpler than bovine spongiform encephalopathy but my guess is that most non-rural folk remain baffled as to what it is. From the tone of the media coverage, and the end-of-the-world warnings from farmers, most Britons probably reckon F&M is a killer disease which, once it touches a herd, rapidly wipes out the lot. As for humans, it's surely a death sentence to eat meat infected with the bug: your foot probably falls off and your mouth seizes up forever. Why else would government rules insist that infected animals be slaughtered instantly and the disease be eradicated so absolutely? It must be a merciless plague.

Not quite. If human beings eat meat infected with F&M, they do not die; at most they might get the odd cold sore. As for animals, foot and mouth rarely kills them either. Some of the herd's sick or young are vulnerable, but for most a bout of F&M means little more than blisters around the mouth, on the teats and between the hooves, an occasional spot of lameness and a loss of appetite. The animal soon recovers and the whole thing lasts no more than two to three weeks.

So why all the fuss? The clue is in that last symptom: loss of appetite. For a sheep with F&M stops gaining weight, an infected cow produces less milk. The animal does not suffer or die - it just becomes less productive, yielding a less juicy lamb chop or fewer pints of milk. In an industry that has become ultra-intensive - squeezing every last drop of value from a sheep, pig or cow - even this slight loss of productivity can make the difference between profit and loss. Put simply, foot and mouth is an economic disease.

A less-intensive brand of farming might take the old 19th-century attitude to F &M: let it run. Back then, says agricultural historian Abigail Woods, who writes on the topic in today's Society section, "no one took any notice of it at all, no one batted an eye-lid." Today's consumers wouldn't notice the difference either.

But farmers can't just let foot and mouth come in, do its worst and blow away - even if that would be the most rational response. Foreign markets won't tolerate infected meat even if we would: the farmers' export trade would collapse. The law demands an extreme response too. A long outdated insistence that British meat be absolutely disease-free has led to the slaughter-on-sight policy, even when it is the emergency measures, not the virus itself, which really threatens farmers' livelihoods. The cure is worse than the disease.

Still, don't expect too much sympathy from the rest of us. For if this outbreak has triggered our incomprehension of modern farming, it has also exposed our indifference to its plight. Typical of the urban mood was Ken Livingstone's instant response, calling on the Countryside Alliance to cancel its planned march on London. With an unerring instinct for popular feeling, the mayor guessed at most Londoners' attitude to the farmers: keep out, and take your mucky boots and strange germs with you. The Alliance duly called the event off.

It's not hard to explain this urban chilliness toward the countryside. BSE was a turning point, breaking forever the cosy Farmer Giles myth of yore: suddenly Britons saw farms as giant agri-businesses, animal factories with profit the only motive. Never mind that many farmers didn't realise they were turning their livestock into cannibals: the trust was broken.

The countryside's war on the Labour government has not helped. Not because they don't have a good case: the depletion of rural bus services and post offices is real. What turns townies off is that country folk never marched on London about any of those concerns: it was only when Labour moved against foxhunting that the countryside got organised. If the Alliance had been formed to save village schools, rather than the right to kill foxes, perhaps they would have enjoyed wider sympathy.

There's one more cause of the town's cold shoulder to the country and it's an irony. For it was Conservative governments - the farmers' party - who per suaded Britons that if an industry is uneconomic, then it must go, even if that destroys communities and their way of life. Pit villages made that plea in the 1980s but no one listened - least of all the farmers who kept voting Tory. Yet now they insist that Britain must subsidise their industry, even if we could import their product more cheaply from abroad. If that logic couldn't save the miners, why should it save them?

The farmers will argue that food is a special case. Britons, they reckon, remember the war - where we had to feed ourselves to stay alive. But few hold to that logic anymore: that's why Thatcherism didn't mind savaging our steel industry, even though we might need that one day to arm ourselves. No, it's a globalised world now; Britons won't mind filling their shopping trolleys from abroad. They do so already.

That sounds harsh and it is. It also lets us off the hook too easily. For if farmers have been driven to ever more intensive methods, it's partly to satisfy our demand for cheap food. As the novelist Jonathan Coe, whose What a Carve Up! skewered the food industry in the mid-90s, told me yesterday, "absolute consumer choice" comes at a terrible price - and it is the farmers now facing ruin who seem set to pay it.

So Frederick Forsyth can hint darkly in the Daily Mail that the foot and mouth virus was introduced deliberately, as a Labour plot against the countryside. But most Britons know better. They know that if farmers are reaping a bitter harvest now, they - and we - sowed much of it ourselves.

fields.headline: Media group calls for Jewish TV shows
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: A consortium is hoping to persuade broadcasters to carry more Jewish programming, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Related site: Jewish.co.uk
fields.body:
A consortium of young Jewish web and media types has launched a campaign to persuade broadcasters to carry more Jewish-oriented programming.

Jewish.co.uk, which has been running a website for the Jewish community for four years, believe broadcasters and programme makers should stop pigeonholing Jewish programming as "religious".

"The TV networks have never really considered that Jewish people want something that is culturally oriented," said a spokesman.

"There are 300,000 Jewish people in the UK, most of whom are licence-fee payers, and we don't feel our needs are being addressed.

"We've always been told 'Oh, that would come under religious programming'," he added.

Jewish.co.uk staff have written to the BBC and commercial broadcasters saying they want 20 hours a year of Jewish programming.

And they are discussing programme ideas with several broadcasters.

One idea in gestation is for a current-affairs magazine programme. It would be "a cross between Black Britain and That was the Week That was" and run for 30-60 minutes.

Useful link
Jewish.co.uk

webTitle: Indonesian forces crack down on Borneo rioters

fields.headline: Indonesian forces crack down on Borneo rioters
fields.trailText: Security forces were today ordered to shoot rioters on sight in a                                                    bid to restore order on the Indonesian island of Borneo and  quell a murderous rampage by Dayak natives against Madurese settlers.
fields.body:
Security forces were today ordered to shoot rioters on sight in a bid to restore order on the Indonesian island of Borneo and quell a murderous rampage by Dayak natives against Madurese settlers.

Police have shot and killed five people caught looting shops and businesses abandoned by fleeing Madurese in the town of Sampit and the regional capital Palangkaraya, a spokesman.

"We are now taking tougher action against rioters and other troublemakers," regional deputy police chief Colonel Muhamad Jatmiko said.

The security forces have been widely criticised for doing little during 11 days of violence. Police today said that at least 469 people, mostly Madurese, had died.

The widespread atrocities have underscored Indonesia's failure to control ethnic and separatist violence as it struggles to form a working democracy after decades of dictatorial rule.

With thousands of Madurese fleeing Borneo, the Dayak campaign to ethnically cleanse the region has been largely successful. Until now, the government has concentrated its efforts on helping the Madurese flee instead of clamping down on the perpetrators.

Critics say the failure to rein in the Dayaks sets a dangerous precedent for the rest of Indonesia, where scores of other ethnic and religious groups might take similar action against minorities.

No other violence was reported today as the national police chief, Suroyo Bimantoro, toured the area.

Mr Bimantoro promised that yesterday's clashes between police officers and military troops in Sampit town's port area would not happen again. Army units currently stationed in the town were being withdrawn because the security situation was improving, he said.

Meanwhile, the evacuation of tens of thousands of terrified Madurese continued as aid officials complained that authorities were not doing enough to help the victims.

In Sampit, constant rain added to the misery of the estimated 25,000 refugees living under plastic sheeting in the partly flooded grounds of the police station. "Our children will die if we do not get more food soon," said Car Noto, a refugee.

Health workers said that at least six refugees had died since the crisis began and that diarrhoea was spreading, especially among children.

"There is only one doctor, and he can't cope with the work," said Dr Endang Widiastuti of the US-based World Vision relief agency. "Sampit needs doctors badly."

webTitle: Councils given the go-ahead to close down the countryside

fields.headline: Councils given the go-ahead to close down the countryside
fields.trailText: Councils have been given emergency powers to close down footpaths and rights of way, effectively banning ramblers and day-trippers from the countryside, as cases of foot and mouth disease continue to rise across the country.
fields.body:
Councils have been given emergency powers to close down footpaths and rights of way, effectively banning ramblers and day-trippers from the countryside, as cases of foot and mouth disease continue to rise across the country.

Authorities that already have confirmed cases of the disease within their areas can use the powers immediately, while others must first apply to the government.

The National Farmers' Union has called on councils to use the powers without delay.

Union president Ben Gill said: "There must be a blanket ban across the country. This could be crucial in helping us to stamp out this highly virulent disease. With new outbreaks being confirmed all the time, we are sure every responsible member of the public will support us."

The move, which covers England and Wales, will bring the countryside a step closer to virtual shutdown, marking it as a no-go area while councils, farmers and the government struggle to contain the highly contagious disease.

Agriculture minister Nick Brown said: "Our advice remains that people should take sensible precautions in the countryside, and avoid any unnecessary visits on farms and especially close proximity with livestock. We have taken powers to ensure that this advice can be enforced."

Councils across the country are already taking action against the disease. Kennet district council in Wiltshire has stopped all rubbish collections from farms that are not directly on main roads.

This measure has been implemented following the outbreak of foot and mouth in the area at an abattoir near Melksham, Wiltshire.

Anglesey county council, meanwhile, says mats soaked in disinfectant are being placed on all approaches to the island.

And Bedfordshire county council has closed car parks on Dunstable Downs and Sundon Hills Country Park in an effort to reduce the risk of people and vehicles unwittingly spreading the disease.

webTitle: Popular pleasures: should reading be improving or fun?

fields.headline: Popular pleasures
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive essay from the London Review of Books James Wood examines John Carey's anti-modernist selection of 'enjoyable books'
fields.trailText: James Wood examines John Carey's anti-modernist, anti-elitist selection of 'enjoyable books'
fields.body:
Pure Pleasure: A Guide to the 20th Century's Most Enjoyable Books by John Carey. Faber, 173 pp., £6.99, 18 September 2000, 0 571 20448 1
Buy it at a discount from BOL

John Carey's new book, like his last one, The Intellectuals and the Masses, is a little swizzle-stick perfectly designed for flattening airy literary bubbles. Surprisingly, it is likable, wise and often right, the more so in tending to contradict The Intellectuals and the Masses, which had none of these qualities. The enemy has stayed the same - roughly, overweening literary Modernism. Has Carey's curious Oxonian populism truly changed, or just, as it were, moved colleges?

The Intellectuals and the Masses was the most lucid and intelligent statement yet of an English conservative anti-Modernism familiar to readers of the Sunday Times and the Spectator. Carey's cousins in populism sometimes include Simon Jenkins, Paul Johnson, AN Wilson and the late Auberon Waugh. An easy moralism animates this worldview. Most of these commentators imagine themselves to be writing a form of intellectual history when they are only pouring gossip into fancy goblets at London book parties. They experience apparently no squeamishness, indeed no awareness of any difficulty, in moving between these troublesome lives and the troublesome work that was produced by them: the one naturally follows the other, as the overnight cell follows the police blotter.
