fields.headline: To El and back
fields.standfirst: Our Spanish football correspondent, Sid Lowe, joins England's opponents as they arrive on our shores and enjoy a wonderful afternoon with the gentlemen of the press
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman's not injured, he's scared. At least, that's the verdict of his Real Madrid team-mate Iván Helguera. "We've been winding each other up over this game for a while now", joked the Spanish international at the team's press conference yesterday. "I saw him yesterday and I told him I knew the real reason why he didn't come over for the match - it's because he knew he'd lose against us".
fields.body:
Steve McManaman's not injured, he's scared. At least, that's the verdict of his Real Madrid team-mate Iván Helguera. "We've been winding each other up over this game for a while now", joked the Spanish international at the team's press conference yesterday. "I saw him yesterday and I told him I knew the real reason why he didn't come over for the match - it's because he knew he'd lose against us".

Helguera's comments are a pretty good indication of the confident and relaxed mood of the Spanish squad, which arrived in Birmingham yesterday for tonight's game with England at Villa Park.

That confidence is hardly surprising, given Spain's current domination of European competition and the presence in the national side of three players each from Real Madrid (Raúl, Helguera and Casillas) and Valencia (Cañizares, Mendieta, and Baraja) - two sides which have more than matched England's run-away leaders Manchester United in the past year. Throw in Pep Guardiola and the league's form players, Luis Enrique and Deportivo's Víctor and it's easy to see why Spain might fancy their chances.

And even the miserable weather did nothing to dampen the spirits as José Camacho's boys confidently strolled out for their mid-morning prominade. It was a bit on the conspicuous side, though. After all, 20 professional footballers in identical tracksuits hardly go unnoticed in Birmingham city centre.

However, no sooner were the La Liga stars back in the warmth of the hotel than they were set upon by the British and Spanish press and though some escaped, others weren't so lucky.

As the voracious pack closed in, Mendieta, Luis Enrique and Co. must have been upstairs laughing their heads off while the unlucky few had to field some of the world's most inane questions. And I'm afraid to say it was mostly the Brits who were the ones to blame.

The hacks wanted to know what Camacho made of England having a Swedish coach, and would Spain ever witness the day when a foreigner was called upon to manage the national side?

But the Spanish boss was sharp, and his responses were telling - you get the impression that he doesn't really rate the English. "Personally, I'd prefer a Spanish coach for the Spanish team. Anyway, I think we've got enough good coaches in Spain. If England have gone for a foreign boss, it's for a reason. It's not for nothing."

Then came the one about the contradiction between Spain's great club sides and its international disasters (which Messrs Guardiola, Helguera and Cañizares had to field as well - lots of times). Again Camacho was ready for it: "England's club sides are doing well, too" he pointed out "but they've not exactly got a brilliant record internationally". Touché.

And there were endless enquiries about David Beckham, too - so many, in fact, that the embarrassed interpreter hardly needed to translate one of Iván Helguera's replies. "¡Otra vez!", exclaimed the Madrid midfielder, rolling his eyes. Yes, Iván, again. (As if Spain's players could tell Britain's tabloids anything they didn't already know, anyway). But the Spaniards remained relaxed, even while the British pressboys gabbled loudly during the Spanish section and tutted "don't any of their players speak English?"

Nor did anyone seem unduly concerned by the last minute withdrawal of captain Fernando Hierro, which left Camacho with a squad of just eighteen and question mark at centre back. There could be a return to defence for Iván Helguera, although he seemed a little bit surprised at the suggestion. "It's a long time since I played at the back", he said, "but the important thing is just to play - wherever".

To say Hierro's withdrawal was late doesn't really do it justice. "I only found out about it on the bus" admitted Camacho, revealing that being Spain's manager is, in fact, just like running a pub side: "What did I think? Nothing. What am I supposed to think? I thought 'I need to get on the phone' I rang [Zaragoza's] Paco and that's that."

Up front there will almost certainly be a debut for La Liga's top-scorer, Javi Moreno. And the Alavés striker was particularly happy to be in Birmingham (well, there's a first for everything). Mind you, he did look like a lost child - all wide-eyed and smiling awkwardly. And there was also a sneaking suspicion that he'd been out the back making notes when Camacho was on the spot.

"Playing for the national side is the most beautiful thing in the world", Camacho had enthused "the chance to pull on the Spanish shirt is lo máximo. A footballer can't ask for any more". Then it was Javi's turn: "For me there's nothing better than having the chance to wear the Spanish shirt. It's everything a footballer can ask for".

One reason for the relaxed atmosphere in the Spanish camp - apart from it being only England, of course - is that it hardly matters what the score is tonight, anyway. It's only a friendly after all.

And maybe that's the key to a great Spanish performance tonight - Iván Helguera admitted that he thought that Spain's failure in major championships was "a lack of a winning mentality". "When we play for Real Madrid we think we're going to win" he explained. "In fact, we're obliged to win. With the national side it's not like that. We don't have a tradition of winning. We don't think that. And we've been unlucky, too". fields.bodyText: Steve McManaman's not injured, he's scared. At least, that's the verdict of his Real Madrid team-mate Iván Helguera. "We've been winding each other up over this game for a while now", joked the Spanish international at the team's press conference yesterday. "I saw him yesterday and I told him I knew the real reason why he didn't come over for the match - it's because he knew he'd lose against us". Helguera's comments are a pretty good indication of the confident and relaxed mood of the Spanish squad, which arrived in Birmingham yesterday for tonight's game with England at Villa Park. That confidence is hardly surprising, given Spain's current domination of European competition and the presence in the national side of three players each from Real Madrid (Raúl, Helguera and Casillas) and Valencia (Cañizares, Mendieta, and Baraja) - two sides which have more than matched England's run-away leaders Manchester United in the past year. Throw in Pep Guardiola and the league's form players, Luis Enrique and Deportivo's Víctor and it's easy to see why Spain might fancy their chances. And even the miserable weather did nothing to dampen the spirits as José Camacho's boys confidently strolled out for their mid-morning prominade. It was a bit on the conspicuous side, though. After all, 20 professional footballers in identical tracksuits hardly go unnoticed in Birmingham city centre. However, no sooner were the La Liga stars back in the warmth of the hotel than they were set upon by the British and Spanish press and though some escaped, others weren't so lucky. As the voracious pack closed in, Mendieta, Luis Enrique and Co. must have been upstairs laughing their heads off while the unlucky few had to field some of the world's most inane questions. And I'm afraid to say it was mostly the Brits who were the ones to blame. The hacks wanted to know what Camacho made of England having a Swedish coach, and would Spain ever witness the day when a foreigner was called upon to manage the national side? But the Spanish boss was sharp, and his responses were telling - you get the impression that he doesn't really rate the English. "Personally, I'd prefer a Spanish coach for the Spanish team. Anyway, I think we've got enough good coaches in Spain. If England have gone for a foreign boss, it's for a reason. It's not for nothing." Then came the one about the contradiction between Spain's great club sides and its international disasters (which Messrs Guardiola, Helguera and Cañizares had to field as well - lots of times). Again Camacho was ready for it: "England's club sides are doing well, too" he pointed out "but they've not exactly got a brilliant record internationally". Touché. And there were endless enquiries about David Beckham, too - so many, in fact, that the embarrassed interpreter hardly needed to translate one of Iván Helguera's replies. "¡Otra vez!", exclaimed the Madrid midfielder, rolling his eyes. Yes, Iván, again. (As if Spain's players could tell Britain's tabloids anything they didn't already know, anyway). But the Spaniards remained relaxed, even while the British pressboys gabbled loudly during the Spanish section and tutted "don't any of their players speak English?" Nor did anyone seem unduly concerned by the last minute withdrawal of captain Fernando Hierro, which left Camacho with a squad of just eighteen and question mark at centre back. There could be a return to defence for Iván Helguera, although he seemed a little bit surprised at the suggestion. "It's a long time since I played at the back", he said, "but the important thing is just to play - wherever". To say Hierro's withdrawal was late doesn't really do it justice. "I only found out about it on the bus" admitted Camacho, revealing that being Spain's manager is, in fact, just like running a pub side: "What did I think? Nothing. What am I supposed to think? I thought 'I need to get on the phone' I rang [Zaragoza's] Paco and that's that." Up front there will almost certainly be a debut for La Liga's top-scorer, Javi Moreno. And the Alavés striker was particularly happy to be in Birmingham (well, there's a first for everything). Mind you, he did look like a lost child - all wide-eyed and smiling awkwardly. And there was also a sneaking suspicion that he'd been out the back making notes when Camacho was on the spot. "Playing for the national side is the most beautiful thing in the world", Camacho had enthused "the chance to pull on the Spanish shirt is lo máximo. A footballer can't ask for any more". Then it was Javi's turn: "For me there's nothing better than having the chance to wear the Spanish shirt. It's everything a footballer can ask for". webTitle: Net closes in on war crimes suspect

fields.headline: Net closes in on war crimes suspect
fields.standfirst:
Anton Gecas lives quietly in Scotland. But within days, Lithuania will ask Britain to deport him on charges of genocide and mass murder

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Anton Gecas lives quietly in Scotland. But within days, Lithuania will ask Britain to deport him on charges of genocide and mass murder
fields.body:
The old man lives a sheltered existence, so frail he rarely leaves the Georgian townhouse. His days are spent in the company of a baby grandchild. Yet there can be no tranquillity behind the facade of his Edinburgh home: any day now the elderly guesthouse keeper will face extradition moves on charges of genocide.

Anton Gecas, 84, is second on the Simon Wiesenthal Centre's list of most wanted suspected war criminals. Only Adolf Eichmann's right-hand man, Alois Brunner, if he is still alive, precedes him. For years Mr Gecas lived anonymously in Scotland, as a miner, an engineer and as a guesthouse keeper. Then, in 1986, the Nazi-hunting centre named him.

Now proceedings against Mr Gecas are about to take a step further. Last week a judge in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, issued a warrant for Mr Gecas's arrest. He is charged with 13 crimes relating to the genocide of Jews and the mass murder of other civilians in Lithuania and what is now Belarus. A formal request for his extradition will arrive at the Foreign Office within days.

For Efraim Zuroff, the Simon Wiesenthal Centre's top Nazi hunter and the man who first pointed the finger at Mr Gecas, it is a defining moment. "I have spent 15 years hunting this bastard and nothing is going to give me greater pleasure than seeing him in court," he said.

"The Lithuanians have done their part, but when the extradition request comes it'll be up to your British system to make sure Gecas is sent to trial."

New evidence

Mr Gecas will be fighting the extradition. "My client maintains his complete innocence of these allegations and if and when an application for extradition is received by the British government we will be fighting it most strongly," said his lawyer, Nigel Duncan.

Key to the extradition battle will be new evidence gathered by Rimvydas Valentukevicius, head of the Lithuanian prosecutor's special investigation unit, with the aid of the US Justice Department. No one will confirm officially the nature of the new evidence but well-placed observers say it is the testimony of those who served alongside Mr Gecas in a battalion.

Shortly after the Germans invaded Lithuania in June 1941, Mr Gecas volunteered for the 12th auxiliary police service battalion as a lieutenant in charge of a platoon. The battalion became one of the second world war's most feared Nazi death squads. Throughout the summer of 1941, it was involved in rounding up and murdering thousands of civilian men, women and children in Lithuania.

In one of the battalion's operations in the town of Slutsk, over two days, around 1,000 Jews were dragged from factories and shops. They were shot and buried in mass graves.

In another operation in Minsk's Jewish ghetto, one member of the battalion remembered Mr Gecas helping in an operation which saw Germans round up a column of Jews "four abreast and more than 300 metres long" in front of specially dug pits. They were all shot.

By the winter of 1941 more than 90% of the country's 220,000 Jews were killed. The battalion moved its operations to Belarus and continued its operations there. Mr Gecas is accused of involvement in the murder of 32,000 civilians.

In a 1987 documentary, Scottish Television said Mr Gecas was a war criminal. Five years later, he lost a £600,000 libel action against the company. He admitted to being involved in six incidents in which soldiers shot civilians, but claimed he was outside the area of the murders. The trial judge, Lord Milligan, said he was "clearly satisfied" he was a war criminal.

Now the Scottish justice minister, Jim Wallace, and an Edinburgh sheriff will have to decide on the weight of evidence against him.

How Mr Gecas got to Edinburgh after the war is a simple story. In 1944, as the tide of the war was changing, he switched sides and joined an invading Polish battalion. He had been decorated by the Germans for his services and he would be decorated too by the Polish army for fighting against the Germans.

In 1947, Mr Gecas travelled to Britain with the Polish army, changed his name from Antanas Gecevicius and was demobbed. He found a job as a miner with the National Coal Board, before he took a course in management at Edinburgh's Heriot Watt University.

He was given British citizenship and, in 1959 when he was 43, he married a 19-year-old nurse, Astrid. They had two children and lived a comfortable existence in their suburban home.

Mr Gecas is well used to pulling the curtains to press and camera crews camped outside his home. He does not give usually interviews but shortly before Christmas he broke his silence for the first time in years.

Accusations

"These accusations have been hard for me and there is not a month which goes by where I am not being attacked as a war criminal," he said. "Every day I worry they may succeed in getting me deported and taking me away from my family."

Those who have followed the case believe he has cause to fret. "I would be astonished if the application is not granted," said Lord Janner, the former Labour MP and British army Nazi hunter. "He was branded a war criminal in the civil action and the Lithuanians believe they have a mass of evidence."

For many Jewish groups, the case of Mr Gecas will be a test of Britain's nerve in its dealings with its last few living citizens who have been accused of second world war atrocities.

His case was the impetus behind the passing of the War Crimes Act in 1991, which enables prosecutions to be brought against naturalised British citizens suspected of offences committed under their previous nationality. But the Crown Office, the Scottish prosecution service, decided there was not enough evidence to bring proceedings against Mr Gecas. There are similar stories across Britain: only one person - Anthony Sawoniuk - has been successfully prosecuted under the act.

The US, and more recently Canada, where many other suspected war criminals fled, deal with these men under immigration law: the US has deported or denaturalised 116 suspected war criminals. The home secretary, Jack Straw, is considering whether similar procedures should be adopted in Britain.

Mr Gecas claims he was merely fighting for his country, with the Germans against the Russians and then with allies against the Germans. "I feel this country is ungrateful for the fighting I did," he said.

Mr Zuroff is unconvinced. "It was opportunism not morality that made him switch sides," he said. "He's an old man, so what? Let him stand trial. This is a brilliant opportunity to bring Gecas before justice. If he's telling the truth, and I'm wrong, what's he got to fear? Your British justice should not ignore this guy again."

webTitle: Myers gets busy with Austin Powers 3

fields.headline: Myers gets busy with Austin Powers 3
fields.trailText: Mike Myers is asking for $25m pay cheque to star in a third Austin Powers movie
fields.body:
Mike Myers' most famous creation may be a naïve and dopey soul, but the man himself is clearly made of sterner stuff. The Canadian-born comic is reportedly demanding a $25m (£17.34m) advance against 21% of the gross to make Austin Powers 3. Negotiations with the film's backers, New Line, are ongoing.

The demands reflect Myers' increased bargaining clout in the light of the success of the two previous Austin Powers films. The first picture, 1997's International Man of Mystery, was a low-budget sleeper hit that later became a bestseller on video. But the follow-up, 1999's The Spy Who Shagged Me, grossed a whopping $309m (£214m) from the worldwide box office.

Variety reports that Myers is preparing to work on the script for Austin Powers 3 alongside regular collaborator Mike McCullers. New Line are also reported to be attempting to again secure Jay Roach, the man behind the first two Powers pictures, as the film's director.

But aside from the money wrangles, the other possible stumbling block is Myers' cramped schedule. The actor is currently poised to reprise Peter Sellers' role as Inspector Clouseau in a remake of The Pink Panther to be directed by Ivan Reitman. Then there is the small matter of Myers' ongoing obligations to Universal and DreamWorks. After bailing so acrimoniously out of the ill-fated comedy Dieter last year, Myers apparently promised to develop another project to replace it. That commitment may keep Austin Powers in deep-freeze for another year or so.

fields.headline: BBC radio readies regional history epic
fields.trailText: 11am: The BBC is lining up a £500,000 radio sequel to millennium documentary The Century Speaks, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has commissioned a major £500,000 radio sequel to The Century Speaks, the millennium documentary series charting ordinary listeners lives in the last 100 years.

A Sense of Place, which is to be transmitted early next year, is billed as a "hard-nosed look" at the historic and modern day forces that have shaped the identity of each region of the UK.

Around 300 programmes will be made for the series, which will go out across the BBC's 40 local radio stations.

"There will be little nostalgia and no rose-tinted glasses," said BBC director of nations and regions Pat Loughrey.

"Through the voices of ordinary people the series will chart the tensions and rivalries between and within communities. It will look at issues of wealth, poverty, class, gender, race and diversity and the impact they have had and are having on people and the places in which they live."

A Sense of Place follows on from The Century Speaks, the 1999 BBC local radio history series that featured more than 6,000 contributors describing life throughout the 20th century in 640 programmes.

Highlights of The Century Speaks were broadcast on Radio 4 and the entire digital archive has been placed in the British Library.

fields.headline: Unions criticise pay gap inertia
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday criticised by trade unions after it rejected proposals to force employers to review pay by gender in an effort to close the 18% pay gap.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday criticised by trade unions after it rejected proposals to force employers to review pay by gender in an effort to close the 18% pay gap.

As a report by the equal opportunities commission confirmed that the UK has the worst record in Europe on equal pay, ministers made it clear that pay audits would remain voluntary.

The recommendation, which was a key to the study's proposals to abolish the pay gap within eight years, is fiercely resisted by business, which claims it would create an impossible administrative burden.

The CBI condemned the proposal as "ineffective and disproportionate", and insisted that women were paid less mainly because of family responsibilities and their concentration in low paid occupations rather than because of discrimination by employers.

However, the TUC said there was nothing to make bad employers review pay. Its president, Bill Morris, said: "If you have ruled out any kind of statutory mechanism, it does not seem to me that you have got too much going for you, because you have ruled out any means of compliance."

Thirty-one years after the passing of the Equal Pay Act, the gap between the hourly earnings of women working part-time and men working full-time has barely changed, standing at 39%. Up to 50% of the pay gap was caused not by occupational segregation or women's share of family responsibilities but by discrimination, the study found.

The recommendations include moves to raise awareness of the pay gap and simplifying the system of equal pay employment tribunals.

However, amid opposition from business, ministers will not impose a statutory duty on employers to conduct pay audits, insisting that a voluntary approach will work.

Employment minister Tessa Jowell said: "We don't think mandatory pay reviews are the way forward as a first step." She said the government would review employers' moves to narrow the gap annually.

webTitle: Damon and Affleck go good talent hunting

fields.headline: Damon and Affleck go good talent hunting
fields.trailText: The two Hollywood stars have launched a competition which will provide the winning film-maker with a $1m budget to make their first movie
fields.body:
Hollywood stars Matt Damon and Ben Affleck are masterminding a competition that will provide a $1m (£690,000) budget for an unknown, untried writer-director to shoot their own movie. The aim, say the Good Will Hunting duo, is to break through the iron curtain of Hollywood nepotism and provide an opportunity for an everyday American with a good script and some promising film skills. "This is not a charity or anything," Damon told Reuters news service. "It's just the right thing to do. Rather than the traditional gatekeeper system, this contest is based on merit."

fields.headline: Murdoch merger delayed
fields.trailText:
10.45am update: Due diligence proceedings are slowing down the merger of Sky Global Networks with DirecTV, reports Dan Milmo.
Murdoch keeps talking
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch must wait until accountants have pored over the books at his News Corporation empire before he can realise his dream of a £49bn merger with US satellite broadcaster DirecTV.

Mr Murdoch told the Variety conference in New York that due diligence, or a very detailed examination of both companies' accounts, is delaying a deal that would create a global broadcasting group.

The complicated deal involves Mr Murdoch's Sky Global Networks satellite TV companies merging into DirecTV's parent company Hughes Electronics, which is owned by US car group General Motors.

"Both sides are still right in due diligence. That's the situation at the moment. I think GM is happy with it and so is News Corp," said Mr Murdoch.

The process will be complicated by the involvement of software giant Microsoft, which is investing £3.5bn in the deal and must be included in the due diligence process.

Rival media executives have praised the DirecTV merger, with Howard Stringer of Sony admitting he was "envious" of the deal.

"Just the ability to spin sports and other programming around the globe represents an extraordinary opportunity," said Mr Stringer.

"I've been envious of a lot of deals in the last few years. This would be one of them."

Barry Diller, chief executive of USA Networks, said a fortified Sky Global Networks could represent a serious threat to the power of cable television in the US.

If the deal is completed, Sky Global will be a satellite broadcaster with a major presence in the US, Asian, European and Latin American markets.

"I think it would be a transforming transaction," said Mr Diller.

fields.headline: Murder wrongfoots the Italian nation
fields.standfirst: Italy has been forced to look into its own soul, says Rory Carroll, after a shocking domestic double murder was blamed on immigrants
fields.trailText: Italy has been forced to look into its own soul, says Rory Carroll, after a shocking domestic double murder was blamed on immigrants.
fields.body:
Just before 8pm last Wednesday Erika La Nardo, 16, hammered on a neighbour's door with the news which would shock Italy. Two men, she stammered. Two men had broken into her house. They had a knife. Her mother, her brother, bleeding, dead maybe. Oh God please help.

Police arrived minutes later, bursting into a crime scene they will not easily forget. Susy was slumped on the kitchen floor in a widening pool of blood. A slim, 45-year-old housewife, she was unrecognisable, repeatedly slashed and stabbed.

Her son, Gianluca, 12, was in a bath upstairs. If anything his wounds were worse, the victim of berserks who did not know when to stop. Mother and son were stabbed a total of 97 times.

The suburban townhouse in Novi Ligure, a small, prosperous town in the north-eastern region of Piedmont, was a slaughterhouse, gasped one detective. A wooden-handled, 15cm kitchen knife was recovered. Of the killers there was no sign.

Francesco La Nardo, Susy's husband, had been playing football during the butchery. A manager at a local chocolate factory, he had no known enemies.

All police had to go on was Erika's description of the intruders: one in his 40s, one in his 20s. They did not speak but had dark hair and sallow skin, typical of Slavs, of illegal immigrants.

Word spread and within hours a furious crowd surrounded the mayor. For months, years, there had been warnings about roving Albanian thugs. Yet the mayor did nothing. The police did nothing. And now Susy and Ginaluca were dead.

As Erika was shown police photos of Albanian criminals the cry went up around the country. Newspapers demanded a crackdown on illegal immigrants.

The Northern League, part of the centre-right opposition coalition, announced a series of demonstrations. Liberals squirmed and conceded that, yes, something would have to be done.

Meanwhile, investigators made some discoveries. Erika said she ran to her neighbour but bloodstained footprints showed she walked. Erika identified the photo of an Albanian who could not possibly have been in Novi Ligure that night. Erika said the intruders were thieves but nothing was missing.

Erika was lying. In a series of twists that have stunned Italy, Erika and her 17-year-old boyfriend have been arrested for the murders. A secret surveillance camera and microphone inside a police interview room caught the couple discussing the killings.

In an echo of the Stephen Lawrence-murder suspects, Erika was filmed miming the stabbings. They are expected to be charged this week. The case has dominated headlines and led news bulletins for seven days.

Italy is peering into its soul and finding only darkness. It is telling that Erika chose to blame immigrants. Linking them to crime is a national pastime: the number of Italians making the connection is twice that of Britons, according to a recent poll.

Politicians, notably those from the centre-right, led by Silvio Berlusconi, say it is a fact. Cracking down on immigrants and crime are electric campaign issues in elections due in May. The ruling centre-left has appealed for tolerance but cannot resist promising its own populist crackdown.

Justice minister Piero Fassino summed up the newfound sense of unease: "I believe that someone should beg the pardon of immigrants. The level of incivility we've seen in this country in the last 48 hours should make us all reflect."

The mayor of Novi Ligure went further: "We've gone from one horror to another." Such sentiments are being overtaken by bewilderment that apparently normal, happy teenagers could be responsible. Motive remains a mystery

Last night Erika and her boyfriend, named only as Mauro, were still accusing each other, giving completely different versions of who instigated the violence.

They agree only that Erika gave Mauro some fruit juice from the fridge before Susy returned home with Gianluca. The horror that followed is tormenting Italy.

Is there a malady at the root of family life, an emptiness in adolescents, a fraying moral fabric? Psychologists, sociologists and psychiatrists have been called on to explain. None has succeeded. "We have met the enemy and discovered that it is ourselves," said Corriere della Sera.

webTitle: Leader: Treasury mistaken on London Underground

fields.headline: Dogma down the tube
fields.standfirst: The Treasury should speak up or shut up
fields.trailText: More than 80% of Londoners are opposed to the government's part-privatisation of the underground system. Practically anyone who is anyone is against it except for one very important man: Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
More than 80% of Londoners are opposed to the government's part-privatisation of the underground system. Even the Conservatives have abandoned their plans to privatise it in the face of unremittingly hostile public opinion. Practically anyone who is anyone is against it except for one very important man: Gordon Brown.

The chancellor - and, to be fair, his department - are implacably opposed even though they know they have lost the argument with electors. They passionately believe that their public/private partnership model would not only leave most of the tube in public hands but would, for the first time, ensure that cost overruns on public projects are met by the private sector and not the taxpayer as happened with the Jubilee extension, which doubled in cost.

If this were true it would be a formidable argument. But opponents simply don't believe that the Treasury has found a solution to the endemic problem of controlling large projects. It points to the Channel Tunnel, a private sector project that doubled in cost, and the fast rail link to the channel that the private sector wouldn't build without a Treasury guarantee. It suggests Mr Brown and his colleagues should drop their political objections to Ken Livingstone and take the TGV on a journey around France ending up with the Paris Métro to see for themselves how government money and control can produce enviable results.

Tony Blair must sort this mess out very quickly. Not because there is an election in the offing but because London's collapsing transport infrastructure demands a speedy solution. If the Treasury, which has been remarkably shy to argue its own case in public, really thinks it has right on its side then it should speak up or shut up. But its case will need to be good. In Bob Kiley, London appears to have found the right man for the right job at the right time. And time is something that suffering underground passengers do not have on their side.

webTitle: Apocalypse Again with new version of cult film

fields.headline: Apocalypse Again with new version of cult film
fields.trailText: Francis Ford Coppola will show his Vietnam epic Apocalypse Now in the way he originally intended at the Cannes Film Festival in May
fields.body:
Few films have divided their audiences as much as the Vietnam drama Apocalypse Now did when it first appeared 21 years ago.

The debate it likely to be resumed, for its director, Francis Coppola, is finally able to show it in the way he originally intended, with nearly an hour added to its length and controversial scenes included.

The new version will be shown at the Cannes Film Festival in May and may finally satisfy those admirers who were aware that much of the original footage was left out of the 1979 version.

The film will run to three hours and 17 minutes, 53 minutes longer than the version that caused such a stir when it was first released and shared the Palme D'Or award at Cannes with The Tin Drum.

Coppola, who also made the Godfather films and The Conversation, said in a statement yesterday that the new version allowed him to reintegrate scenes which he believed made the film stronger and provided a greater historical context.

"It is a more disturbing, sometimes funnier and more romantic film, whose historical perspective has become more forceful," he said.

The re-edited film includes the "French plantation" scenes with the late Christian Marquand and Aurore Clement.

Fans of Marlon Brando, who starred as the mad renegade Colonel Kurtz, will have a chance to see him in previously unshown footage.

"It seems to me important ... just one year after the first visit of an American president to Vietnam, to show that this work has lost none of its force or disturbing impact," said Gilles Jacob, president of the film festival.

Bill Clinton visited Vietnam last year, the first time a US president had done so since the war.

The film, loosely based on the Joseph Conrad short novel Heart of Darkness, charts the progress up the Mekong river of an army captain, played by Martin Sheen, who is sent to assassinate Kurtz. Its making became almost as famous as the film itself: the budget increased from $12m (£7m) to nearly $30m and filming in the Philippines took 16 months.

A documentary, Hearts of Darkness, was made about its making. The delay in completion led to it being nicknamed Apocalypse Later.

When it was first shown it polarised the critics. Time magazine called it "emotionally obtuse and intellectually empty", and others suggested that its hit-and-miss quality made Apocalypse Now and Then a more suitable title. Others placed it among the great American movies.

Coppola said at the 1979 Cannes festival: "It's more of an experience than a movie. At the beginning there's a story. Along the river the story becomes less important and the experience more important."

The cinematographer Vittorio Storaro and Walter Murch, one of the original editors, who both won Oscars for the film, have both worked on the re-edited version.

fields.headline: Sun edits out Desmond's Fantasy
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: The Sun is to remove references to Richard Desmond's Fantasy Channel from its TV listings, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Sun is removing Richard Desmond-owned Fantasy Channel from its TV listings as the circulation war with the new Express owner hots up.

And it is believed executives at the company have told journalists not to make additional references to the soft porn channel that could give Mr Desmond additional publicity.

Sun executive editor Chris Roycroft-Davies told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "It's really a matter for the editor of the Sun and the staff. We would not wish to discuss it."

But an insider said: "Now Richard Desmond is perceived as being a rival press baron, the Star is perceived as a rival - however distant, it's still a rival."

The move could have repurcussions for high profile TV columnist Garry Bushell who was one of the station's biggest fans.

He even presented a series on the station about lap dancers.

Mr Desmond, who owns the Express, the Sunday Express and the Star, has announced he wants to sell off his paper-based pornograph interests.

But the Fantasy Channel, the subscription-based service thought to account for most of his estimated £100m wealth, is not up for sale.

fields.headline: Share-tipping curbs on reporters are 'unworkable'
fields.trailText: The government's proposals to curb journalists from share-tipping have been criticised as 'unworkable', writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The head of the Newspaper Industry's Code of Practice Committee has attacked new government proposals to curb journalists from share-tipping as "completely unworkable".

Les Hinton, who is also the executive chairman of News International, has written a strongly-worded letter to the economic secretary to the Treasury, Melanie Johnson.

The letter states: "In any newspaper or magazine, a substantial number of people have an involvement in an article - not just the journalist who writes the article, but the commissioning editor, the City (or possibly political or home affairs) editor, the sub editor, on occasion the picture editor, a copy taker, a lawyer who may clear the article, the deputy editor and the editor."

Mr Hinton argues that the new proposals do not make clear with whom the ultimate responsibility lies.

"If copy is changed after the journalist writes it - in a manner which brings it within the scope to the Order - is the originating journalist still responsible?" the letter asks.

Under new rules journalists will have to declare if they have any interest in any shares tipped or written about.

The rules have been drafted in the wake of the scandal generated by the former City Slickers, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who were sacked last year from the Mirror.

The Mirror's editor, Piers Morgan, was found to have bought shares in computer manufacturer Viglen after the two journalists had tipped the shares in their City column.

Other financial journalists are incensed by the plans, believing the rules to be cumbersome and unworkable.

National newspaper groups put forward arguments to the Treasury that self-regulation was the best way to prevent insider dealing, market manipulation and other new financial crimes.

The rules are part of the legislation that will enable the Financial Services Authority to begin its regulatory powers later this year.

fields.headline: Cleese lambasts 'interfering' BBC execs
fields.trailText: 10am: John Cleese has called the making of his new BBC series The Human Face as a 'total nightmare', writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Comedy legend John Cleese has launched an extraordinary attack on BBC management, describing the experience of making his new documentary series The Human Face a "total nightmare".

Mr Cleese said working for the BBC again, for the first time since his involvement in ground-breaking 1970s shows Monty Python's Flying Circus and Fawlty Towers, had been "a pretty ghastly experience" because of interference from executives.

"All the way through the BBC there are very nice people making the most fundamental management errors," he added.

"They said to me several months ago, 'Oh, in a landmark series it's always like this John'. ...And I said, 'Why didn't you say that... the past four months would be a total nightmare and I wouldn't be able to sleep properly?'.

"The disorganisation and bad management at times has been beyond belief," Mr Cleese said in an interview in today's Telegraph.

"Which is why the series has taken ten-and-a-half months to complete instead of five.

"Nobody has been rude, no one has been unpleasant, people have tried very hard. And yet it's just been bloody impossible."

BBC executives insisted on toning down the humorous elements of The Human Face - which goes out on BBC1 from next Thursday - and inserting more factual content, said Mr Cleese.

"If you read an email saying, 'We've had enough of Cleese's fooling about by now' you think 'Well, I don't mind them feeling that way, but why did they ask me to do it in the first place?'," he said.

A BBC spokeswoman defended the way The Human Face was made.

"Like many factual series it has evolved since it's initial concept. But it's still a lively mix of popular science, psychology, culture and comedy."

Mr Cleese said he did not think Monty Python would have lasted more than four episodes in today's BBC.

"When Fawlty Towers worked or Monty Python worked, they trusted you," he added. "But I think there's much more fear of failure now than there used to be. When people get anxious they become control freaks."

Mr Cleese also implicitly criticised BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey, who replaced Peter Salmon while The Human Face was in production last year.

"He doesn't call to tell you he's leaving and she doesn't call to tell you she's taking over. It's basic management practice to ring people up and say, 'I'm now in charge' but it just didn't happen."

But the BBC spokeswoman dismissed the claim, saying Ms Heggessey had had several conversations with Mr Cleese about The Human Face.

"She is delighted with both the series and John as a presenter," the spokeswoman added.
fields.bodyText: Comedy legend John Cleese has launched an extraordinary attack on BBC management, describing the experience of making his new documentary series The Human Face a "total nightmare". Mr Cleese said working for the BBC again, for the first time since his involvement in ground-breaking 1970s shows Monty Python's Flying Circus and Fawlty Towers, had been "a pretty ghastly experience" because of interference from executives. "All the way through the BBC there are very nice people making the most fundamental management errors," he added. "They said to me several months ago, 'Oh, in a landmark series it's always like this John'. ...And I said, 'Why didn't you say that... the past four months would be a total nightmare and I wouldn't be able to sleep properly?'. "The disorganisation and bad management at times has been beyond belief," Mr Cleese said in an interview in today's Telegraph. "Which is why the series has taken ten-and-a-half months to complete instead of five. "Nobody has been rude, no one has been unpleasant, people have tried very hard. And yet it's just been bloody impossible." BBC executives insisted on toning down the humorous elements of The Human Face - which goes out on BBC1 from next Thursday - and inserting more factual content, said Mr Cleese. "If you read an email saying, 'We've had enough of Cleese's fooling about by now' you think 'Well, I don't mind them feeling that way, but why did they ask me to do it in the first place?'," he said. A BBC spokeswoman defended the way The Human Face was made. "Like many factual series it has evolved since it's initial concept. But it's still a lively mix of popular science, psychology, culture and comedy." Mr Cleese said he did not think Monty Python would have lasted more than four episodes in today's BBC. "When Fawlty Towers worked or Monty Python worked, they trusted you," he added. "But I think there's much more fear of failure now than there used to be. When people get anxious they become control freaks." Mr Cleese also implicitly criticised BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey, who replaced Peter Salmon while The Human Face was in production last year. "He doesn't call to tell you he's leaving and she doesn't call to tell you she's taking over. It's basic management practice to ring people up and say, 'I'm now in charge' but it just didn't happen." But the BBC spokeswoman dismissed the claim, saying Ms Heggessey had had several conversations with Mr Cleese about The Human Face. "She is delighted with both the series and John as a presenter," the spokeswoman added.

fields.headline: Desmond wants Hyland for the Star
fields.trailText:
9.45am: Sunday Mirror showbiz columnist Ian Hyland is being wooed by Richard Desmond to join the Star, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 9: Desmond woos Hyland
fields.body:
Ian Hyland, the Sunday Mirror's showbusiness columnist, is being wooed by Richard Desmond, who wants him to join the Star as one of his new signings.

It is understood a big money offer has already been made to the Mr Hyland which is now being considered.

"Everyone here is talking about it but they would mad to lose him," said one staffer on the paper.

Talks between Mr Desmond's representatives and the star columnist have previously centred on a possible job on the Sunday Express.

The approach has surprised many because Mr Hyland is the scourge of many stars but particularly Victoria Beckham - one of Mr Desmond's celebrity friends and a regular on his OK! magazine.

He wrote on one occasion that she and husband David Beckham had agreed to pose nude for a Playboy centrespread, and has also alleged that she wore a wig on stage with the Spice Girls.

The move would be likely to create friction on the Express titles, where showbusiness journalists have been asked not to write negative stories about the Beckhams and other celebrities who Mr Desmond wants to woo for his OK! magazine.

Mr Desmond, who bought the Express, Sunday Express and the Daily Star at the end of last year, wants to make the Daily Star a rival to the Sun.

He has already poached the Sun's football columnist Brian Woolnough and is believed to have approached Garry Bushell about joining the paper.

fields.headline: Eidos faces more misery
fields.trailText: Tomb Raider games maker Eidos has admitted it faces another miserable year, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Computer games maker Eidos has admitted it faces another miserable year, as the non-appearance of the PlayStation 2 console continues to hurt the company.

The admission came as the designer of the Tomb Raider series said it had racked up a nine-month loss of £68m.

The loss is blamed on an ill-advised internet investment and the writing off of a stockpile of unwanted games.

Two years ago Eidos was soaring on the back of the success of Tomb Raider.

But the appeal of its products has faded and the company is relying on the much-delayed PS2 console to kick-start its fortunes once again.

"While the company remains confident in the mid to long-term prospects of the entertainment software market, there continues to be a lack of visibility through to Christmas 2001," said Eidos chief executive Mike McGarvey.

He said the company was "cautious" about the next 12 months.

Sony is still experiencing delays in producing the PS2 box, and Microsoft's rival Xbox is up to a year away from arriving in Europe.

Mr McGarvey said 2002 will be the real "growth year" for PS2 consoles, when Sony begins full production of its much-hyped product.

"While we are certainly very excited about the new platforms, I think we will be cautious into next year.

"We will remain wary until we see the consoles in the marketplace," he added.

The Eidos turnover figures for the nine months to December last year underlined the cyclical nature of the games market, which is boosted every time a new console appears.

Turnover fell from £142.6m in 1999 to £137.8m, despite the company selling 1m copies of its Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? tie-in.

webTitle: Milburn plans to cut death rate of poor

fields.headline: Milburn plans to cut death rate of poor
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today signal a historic shift in NHS policy when he announces a 10-year plan to reduce infant mortality and premature adult deaths in the poorest parts of England.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today signal a historic shift in NHS policy when he announces a 10-year plan to reduce infant mortality and premature adult deaths in the poorest parts of England.

In a speech that is meant to unveil the "big idea" for Labour's general election manifesto on health, he will announce the first government targets to reduce the most flagrant examples of health inequalities that are blighting the lives of the poor.

Unlike previous targets for reducing NHS waiting lists and increasing the input of re sources flowing into the service, the new targets will focus on health outcomes.

The first will be to save the lives of at least 3,000 children a year by bringing infant mortality rates in the poorest areas closer to the national average.

The second will be to reduce the gap in life expectancy that causes people in the poorest areas to die about seven years earlier than their contemporaries in more prosperous areas. Similar targets are expected in the manifestos for Scotland and Wales.

"For too long the health debate in this country has been focused on the state of the nation's health service and not on the state of the nation's health," Mr Milburn will say in a speech in London to the Long Term Medical Conditions Alliance, a group of patients' organisations.

"The progress we have made in our first term allows us to set a new ambition for the second term. It is to undertake the biggest assault our country has ever seen in health disadvantage - to start to break the link between poverty and ill health ... to improve the health of the poorest fastest."

The drive against infant mortality was triggered by government figures showing six children in every thousand died before their first birthday in poor areas, compared with a national average of 5.5. Mr Milburn will pledge to reduce the gap by at least 10% by 2010.

He will set a similar target to reduce inequalities in the adult death rate. Figures from the office of national statistics show life expectancy for men in England ranged from 70.1 to 78.4 years and for women from 76.8 to 83.5 years.

Mr Milburn will say it is unacceptable that a boy from the most disadvantaged social group will live nine years less than a boy from the most disadvantaged. A boy born in Manchester can expect to die seven years earlier than a boy from Oxfordshire.

Policies to close the inequality gap would initially be directed at health authorities where the problem is greatest.

These areas will get a larger share of the growth in the NHS budget. Policies will include extension of the Sure Start programme to help pregnant women and their partners, better health education in schools and an intensive drive to cut smoking and reduce coronary heart disease. There will be a new health poverty index to measure health inequalities more accurately.

As a first step, Mr Milburn will today start to provide 80,000 children aged four to six with free fruit during every school day. It was being billed by the Department of Health last night as the biggest health promotion initiative in schools since the start of free school milk in 1948.

fields.headline: Reuben Singh in dot.com deal
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Reuben Singh is on the verge of closing a fundraising round for a new dot.com venture that he claims will be valued at £85m. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
Reuben Singh, the 24 year old entrepreneur who made a fortune from the sale of his Miss Attitude retail chain, is on the verge of closing a fundraising round for a new dot.com venture that he claims will be valued at £85m.

alldaypa, an internet based virtual office, is in advanced talks with the Arizona based Phoenix Fund, a specialist technology investment vehicle backed by five unnamed internet entrepreneurs, a spokesman for Mr Singh said.

Phoenix has offered to buy a 10% stake in alldaypa for £8.5m and may provide further cash for expansion into the US, he added.

If the deal is completed it would value Mr Singh's shareholding at around £60m. He provided the two year old firm with seed funding of around £3m.

alldaypa launches this week and offers secure data storage, unlimited web space, virtual secretarial services and online personal organisers.

Mr Singh says he has 11 strategic partnerships in place and is talking to a major high street bank about providing services for 550,000 small and medium sized business customers.

The Manchester based entrepreneur started girls fashion accessories chain Miss Attitude when he was a teenager and would be driven to meetings in a Rolls-Royce. The business was sold for a reported £22m but observers suggested Mr Singh received as little as £500,000.

He has been warmly embraced by the government who have appointed him to the DTI's competitiveness council and the department of culture media and sports e-commerce steering body.

His portrait hangs in the National Portrait Gallery.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: letters
fields.body:
Joe Phillips
Bingham, Notts

 You report on the "discrimination" allegedly experienced by faith-based welfare organisations when seeking public funding. You could also usefully explore the discrimination widely practised by these organisations against other people.

Some religious groups have been guilty of discriminating both against those seeking help or those they employ because they failed to lead a sufficiently "Christian" lifestyle. There is copious evidence of this in the report Christian Homophobia, published by the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement. Suspected co-habitees and adulterers have also been targeted.

If more public money is to be made available to religious groups, it should be ring-fenced for the benefit of service users, rather than being used for proselytisation or for the promotion of a particular religion. Any organisation wanting public money should be willing to apply equal opportunities to its service provision and employment policy.

Terry Sanderson
Council member, National Secular Society, London

National concern

The government's last minute concessions over patient representation in the health and social care bill go some way towards limiting the damage done by the abolition of community health councils (Malcolm Dean, February 21). Crucially, they begin to address concerns about the lack of both an integrated local watchdog and of independent advocacy.

However, there is one glaring omission: a national body. The health and social care bill abolishes the Association of Community Health Councils (ACHCEW), a national patients' watchdog, without putting any other national structure in its place. This will mean that patients lack a single statutory body to represent them at a national level and that nation-wide information gathering, such as that which goes into our annual national "Casualty Watch" survey, simply cannot take place. It will also mean that patient representatives within the new system will be deprived of the training, information and legal advice that they now receive from ACHCEW.

It is not enough to have more patient representatives within the system. We need to ensure that those representatives have access to training, support, information and a network of others in a similar position. We also need to ensure that they have a means of raising their concerns at a national level. Sometimes the problem doesn't rest with an individual trust or health authority but with the Department of Health itself. Maintaining a national patients' voice is the only way to make sure the right people get the message.

Donna Covey
Director, Association of Community Health Councils of England and Wales

Staff of life

I sympathise with ND Smith (Letters, February 14), whose mother-in-law in Leeds has to move because her nursing home is to close as it cannot afford the improvements required under the new legislation.

Of course, physical standards are important, but the care offered in nursing homes is surely more so. It is little comfort to be in a single room if one is left alone, hungry, wet and thirsty. Staffing problems are well known. The shortage of nurses is acute and some moonlight in homes on their days off from the local hospital or work excessively long hours. In the home my mother was in, staff often had to "cover" for missing colleagues, and all the staff changed constantly.

Much needs to be done in recruitment, training, management, conditions of service and support. Improvement in these areas would also be expensive and harder to achieve than putting in an extra lavatory. The other danger is that if physical standards are good, assumptions may be made about the quality of care - for example, by an inspector on a pre-arranged visit.

A greatly strengthened inspection system, as is planned, is welcome, but my choice would have been to tackle staffing issues first.

Some residents in the nursing homes are so frail they cannot ask for a drink or even pick up a cup; they are completely helpless and some are utterly alone in the world. All of them deserve better from us.

If all the people who object to cigarette breaks hadn't complained in the first place, the smokers wouldn't have to leave their work to smoke (Smoking gun? February 14). So why don't they invite them back into the office and then they'd all be happy, wouldn't they?

fields.headline: Mezzanine sells net music arm
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Mezzanine, the bar and restaurant group, yesterday announced it had sold its loss-making internet dance music business to its management. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Mezzanine, the bar and restaurant group, yesterday announced it had sold its loss-making internet dance music business, mezzmusic, to its management.

The company, which introduced mezzmusic in February last year in a blaze of publicity, sold the dot.com arm for £750,000 but will keep a 19.9% stake.

The group has agreed to defer the payment for two years.

It has poured £2.5m into the site and last year planned to list mezzmusic on the stock exchange.

"We still believe it has got a great future, though. We just take the view that it was wrong to put aside the huge amount of funds that would have been necessary," chief executive Marios Georgallides said.

Radio One disc jockey Dave Pearce, who in 1999 was drafted in to attract young customers by jazzing up the image of Mezzanine, will stay with the internet branch.

The announcement came as the company posted a pre-tax loss of £1.3m for the six months to the beginning of December, including losses of £813,447 at mezzmusic, compared with a profit of £23,442 for the previous six months. Turnover increased from £2.5m to £4.6m.

The group, which is focused on its core activities of restaurants, bars and clubs, plans to roll out further Smollensky's bars and restaurants - described by chairman Roddy Sutherland as being like "an American Chez Gerard".

The company opened Attica, a club and restaurant in Soho, in December and is looking for acquisitions.

There are concerns in the City, however, about the long-term strength of the Smollensky's brand and the company's ability to generate enough turnover to cover costs and to expand.

Shares in Mezzanine rose 1.5p to 16p.

fields.headline: 'Musical lottery tickets' unveiled in holiday promotion
fields.trailText: 8.30am: National Lottery ticket terminals will play music to players if they win one of 200 holidays worth £5,000, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
In a drive to inject more excitement and fun in to playing the National Lottery, ticket terminals will play music to players if they win one of 200 holidays worth £5,000.

Camelot is giving away the holidays in a tie-up with Thomas Cook.

It is the first major product giveaway for the main lottery game and heralds a move by Camelot to involve third-party brands.

A National Lottery Instants game currently running, Cars and Cash, is giving away 200 Vauxhall Astra cars and lottery tickets have offered value-added promotions in the past - such as discounted entrance to tourist attractions.

Players have to listen out for a musical fanfare when buying their National Lottery ticket between March 4 and March 10. Winners will hear the music and a congratulation message will appear printed on the ticket.

A national TV and radio advertising campaign created by advertising agency WCRS will support the promotion.

The promotion will be flagged up in 700 Thomas Cook shops and 24,8000 National Lottery outlets by point-of-sale material designed by Hicklin Slade.

A 20-second TV advert will break on Sunday March 4 with the 30-second radio spot going on air the day after.

Both adverts focus on showing players how to take part in the promotion and how to know if they are a winner.

Winners can spend the £5,000 on the holiday of their choice as long as it is booked through Thomas Cook.

"Brand initiatives such as this form an integral part of Camelot's core marketing strategy and this promotion is designed to reward National Lottery Game players, as well as give them an extra bit of fun and excitement," said Camelot sales and marketing director Ian Milligan.

fields.headline: Thames in hot water over advertising claims
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Thames Water has been criticised over a newspaper campaign in which it claimed tap water tastes better than bottled. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Thames Water has had its wrists slapped by advertising watchdogs over a high-profile national newspaper campaign in which it claimed tap water tastes better than bottled.

The Advertising Standards Authority upheld two complaints about the campaign - one from the Consumers Association, which claimed Thames Water had used its research for the adverts without its permission, and one from the Natural Mineral Water Information Service.

The campaign stated: "In a recent Health Which? magazine survey, Thames Water came out top for taste against bottled varieties."

The Consumers' Association, which owns Which? magazine, claimed its research had been used without its permission, while the NMWIS complained the advert misleadingly implied that Thames Water had come out above all bottled water varieties, which was not the case.

But a national press advert that appeared to encourage traffic warden-bashing escaped censure.

The campaign, for the Mercedes A-Class, featured a photograph of a traffic warden standing next to a large puddle with the catchline, "Some things are even harder to resist. If soaking traffic wardens is tempting, how about an A-Class from only £12,790".

Several members of the public complained the advert encouraged anti-social behaviour, but the ASA ruled it was unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence.

The Halifax building society was criticised over a press advert headlined, "Challenge us to chop your monthly loan costs".

The advert carried a table that compared the cost of a personal loan with the Halifax with its rivals, with the cost of the Halifax loan coming out the lowest.

The complainants challenged whether the comparison was fair and also complained that the advert was misleading because it did not make it clear that customers would have to have a Halifax mortgage and savings account to qualify for the loan.

The ASA ruled the comparisons were unfair because some of the other loans mentioned in the table did not require the borrower to have an existing relationship with the lender.

The watchdog asked the Halifax not to make similar comparisons in future advertising

webTitle: Heat signs Popstars for celebrity auction

fields.headline: Heat signs Popstars for celebrity auction
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Emap magazine Heat is organising a celebrity auction featuring ITV's Popstars, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 15: Heat rises 135%
fields.body:
Heat, Emap Elan's celebrity magazine, which recorded a through-the-roof sales increase in the recent ABCs, is organising a celebrity auction featuring the ITV Popstars band Hear'Say.

Myleene, Kym, Noel, Danny and Suzanne will perform their single Pure and Simple on March 14 at the Park Lane Hilton.

The performance will be the culmination of an auction that will see Liz Hurley's silk Versace shoes and Mariah Carey's cut-off jeans go under the hammer.

The proceeds will go towards the Aids and HIV charity Crusaid, which is supported by, among others, Rupert Everett and Sharleen Spiteri.

The auction indicates the growing confidence of celebrity magazines, all of which recorded rises in readership at the last ABCs.

Heat, edited by Mark Frith, saw its circulation rise by almost 140%.

Related story

fields.headline: Hello! plans 'cool' supplement
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The new-look Hello! is to launch a listings and entertainment supplement called Seven Days, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Phil Hall's new-look Hello! is to launch a listings and entertainment supplement called Seven Days.

The magazine, which is to be edited by former Cosmopolitan deputy Leah Hardy, is the next stage in Mr Hall's drive to give Hello! a younger, more upmarket appeal.

Mr Hall said the 56-page supplement would include TV, health, shopping, property and astrology sections, but would be closer in tone to a weekend supplement than a listings magazine.

"The tone will be cool, picking up cool new trends from cool people," said Mr Hall, who was brought in as editor-in-chief earlier this year.

Seven Days will be produced by John Brown Publishing, which already publishes Viz, Bare and successful contract magazines such as Waitrose Food Illustrated and Virgin's Hot Air.

The tone and feel of Hello! has already changed since Mr Hall took over as editor.

Famous as the home for minor European royals, the magazine is now in hand-to-hand combat with OK! magazine, seen as the home of mass market celebrities such as Posh Spice and husband David Beckham.

This week's magazine, for example, devotes 20 pages to Celine Dion and her new miracle baby and seven pages to Leonardo di Caprio's fiance Gisele Bunchen and five pages to an ITV star from Heartbeat Tricia Penrose.

Mr Hall has also hired Debbie Frank, Princess Diana's former astrologer, David Billington, the former Express art editor, and Clair Woodward, the former OK! deputy editor.

Seven Days will launch on March 13 and be bound in the centre of Hello!

fields.headline: WCRS to raise profile of Vizzavi
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Vizzavi, the portal owned by Vivendi Universal and Vodafone, has hired WCRS to handle its advertising, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Vizzavi, the multi-access portal owned jointly by Vivendi Universal and Vodafone, has confirmed it has hired WCRS to handle its European advertising business.

The task, which involves building brand awareness quickly and encouraging customer acquisition, is worth up to £100m.

Vizzavi's consumer campaign will run across five territories: UK, France, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands.

It will be led by WCRS London with support from agencies in its European network.

WCRS scooped the account from Vizzavi's incumbent agency Publicis, while other agencies shortlisted were BMP DDB, Bates UK and D'Arcy.

The news is a welcome boost to WCRS, which was ditched by long-term client Orange last year.

"While WCRS's knowledge of the mobile arena was advantageous, its strategic thinking and brand positioning work won it the account," said Guy Laurence, Vizzavi's chief marketing officer.

At the beginning of this month, Vodafone appointed WCRS to its £48m UK advertising account.

The agency is also pitching for Vodafone's wider global business.

Vizzavi was unveiled in the UK last summer with a press and poster advertising blitz but it has since maintained a low profile.

The service is available online and via Wap devices but the company wants to roll it out to other platforms, including digital television.

The branded multi-access portal will compete with the US giants AOL Time Warner and Yahoo!

Optimedia and CIA Medianetwork are understood to be fighting for Vizzavi's media buying account.

The company said it would announce the winner of this pitch shortly.

fields.headline: Williams returns to Burson-Marsteller
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The world's largest PR network has lured Dr Emyr Williams from KPMG to be a director, reports Julia Day.
Feb 8: Crawshaw joins Burson-Marsteller as interactive head
fields.body:
Burson-Marsteller, the world's largest PR network, has appointed a director from new media consultancy KPMG.

Dr Emyr Williams will join Burson-Marsteller's London office.

He is returning to the agency, having worked as Burson-Marsteller's deputy managing director from 1987-1988.

Dr Williams has spent the past 12 years as a consulting partner with KPMG, where he will remain a senior adviser.

At KPMG, he worked with clients across Europe and the US on commercial strategy, brand development and customer management.

His clients at KPMG included PepsiCo, Nestle, AstraZeneca, Visa and Unilever.

Burson-Marsteller's clients include BT, BP, Johnson and Johnson and Accenture, previously Andersen Consulting.

At Burson-Marsteller, Dr Williams will continue to advise clients on their business plans and the anticipation of future issues that may affect them.

"Burson-Marsteller is moving forward in leaps and bounds and I look forward to being part of the agency's great success," said Dr Williams.

Burson-Marsteller chief executive Allan Biggar said: "I am delighted Emyr has chosen to return to the fold.

"As Burson-Marsteller continues its drive to become the PR agency of choice, his wise counsel will offer an important contribution in reaching that goal," he added.

fields.headline: Mori blasts BBC consultation process
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC's public consultation on its proposed digital services has been rubbished by the polling body, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC's public consultation on its proposed digital services has been rubbished for being "not representative of the public in any meaningful sense" by leading polling organisation Mori.

The Mori analysis of the BBC consultation process was commissioned by a group of the corporation's commercial broadcasting rivals.

It concluded: "The respondents as a group are insufficiently representative of the general public to 'demonstrate conclusively' anything about the opinions of licence payers in general".

As a result, the consultation was "clearly not representative of the public in any meaningful sense and cannot be considered a reliable measurement of public opinion", according to Mori.

"We see little evidence the BBC's consultation exercise is adequate to support the conclusions drawn from it and submitted to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport in its application for approval of new public services," the survey concluded.

But a BBC spokesman dismissed the Mori analysis.

"This is a pretty desperate attempt to undermine plans for the future of public service broadcasting in this country and expand the free-to-air choice in the digital future," he said.

Mori's study concluded the BBC consultation was based on a "self-selecting group" responding either to broadcast trails on corporation services or via the BBC website.

The polling body also noted the final sample of 6,768 people was "considerably skewed with, for example, 72% of respondents being male, compared with 48% of the UK adult population".

Mori's survey of the BBC consultation questionnaire found some individual questions to be "meaningless" and "badly designed", with the overall document reckoned to be of "limited worth".

The BBC spokesman defended the consultation, saying it had been the "biggest ever" undertaken by the corporation.

He added the TV and radio trails alone would have reached 85% of the UK population.

The BBC also promoted the consultation with press advertising, a press conference, public events and through its website.

The spokesman said the BBC had also used South Bank Consultants to do an independent assessment of the validity of the consultation exercise.

In addition, a parallel survey had been commissioned from BMRB, using a representative sample.

"The responses that came back from BMRB were even more positive than the so-called self-selecting results," he claimed.

The Mori analysis was commissioned by BSkyB, Artsworld, Fox Kids, Nickelodeon UK, MTV Networks Europe and the Commercial Radio Companies Association.

Today is the deadline for submissions to the DCMS on the BBC's digital service proposals.

webTitle: SMG raises its stake in Scottish Radio Holdings

fields.headline: Media manoeuvres
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: SMG raised its stake in rival Scottish Radio Holdings to 24.9% yesterday, underlining its hope that changes in ownership rules will eventually allow a full takeover.
fields.body:
SMG raised its stake in rival Scottish Radio Holdings to 24.9% yesterday, underlining its hope that changes in ownership rules will eventually allow a full takeover.

SMG's action was described by chief executive Andrew Flanagan as a "positioning move ahead of legislative change".

The rules on cross-media ownership would block a takeover but Mr Flanagan quashed speculation that SMG would be prepared to sell its ITV franchises to facilitate a deal.

"We hope cross-media legislation will change in the communications bill," he said. "If it didn't we would be loath to sell our ITV business. That is not in our plans."

SMG, which also owns businesses including Virgin Radio, the Herald newspaper, and cinema advertising unit Pearl & Dean, reported a 24% increase in revenues to £300m for 2000. Pre-tax profits were 18% higher at £59m.

webTitle: Murdoch cautious about DirecTV deal prospects

fields.headline: Murdoch keeps talking
fields.standfirst:
News Corp chief cautious about DirecTV deal prospects

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Merger talks between News Corporation and Hughes, the US firm that owns DirecTV, are proceeding but only "slowly", Rupert Murdoch said yesterday.
fields.body:
Merger talks between News Corporation and Hughes, the US firm that owns DirecTV, are proceeding but only "slowly", Rupert Murdoch said yesterday.

Mr Murdoch has made no secret of his desire to do a deal with Hughes, which is owned by General Motors. The two sides, however, are still discussing financial terms months after the reverse takeover talks started. GM is understood to want a higher proportion of the price paid in cash than Mr Murdoch is prepared to hand over.

At a conference organised by investment bank CSFB and Variety, the entertainment magazine, Mr Murdoch said: "We have had a few false starts. This may be another false start."

He said US regulations made him unable to talk about the deal yesterday but he thought a combination of his satellite television assets and DirecTV would be a good one. He said US satellite viewer numbers could easily double in the next few years.

He added that he did not need the US market to expand his satellite operations. "There is more opportunity outside the US than inside it.

Mr Murdoch has teamed up with John Malone, the billionaire cable investor, and Microsoft to discuss a reverse takeover of Hughes.

In a wide-ranging interview, Mr Murdoch poured scorn on several of his competitors, with the exception of Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of Vivendi Universal who addressed the conference hours before Mr Murdoch did.

The two media moguls have fallen out over Mr Messier's sale of his 22% stake in BSkyB, the UK part of Sky Global. The Vivendi chief offered to sell his stake in order to win approval of his takeover of Seagram.

Mr Messier yesterday denied that there was a battle between the two men: "It is in the interests of both that we divest at the right time and for the highest value."

He also said that the sale agreement gave him "plenty of time" - two years - to sell.

Mr Malone is understood to be the most likely bidder for the stake. But Mr Messier said yesterday that Mr Malone was "one of many alternatives for the divestiture of BSkyB".

The News Corp chief was critical of last year's merger of America Online, the internet service provider, and Time Warner, the media group.

"I am not worried about the merger as I don't really believe in the synergies," Mr Murdoch said.

He also claimed that he was unlikely to buy Yahoo! even though the company's share price has fallen sharply in the past year.

fields.headline: Hollick defies advertising auguries
fields.standfirst:
United halts disposals despite publishing sector uncertainties
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: United halts disposals despite publishing sector uncertainties.
fields.body:
United Business Media yesterday added its concerns to the growing sense of disquiet over the health of the advertising market.

Lord Hollick, United's chief executive, also signalled a temporary halt to the disposals which have transformed the group over the past year.

The company said the outlook for its business publishing division, which is heavily exposed to the US hi-tech market, "remains uncertain". After a series of sales last year including United's ITV franchises and Express Newspapers, the group's US hi-tech publishing division, CMP, accounts for 46% of revenues.

United was not, he added, "spooked" by the nervousness in the market. In the first eight weeks of the new year, advertising revenues have roughly matched the same period in 2000.

"There is uncertainty and softness in the market but this is not a market in a tailspin. We have no crystal ball but we have performed pretty well so far," Lord Hollick said.

United reported a 22% fall in pre-tax profits to £214m for 2000 after online losses of £128m. Turnover was 23% higher at £1.05bn. The numbers beat expectations and United shares rose 2.6% to close at 748.5p.

The company has again reduced its investment in the internet and said it would invest no more than £45m in the business-to-business market this year. About 30 websites related to CMP titles, one-third of the total, will be closed.

Lord Hollick said United would hold on to its 35% stake in Channel 5 for the medium term, ruling out a disposal this year. The company will retain its consumer publishing titles including Exchange & Mart until conditions improve. "Now is not a time to sell. Now is a time to buy," he said.

Lord Hollick said the dispute with Channel 5's majority shareholder, RTL, over the broadcaster's programming budget had been resolved in United's favour. The company said a budget of £140m had been agreed, lower than the £180m for which RTL had argued.

After returning £1.25bn to shareholders, United will still have £300m in the bank, no debt and borrowing facilities of £1.5bn.

The sale of some smaller consumer assets is under way. Discussions are continuing about a collection of businesses including TV channel Rapture, and online businesses LineOne, dot.music and Spaced.
