webTitle: Comment: Murdoch says Blair deluded on EU

fields.headline: Blair 'deluded' on EU, says Murdoch
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch yesterday called Tony Blair's support for Europe "deluded" in a speech that was otherwise highly supportive of the prime minister.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch yesterday called Tony Blair's support for Europe "deluded" in a speech that was otherwise highly supportive of the prime minister.

In an hour-long interview at a media conference in New York, the owner of four national newspapers In Britain, including the Times and the Sun, said he was "suspicious" of Mr Blair's motives in Europe.

"He is deluded if he thinks the UK needs Europe," he said. "If you take someone else's currency, you lose your sovereignty."

When asked after the speech whether his newspapers would endorse Mr Blair at the forthcoming general election, Mr Murdoch said: "I would have to see what his policies are and what he says at the time. And I have to talk to the editors."

His comments echo those of the Sun, which has been broadly supportive of the Labour leader but highly critical of any attempt to strengthen national ties with Europe.

Mr Murdoch said he both liked and admired Tony Blair. "I like him personally. I like what he is trying to do; he is trying to make a meritocracy out of Britain."

He singled out the Labour party leader's education policies for support.

When the News International boss was asked later what he thought of William Hague, Mr Murdoch said: "I have a lot of respect for them both."

But he was scathing about European political institutions, saying the European Union was "not a democratic organisation".

"If they sat back and tried to take 100 years to do it, fine. But they are trying to do it yesterday," he said.

In a surprisingly candid interview, the media boss said he felt "bad" that he faced his 70th birthday in a few weeks' time.

He pulled out a list on which he had worked out the number of productive days he had spent and said: "I have wasted almost half my life." He also described himself as a "radical" and talked about the crushing of the print unions in the UK as "one of the things I am remembered for". Asked what he thought about the damaging strikes that changed the face of Fleet Street, he said: "It was a long, messy battle and a very, very unpleasant one. But I would certainly do it again."

The supporter of former president Reagan and prime minister Margaret Thatcher said he liked George Bush but would change his $1.3 trillion tax plans so that they helped lower and middle income earners.

webTitle: Jazz review: National Youth Jazz Orchestra

fields.headline: Teenage genius at Ronnie Scott's
fields.standfirst:
National Youth Jazz Orchestra
Ronnie Scott's
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: National Youth Jazz Orchestra, Ronnie Scott's, London
fields.body:
The National Youth Jazz Orchestra is now a pretty venerable institution. This hothouse, which has included such prodigies as Guy Barker, Dave O'Higgins and Gerard Presencer (who joined when he was 11), is celebrating its 35th anniversary. The present combination of a mostly teenage line-up and the orchestra's indefatigable maestro (the silver-haired, schoolmasterly Bill Ashton) certainly has something going for it. NYJO can play as many as a hundred concerts a year, a rarity on the UK jazz circuit for a group of its size.

The outfit is playing its annual high-profile week at Ronnie Scott's opposite the dynamic multi-instrumentalist Gary Husband Trio, and it is worth showing up early to catch both. The NYJO is very good on clever, hard-swinging, hairpin-turn arrangements and explosive brass licks, while Husband's trio is a constantly unpredictable class act, its material full of surprises.

NYJO played a mix of vivacious orthodox swing-band pieces and an extract from its impressionistic new suite, Out of Hamelin - Paul Hart's composition drawn from the Pied Piper story. The crispness of its section-playing and the power of its brass ensembles impart an exuberant energy to all kinds of pieces, from uptempo Latin groovers bustling with swaggering trombone sounds to the climactic episodes of more devious works.

A quiet, piano-led waltz dedicated to Cannonball Adderley became a punchy swing feature with casually complex downward-sliding riffs like a clip from Ellington's Happy Go Lucky Local. The follow-up, also in Adderley's memory, was the Allan Ganley arrangement of Cannon Fodder, engaging in its blend of busy, boppish lines against smoothly singing undercurrents. Two parts of the Pied Piper suite ran through some arresting contrasts of soft flugelhorn overtures, themes of warm and supple simplicity increasingly diverted by prancing jigs and slamming swing.

Tensions between the implications of youth and age are inescapably part of the story of this band, in ways that they aren't for classical youth ensembles, in which the personal idiosyncrasies and spontaneous creative contributions of the players come a distant second to formal interpretative skills. Youthful freshness of vision and an appetite for unlikely cultural collisions are not part of NYJO's picture of youth music. But section-playing professionalism, exuberant handling of a mainstream repertoire, together with warp-speed sight-reading, certainly are.

If the system produces a particular type of jazz player, it is a consummately expert one. And as the illustrious line-up of former NYJO jazz celebrities confirms, some of them turn out to be a great deal more than that.

· Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

webTitle: From farm to plate - a sick industry

fields.headline: From farm to plate - a sick industry
fields.standfirst:
The drive for agricultural efficiency has produced high yields and low prices - but the benefits have come at a price

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The drive for agricultural efficiency has produced high yields and low prices - but the benefits have come at a price
fields.body:
 Farming has become increasingly intensive, large scale and globalised in the drive for cheaper food

 In the last 10 years in Britain, the number of farms has fallen 25%, to 168,000 from 233,000

 Animals are reared on production lines. About 750m broiler chickens are reared and slaughtered in Britain each year, 98% of them intensively. They spend the last week of their lives in a space the size of an A4 sheet of paper. The spread of disease is a problem

 In two decades, new production methods have increased a dairy cow's average yield from 4,000 litres to 5,800 litres a year

 A cow named Marissa is set to break milk records: at nine years old, she had produced more than100,000 litres of milk from just seven calvings, averaging 35 litres a day for 10 years

 In 2000, 939,000 tonnes of pork and bacon were produced in Britain, 210,000 tonnes were exported and 520,000 imported

 Food processors usually want large quantities of uniform quality produce or animals at specific times. This is ideally suited to intensive farming methods which favour synthetic chemicals, land degradation and animal welfare problems

 Processed food may be of high nutritional quality, but it can add to environmental and social costs

 Often, food must be taken long distances to factories. Animal welfare groups have long fought to improve the conditions of animals which are routinely moved hundreds of miles in cramped conditions

 Because people buy so much in the way of processed ready meals, they often do not understand the need for proper cooking. This leads to greater potential for food poisoning - the incidence of which has been rising steadily in Britain

 Food processing further separates the urban consumer from the farm. Many children do not know how food is grown or how animals are reared

 Between 1978 and 1998, the distance food was transported increased by 50%

 Transporting animals long distances to slaughter has made it almost impossible to contain outbreaks of serious diseases such as foot and mouth

 Journeys of 200-400 miles to slaughter are not unusual for animals today

 The average journey to abattoir has been estimated at 100 miles

 In 1996, Britain imported 233,000 tonnes of beef - 80,000 tonnes of which were from outside the EU. The beef came from as far away as Namibia (9,500km) and Australia (21,000km)

 In order to be transported long distances food must be heavily processed, packaged, or chemically preserved

 25m tonnes of waste was produced in Britain in 1997 and one-third of that was packaging

 Britain's food market is dominated by five big supermarekt groups: Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda, Safeway and Somerfield

 The big five between them account for more than 80 % of all grocery sales

 The combined profits of the top four supermarkets was £2.1bn in 2000

 An inquiry by the competition commission looked into whether cheaper farm prices were passed on to the consumer. It found that the fall in prices which has hit farmers was passed on to the consumer - or that where it was not, this was because there were other increases elsewhere in the supply chain

 The inquiry also found that the real price of food had fallen by more than 9% between 1989 and 1998

 Supermarket profits are much greater than the combined income of all UK small farmers

 Each new major supermarket in a city has been found to cause up to 200 job losses

 The food we eat is increasingly processed

 Sales of chilled ready meals grew by 12% in 1999, while fresh fruit consumption fell by 3%, although sales of fresh fruit and vegetables had been increasing

 The major growth area in 1999 was in processed meats and meat products. Frozen convenience meat products have grown by 127% since 1978

 Milk Farmers get an average of 17p a litre for milk, though it costs them an average of 22p a litre to produce. A typical supermarket price is 35p a litre

 Beef It is almost impossible for a farmer to make a living producing beef in this country. Compensation for BSE cost £607m

 Fruit We now import four out of every five pears we eat. 65% of apple orchards have been lost. We imported 434,000 tonnes of apples in 1996. Cox's receive an average of 16 pesticide sprays

 Salad Lettuces can come from Spain, Turkey, Zimbabwe and Mexico. A typical crop will be sprayed 11.7 times

webTitle: Can the much-maligned tower block be making a comeback?

fields.headline: Tower blocks to make a comeback
fields.standfirst: Can the much-maligned tower block be making a comeback? As  John Cunningham reports, some housing groups are reaching for the sky again
fields.trailText: Can the much-maligned tower block be making a comeback? As John Cunningham reports, some housing groups are reaching for the sky again
fields.body:
Tower blocks, the detested public housing blamed for aggravating the social problems they were built to combat, are set to make a popular comeback after 30 years' controversy.

Scores of uninhabitable concrete monsters have already been demolished by councils, to the joy of disgruntled former residents. And William Hague believes that many high-rise council estates are still so unpopular that he has committed the Conservatives to tear down all remaining blighted blocks.

But this block-bashing is balanced by new enthusiasm for homes in the sky. Housing minister Nick Raynsford today opens a unique scheme in Portsmouth: the conversion of a city centre office tower into 96 flats; a mix of housing association and private ownership. And in London, Peabody Trust, the housing charity, is breaking new ground with plans for three projects of up to 20 storeys.

Jeff Welling, Portsmouth's housing services director, says that a shortage of land for housing in the city was the impetus for utilising an empty office building, renamed Chandos Rise.

In London, intense demand for accommodation for key workers in inner boroughs, and for low-income tenants, plus the prohibitive cost of new sites, is steering Peabody to plan far taller buildings than it has previously constructed, says the trust's director of development, Dickon Robinson.

Peabody has its eye on sites in Hackney, North Kensington and Southwark. If the schemes go ahead, Robinson believes that flats on the upper floors should have bigger rooms than those below, to attract occupants; and that maintenance must be of a guaranteed high standard.

Horror stories - everything from design defects to drugs; from mould to muggings - began to plague high-rise living almost as soon as blocks were erected en masse in the system-built 60s.

Catastrophes, such as the gas explosion that ripped through the corner flats of the 22-storey Ronan Point in east London in 1968, killing five people, fixed the image. Yet the reality is that most councils, while they might have pulled down some scarcely habitable blocks, still have a mix of well-run and run-down high-risers - 4,000 in all, providing homes for an estimated 800,000 people.

While there has been a national campaign by disillusioned tenants to get rid of tower blocks, there's been no concerted effort to persuade professionals in the housing sector, and residents, of their merits - until now.

The pressure group formed for this purpose hasn't picked a catchy name - the National Sustainable Tower Blocks Initiative (NSTBI) - but at least the four founding partners (Community Development Foundation, Going for Green, Groundwork and Shell Better Britain) have chosen a good moment for a campaign. In the next few years there is expected to be a huge transfer of blocks by councils to housing associations, many with no experience of the specific problems of multi-storey buildings.

There is a lot of muddle about what to do with the tower block legacy. It is roughly 10 times more expensive to refurbish than to demolish them. Finance is more easily obtained for housing association new-build schemes than for renewing local authority stock.

No wonder there are conflicting views. Put problem families or refugees in otherwise unlettable high-rise blocks on a short-term basis, says one camp; patch up the blocks and make the best of a bad job, runs another argument. What is true is that some councils have reversed decisions to condemn blocks - and the result has been a spectacular success. This confusion has at least shown the need for a new discussion.

Several of the NSTBI's founders are, or were, environmental campaigners, and it's the extension of their concerns from countryside to cities that is leading to a re-think about high-rise. Chris Church, initiative coordinator, stresses that they are not in favour of retaining all blocks, whatever the cost. Those that are structurally unsound, saturated with social problems, or located on badly planned estates, may be beyond any recovery programme.

But Church, who started in Greenpeace in the 1970s, insists that revitalising the blocks must be done in a wider social, environmental and economic context.

Socially, blocks often fail because they are used inappropriately, which means they are not suitable for families with young children. For a sense of community to flourish, they need residents who are happy to be there, not desperate to move out, and residents have to be given a democratic voice in running their estates.

Economically, tower blocks in or near city centres can help improve urban life if some of the accommodation is reserved for employees who keep vital services running - transport, health and welfare.

Environmentally, the initiative argues that tower blocks have the advantage of often leaving a smaller "ecological footprint" than conventional housing. They can be more energy-efficient, and sharing facilities and services - food co-ops, community cafes and growing vegetables - can reduce waste and save residents money.

Church and his colleagues have held seminars and produced reports detailing the past perils of high-rise; and have defined the essentials for well-run blocks, as a sort of good practice guide. They argue that, as the government predicts 4.4m new households will be formed by 2016, tower blocks will be ideal for small family units. They point out that the government should realise how relevant they are to Labour policies on social inclusion, local democracy and active citizenship.

The initiative makes a cogent, well-argued case. The partners have yet to bend a ministerial ear, and still have to persuade most local authorities to support their ideas. But at least they are beginning to spread the practical message that there are plenty of examples of successful tower block communities that can be copied.

Salford, in Greater Manchester, shows how it can be done - on the Pendleton estate, whose 30 towers once made it the highest density estate in Europe. Area housing manager John Oakley says Salford council has always invested heavily in maintenance, kept vandalism to a minimum with CCTV, formed a residents' management committee, and added many communal facilities, including landscaped gardens. It has also marketed the estate's good reputation when advertising vacant flats.

Star of the estate is the 16-storey Apple Tree Court. Betty Burton, a lynchpin of the community for 22 years, surveys her desirable domain from the cafe built - together with a grand conservatory - with almost £200,000 from the national lottery charities board. "It's always been a good block," she says, listing the improvements that the tenants' association has implemented. The best testament is the list of 14 prospective tenants waiting to be interviewed for a vacant flat.

There is, perhaps, a whiff of creating model communities in tower blocks in the minds of Chris Church and his colleagues. Some might sniff at it. It is easy to see why harassed housing managers and councillors, faced with "slums in the sky", see demolition as the solution to a well-meant bit of 1960s social policy gone sour. But projections show we may need high-rises for decades to come.

Setting up a national network of tower block residents' groups is one of the initiative's ideas. Even simpler is its suggestion for a national tower blocks day, to mark the joys of living aloft.

webTitle: Court case highlights inspection gaps in childcare system

fields.headline: Monitor hazards
fields.standfirst: Court case highlights inspection gaps in childcare system
fields.trailText: Court case highlights inspection gaps in childcare system
fields.body:
Disturbing questions have been raised about the monitoring of multiple fostering and adoption placements, after a high court judgment which followed a £6m-plus investigation into the work of a former "carer of the year".

Children in the care of Jeannette Roberts, who fostered or adopted more than 80 young people in 30 years, were judged to have been "clearly at risk". Yet Roberts had been widely feted for taking so many disturbed and disabled children and vulnerable adults into her home at the Old Convent, in Bicknacre, Essex.

According to Essex social services, the fact that Roberts's home was technically a private residence, not a children's home, made it very difficult to act on concerns about her childcare practices. Ann Goldsmith, acting head of children and family services, says: "If she had been running a children's home, it would have received annual inspections, with action plans and checks on staff. But with so many of the young people subject to adoption and residence orders, many with blood or relationship ties, we had little authority to inspect."

Under the Children Act 1989, the normal limit on numbers placed with a foster carer is three. Sometimes, for example if siblings are involved, an exemption order can raise the limit to five. This did happen on occasion with the Old Convent.

"With hindsight, if there had not been such a great shortage of foster carers, Jeannette Roberts would not have been our social workers' first choice," admits Goldsmith. The authority's former head of inspection, Leo Bishop, adds: "Reflecting on that time, with an establishment of that size, we would normally have expected it to be inspected. The problem was, it didn't meet the requirements for regulation."

The new Care Standards Act has tightened local authority control of small children's homes. And, by 2002, private fostering agencies - many of them involved in multiple placements across different authorities - will for the first time be subject to inspection. But none of this would materially have affected the status of the Old Convent.

After Roberts moved to Essex from the east end of London in 1985, a number of London authorities did express concerns about the children in her care. Neil Walker, then Tower Hamlets social services director, tried to investigate methods used at the Old Convent - in particular, the practice of cutting off residents from parents and carers.

The authority was worried enough to remove up to six chidren, Walker says. But the inquiries hit an impasse until a series of allegations surfaced years later, culminating in Operation Camberley - a joint police and social services investigation that has cost the county council alone £6m.

After the longest case in family court history, Mr Justice Hughes last Friday rejected claims that the Old Convent's regime was habitually violent. All criminal charges have been dropped.

Nevertheless, the woman once described as a saint by BBC Children in Need, and named carer and mother of the year, has been branded a liar and a risk to young people. The benefits she brought to those in her care, the judge said, had been "bought at the price of deceit, manipulation and considerable emotional damage to many dependent people".

What the judgment leaves unanswered is whether greater vigilance, supervision and support from social services could have led to a different outcome of the affair. This is one of a number of issues being addressed by a Department of Health "serious case review", chaired by Olive Stevenson, former professor of social work at Nottingham University, which is due to report later this year.

As Ian Grant, the lead social services manager throughout Operation Camberley, maintains: "There needs to be a single authority responsible for all aspects of individual premises where different legislation and different placements are involved. At present, it's just too easy for individual children's needs to fall through the gap."

fields.headline: Going it alone
fields.standfirst:
While officials try to disguise tensions between the EU and US over security, Europe is being urged to make unabashed autonomy the goal

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: While officials try to disguise tensions between the EU and US over security, Europe is being urged to make unabashed autonomy the goal
fields.body:
The official line after last week's Camp David meeting between George Bush and Tony Blair was that the "special relationship" remains in place and intact. And Nato. The president said the prime minister promised: "Nato is going to be the primary way to keep the peace in Europe". But how to square assurances to the Americans that European defence moves will not undermine Nato with French insistence that the European Union must have its own "autonomous" defence planning structure?

The Nice Treaty, signed by EU ministers on Monday, says that common foreign and security policy shall include "all questions relating to the security of the union". A long annex to the conclusions of the Nice summit last December, to which the treaty does not refer, said the aim was to give the EU "an autonomous capacity to take decisions and action in the security and defence field". But UK ministers quickly point to a succeeding passage in the annex which affirmed this "does not involve the establishment of a European army. The commitment of national resources by member states to such operations will be based on their sovereign decisions. Nato remains the basis of the collective defence of its members and will continue to play an important role in crisis management. The development of European security and defence policy will contribute to the vitality of a renewed transatlantic link".

So far so unclear. Debate about European security has been poverty-stricken, a confection of past cliches. Carefully-worded EU texts have sought to disguise tensions. Yet they are unable to hide the shifting of the tectonic plates beneath the Atlantic, symbolised above all by American plans for missile defence. A seismograph is applied in a pamphlet out tomorrow from the Centre for European Reform*.

It offers a calm and sober analysis of points which few people in this country have been prepared to face up to. It is all too easily assumed, the authors warn, that once the EU equips itself with credible means for military action, it will move into line with American views and strategies. "In fact the opposite may well be true".

The Kosovo conflict was humiliating, dominated by American forces and technology: it served as a catalyst for more European defence co operation. But the authors point to what they call a "more subterranean yet even more powerful motive for the new emphasis on European defence: the growing sense that America and Europe no longer automatically see eye-to-eye in security matters".

In the post-cold war world, threats no longer unite since they rarely affect the basic interests or even the existence of all Nato members at once. On so-called "rogue" states, the Europeans know there is no such thing as invulnerability anywhere on the old continent. So they would like to defuse threats by means of dialogue and material incentives - witness different approaches towards Iraq and Libya (where of course the point about incentives and self-interest works both ways). The Europeans are also more sensitive to Russia's concerns.

And while the US spends much more money on weapons the Europeans spend much more on "soft security" issues such as development aid. The Europeans are greater believers than the Americans in multilateral institutions and treaties.

All this might suggest we agree on a division of labour - "the Americans make war, we do the dishes" as one European analyst has put it. It is unlikely to wash with the Europeans, not least France. Nor the UK, which has been the driving force behind plans for joint EU military operations, while remaining particularly sensitive to Washington's concerns. The UK believes the Europeans must put their money where their mouth is and improve their military capabilities. The chart shows how defence spending varies between members of the EU.

The way forward, according to the pamphlet, is to set EU-wide targets, with all members committed to spend at least 2% of their GDP. Some 25% of defence budgets should be devoted to arms procurement and research and development, leading eventually to a special European defence budget.

Far from adopting a low-profile, over-anxious response to imperious noises from Washington, the EU should adopt a much more confident and higher profile approach on defence. The post of external relations commissioner, now held by Chris Patten, should be merged with that of the high representative for security policy held by Javier Solana. And Europe should indeed operate autonomously.

"Unless autonomy is the goal, the effort to create a European defence capability is bound to be half-hearted. Eu ropeans have for too long been accustomed to rely on the US to make up for their military deficiencies". The US could only benefit from a more capable and confident Europe in a new partnership.

Leadership needs to be provided by the UK, France, and Germany. The three countries represent a broad coalition of interests, though with different and, dare it be said, complementary perspectives. The UK's is more global and Atlanticist, France is more keen on an "autonomous" Europe, while Germany embodies the virtue of the EU as a civilian power. Whether they are prepared to take on such responsibility remains to be seen.

* Europe's military revolution by Gilles Andreani, Christoph Bertram and Charles Grant, www.cer.org.uk Richard Norton-Taylor is the Guardian's security affairs editor

webTitle: Switch to local suppliers urged to end crises

fields.headline: Switch to local suppliers urged to end crises
fields.standfirst:
Modern farming methods blamed for poor record
Guardian Unlimited Shopping
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Modern farming methods blamed for poor record.
fields.body:
Anxious neighbours of Willy Cleave, the Devon farmer whose cattle were found to have foot and mouth disease on Sunday, were shaking their heads in disbelief at his "bad luck."

But as the disaster deepened, it became harder to blame it all on bad luck. And there were calls from consumer groups for a radical rethink of our policy on food and farming.

Mr Cleave, with his big business complex of farms, livestock transporting, dealing and exporting was beginning to look more like a symbol of everything that disturbs people about today's agriculture. The deadly virus might have blown in on a breeze, but this was British farming policy reaping the whirlwind - and consumers were saying enough is enough.

"Ordinary people can see the enormity of this. There is a powerful and growing sense that things cannot go on like this," said Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University. "Why does British farming keep churning up crises like these? It isn't working."

Protests at modern farming methods were popping up everywhere, he added, "whether it's the animal welfare movement in the UK, the slow food movement in Italy or the sense in France that the balance is all wrong."

People are already finding ways round the industrialised system. Farmers' markets, where producers sell direct to the public have proved enormously popular.

Whenever there is a food crisis, independent specialist retailers see a surge in interest. Roger Kelsey, a butcher in Shenfield, Essex, a few miles from the Cheale abattoir where the outbreak of foot and mouth disease was first confirmed, says customers are showing more and more interest in what they buy and where it comes from.

"I know all about where my meat was reared, how it lived, and where it was slaughtered. You can't get that in the supermarkets."

Mr Kelsey uses a small abattoir near Chelmsford, even though Cheale's is just down the road, because it is a small operation with craft skills and it is closer to the farms where he gets his supplies. That means the animals do not have to travel so far, which is better for them but also because it minimises the stress, and means that the quality of the meat is better.

Sales of organic foods have grown faster than anyone could have anticipated and are up 40% year on year.

Mike Collins, of the Soil Association, said: "When you are dealing with organic food that hasn't been imported, the emphasis is very much on keeping it local, where the supply chain is at its most simple and people can have real confidence in what they are eating."

But a movement back to buying locally from specialists - often a pleasurable foraging activity for those with money to spare rather than shopping for essentials - will not on its own bring signficant change. Organic food still accounts for only 1% of the total UK food market, and much of it has to be imported.

Sustain, the alliance for better farming and food, says the radical redirection consumers want can be brought about by switching the huge subsidies we pay through government and the EU to help those who farm in a different way.

Policy director Vicki Herd says subsidies could be earned by those who, instead of supporting mass production, agree to farm in a way that protects the environment, provides healthy food and work locally.

Mr Lang has a longer shopping list to bring about real change. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has asked experts about a radical review. At national level Mr Lang thinks that means redefining the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) so that healthy food becomes its core role, and instead of promoting agriculture its focus shifts to rural affairs. That requires joined-up thinking on transport and town planning, so that people can walk comfortably to local shops and so that the poor are not excluded.

At a local level, the regional development agencies could help to rebuild a local supply and local consumption chain by marketing British produce to Britain instead of just abroad.

But people also need to think about how much they pay for their food. "You can't have cheap beans in a supermarket shed on the ring road and a vibrant, diverse local market," he says.

Professor Richard Lacey, of Leeds University, similarly has no time for Maff's cautious inquiries into possible links between the intensification of farming and the spate of food crises. (He was the eminent microbiologist who as far back as 1988 suggested that humans could catch CJD from eating meat carrying BSE. He was pilloried for his pains.)

"We can attribute foot and mouth directly to our industrialised agriculture and food system," he said. The immediate key to it in his mind is the centralised production. "If you have local food and local shops, things may go wrong but they don't spread like this." But for things to get better, we are going to have to change our attitude to food.

The whole post-war philosophy for farming has been "a preoccupation with an abundance of cheap food, and particularly cheap meat, and government has put in the mechanisms in the form of subsidies and regulation to produce it." If people want safer, nutritionally better, ethically better food, they will have to pay more. "If people ate less, but more expensive meat and replaced some of it with more cereals, rice, fruit and vegetables, overall the cost to them would probably remain about the same," he argues.

At a European level, the thorniest obstacle to change is reform of the common agriculture policy. But even here there seems to be a new mood, with the Germans and French, like us, forced into soul-searching by the recent farming crises.

Tim Lang is optimistic. "This is a historic moment. We are talking about a dramatic cultural change. This is about the quality, pace and scale of people's lives."

fields.bodyText: Anxious neighbours of Willy Cleave, the Devon farmer whose cattle were found to have foot and mouth disease on Sunday, were shaking their heads in disbelief at his "bad luck." But as the disaster deepened, it became harder to blame it all on bad luck. And there were calls from consumer groups for a radical rethink of our policy on food and farming. Mr Cleave, with his big business complex of farms, livestock transporting, dealing and exporting was beginning to look more like a symbol of everything that disturbs people about today's agriculture. The deadly virus might have blown in on a breeze, but this was British farming policy reaping the whirlwind - and consumers were saying enough is enough. "Ordinary people can see the enormity of this. There is a powerful and growing sense that things cannot go on like this," said Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University. "Why does British farming keep churning up crises like these? It isn't working." Protests at modern farming methods were popping up everywhere, he added, "whether it's the animal welfare movement in the UK, the slow food movement in Italy or the sense in France that the balance is all wrong." People are already finding ways round the industrialised system. Farmers' markets, where producers sell direct to the public have proved enormously popular. Whenever there is a food crisis, independent specialist retailers see a surge in interest. Roger Kelsey, a butcher in Shenfield, Essex, a few miles from the Cheale abattoir where the outbreak of foot and mouth disease was first confirmed, says customers are showing more and more interest in what they buy and where it comes from. "I know all about where my meat was reared, how it lived, and where it was slaughtered. You can't get that in the supermarkets." Mr Kelsey uses a small abattoir near Chelmsford, even though Cheale's is just down the road, because it is a small operation with craft skills and it is closer to the farms where he gets his supplies. That means the animals do not have to travel so far, which is better for them but also because it minimises the stress, and means that the quality of the meat is better. Sales of organic foods have grown faster than anyone could have anticipated and are up 40% year on year. Mike Collins, of the Soil Association, said: "When you are dealing with organic food that hasn't been imported, the emphasis is very much on keeping it local, where the supply chain is at its most simple and people can have real confidence in what they are eating." Organic food still accounts for only 1% of the total UK food market, and much of it has to be imported. Policy director Vicki Herd says subsidies could be earned by those who, instead of supporting mass production, agree to farm in a way that protects the environment, provides healthy food and work locally. Mr Lang has a longer shopping list to bring about real change. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has asked experts about a radical review. At national level Mr Lang thinks that means redefining the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) so that healthy food becomes its core role, and instead of promoting agriculture its focus shifts to rural affairs. fields.headline: Bugs 'found in 16% of supermarket chicken'
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Shopping
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Food poisoning bugs are rife in chickens, with almost one in six bought from supermarkets a potential food risk, according to a report from the Consumers' Association.
fields.body:
Food poisoning bugs are rife in chickens, with almost one in six bought from supermarkets a potential food risk, according to a report from the Consumers' Association.

A survey published today in Which? magazine says that tests on more than 300 fresh raw chickens and chicken pieces found 16% containing unwelcome bacteria, including salmonella. The tests used are not the most sensitive and may well underestimate the scale of the problem.

Which? went undercover to a slaughterhouse to investigate the causes, and found live chickens in crates stacked on top of each other.

"These crates were made of plastic mesh with spaces large enough for faeces to drop through on to the birds below and spread bacteria. After being killed the birds were dunked in a scalding tank to make their feathers easier to remove. The water was changed only once a day. Many thousands of dead chickens went through it. Brown scum floated on the top - the water was cool enough for salmonella and campylobacter [the commonest form of food poisoning bacteria] to live in."

The magazine said that in the area where birds were cut into pieces, staff were handling chickens without cleaning their gloves. "Our source told us he had seen a member of staff return to his job still wearing an apron which had trailed in a urinal when he visited the lavatory. "Chickens left over after the firm had sent out the day's orders were rewrapped the next day with a new sell-by date," a practice which a Meat Hygiene Service source said he feared went on at other slaughterhouses. "Chickens aren't born with salmonella or campylobacter, they catch it," the association said. "This can happen at any stage in the food chain. On the farm infection can spread if chickens are confined in small spaces."

In the Which? tests, chicken from Tesco was found to be contaminated the least, in 6% of cases. Sainsbury's, at 22%, and Safeway, at 21%, were the worst.

webTitle: Hidden costs behind the checkout prices

fields.headline: Hidden costs behind the checkout prices
fields.standfirst: Cheaper food from intensive farming brings other problems
fields.trailText: Cheaper food from intensive farming brings other problems.Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.body:
In 1960 almost one third of the average household budget was spent on food. Today the figure is less than one fifth.

When the competition commission investigated whether the big supermarkets were fixing prices to British consumers, it found that there had been a decline in the real price of food of over 9% between 1989 and 1998.

Farmers feel aggrieved that they get so little for what they produce. Michael Hart, a farmer in Cornwall who leads the Small and Family Farm Alliance, is in no doubt that prices should be higher. "There's very little we are producing in this country that we are selling above the price of production," he said.

His income last year was £1,800 from 120 acres. He switched from dairy farming to beef and sheep 12 months ago to allow more time for driving a lorry at £4.50 an hour.

He says people have to choose between mass-produced, intensively farmed food or high quality produce which comes with animal welfare attached, at prices which might well be out of reach of the poor.

Although food appears cheap at the checkout, there are huge hidden costs, according to Jules Pretty, an agriculture economist at the University of Essex. "We pay three times over - once at the till, then again through tax for EU subsidies andthen again through hidden subsidies," he said.

About half of EU expenditure goes on farm support: about £23bn is spent across Europe each year, with about £3bn a year of subsidies being paid to farmers in the UK.

Professor Pretty has examined the costs of intensive farming which consumers and taxpayers bear indirectly. They include the costs of cleaning up after disasters created by industrialised farming - £607m for BSE alone.

In 1996 water companies spent £120m on taking pesticides from farming out of water, a bill which was passed on to water customers. Prof Pretty's conservative estimates of these hidden costs, for damage to soil structure, pollution and other environmental damage, was £2.34bn.

The UK also has some of the highest figures for heart disease and cancer in the western world, diseases which have many causes but have been strongly linked to a poor quality diet.

webTitle: Tories involve US envoy in funds plea

fields.headline: Tories involve US envoy in funds plea
fields.standfirst:
Party claims £10,000 donations will give access to ambassadors
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservative party was embroiled in a new cash row last night after it emerged that it was using the outgoing US ambassador, Philip Lader, in its fundraising literature.
fields.body:
The Conservative party was embroiled in a new cash row last night after it emerged that it was using the outgoing US ambassador, Philip Lader, in its fundraising literature.

A circular claims that donations of £10,000 to the Tory party will give donors access to small and exclusive dinners, some attended by the US and Italian ambassadors.

It is understood the US embassy will be sending a letter of clarification to the Conservative party.

The Tory fundraising circular, recently sent out by the Conservative treasurer, Lord Ashcroft, claims anyone who gives more than £10,000 to the party will be made a member of the Renaissance Forum, from which it will be possible to make "your personal contribution at the highest level".

The circular claims that by joining the Renaissance Forum, "you will be directly supporting the Conservative party". It adds: "You will also meet face to face prominent decision makers, opinion formers, leading members of the Conservative front bench and senior party figures at small and exclusive dinners." One of the recent Renaissance Forum events cited in the brochure is a dinner with the US ambassador. It also claims that a recent event saw Michael Portillo, Sir Clive Thompson and the Italian ambassador discussing the single currency.

A spokesman for the US embassy said last night: "It is totally wrong to suggest that the US ambassador would support partisan political events. He would not attend a fundraising event, nor would he like it to be portrayed that he has attended one."

The ambassador's office suggested that in February last year he had been asked to attend an event described to him as Lord Feldman's Conservative Forum.

He had not been aware that it was connected with Conservative fundraising or that he was being cited as an example of the benefits of joining the forum.

Mr Lader, a Democrat, retires from his post today, when he will return to the US.

The Conservative literature claims "the forum is the most prestigious of our donor clubs".

It adds: "Your membership will reserve your place at a series of private political lunches, dinners, receptions and social gatherings throughout the year".

The brochure has been sent out by the treasurer's department in a bid to raise as much as £15m ahead of the general election. The letter claims the Labour party will be fighting the campaign with as much as £40m.

A Conservative party spokesman said: "I am sure that we would not have invited anyone to attend anything under false pretences."

Conservative sources also insisted that the dinners were not themselves fundraising events, but events to which donors were invited to attend. He went on: "There are about four of these events a year, and they are addressed either by a Conservative politician, or a person of distinction."

Speakers at recent events included the former chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, John Witherow, editor of the Sunday Times, and Charles Moore, editor of the Daily Telegraph. Frank Field, the former Labour welfare minister, had spoken at one dinner.

Apart from the Renaissance Forum, the Conservatives have set up a Front Bench Club available to anyone who provides more than £5,000.

The majority of these functions are held in the Houses of Parliament, so numbers are often restricted to 20 people.

Anyone providing more than £1,000 is allowed to attend Team 1000. As a result they will be invited to regular private gatherings to meet shadow ministers, MPs and officials from Conservative Central Office.

The Labour party arranges similar exclusive access to ministers, but not on quite the same systematic basis.

fields.headline: No 1828 Harrison Ford
fields.trailText: Ah, the professionally craggy Star Wars icon and occasional Indiana Jones, 59 and counting. Oh yes.
fields.body:
Ah, the professionally craggy Star Wars icon and occasional Indiana Jones, 59 and counting. Oh yes.

Famously more enthusiastic about doing DIY at his ranch in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, than hanging out at Hollywood soirees. Indeed.

Looks good for his age, doesn't he? Certainly does. Still, you might have a certain colour to your cheeks if you were getting what he's getting.

Pardon? It's been announced that the grizzled pin-up is to earn $25m for 20 days' work on the cold war drama K19: The Widowmaker. It's the kind of payday not seen since a chronically overweight Marlon Brando received $3m for a four-day shoot on Superman.

Yeah, but he had all those puddings to pay for. How could Harrison possibly need that kind of cash? Have you seen the price of MDF at the Jackson Hole Homebase lately? Then there's his expensive taste in leisure activities.

Meaning? Well, late last year he was pictured sipping vintage champagne in an exclusive Manhattan nighclub with actress Lara Flynn Boyle (more often seen on the arm of Jack Nicholson).

Champagne! Nightclubs! Lara Flynn Boyle! The old devil! Er, quite. Although that might not have been the phrase his wife, the screenwriter Melissa Mathison, used when she saw the photos in a US tabloid. The pair separated soon after. Harrison, however, is keen to reconcile and therefore less than eager to be away from Wyoming for long periods of time.

Ahh. Isn't that sweet? It is. It's also presumably the reason why he wants $40m for turning out in the forthcoming Indiana Jones and the Lost Continent.

I don't blame him. That kind of thing can be very sensitive for a man of his age. I'd want $40m to star in a movie wearing a nappy. No, I said Lost . . . oh, never mind.

Do say: No more Jedi nights for you, Harrison.

Don't say: Personally, I always preferred Chewbacca.

fields.headline: All your base . . .
fields.standfirst:
If these words mean nothing to you, you are hopelessly out of touch with the latest internet craze. Rich Johnston reveals all about the Zero Wing phenomenon

More net news
fields.trailText: If these words mean nothing to you, you are hopelessly out of touch with the latest internet craze. Rich Johnston reveals all about the Zero Wing phenomenon.
fields.body:
What you are reading is a dead story. Hundreds of thousands of designer hours went into it, gigabytes of computer memory and bandwidth were taken over transmitting it and for two weekends, the phrase "All your base are belong to us" became one of the most requested on internet search engines across the world. Now, even this article mentioning it is passe.

More than two weeks ago, I received an amusing email. And then received it again, 17 times. Every message board I went to, every forum I visited, has a discussion thread named after it. Remarkably, it didn't involve sexual thrills, jokes about pets or scenes of gratuitous violence. It was the introduction to a 10-year-old computer game called Zero Wing for the Sega Genesis console. This consisted of a series of Japanese cartoon-style stills telling a story. The dialogue below the images had been very badly translated from the original Japanese. Accompanying scenes of a battle in outer space, they read:

In A.D. 2101

War was beginning.

Captain: What happen?

Operator: Somebody set up us the bomb.

Operator: We get signal.

Captain: What!

Operator: Main screen turn on.

Captain: It's you!!

Cats: How are you gentlemen!!

Cats: All your base are belong to us.

Cats: You are on the way to destruction.

Captain: What you say!!

Cats: You have no chance to survive make your time.

Cats: Ha ha ha ha ha!

Cats: Take off every "zig".

Captain: You know what you doing.

Captain: Move "zig".

Captain: For great justice.

A day or so later, the pictures began to follow. These were photographs taken and altered by computer designers, with the most popular phrase - "All your base are belong to us" - inserted where appropriate. Street signs, restaurant awnings, cinema fronts, advertising, cartoons, T-shirts, tattoos, golf balls inserted into turtles, all bearing this new phrase. What was remarkable was the time and effort that must have been spent on making the words fit perfectly into the background, finding the right font, matching perspective and accounting for folds in the material that the message appeared on.

This craze started around the middle of last year, sent around by a close group of technical experts. An in-joke to greet friends at the bar, an email signature, a punchline to a shared gag. And then it jumped, from speech and text to something visual.

An early example is a photo of the alien puppet Alf from the US sitcom of the same name, speaking on the phone with a speech bubble containing the phrase. The Somethingawful.com forum picked this up and ran with it, continuing the pattern of placing the speech bubble on to existing photos. From December through to January, the phrase infected other message boards, with Tribalwar.com taking the strain. It was still mostly a techie/gamers-only craze, and new executions were more likely to have the phrase embedded in the photo rather than just pasted on in a speech bubble. Often a labour-intensive job, this was a chance to show off, to be part of the gang, and probably lost each individual's employer hours of gainful employ. Variations included Uncle Sam pointing at the screen, road painters daubing the phrase onto the street behind them, airplanes branded with the phrase, Bart Simpson writing it a hundred times on a blackboard and the cover of Time magazine with a shot of President Bush.

In February it jumped again, hitting the mainstream. The Popbitch.com message board was essential in introducing the British to this phenomenon. And the various executions grew, multiplied and evolved. From the Popstars variation, All Your Base Are Belong To Darius, to the kitchen variety, All Your Turkey Basters Are Belong To Us, this time it hit the big time, outstripping the Hamster Dance, The Singing Hat and Am I Hot Or Not?

Next came the T-shirts. The best were arguably from http://www.cafepress.com/dreldarion, which offered a nice line in mugs and mouse mats as well. A previously recorded dance track, Invasion of the Gabber Robots by Laziest Men on Mars, became a hugely popular download from Napster due to the repetitive strain "All your base are belong to us". We had been well and truly invaded.

And then it died. Within a week of its new- found popularity, Guardian writer Charlie Brooker had added a wonderful parody to hishttp://www.tvgohome.com site, featuring the listing for I Love All Your Base Are Belong to Us. Following this was a small piece criticising media types who try to parade the latest craze on their T-shirt. Message boards began to deride any newcomer posting doctored photos. New email viral messages were touted as "The funniest thing since All Your Base". All it needs now is a Daily Mail feature to be truly killed off. This very article may well do the job.

A few years ago, a craze could last for years before being picked up by the mainstream, giving it at least six months of credibility. Having a Frankie Says T-shirt wouldn't be derided for at least a year. Even pashminas lasted a good nine months. Now it takes two weeks. Trends can be gone before most people ever knew they were even there.

Still, there are brands that would have killed for this kind of exposure. If Sega had attached its name to the original animation (for a long time many were unaware of where it came from), new life may have been breathed into its now cancelled Sega Dreamcast console. If Nike had placed their swoosh upon it and launched an All Your Base Are Belong To Us range, they'd have cleaned up. fields.headline: At this price?  NCipher
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Investors in NCipher, the Cambridge-based internet security products company, know what it is like to ride the e-commerce rollercoaster.
fields.body:
Investors in NCipher, the Cambridge-based internet security products company, know what it is like to ride the e-commerce rollercoaster.

The firm, which reached a high of 425p shortly after making its stock market debut last October, yesterday saw its shares plummet 48.03% to a record low of 145p after warning its growth prospects for 2001 had "softened" on the back of a slowdown in the US economy.

The cautious statement from nCipher came as the group announced better than expected results for the year to the end of December.

The firm reported a pre-tax loss of £1.8m, within analysts' expectations, compared to £892,000 in 1999, due to expansion and development of sales and marketing and product development.

Revenues for the year were £13.5m, a rise of 188% on the previous year and nCipher still has £108m in the bank for future acquisitions.

"It is a great market to be in. Things are getting cheaper," said Alex van Someren, chief executive officer.

Analysts said everything had been going well until the company admitted the slowdown in the US would reduce its rate of continued growth and predicted a slightly more cautious date of the end of 2002 for reaching profitability. "We still have a reasonable degree of optimism about the longer term. The need for security doesn't diminish just because of economic conditions," Mr van Someren said.

He emphasised that the business was diverse, with offices all over the world. Despite shrinking US revenues it said it would be insulated from a downturn.

The company does have a useful amount of cash in the bank and in the long term investors could see good products coming to market, backed by effective sales and marketing. But the short term looks bleak and risky.

Investors who still have shares in nCipher should hold. Anyone else would be advised to avoid the company for the moment.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: City diary
fields.body:
 Investor relations is a trying and tiring business, and so it comes as no surprise to have to relate the following tale from last week's Ofex 2001 show held in London. An investment professional was surveying the various stands run by companies that have floated on Ofex - the stock exchange regulated with only the lightest of touch - when he was approached by a marketing person from the stand of ruby miners Agricola Resources. Despite being slightly disconcerted by the woman's gentle swaying, the investor started to explain what he did - whereupon she told him to "fuck off", and loudly complained that "all this fucking investor bullshit is giving me a headache". She then marched off in the opposite direction before lurching back to her stand. But this story has a happy ending. When the investor passed the Agricola stand a couple few hours later, the woman was fast asleep at the back of the stand, with the rest of the company's staff clustered around in front to obscure this charming view.

 If it were a crime to be too modest, then Goldman Sachs would be guilty. One of the investment bank's suppliers (who can't be named for fear of retribution) asked if it could use Goldman's name in some minor publicity. No, came the reply from the retiring bankers, and you can't even make an unnamed reference to us as the City's leading investment bank. Why? the supplier asked. "Because everyone will know it's us," was the typically non-arrogant reply. Now that Goldmans has been floated, it's time this coyness stopped.

 Last week (you may recall) there was the sorry tale of pensions company NPI and its squirrel mascot suit, which had become too smelly (for unfortunate reasons) and had to be replaced. I know people think we make these things up, but here's proof - a picture of "Tufty", the fragrant new NPI squirrel, taking a well-earned break from nut hunting by reading a copy of the Guardian.

 The Guardian's business pages are officially squirrel-friendly. Unlike the Financial Times, which on Saturday carried a recipe for cooked squirrel (by Robin Lane Fox, father of Martha LF - another good reason not to like the Lane Fox family). Take three squirrels, preferably gray, cut off their tails and - sorry, there's no place for recipes in diaries.

 Shame on those of you who suggested that there was something noteworthy in the fact that Brian Buchan, the new head of condom makers Durex, had formerly been in charge of the Always brand of sanitary pads. I am tempted to ask Mr Buchan if he enjoys working in this area - but another time, perhaps.

 With uncanny and seer-like timing, the OECD's latest economic survey of Turkey comes thudding onto the doormat. It's fascinating stuff, with the OECD praising the "pro-active" exchange rate controls imposed last year by the IMF. So useful did the controls prove they were scrapped just last week as the country's currency sank like, er, a lead turkey. But the OECD was right that an appreciation of the lira "need not be an over-riding concern" - particularly not after its 30% slump.

fields.headline: Gallaher still acquisitive
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: After announcing flat profits due to last year's overseas expansion, tobacco manufacturer Gallaher yesterday insisted it was interested in buying Austria Tabak.
fields.body:
After announcing flat profits due to last year's overseas expansion, tobacco manufacturer Gallaher yesterday insisted it was interested in buying Austria Tabak.

Chief executive Nigel Northridge said the purchase of Russia's Liggett-Ducat had produced £5m of profit in five months and he was upbeat about the prospect of further foreign expansion.

At least five other companies have expressed an interest in Austria Tabak, including Imperial, Germany's Reemtsma, BAT, Altadis and RJ Reynolds.

On the home front, tobacco consumption remained flat at 84bn sticks with 30% of those consumed being non-duty paid - either legally or smuggled in.

Last night Gallaher's share price was up 2p at 448p, edging closer to its 461.5p year-high and comfortably ahead of the 203p low.

fields.headline: Farm crisis hits the markets
fields.standfirst:
Market forces
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The outbreak of foot and mouth disease claimed more victims yesterday with food producers, racecourse owners and leisure groups all left helpless as share prices withered before their eyes.
fields.body:
The outbreak of foot and mouth disease claimed more victims yesterday with food producers, racecourse owners and leisure groups all left helpless as share prices withered before their eyes.

Investors were already shunning many of the stocks before the Jockey Club's announcement that all horseracing in Britain would be suspended for one week starting today.

Racecourse owner Arena Leisure lost 3.6% at 92.5p, bookmaker Stanley Leisure slipped 3.5p to 211.5p and the Hilton Group , which owns the Ladbrokes betting shops, suffered a 7.25p fall to end the day at 216p.

Food manufacturers fared little better. But while animal feed producer Cranswick dropped 6% to 335p, Northern Foods gave the market some reasons to smile as assurances that supplies of meat can be maintained lifted its shares 2p to 135.5p.

The epidemic did not infect the rest of the FTSE 100 which ended yesterday's session up 24.5 points at 5,941.2, thanks largely to a decent performance from the telecoms and oil sectors. But it was an erratic day, especially when the Nasdaq lost 2% after figures showed US consumer confidence had sunk in February to its lowest level for more than four and a half years.

For the second day running banks were the achilles heel, accounting for 11 points of the FTSE fall. As the City fully digested its disappointing results, HSBC fell a further 4% to a two-month low of 917p, while Royal Bank of Scotland dropped 18p at £15.10 and Barclays shed 11p to close at £21.25.

Among companies reporting yesterday, United Business Media put on 19p to 748.5p after announcing an 11% rise in 2000 profits, insurer CGNU was up 33p on the back of decent profits, while Legal & General's 15% rise in annual profits was reflected in a 2.5p rise in the share price which ended at 173p.

There was also some interest in Miller Fisher , the insurance services group which admitted last week that it was in takeover talks with a potential buyer. Its shares ended the session up 0.25p at 22p on the back of gossip that the board of Miller Fisher has agreed a 35p-a-share offer.

Microchip designer Arc International fell almost 8%, or 14p, to 162.5p, dragged down by fears of a gloomy set of results being issued today.

Elsewhere, Brandes Invest ment Partners became the largest shareholder in Marks & Spencer with news that its stake is now 9.4%. The retailer's shares lost 6.75p to close at 238.25p.

The mysterious case of online bank Egg's rising share price was finally solved. On Friday and again on Monday, Egg shares moved against the downward trend in the banking sector, with most traders attributing the strength to in vestors switching out of traditional mortgage banks, which had been unsettled by the prospect of home loan price war. A rather less complex explanation is behind the rise - analysts are starting to turn positive on the company.

Deutsche Bank looks to be just the first. Yesterday the broker, one of the biggest bears of Egg since its flotation last June, lifted its rating on the company to "market perform" and said a fair value for its shares was 150p.

According to Deutsche, the Egg credit card is here to stay and will be not only a key customer acquisition vehicle, but also the key driver to profitability.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is lowering its forecasts and price target on Marconi , which dropped 13p to 498.5p, citing the difficult North American market.

A profits warning from Brewin Dolphin Securities , which saw the company's shares lose more than 6% at 152p, sent a shiver through the small brokerage industry

In other indices, the FTSE 250 Midcap index closed up 39.9 points at 6,680.5, while the FTSE Techmark was 10.91 points stronger at 2,353.66.

webTitle: Bitter weather brings paralysis to the north

fields.headline: Bitter weather brings paralysis to the north
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Atrocious weather conditions brought chaos to the north of Britain and Northern Ireland yesterday as more than 200,000 people were left without electricity and scores of passengers were stranded on rail and road routes.
fields.body:
Atrocious weather conditions brought chaos to the north of Britain and Northern Ireland yesterday as more than 200,000 people were left without electricity and scores of passengers were stranded on rail and road routes.

Heavy snowfall, high winds and plummeting temperatures in Scotland, Northern Ireland and northern regions of England meant many motorists were forced to spend the night in their cars, and railway passengers were unable to get to their destinations.

The east and west coast rail routes between Scotland and England were closed as Virgin trains reported snow drifts as "as high as the platforms" in some areas.

Flights were cancelled and police across the country warned against travel.

Overnight, winds gusting up to 70mph brought down power cables and electricity company engineers were forced to fight against appalling weather conditions as they attempted to restore power to many thousands of people.

The situation was particularly acute in Scotland, where ScottishPower had 600 engineers attempting to restore electricity to homes in Fife, East Lothian, the Borders and Berwickshire. "The problem remains trying to get to where the faults are, although we now have seven helicopters helping out," said a spokeswoman.

On the roads, drivers faced treacherous conditions as the M74, the main west coast route between Scotland and England, became blocked in places.

Some motorists remained trapped in their cars throughout yesterday as efforts to reach vehicles in parts of Aberdeenshire were hampered by drifting snow.

Seventy passengers were stranded on a train for more than 16 hours after leaving London on an overnight service to Scotland. The ScotRail sleeper service to Glasgow and Edinburgh became stuck behind a broken down freight train north of Lockerbie at 6am.

The weather conditions meant the train could not be towed north, and with blockages on the M77, many of the passengers spent last night in a Carlisle hotel.

A spokesman for GNER said all services were stopping at Newcastle. A spokesman for Virgin said all its cross-border services were cancelled.

Six mountain rescue teams continued their search for Norah Elwell-Sutton, 31, a teacher from Glasgow, who went missing near Loch Lomond on Sunday. Near Fort William, another search was under way for two missing climbers.

In Northern Ireland, snowdrifts, fallen trees and power lines were blocking many rural roads. Northern Ireland Electricity was trying to cope with 20,000 calls at a time. Police advised motorists not to travel unless absolutely necessary. Buses and trains were delayed.

Belfast International and City airports remained open, but some flights were cancelled and many others delayed. Dozens of schools were shut because of power failure. • Kylie Minogue delayed the opening night of her first tour in nine years because of weather and transport problems. The singer was to begin the 17-date tour in Dublin, but will now appear first in Glasgow at the SECC on Saturday.

fields.headline: Downside
fields.standfirst: Investors need patience
fields.trailText: It may not be the crash in financial markets that buries investors but delay in the recovery.
fields.body:
It may not be the crash in financial markets that buries investors but delay in the recovery.

Just as markets are frequently overbought and prices pushed to unrealistically high levels, so they can also tumble well below what might be regarded as fair value as greed gives way to panic.

The classic example is the Wall Street crash of 1929. Though the market staged an initial rally it went into a second downturn. It had not recovered when the US entered the second world war.

The impact of the 1929 crash was exacerbated by the US government's reaction which did much to turn the drama into a crisis. In 1987 policymakers were not to be caught out and acted promptly and effectively.

Yet in the UK it took a year before the equities market dragged itself out of the post-Black Monday doldrums and another year before it recovered to previous levels.

One concern about the current state of equity markets is that, having gone through a "new economy" boom (which is startlingly reminiscent of the pre-crash hype in 1929), markets may be slow to shrug off over-indulgence in the dot.com sector. That, especially in the US, could contribute significantly to the uncertainty which is hanging over Wall Street.

Indeed, there is a risk one will feed on the other as economic worries add to market uncertainty and vice-versa. That might leave valuations artificially depressed but, to borrow a phrase attributed to John Maynard Keynes: "Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent." Mr Greenspan, take note.
fields.bodyText: It may not be the crash in financial markets that buries investors but delay in the recovery. Just as markets are frequently overbought and prices pushed to unrealistically high levels, so they can also tumble well below what might be regarded as fair value as greed gives way to panic. The classic example is the Wall Street crash of 1929. Though the market staged an initial rally it went into a second downturn. It had not recovered when the US entered the second world war. The impact of the 1929 crash was exacerbated by the US government's reaction which did much to turn the drama into a crisis. In 1987 policymakers were not to be caught out and acted promptly and effectively. Yet in the UK it took a year before the equities market dragged itself out of the post-Black Monday doldrums and another year before it recovered to previous levels. One concern about the current state of equity markets is that, having gone through a "new economy" boom (which is startlingly reminiscent of the pre-crash hype in 1929), markets may be slow to shrug off over-indulgence in the dot.com sector. That, especially in the US, could contribute significantly to the uncertainty which is hanging over Wall Street. Indeed, there is a risk one will feed on the other as economic worries add to market uncertainty and vice-versa. That might leave valuations artificially depressed but, to borrow a phrase attributed to John Maynard Keynes: "Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent." Mr Greenspan, take note.

webTitle: When fangs are bared it's no fairy tale for the Fed

fields.headline: When fangs are bared it's no fairy tale for the Fed
fields.standfirst: The G7 predicts a V-shaped recovery. Wall Street's letter of the lore is different
fields.trailText: The G7 predicts a V-shaped recovery. Wall Street's letter of the lore is different.
fields.body:
Despite their tough image, the financial markets are suckers for a good story. The story they have enjoyed most in recent years is the one told by uncle Alan Greenspan about the perfect Goldilocks situation in the US - not too hot and not too cold. So you can rest assured that the dealers on Wall Street will be sitting comfortably when Al starts his latest tale before Congress later today.

What they want to hear from the Federal Reserve chairman is that the story of the US economy has a happy ending coming soon. At the moment the fairy tale of how the American economy could go on growing and growing as if by magic has turned dark and gloomy: not enough about Goldilocks, too much about the bears.

Like children gathered round the teacher, the markets have total faith in Mr Greenspan. Forget the fact that the titans of American business have been delivering profits warnings by the score. Forget the fact that the air is thick with dot.coms going to the wall. Forget the fact that the outlook for the global economy has darkened since Mr G gave the first half of his biannual testimony on monetary policy just weeks ago. None of this matters, because even if there are problems the Fed will ensure they are short-lived.

Despite figures out last week showing an unwelcome surge in inflation, the markets are expecting Mr Greenspan to signal nothing less than another half-point cut in interest rates when the US Federal Reserve stages its next meeting on March 20, taking the cumulative easing of monetary policy since since the beginning of January to an aggressive 1.5 percentage points.

So gloomy have the markets become that some analysts are anticipating a surprise, interim move. "The Fed chairman might well see a need to act immediately if equities markets continue to struggle in the weeks ahead," said Marc Wanshel of JP Morgan in New York.

This may be one of those times when markets would do well to remember DH Lawrence's dictum, however - never trust the artist, trust the tale.

Officially, policymakers continue to express "cautious optimism" about the outlook for global growth. When finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven industrialised countries - the US, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - got together 10 days ago for their first summit of the year in Palermo, Sicily, there was a lengthy debate about the shape of the US recovery. Would it be V, U, L or W-shaped? The G7 settled for the most optimistic scenario, predicting that it would be a V-shaped recovery. In other words, after a sharp slowdown in growth in the first half of the year, US growth would rebound smartly in the second.

But the failure of Wall Street to respond to the full percentage point off rates announced by the Fed in January, coupled with the torpor of Japan's Nikkei Dow, could be rather more meaningful than the attempts by politicians and central bankers to sound notes of cosy reassurance. Analysts in New York may be trying to convince investors that America is simply experiencing a short V-shaped recession, but the main stock market indices hardly suggest an imminent recovery. Indeed, the 18% drop in the Nasdaq since the end of January, the 9% fall in the Wiltshire 5000 over the same period and a 4.3% drop in the value of the Nikkei point to an entirely different conclusion.

Cruising level

Quite simply, the markets were wrong a year ago to assume that America had rewritten the laws of economics and could grow at 5% indefinitely, they were wrong six months ago to assume that the economy would descend to cruising level before taking off again, they were wrong three months ago to assume that the economy would have a soft landing and they are wrong now to assume that the recession nobody forecast 12 months ago will be short and sweet.

Why could that be? The simple answer is that the American economy is at the end of a classic business cycle in which the length of the boom produced such heady optimism that businesses over-invested and over-expanded, building up productive capacity that would have struggled to be profitable even when the economy was growing by 5% a year. Now it is clear that over-optimistic forecasts for profits and earnings are not going to be met, firms are scrapping plant, scaling back investment and laying off staff to try to repair their balance sheets.

Some analysts, such as Charles Dumas at Lombard Street Research, believe that interest rate cuts may delay the adjustment but that ultimately there has to be a day of reckoning. They believe that cutting interest rates is the equivalent of giving a junkie a fix. Having initially responded enthusiastically to rate cuts in January, the markets are now crying out for another shot of Dr Greenspan's medicine. Painful though it will be, a period of cold turkey for the US is unavoidable.

Other analysts believe that rate cuts could do the trick, however - provided they are made quickly enough.

Graham Turner of GFC Economics said: "Mr Greenspan showed in 1991 that he is prepared to cut real [inflation adjusted] interest rates toward zero if the conditions merit such a move. The current backdrop suggests real rates may have to fall to similar levels.

"Unless the Fed Funds rate is lowered to around 3% by the summer, the downturn in the economy could prove to be more protracted than is necessary."

On top of declining corporate earnings and the sharp fall in consumer confidence announced yesterday, dealers are also now fretting about the possibility of another emerging-markets crisis triggered by events in Turkey, and by the continued failure of the world's second-biggest economy, Japan, to emerge from its 10-year-period of slow growth.

What the global economy needs to avoid is a repeat of the financial crises of three years ago. Julian Jessop, economist at Standard Chartered, says: "Contagion is the fear in emerging markets, ever since the crises of 1997 and 1998. With events then still fresh in the memory, the floating of the Turkish lira has added to existing worries around the globe."

Mr Jessop says many countries share the same problems as Turkey. The Czech Republic, Poland, Argentina and Brazil, for example, all have high levels of short-term debt. Argentina also has a similar currency regime, about which the markets have long had doubts. A speculative attack on any of these countries cannot be ruled out.

In late 1998, Mr Greenspan was ahead of the game.

He ensured that the story did not turn into Nightmare on Wall Street. This time he is behind the game, struggling to catch up. Even the master storyteller has no idea what is on the last page of the book this time.
