fields.headline: Russia pressured on Grozny bodies
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: The Council of Europe human rights commissioner, Alvaro Gil-Robles, flew to Chechnya yesterday and into a storm raised by the discovery at the weekend of corpses dumped near Russia's main garrison.
fields.body:
The Council of Europe human rights commissioner, Alvaro Gil-Robles, flew to Chechnya yesterday and into a storm raised by the discovery at the weekend of corpses dumped near Russia's main garrison.

The Russian authorities are trying to control the investigation, but independent watchdogs want the council to send forensic experts to help discover what happened to the Chechens whose bodies were found in the ruins of a deserted settlement of summer homes on the fringes of Grozny.

Russian officials said 16 bodies had been found at the Health holiday village, half a mile from the Khankala base, Russia's biggest in Chechnya. Independent Russian experts said 27 bodies had been found, some grotesquely disfigured.

Human Rights Watch said as many as 200 bodies could have been dumped in the settlement, and wrote to President Vladimir Putin demanding a full and transparent inquiry.

Allegations by the Russian investigative journalist Anna Politkovskaya of torture and human rights abuses by Moscow's forces in Chechnya were published in the Guardian yesterday.

The Russian army has dismissed her claims as "baseless", but yesterday Vladimir Kalamanov, the Russian presidential representative for human rights in Chechnya, said he had ordered an inquiry.

Human Rights Watch said the bodies found at the weekend had knife and gunshot wounds and broken limbs and many had been severely mutilated. Many were boobytrapped.

It named three Chechen males, aged 15, 17 and 18, who were detained by the Russians last June, taken to Khankala and not heard from since.

"We have established a clear pattern of cases when people 'disappear' in the custody of Russian troops," the executive director of its Europe and Central Asia division, Holly Cartner, said.

Russian officials have issued contradictory statements. First they said the bodies were of Chechen fighters killed in the battle for Grozny a year ago, then that they were the victims of feuding between rival Chechen gangs.

webTitle: Dreams lie buried in a land of hate

fields.headline: Dreams lie buried in a land of hate
fields.standfirst:
I wonder what Mugabe would say if my Uncle Guy was still alive
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: I wonder what Mugabe would say if my Uncle Guy was still alive
fields.body:
Watching each new, hate-filled excess of Robert Mugabe's directed against the whites who he now condemns as the source of Zimbabwe's problems, I wonder how he would have dealt with my Uncle Guy if he had still been living there today. For just six years ago, when Guy Clutton Brock died, Mugabe came to his memorial service in Britain to collect his ashes and take them to be scattered in Zimbabwe at Hero's Acre - the first time a white man had been buried there.

My uncle was an improbable hero for the black liberation government in a country which, during his time there - he arrived in 1949 and was removed by the white regime in 1971 - knew only oppression by Southern Rhodesia's white leaders. He was a quintessential blue-blooded Englishman with his blond, rangy good looks, a double-barrelled name and a Magdalene College education. He had no idea what to expect when he decided to take his agricultural skills to Africa. He simply felt it was "the right place to be". He and his wife Molly went to St Faith's Mission in Rusape, although he had no religious intentions for his work. But he was shocked by the poverty and sickness he found among the community of 700 blacks attempting to farm smallholdings eroded by years of over-use. It was clear to him that they needed help to achieve rights and equality with the whites. He started by refusing to be the boss man. Instead, in what sounds a quaint and quixotic gesture these days, he formed the African-European cooperative, with an African manager, herdsman and tractor driver, while the bursar and stockmen were Europeans.

The crops flourished as farming methods improved, word spread that "CB" could be trusted, and it was here that Guy helped write the constitution for the Southern Rhodesia African National Congress - he was asked to be president, but refused. Mugabe became a close friend; Guy and Molly said they felt he would be "good for the country".

N eedless to say, Guy, who had been granted citizenship in 1951, was not so popular with the white regime - he was living, eating and working alongside blacks, demonstrating they could live together equally. In 1959 he was detained without trial, but promised freedom if he would relinquish his citizenship and go. He refused: "African nationalism had not been achieved," he explained simply, and he and Molly - who had set up the Mukuwapasi Clinic, where she worked as a physiotherapist with children - took themselves across the border to Botswana for a while, then returned and bought a large piece of land with like-minded whites - it would not have been possible for blacks to purchase it. The Cold Comfort Farm cooperative outside Salisbury drew unemployed young men and women, including people like Didimus Mutasa and Moven Mahaci, who went on to become political leaders after independence. Agricultural skills were learned and political ideas discussed endlessly.

The white police regularly searched the farm for "terrorist weapons", but it was Ian Smith who, in 1971, passed the Citizenship Act and kicked Guy out. There are pictures of a large crowd of Africans weeping at the airport as he went, shouting: "I am glad to share in the fellowship of the dispossessed... I regard the present regime as only temporary."

Guy died happy, having seen independence achieved, and it seemed that when Mugabe came to power the memory of that group of committed and determined whites held a meaning. It seemed the new president had a real will to make reconciliation work, and for more than 15 years blacks and whites appeared to live pretty much peaceably alongside each other. And although the much-needed land reform which would give Africans some of the quality land mostly still owned and farmed by whites clearly needed to be done, the hope had been that Mugabe would bring it about in a measured way.

That all appears a sad, sick dream now. But there is another question worth asking: should blacks, once they gain independence, be obliged to go on paying obeisance to even the most supportive of whites? It is not a question for me to answer, but a young African who became a friend of my son's while he was teaching in Zimbabwe a few years ago and remains in touch, believes his generation gains from hanging on to those memories and understanding that there are whites who believe in justice for Africans. He has as good a reason as any to hate whites - his father was killed by a Rhodesian policeman - but he says he has been happy growing up in a country where it has been possible to be friends with whites and see reconciliation, for all its imperfections, working.

Clearly Mugabe does not listen to this new generation, and I suspect if Guy were in Zimbabwe now the colour of his skin would be the point, not the "immense contribution" which Mugabe spoke of him having made just six years ago.

webTitle: £3m drive to double organ donor cards

fields.headline: £3m drive to double organ donor cards
fields.trailText: The government yesterday launched a £3m effort to increase life-saving transplant operations, pledging to double the number of organ donor card holders from 8m to 16m by 2010.
fields.body:
The government yesterday launched a £3m effort to increase life-saving transplant operations, pledging to double the number of organ donor card holders from 8m to 16m by 2010.

The shortage of organs - particularly of kidneys but also hearts and lungs - has been rising for years, exacerbated by a reduction in fatal car accidents, thanks to seat belts. There were 4,890 people waiting for kidneys in the last year, while only 153 transplants were carried out.

Since the Alder Hey scandal, when parents discovered that organs had been removed from their children during postmortem examinations, there have been fears of a further fall in donors, though the number registered has remained the same.

But the scandal has galvanised the government into renewed action. Yesterday the health secretary, Alan Milburn, promised to double kidney transplants by 2005 and increase the number of heart and lung transplants by 10%.

"The organ transplant service depends entirely on the generosity of donors and their families," he said. "The circumstances are by definition tragic. And yet, from such an event an unselfish act helps others. I want to express my personal respect and gratitude for those who make this life-saving gift.

"We need to ensure the public are better informed and better able to give their consent; staff are better trained and higher standards of service are set in this vital area of work. We will continue to work together to improve these services which genuinely save lives."

An "opt-out" scheme, favoured by the British Medical Association, which would presume anyone who died had given consent unless he or she had registered their opposition, has been ruled out.

webTitle: American and Russian space clipper to set sail

fields.headline: American and Russian space clipper to set sail
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A test firing from a Russian nuclear submarine in April could mark the start of the ultimate space adventure - a space clipper, sailing in the wind from the sun.
fields.body:
A test firing from a Russian nuclear submarine in April could mark the start of the ultimate space adventure - a space clipper, sailing in the wind from the sun.

The Planetary Society, a powerful US pressure group, announced yesterday it was preparing a 30-minute flight launched from a converted intercontinental ballistic missile launcher aboard a submarine in the Barents sea in April. If the launch is successful, a unique, privately funded Russian-American adventure will begin in the autumn.

The same system will launch a tiny 40kg vehicle called Cosmos 1 more than 850km into space. Once in high orbit, Cosmos 1 will inflate a series of tubes which will flower into eight ultra-thin, triangular reflecting petals, which will form a sail 30 metres across. Light in a vacuum exerts a tiny pressure, and with no air resistance, this "solar wind" pressure would be enough to get a spaceclipper slowly accelerating, eventually to colossal speeds.

The launch of Cosmos 1 will be the end of a dream first proposed in 1924, and then pressed by the late Carl Sagan, an astronomer, and Louis Friedman, director of the Planetary Society founded by Sagan. The commercial sponsors of Cosmos 1 will be Cosmos studios, headed by Sagan's widow, Ann Druyan.

The April prototype will deploy only two blades, inflate a re-entry shield, take a few photographs of itself and then fall back to Earth in the Kamchatka region of Siberia.

The autumn launch will unfurl 600 square metres of sails, which can be pitched like helicopter blades to control the ship's attitude and enable her to tack against the solar wind.

Space sailing offers the dream of journeys without fuel. Launch costs are huge - $10,000 (about £7,000) to put 1lb into orbit. And there are limits to the amount of fuel a spacecraft heading for Mars or Jupiter could carry.

Although a spaceclipper would start slowly, theorists reckon one could get to speeds of 1km a second in eight days. The bigger and lighter the sail, and the smaller the cargo, the faster it would accelerate. A sail six miles across could carry six tons of cargo to Pluto - at the edge of the solar system - in 18 months. The fuel-driven Cassini spacecraft now on her way to Saturn will have spent seven years on the journey.

Dr Friedman says the experiment will fulfill several dreams - of Russians and Americans working together, of weapons turned to a peaceful adventure, and of privately funded space experiments.

Cosmos 1 could fly for months while scientists test the technology and measure the acceleration. Experts may even try an extra "puff" of light-wind from a laser on Earth. Sunlight pressure would be enough to push it around the inner solar system. Beyond Jupiter, powerful focused lasers could drive it even further and faster.
fields.bodyText: A test firing from a Russian nuclear submarine in April could mark the start of the ultimate space adventure - a space clipper, sailing in the wind from the sun. The Planetary Society, a powerful US pressure group, announced yesterday it was preparing a 30-minute flight launched from a converted intercontinental ballistic missile launcher aboard a submarine in the Barents sea in April. If the launch is successful, a unique, privately funded Russian-American adventure will begin in the autumn. The same system will launch a tiny 40kg vehicle called Cosmos 1 more than 850km into space. Once in high orbit, Cosmos 1 will inflate a series of tubes which will flower into eight ultra-thin, triangular reflecting petals, which will form a sail 30 metres across. Light in a vacuum exerts a tiny pressure, and with no air resistance, this "solar wind" pressure would be enough to get a spaceclipper slowly accelerating, eventually to colossal speeds. The launch of Cosmos 1 will be the end of a dream first proposed in 1924, and then pressed by the late Carl Sagan, an astronomer, and Louis Friedman, director of the Planetary Society founded by Sagan. The commercial sponsors of Cosmos 1 will be Cosmos studios, headed by Sagan's widow, Ann Druyan. The April prototype will deploy only two blades, inflate a re-entry shield, take a few photographs of itself and then fall back to Earth in the Kamchatka region of Siberia. The autumn launch will unfurl 600 square metres of sails, which can be pitched like helicopter blades to control the ship's attitude and enable her to tack against the solar wind. Space sailing offers the dream of journeys without fuel. Launch costs are huge - $10,000 (about £7,000) to put 1lb into orbit. And there are limits to the amount of fuel a spacecraft heading for Mars or Jupiter could carry. Although a spaceclipper would start slowly, theorists reckon one could get to speeds of 1km a second in eight days. The bigger and lighter the sail, and the smaller the cargo, the faster it would accelerate. A sail six miles across could carry six tons of cargo to Pluto - at the edge of the solar system - in 18 months. The fuel-driven Cassini spacecraft now on her way to Saturn will have spent seven years on the journey. Dr Friedman says the experiment will fulfill several dreams - of Russians and Americans working together, of weapons turned to a peaceful adventure, and of privately funded space experiments. Cosmos 1 could fly for months while scientists test the technology and measure the acceleration. Experts may even try an extra "puff" of light-wind from a laser on Earth. Sunlight pressure would be enough to push it around the inner solar system. Beyond Jupiter, powerful focused lasers could drive it even further and faster.

webTitle: African women tricked into sex slavery in Spain

fields.headline: African women tricked into sex slavery in Spain
fields.trailText: Jennifer has come a long way from Benin City, her home in Nigeria, to the freezing Casa de Campo park in Madrid. But she has no option but to stand there alongside a hundred other prostitutes, trying to scratch together enough money to prevent her being killed.
fields.body:
Jennifer has come a long way from Benin City, her home in Nigeria, to the freezing Casa de Campo park in Madrid. But she has no option but to stand there alongside a hundred other prostitutes, trying to scratch together enough money to prevent her being killed.

The Spanish police say the 20-year-old woman they call Jennifer is proof that there is a flourishing slave trade in prostitutes between Africa and Europe.

On a recent raid on the headquarters of one prostitution gang in Madrid they found a "contract" signed by Jennifer.

Written in pure Spanish, it said: "I promise to pay the sum of $40,000 [about £28,000] to my auntie Iveve and declare that I ... will not break any rules or tell the police anything until this amount is paid. If I fail, auntie Iveve has the right to kill me and my family."

Ten other contracts for similar sums, and with death threats included, were discovered. The police estimate that up to 100 women may have passed through the gang's hands in the past 18 months.

"Auntie Iveve" was arrested last week, with 19 other people, for keeping Jennifer and a dozen other women in conditions of slavery. It would take Jennifer at least five years to pay off her debt, the police said.

The women were brought overland through Africa and on a dangerous ride in speedboats across the Strait of Gibraltar from Tangiers, in Morocco. They were then taken to Madrid, made to sign their "contracts" and put to work.

Packed in small flats on the outskirts of the city, they were bussed into the Casa de Campo as darkness fell and picked up again at dawn.

"Some were prostitutes in Nigeria, but others were tricked into coming, told that they would be given work as secretaries or hostesses," one of the police officers in charge of the operation said.

"The police said some of them had their debt bought by Spanish pimps, who took them to work in roadside brothels.

Others went to brothels abroad.

"They were sold to other people, both Spanish and foreign, for sums of up to 2m pesetas [£7,600]," the police officer said.

"That was simply added to their debt, with the girls expected to pay off their purchaser as well as the gang that brought them to Spain."

The arrest of Auntie Iveve has not put an end to Jennifer's life in the Casa del Campo, the police said.

Without friends in Madrid and with a debt still to pay off, she is back there working.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Trust closes properties |  RSPCA guards against disease |  Spam birthday postponed
fields.body:
Trust closes properties

The National Trust has postponed school visits to its countryside properties because of the foot and mouth outbreak, closed its properties in the north east, and closed or restricted access in other areas where there are livestock. All Scottish national nature reserves have been closed to the public until further notice, said conservation agency Scottish Natural Heritage.

RSPCA guards against disease

The RSPCA yesterday ordered animals at its 50 centres to be kept in isolation from the public to guard against foot and mouth. Two zoos, Howletts and Port Lympne near Hythe, Kent, were last night closed to protect species there, including antelope, water buffalo and bison.

Spam birthday postponed

Celebrations for Spam's 60th birthday have been put on hold as a mark of respect for farmers hit by foot and mouth. The US and Danish companies behind the chopped pork and ham product are cancelling a week of promotional activities in the UK.

Shipman patient unlawfully killed

A South Manchester coroner yesterday recorded a verdict of unlawful killing on Charles Killan, 90, of Hyde, Greater Manchester, who was seen by the serial killer Harold Shipman just before his death and is suspected of being his first male victim. The GP was jailed for life last year for the murders of 15 women by morphine injection.

Smoke damage at cathedral

Officials at Coventry Cathedral were assessing smoke damage to the building's priceless artefacts, including the world's largest tapestry - Graham Sutherland's Christ in Glory - after a fire, which was confined to a basement storeroom by West Midlands fire service, broke out yesterday morning.

Man charged over lake body

Bashir Ahmed, 44, who was extradited from New York yesterday, has been charged by magistrates in Buxton, Derbyshire, with the murder of factory worker Tony Price, 31, from Oldham, whose dismembered body was found in three plastic bags during drainage work at Woodhead reservoir, Derbyshire in 1981.

Bishop attacks asylum policy

The Bishop of Winchester, the Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, yesterday attacked the government for holding asylum seekers in prison after they have been refused permission to stay in the UK. In a letter, he told Jack Straw, the home secretary, that refugee centres, where the asylum seekers would not feel so isolated, should be used instead.

DJ criticised for 'moron' jibe

The Broadcasting Standards Commission yesterday described as "ill-judged and unfortunate" on-air remarks by the DJ Jon Gaunt, of BBC Three Counties Radio, who called a listener a "moron" and threatened to "go to his home with a baseball bat" in August last year after the listener criticised him in a letter to a local newspaper. Mr Gaunt later apologised on air for his "unnecessarily rude and aggressive" remarks.

webTitle: Europe rethinks policies Organic methods on increase

fields.headline: Europe rethinks policies Organic methods on increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: France
fields.body:
France

France has been battered by a series of recent food scares, ranging from listeria-infected cheeses and dioxin-tainted chickens to sewage-fed pigs and BSE cows.

Sales of beef plummeted by up to 40% last year at the height of a nationwide BSE panic, although France has so far discovered only 270 cases of BSE - against 180,000 in Britain.

Sales of organic meat, fruit and vegetables have risen by 25% over the past two years.

Successive food crises only increase Europe-wide calls for a fundamental shift in agricultural policies and practices. But agricultural reform to improve food production methods - and particularly any reform of the EU's common agricultural policy (CAP) - will be more difficult to sell in France than anywhere else in Europe.

French farmers benefit more than any others from the CAP. They are capable of bringing the country to a standstill and used to getting what they want from nervous French governments.

Jon Henley

Germany

Green politician Renate Künast was appointed last month as the new food, agriculture and consumer minister to steer Germany towards a more organic future in the wake of the BSE crisis which hit the country in November.

The 45-year old lawyer has pledged to bring food production "closer to nature", in contrast to her predecessor, Karl-Heinz Funke, an advocate of intensive farming. She is working hard to win over the farming lobby, but among the public whose consumer confidence has been severely battered, her support has grown rapidly.

Only 2.1% of Germany's farms are organic, or in the process of conversion, compared with Sweden, with 11.2%, Austria 10%, Denmark 6% and Britain 3%.

Ms Künast aims to push for 20% of farms to become organic within10 years.

Kate Connolly

Denmark

An aggressive environmental policy has made Denmark one of Europe's most organic countries. Even its agricultural minister, Ritt Bjerregaard, is an organic farmer.

But throughout the 1970s and 1980s Denmark's pigs were intensively farmed, its cows suffered and its crops were heavily dosed in synthetic chemicals.

Modern organic farming in Denmark started in the 1970s as a popular protest against intensive conventional agriculture and due to increasing concerns about environment, animal welfare and product quality.

In 1988, the Danish government became the first in the world to adopt regulations governing organic farming. Unlike Britain, where organic farming is still marginalised and barely funded, the Danish government sees no problems for economic growth or competitiveness.

The country exports £21m of organic food a year. The government also pays handsomely for farmers to convert and is turning more money to research.

Marianne Hartz

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: With the issue of freedom of speech and the local press in mind, we ask why his constituents never read a word about Alan Duncan's business.
fields.body:
 With the issue of freedom of speech and the local press in mind, we ask why his constituents never read a word about Alan Duncan's business ... his lucrative work for Marc Rich, for example, and for the Yemeni arms dealer Sheikh Ahmed Farid, as reported by the Sunday Times last August.

So why, we ask Melton Times editor Andy Place, did not a word of this reach your readers? "How well do you know Mr Duncan?" asks Andy after a deep breath. "We had no evidence that it was true. And he's got a lot more money than us, our dapper MP." The Rutland Times's Brian Martin tells us: "Mr Duncan ... has quite often said he will take us to court, so we can't afford to print those things," while the Leicester Mercury editor Nick Carter went off the record to say much the same. As for Tim Robinson of the Stamford and Rutland Mercury, he seemed confused, first claiming he missed the story in August, and then insisting his news editor couldn't stand it up.

Meanwhile, last week's Melton Times ran a photo of Little Alan posing with a packet of Fortnum's teabags (an imbecilic stunt; don't ask), and smiling broadly, tickled perhaps by the thought of our grotesque libel laws and how they make such a joke of freedom of speech.

 I am delighted to announce the new Book of the Month for March. It is To Dream A Dream (Blake Publishing), Piers Morgan's no-holds-barred 1992 biography of the richly-talented TV presenter and musical actor Phillip Schofield.

 Going far, far beyond the call of duty, I've waded through the unabridged Andrew Neil rant about the Guardian over the article outlining how he's blown 120 of the Barclay's millions. In one section, Andrew appears to accuse our financial editor, Paul Murphy, who wrote the piece, of being drunk when the two met at Jeff Randall's Sunday Business leaving do.

Andrew, you naughty boy, who was it who had the audience tittering by referring to Mr Randall leaving the Sunday Times? More water with it for you. As for your notion that the editors of this title and others called emergency meetings to discuss your whinge about horrid media diaries picking on you, for God's sake, man, grow up. No more whining. The last thing your heroine liked was a moaning minnie. Be a brave boy for Margaret.

 In the Sun, Richard Littlejohn strives for fresh ground, turning his mind to homosexuality in connection with the new Monty biography. "We're all repressing something - axe murderer, ballroom dancer. Who knows?" writes Richard. "I hate to think what they're going to say about me when I'm gone." Richard, old love, worry no more. They've been saying just that about you for years and years.

 With her area of specialism going through a quiet spell, Times countryside editor Val Elliot calls concerning the resurgence of the microwave plug crisis (we reported yesterday, you will recall, how the plug was snipped off again and planted in Val's top right hand drawer while she was on holiday). Calling from a foot and mouth press conference, Val seems cross. "This is ridiculous," she says. "I haven't been on holiday. Don't you check your sources?" Sorry, don't we what? "It's not even funny." Oh. May we ask when you last did take a holiday? "Er, I had two days off, if that counts as holiday." Right, thanks, Val. Goodbye.

 There is no space today, alas, for Marina's debate with Times managing editor George Brock, the dandy of Wapping, about what constitutes a tank top. Perhaps tomorrow.

 Surveillance: the kangaroo suit needed to deliver Skippy Hammond's jigsaw, outside the Musicians Union headquarters at the Oval, south London, at about 2pm on Monday, in a protest about the suspension of an official. Whoever you are, return the bloody thing to the shop at once.

fields.headline: John Morrison
fields.trailText: Kind, and always helpful to his staff and students, his success was rooted in going to the fundamentals of a problem, and logically applying sound engineering science to obtain the best solution.
fields.body:
Professor John Morrison, who has died aged 94, was a great engineer. In 1964, with Bernard Crossland, he co-authored An Introduction To The Mechanics Of Machines, a book which lit fires in students rather than filled pails with water. For years the standard - and very readable - undergraduate text on dynamics, it was based on his wealth of practical experience.

John was a career academic, who maintained active links with industry through- out his time at Bristol University. Passionately devoted to teaching, and an excellent researcher, he pioneered project work in mechanical engineering courses. He believed in application, rather than just teaching equations and finding their solutions.

His final-year students at Bristol worked in pairs on original research or development, projects that brought out the basics and showed them that real engineering was broadly based, interesting and fun. It was also the first serious attempt to weaken reliance on exam-inations for assessment.

Curiously, John's research was more towards the behaviour of engineering materials than on dynamics. He was encouraged by his own mentor at Bristol, another great engineer, Andrew Robertson, to look at the problem of accurately measuring the yield point of structural steels. Because reliable and accurate electrical measuring methods were not then available, he invented special optical extensometers which could measure deflections in tension and torsion.

John was born in Biggar, Lanarkshire. At the age of five, he decided to become an engineer, and, in 1927, graduated with first-class honours in engineering at Glasgow University. After a year as a graduate apprentice with Harland & Wolff in Belfast, which he did not enjoy, he joined Bristol University as a junior lecturer.

During the second world war, he worked for the Bristol Aeroplane company, and served on a number of official committees, including the scientific advisory council's gun design committee, which got him interested in the high-pressure testing of pressure vessels.

Thus did he work with WRD Manning, of ICI, who was involved in the design of high-pressure equipment for the manufacture of polythene. In those days, polythene could only be made by compressing ethylene gas to pressures of the order of 1,500 atmospheres; the equipment was also prone to catastrophic fatigue failure.

In 1949, a research programme, with Bernard Crossland and John Parry, was started to study the strength of thick-walled tubes subjected to repeated internal pressure. The objective was to design and build a fatigue testing machine to subject a 25mm-bore test cylinder to repeated cycles of pressure up to 3,000 atmospheres at a rate of 600 cycles/minute.

For serving - actively - on, and chairing, so many government committees, John was awarded the CBE in 1957. He contributed to the development of his profession through the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, and was chairman of its western branch (1951-52) and its president for 1970-71.

Kind, and always helpful to his staff and students, his success was rooted in going to the fundamentals of a problem, and logically applying sound engineering science to obtain the best solution. He married Olga Nierenstein in 1936; she survives him, as do their sons, Peter and James.

John Lamb Murray Morrison, engineer and academic, born May 22 1906; died February 6 2001

fields.headline: Tom Baker
fields.trailText: During blasting operations at South Garesfield colliery, County Durham, on May 17 1929, a colliery deputy was seriously injured about a mile and a half from the shaft in six-west district of the Victoria seam.
fields.body:
During blasting operations at South Garesfield colliery, County Durham, on May 17 1929, a colliery deputy was seriously injured about a mile and a half from the shaft in six-west district of the Victoria seam. Hearing the news, Robert Glendinning, an over-man, went down the pit and collected James Purvis to search for the injured man. With them was a 17-year old pit-lad, Tom Baker, who has now died aged 88.

As they neared the scene, the three men were met by another miner, who reported that his four companions - who had gone to help - had been overcome by carbon monoxide gas. Realising that more help was needed, Glendinning took two additional men and, equipped with relatively primitive breathing apparatus, went on to where the deputy and four miners lay unconscious.

As the rescue started, the two additional men col-lapsed. Glendinning, Baker and Purvis were now faced with trying to rescue seven men. Sending Purvis back for help, Glendinning and Baker moved the two collapsed members of the rescue party, then the injured deputy, and finally the four unconscious men.

For well over an hour, the two men struggled back and forth through black smoke and gas carrying their fellow miners to safety. fields.headline: Roberto Gabetti
fields.trailText: After 1945, turning their backs on the rationalist movement - for them, too closely associated with fascism - a number of Italian architects reintegrated tradition into the modern experience, among them Roberto Gabetti.
fields.body:
After 1945, turning their backs on the rationalist movement - for them, too closely associated with fascism - a number of Italian architects reintegrated tradition into the modern experience, giving Italian modernist architecture a character that is today admired the world over for its emphasis on the expressive qualities of materials and sensual details, while reappropriating older shapes and spatial archetypes.

Each region produced its local protagonists, which, in Piedmont, was the team of Aimaro Isola and Roberto Gabetti, who has died, aged 75, in his native Turin.

Gabetti was born into Italy's crème de la crème. He graduated in architecture from Turin Polytechnic in 1949, joined its faculty in 1950 as an assistant to Carlo Mollino, a major influence, and, in 1967, became professor of architectural composition, founding and directing Italy's most important architectural library.

He began working with Isola in 1950 and, from the start, their output was controversial. It began with the famous Bottega d'Erasmo (1953-56), a centre for Jewish studies, built in the shadow of Alessandro Antonelli's towering Mole Antonelliana (1889).

This building was condemned by the doctrinaire Vittorio Gregotti as breaking faith with the supposedly canonic rules of authentic modernism. It explored the expressive possibilities of decorative brickwork, turning its back on the industrialised approach modernism was supposed to embrace, and introduced quasi-middle-eastern pointed arches. This was an emotive, anti-rational approach that became known as "neoliberty", and was characterised by Charles Jencks, in Modern Movements In Architecture (1973), as a revolt against the machine aesthetic.

But Gabetti's divergence from orthodoxy was no rebellion. Fortunate to be born into Turin's modernist, cultivated elites, he and Isola never needed to join any movement to make their influence count. Through Italy's traumatic 1950s reconstruction, the 1960s revolts, and the years of the Red Brigades in the 1970s, they were as sured of commissions, and became the best known architects in Turin high society.

Thanks to this patronage, they were able to develop their work, not as a rebellion, but in complete detachment, revisiting and exploring traditional building forms. If their work - admired by Italian architects - is little known elsewhere, it may be because of this regional flavour. Yet it is also highly sophisticated and cosmopolitan, combining quasi-traditional building elements with modern engineering and materials.

Gabetti's output with Isola comprises an eclectic series of one masterpiece after another, such as the elegant Turin equestrian club (1959-60), the Turin stock exchange (1952-56), and the amazingly advanced residential centre in Ivrea (1969-74), a glass and steel crescent of service flats for Olivetti employees, buried under grassy lawns, in which some see allusions to Bath.

Long before sustainability in architecture became a widespread concern, Gabetti was working on low-energy, environmentally friendly projects, such as the Casa Solare at Orbassano (1982) and the widely-admired office complex for the SNAM company in Milan (1986), in which he and his partner explored the technology of the double glass wall. In these buildings, advanced construction technologies were always kept under control and manipulated to achieve the most expressive result.

Gabetti is badly missed at Turin Polytechnic, where he pursued interests that were an integral part of his investigations into tradition and modernity.

He is survived by his wife Margherita and his son.

 Roberto Gabetti, architect and academic, born November 11 1925; died December 7 2000.

fields.headline: Ugo Fano
fields.standfirst: Brilliant physicist who pioneered atomic research
fields.trailText: Brilliant physicist who pioneered atomic research dies aged 88
fields.body:
An indication of the pervasive impact of Ugo Fano, the theoretical atomic physicist who has died aged 88, remains in the number of phenomena that he explained and which bear his name: the Beutler-Fano profile, the Fano-Lichten mechanism, the Fano effect, and the Fano factor. His career spanned more than 60 years of research.

Fano belonged to that generation of brilliant researchers who studied in Italy in the 1930s under Enrico Fermi, the Nobel prizewinning physicist, and played a central part in the development of modern atomic physics. Fermi himself fled from anti-semitism to the United States in 1938, built the world's first atomic pile at the University of Chicago and carried out the first controlled nuclear chain-reaction in 1942.

Fano emigrated to America soon afterwards to work at the Washington Biophysical Institute and the Carnegie Institution. His research was dedicated primarily to understanding the dynamics of atoms and molecules, and the ways they interact with light, electrons, and each other. He published his first scientific paper in 1934, and his last more than 65 years later, not long before he died. One of his research papers is the most widely cited in modern atomic physics.

His research in theoretical physics provided the basis for a raft of practical experiments by others, leading to inventions such as the gas laser, which depended on a detailed knowledge of how to manipulate the atomic and molecular energy levels of particular materials to generate a laser beam.

His research into a basic understanding of the physics involved when penetrating radiation, like X-rays and ultraviolet radiation, interacted with matter - especially the damage to living tissue - was equally valuable. It was used to develop new techniques in materials research, and laid the foundation for discoveries in medical research, with revolutionary diagnostic and therapeutic applications.

Fano was born in Turin, the son of a mathematician at the University of Turin, who kept the young Ugo informed about the great discoveries and debates in physics and mathematics. Fano recalled being introduced to Niels Bohr's atomic theory at the dinner table when he was 12 years old. After receiving a doctorate in mathematics at Turin in 1934, he worked under Fermi at the University of Rome from 1934, and with another Nobel prize- winning physicist, Werner Heisenberg, at the University of Leipzig in 1936.

He joined the US National Bureau of Standards in 1946, where he worked for 20 years as chief of radiation theory. In 1966, he moved to the University of Chicago and the James Franck Institute, where he continued his research until recently.

He received many of the highest academic honours. He was a member of the US National Academy of Sciences, a fellow of the Royal Society, and a member of the Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei, Rome. In 1995, he won the Fermi Award, among the most prestigious scientific prizes given by the US government.

To emphasise his long identification with one of the world's greatest physicists, Fano told a story about hiking in the mountains with his father as a boy in 1924. They were overtaken by a group of scientists, who exchanged a few words with his father. As the scientists moved on, his father pointed to one of them and said: "That man is expected to go far in life. His name is Fermi."

He was acutely aware of the pace of change in science: when he started, there might have been 1,000 physicists worldwide; now there are more than 40,000 physicists in the American Physical Soc-iety alone. He lamented the passing of a style and tradition of doing physics that accompanied this progress. It bothered him that increased specialisation meant that it had become difficult for physicists to talk to each other.

His wife, Camilla, and two daughters survive him.

Ugo Fano, atomic physicist, born July 28 1912; died February 13 2001

fields.headline: Robert Enrico
fields.standfirst: Director whose first classic film outshone his later work
fields.trailText: Director whose first classic film La Rivière Du Hibou (Incident At Owl Creek) outshone his later work
fields.body:
In 1961, at the outset of his career, the French film director Robert Enrico, who has died aged 69, made a 27-minute fictional short, La Rivière Du Hibou (Incident At Owl Creek), which remains to this day a classic of that genre.

The black and white film, adapted from the late 19th-, early 20th-century American writer Ambrose Bierce's macabre tale, An Occurrence At Owl Creek Bridge, relates how a man about to be executed as a spy during the American civil war apparently cheats the hangman and escapes through sun-dappled woodland to be reunited with his wife, only for this adventure to be revealed as the fantasy that has flashed through his imagination in the momentary space before he drops to his death.

With a minimum of dialogue, and aided by lyrically atmospheric camera work by Jean Boffety - with whom he was to collaborate frequently -Enrico achieved a tour de force of visual narrative. Unfortunately, it was to prove no harbinger of his later work.

Born of Italian parents in Liévin, northern France, Enrico studied at the Sorbonne and the Idhec film school, and went on to work in documentaries, subsequently directing army training films during military service. La Rivière Du Hibou won him the Palme d'Or at Cannes in 1962 and an Oscar in 1964. In Britain, it received the unexpected accolade of a circuit release as support to Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds. In the United States, it was networked in Rod Serling's Twilight Zone series.

Enrico subsequently incorporated the film into a triptych of Bierce adaptations, Au Coeur De La Vie (1962), his first full-length feature, though this failed to register any comparable impact. But he was launched as a feature director.

In early films like La Belle Vie (1963) - an impressionistic account of a young ex-soldier returning to Paris at the time of the Algerian protests - he appeared to be conforming to the tenets of the nouvelle vague , which had recently become such a dominant influence on French cinema. Tante Zita (1968) was similarly impressionistic in style, following its heroine in a nocturnal prowl around Paris as she seeks to come to terms with the impending death of a beloved aunt. But the glossy thriller, Les Aventuriers (1967), starring Alain Delon and Lino Ventura, about a hunt for sunken treasure off the African coast, had al ready intimated Enrico's gravitation toward more overtly commercial material.

In similar vein, he directed Jean-Paul Belmondo in Ho! (1968), while in Boulevard Du Rhum (1971), an exotic tale of rum runners, his star was no less than Brigitte Bardot, by that time approaching her retirement from the screen. Such films may have been largely formulaic, but were at least distinguished by superior production values and clear-cut narrative.

The same could hardly be said of some of Enrico's later melodramas, which tended to overlay their routine material with elements of less than coherent pretension. Le Secret (1974) was a conspiracy thriller of a tolerably ingenious sort, leaving the spectator uncertain as to whether the action is "real" or only a projection of the paranoia of its protagonist (Jean-Louis Trintignant) - perhaps an echo of the ambiguity which underpinned La Rivière Du Hibou.

On the other hand, the César-winning Le Vieux Fusil (The Old Gun, 1975) was, despite the presence of Philippe Noiret and Romy Schneider, an implausible tale of a French doctor's wartime revenge against SS troops who had murdered his wife and daughter. The film had little impact as a thriller, while succumbing, in its flashbacks of happier times, to that sentimentality which had, less obtrusively, dogged some of Enrico's better films.

Enrico continued sporadically working into the 1980s, to no very great effect; none of his post-1975 films ach- ieved British distribution. One of his later directorial outings was, though, on a bigger physical scale than anything he had attempted before - a multi-national co-production called The French Revolution: Years Of Light, released in 1989 to mark the bicentennial of the storming of the Bastille.

fields.headline: RUC warns death list republicans
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Detectives are trying to track down 500 republicans to warn them their lives could be at risk, after the RUC seized documents and computer disks thought to belong to loyalist paramilitaries in north Belfast.
fields.body:
Detectives are trying to track down 500 republicans to warn them their lives could be at risk, after the RUC seized documents and computer disks thought to belong to loyalist paramilitaries in north Belfast.

The discovery, the biggest of its kind in two years, is linked to the Ulster Volunteer Force and its sister organisation, the Red Hand Commando.

Guns and ammunition were also recovered in two separate searches and a number of people have been charged in connection with the find.

Many of the details, some of which include photographs and addresses, are up to 10 years old, but two or three entries were made between 1997 and 1999.

More than 150 names, a street map with marked houses, and several surveillance photographs were found in a plastic-wrapped package, and police believe the names of another 300 republicans were downloaded from a prisoners' website. The names of 30 loyalists were also found.

News of the discovery came as Sinn Fein members of the Northern Ireland assembly called for an independent investigation into alleged collusion between RUC Special Branch, British military intelligence and loyalist terrorists, which republicans believe has led to the murder of hundreds of Roman Catholics.

Gerry Kelly, Sinn Fein assemblyman for North Belfast, said the issue went right to the heart of his party's problems with the new policing legislation and he called for Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, currently investigating collusion claims, to stand down in favour of a public inquiry.

"The finding of these files cannot be taken lightly," he said. "The people named on this list should be contacted as a matter of urgency."

The RUC's assistant chief constable, Alan McQuillan, said there was nothing to suggest the details were connected to police or army records but it was a possibility.

He said two teams were working on the case, one advising the people on the lists on their personal security and the other investigating the compilers. But he said it could be some time before all those named could be traced.

All the information has been passed to detectives investigating the loyalist murders of Catholic solicitors Pat Finucane and Rosemary Nelson, where relatives claim there was collusion with security forces.

Mr Finucane was shot dead at his north Belfast home in 1989, while Mrs Nelson was killed by a car bomb outside her house in Lurgan, Co Armagh, in 1999.

webTitle: Global trade forces exodus from land

fields.headline: Global trade forces exodus from land
fields.standfirst:
Big operators carve out overwhelming advantage

Special report: the countryside in crisis
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Today animals are mostly reared indoors, there are few people working the land, the smallest viable farms in the area are mostly 400 acres or more, and many villages are half empty most of the week.
fields.body:
In 1753 William Cobbett, chronicler of 18th century English rural life, stood on the downs above the Vale of Pewsey in Wiltshire and declared the patchwork of small fields, hedgerows, orchards and villages below him to be "the promised land".

"It is impossible," he wrote, "to imagine any life more easy and happy than men might lead here if they were not tormented by an accursed system that takes the food from those that raise it and gives it to them who do nothing."

Some 250 years later, as another economic system haunts the vale, Cobbett's vista of people and animals busy in the Pewsey fields is long gone. Today the animals are mostly reared indoors, there are few people working the land, the smallest viable farms in the area are mostly 400 acres or more, and many villages are half empty most of the week.

The big farms are often owned by companies who employ contracters at planting and reaping time; the orchards have been mostly grubbed up because the five supermarkets who dominate the British food supply industry choose not to sell the fruit; and the downs are dominated by 4,000-acre farms owned by international businessmen and worked for wheat by £150,000 tractors aided by satellite navigation.

The Vale of Pewsey, like almost every corner of Britain, has been globalised. The carrots in the local supermarket may have come from Spain, the apples from New Zealand, the flowers from Africa and the beans from Asia. The meat could be from Botswana or Brazil, the sheep reared on the downs may well be exported to the Middle East and the milk quite likely will be processed and sent to Africa.

For the Pewsey farmers who cannot match the technology needed for intensive large-scale farming, or just the favourable climates in other places, the globalisation of agriculture spells ruin. In 1998 Clive Hibberd who farmed 200 acres at Oak farm got out after 40 years. "I just cannot compete any more," he said.

His neighbour, Alan Lathan of Wilds farm, was blunt: "Outside economic forces have done me in. You have no control over prices, everything is set by outsiders. It doesn't matter how well you farm, it just gets harder and harder." He, too, has left.

The same forces that affect Britain are sweeping through rural areas everywhere. The twin motors have been rapid globalisation, backed by world trade rules which are opening every market to international competition, and a system of subsidies that encourages intensification.

Steve Gorelick, a US farmer and co-founder of the International Society for Ecology and Culture, said 235,000 farms and 60,000 rural companies in the US were driven out of business in the 1980s. The massive decline in farm income in Britain is matched in the US, where incomes halved between 1996-99 and suicide, says Mr Gorelick, is the commonest cause of death among farmers.

In Europe 200,000 farmers left agriculture in 1999. In India farmers are unable to compete with cheap imports. Several hundred million Chinese have left the countryside for the cities in 20 years of agricultural modernisation.

The UN Food and Agriculture Organisation says global agricultural trade is worth some £300bn a year and has almost doubled since 1980. The benefits of exporting food, say its advocates, are increased wealth and food supplies. Critics argue that countries' food "security" is undermined by making them dependent on others.

Multinational corporations are also extending their power and control over agricultural production, making farmers dependent on them for seed, technological inputs, credit and outlets for their produce.

The lion's share of global agribusiness has been snapped up by a few countries and companies. According to US author David Korten, 10 companies involved in seed, fertilisers, pesticides, processing, and shipments control more than 60% of the international food chain.

"One company, Cargill's, controls 80% of the world's grain supplies, four companies control 87% of US beef, five account for 65% of the global pesticide market, another four control the world's supply of corn, wheat, tobacco, tea, rice, pineapple, jute, timber and many other commodities," he says.

In Britain, 80% of agricultural subsidies are taken by the largest 20% of farmers. In the US, says Peter Rosset of California-based agricultural think tank Food First, taxpayers subsidise the biggest 10% of farmers by more than $13bn a year - 60% of the total $22bn paid to US farmers directly. "It's a transfer of money to large multinational corporate farmers who dominate the world trade," says Dr Rosset. "They buy the grain, or whatever, at giveaway prices and use the subsidies to capture markets around the world and drive farmers out of business in Mexico, Africa, Asia and South America."

Just as the small farmers cannot equally compete with the large players in Britain, so there is a similar disparity between the richest 16 countries and the rest of the world. OECD agricultural subsidies total almost $362bn a year, compared to less than one 20th of that for the rest of the world's countries.

Increased transport distances between producers and consumers bring social and environmental costs, says Tim Lobstein of the Food Commission, an independent agricultural think tank.

"Take apples. We now consume more French than British ones.

"We have grubbed up half of our orchards since the 1950s and now bring in apples from Europe, New Zealand, South Africa, Chile and the US. We could produce many more in the UK, benefiting rural communities, but we don't because the big supermarket buyers can get a better deal from the French.

"For a few pence, the rural economy in Britain is depleted - and the subsequent social and environmental costs of this depletion will then have to be paid for."

webTitle: French vineyards feel the New World squeeze

fields.headline: French vineyards feel the New World squeeze
fields.trailText: French wine sales to the UK fell by a record 15% last year as British drinkers, for long the world's most avid consumers of Bordeaux, Burgundy and the like, turned their noses up at what many now consider to be over-priced and over-hyped plonk.
fields.body:
French wine sales to the UK fell by a record 15% last year as British drinkers, for long the world's most avid consumers of Bordeaux, Burgundy and the like, turned their noses up at what many now consider to be over-priced and over-hyped plonk.

"Unless we do something drastic, in five years we'll be headed for catastrophe," Christian Delpeuch of the Bordeaux wine merchant Ginestet said, reflecting the anxiety of thousands of French growers at the figures released yesterday by the Wine and Spirits Export Association.

"The sad fact is that at least half the total output of the whole Bordeaux region now faces terrifying competition from New World wines, particularly Chilean and Australian.

"The Germans are snubbing us as well - things really couldn't look much grimmer."

Although the value of French wine and spirit exports remained stable last year at £4.9bn, the figure disguised a disastrous downturn in wine sales: exports to Germany dropped by 12% and global sales by 5%.

A 15% rise in spirit sales helped the total, the association said, particularly the remarkable revival in the fortunes of Cognac.

Although prestigious wine vintages continued to find an appreciative market, mid-range AOC (the appellation controlée system) and table wines were hit hard by the lower prices and aggressive marketing of wine growers in the US, Australia, New Zealand, Chile, Argentina and South Africa, the export association's president, Bertrand Devillard, said.

"Here in France we simply have too many constraints," he said.

"Whereas in Burgundy we may plant 300 hectares [750 acres] with vines over several years, the tax advantages growers are given abroad mean that in Chile they will be planting 450 hectares, and in Australia several thousand."

He said that France needed to relax the complex rules governing production and simplify the AOC system, which far from promoting Gallic quality simply confused many foreign drinkers.

fields.headline: Bleak future for small farms
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the countryside in crisis
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: In 1939, Britain could still be called a nation of small farmers. There were almost 500,000 farms, the majority fewer than 100 acres and worked by families. Between them they employed up to 15% of the population.
fields.body:
In 1939, Britain could still be called a nation of small farmers. There were almost 500,000 farms, the majority fewer than 100 acres and worked by families. Between them they employed up to 15% of the population. The rural economy revolved around them, they were a significant political and social force and their standing in the community was generally high.

Within 30 years, the number of farms had almost halved and by 1990 fewer than a quarter of the farmworkers had survived. In the last 10 years the number of farms has fallen a further 25% from 233,000 to 168,000.

The latest figures suggest that 42,000 farmers and farmworkers have left the industry in the past two years. Today about 2% of the workforce is actively engaged in farming.

In Ireland, a government inquiry into the state of small farms recently found that the numbers had declined by 90% in the last 20 years and that dairy farmers had fallen from 212,000 in 1974 to fewer than 30,000 today.

"The pressure on small farms is becoming more and more acute," it reported. "Only 20-30% of farmers can hope to make a profit and 37% cannot even get the minimum wage for agricultural workers. Yet 70% of the rural population continue to be largely dependent on agriculture."

Similarly, in mainland Europe, 200,000 farmers gave up agriculture in 1999.

But we may have seen nothing yet, says Michael Hart, of the Small Farms Alliance. "We have lost a third of all family farms in the past decade. There are still 100,000 under 120 acres, but more and more farmers are going part-time just to survive."

Ironically, small farms have been shown in study after study in Britain, the US and India to be more productive per acre, less polluting, better for employment and wildlife and environmental diversity.

In Britain "the government does not recognise the small farmer at all," says Mr Hart. "They see us purely in economic terms and say you're inefficient and must intensify. They take the line that it is inevitable that we will go. They have told us to diversify but they offer no way forward. They have done almost nothing to help us."

Without the small farm, production, distribution, sales and the rise of new ideas like organic farming becomes more and more concentrated into the hands of the few. "I can foresee the time when there are fewer than 10,000 people making decisions about farming in Britain," said one large-scale contract farmer.

fields.headline: The fat of the land
fields.standfirst:
Farming is a sick industry, but small

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farming is a sick industry, but small
fields.body:
There is a simultaneous danger of overreacting to the outbreak of foot and mouth disease on a number of English and Welsh farms and missing the ways in which this latest agricultural crisis ought to lead to fundamental change in the way livestock is reared, farms managed and food prepared and purchased.

Press and television pictures of those hecatombs of dead cattle and pyres of pigs have led some to come on like Homer. It is hard, however, to see anything epic in the condition of English agriculture. The killings and the disruption are disturbing but a sense of proportion is needed; the postponement of racing at Chepstow is no big deal. Animal farming accounts for small proportions of national income and employment. Meat shelves increasingly stocked from overseas may become acceptable to more consumers.

It is hard to separate this latest episode - an accident on present evidence - from the human costs of BSE and market changes, affecting for example sheep farmers. Yet again, the plight of a small number diminishes in the face of the thousands in steel, car and clothing manufacture. The urban working class do not perhaps attract quite the same bucolic sympathy as the rural poor. A note of exaggeration has been heard in some reporting: BBC editors may regret the way they let it be suggested without a shred of evidence that the virus might have been spread deliberately. Preposterous suggestions have been made, for example that the general election should be deferred because a handful of farms are quarantined.

By contrast the response of the authorities in affected areas has been calm and effective. County councils, the police, the much-maligned Ministry of Agriculture and the veterinary profession have mobilised to make heroic efforts in containing and tracking down carriers of the virus. We too often take for granted our public service infrastructure. Oddly, the unprepossessing figure of Nick Brown has fitted the occasion - he looks like a minister more concerned with managing a crisis than presentation.

Even if the causes of the outbreak have yet to be found, it is not too early to wonder what should happen next. How they laughed in Wales two years ago when a vegetarian was put in charge of agriculture. But perhaps the time has come for the cosy cartel of Maff, farmers and overly-solicitous politicians to be broken up. No longer should landowners be treated as if they invariably had the best interests of the countryside at heart. We are learning about the "poor" farmers who own multiple properties who make a living from trucking squealing pigs hundreds of miles around the country to be squeezed into sheds for brokerage in disease-ridden conditions of squalor. Those fattening pens are one of the faces of the Countryside Alliance - another shines from those pleasant market towns where, a survey this week shows, property prices have been rising nicely of late, more steeply even than in London.

Now, as never before, English animal husbandry needs to reinvent itself. As an industry it is, to put it bluntly, sick. Meat farmers do have a future, perhaps in smaller numbers, but more as conservers of land and animals and less as exploiters. Practices will need to change the length of the food chain, from slaughtering to supermarket to dining room. Food prices will have to rise - but in a nation where so many children are clinically obese, where diet and ill-health are all too closely associated and where cheap food is being increasingly shown to be unsafe to eat, that may be no bad thing.

webTitle: US has no problem with European force, says Powell

fields.headline: US has no problem with European force, says Powell
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Washington used a visit to Nato headquarters by the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, yesterday to send it clearest signal yet that it has no real problem with European Union plans to create a rapid reaction force.
fields.body:
Washington used a visit to Nato headquarters by the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, yesterday to send it clearest signal yet that it has no real problem with European Union plans to create a rapid reaction force.

In effect handing a pre-election gift to Tony Blair, Mr Powell told Nato foreign ministers that the Bush administration genuinely welcomed Europe's new defence initiative, and did not regard it as a threat.

"The United States supports and welcomes the creation of a European defence facility, and believes that as long as it avoids duplication measures and has some kind of joint planning arrangements with Nato that it will actually enhance and strengthen the alliance's capabilities," he is reported to have said.

Mr Powell went out of his way to hammer home the point at the extraordinary meeting of the North Atlantic Council, stressing that his view was shared by the entire Bush administration, including such ultra-conservatives as the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld.

His positive attitude to the European security and defence initiative (ESDI) delighted Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, who said Mr Powell had defused the issue, once and for all.

"It puts to bed any idea that there is going to be division between Europe and the United States on security," Mr Cook said.

The Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, also said the matter was no longer a source of contention, undermining the claim by the Tories that the plan to create a 60,000-strong force for crisis management and peacekeeping operations threatens Britain's "special relationship" with the United States.

"At present, if Europe wants to act, it's Nato or nothing, and that means the US or nothing," he said.

"There can be and will be no substitute for Nato, which remains the cornerstone of European defence.

"But it's right that Europe should have the ability to act together when Nato as a whole is not engaged, and there is no difference between the US and Europe on this."

Nevertheless, the shadow defence minister, Iain Duncan Smith, continued to argue that the new "Euro army" would be independent of Nato in terms of planning, and said that France for one was adamant that this was the way forward.

But the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, who met Mr Powell yesterday, sounded a more conciliatory note, avoiding the sometimes contentious detail surrounding the issue while defending the rapid reaction force.

"The risk to Nato, to the transatlantic link and to the Euro-American relationship, does not stem from what Europe is building. The risk could only come from Europe not doing it," he said.

Mr Powell left his audience in no doubt, however, that the controversial US plans for a national missile defence shield - dubbed Son of Star Wars - remain firmly on track, and he stepped up the US effort to ease the increasing European fear that the development could bring about a new arms race.

"We believe that it is our responsibility to have a missile defence shield to protect the United States and our friends and allies from rogue states," Mr Powell said.

He added that Washington was happy to consult other governments before moving ahead with the project.

But he said that the threat presented by rogue states such as Iraq and Iran was very real and necessitated a military response.

That was a widely recognised fact in Europe, and even in Russia, he said.

In effect handing a pre-election gift to Tony Blair, Mr Powell told Nato foreign ministers that the Bush administration genuinely welcomed Europe's new defence initiative, and did not regard it as a threat. "The United States supports and welcomes the creation of a European defence facility, and believes that as long as it avoids duplication measures and has some kind of joint planning arrangements with Nato that it will actually enhance and strengthen the alliance's capabilities," he is reported to have said. Mr Powell went out of his way to hammer home the point at the extraordinary meeting of the North Atlantic Council, stressing that his view was shared by the entire Bush administration, including such ultra-conservatives as the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld. His positive attitude to the European security and defence initiative (ESDI) delighted Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, who said Mr Powell had defused the issue, once and for all. "It puts to bed any idea that there is going to be division between Europe and the United States on security," Mr Cook said. The Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, also said the matter was no longer a source of contention, undermining the claim by the Tories that the plan to create a 60,000-strong force for crisis management and peacekeeping operations threatens Britain's "special relationship" with the United States. "At present, if Europe wants to act, it's Nato or nothing, and that means the US or nothing," he said. "There can be and will be no substitute for Nato, which remains the cornerstone of European defence. "But it's right that Europe should have the ability to act together when Nato as a whole is not engaged, and there is no difference between the US and Europe on this." Nevertheless, the shadow defence minister, Iain Duncan Smith, continued to argue that the new "Euro army" would be independent of Nato in terms of planning, and said that France for one was adamant that this was the way forward. But the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, who met Mr Powell yesterday, sounded a more conciliatory note, avoiding the sometimes contentious detail surrounding the issue while defending the rapid reaction force. "The risk to Nato, to the transatlantic link and to the Euro-American relationship, does not stem from what Europe is building. The risk could only come from Europe not doing it," he said. Mr Powell left his audience in no doubt, however, that the controversial US plans for a national missile defence shield - dubbed Son of Star Wars - remain firmly on track, and he stepped up the US effort to ease the increasing European fear that the development could bring about a new arms race. "We believe that it is our responsibility to have a missile defence shield to protect the United States and our friends and allies from rogue states," Mr Powell said. He added that Washington was happy to consult other governments before moving ahead with the project. But he said that the threat presented by rogue states such as Iraq and Iran was very real and necessitated a military response. That was a widely recognised fact in Europe, and even in Russia, he said.

fields.headline: Chief justice defies Mugabe's axe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's white chief justice refused to be sacked and replaced by a government supporter yesterday, setting the stage for a potentially violent struggle with President Robert Mugabe for control of the courts.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Johannesburg and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's white chief justice refused to be sacked and replaced by a government supporter yesterday, setting the stage for a potentially violent struggle with President Robert Mugabe for control of the courts.

The government's dismissal, of Anthony Gubbay was to have been the first step in a wider purge of judges who refuse to sanction the confiscation of white-owned farms, the oppression of political opponents, and the official flouting of the rule of law.

The justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, accused Mr Gubbay of misconduct and said he would be replaced tomorrow by a prominent Zanu-PF supporter, Godfrey Chidyausiku.

But Mr Gubbay said that would be illegal, and he would not vacate his court or official residence.

Earlier this month, his safety threatened by Mr Chinamasa, Mr Gubbay agreed to take early retirement in June.

The government is preparing to set up a disciplinary panel to sack other supreme court and high court judges who are considered to have a "Rhodesian mind-set". Whoever is chief justice will preside over the panel, and the government is apparently keen to ensure that its man is in place.

Mr Gubbay's lawyer issued a statement saying he opposed "the unlawful demands made by the minister of justice for him to vacate his chambers and house and any further unlawful action the minister of justice may take".

Mr Gubbay says he is now reconsidering his agreement to early retirement.

The information minister, Jonathan Moyo, justified the plan to remove judges by saying that Jews would not accept their "former Nazi tormentors" judging them.

The chairman of Zimbabwe's bar council, Adrian de Bourbon, backed Mr Gubbay. "They pushed him too far and he decided to fight back. I don't know how the government is going to react to this," he said.

Britain has pressed the EU and the Commonwealth to confront Mr Mugabe.

Sweden, which holds the EU presidency, says it is starting a "critical dialogue" with Mr Mugabe through its ambassador in Harare. The Commonwealth will send a team to investigate human rights abuses.

But it is to South Africa that many are looking, after President Thabo Mbeki bowed to growing criticism from foreign business interests, trade union allies and the judiciary of his policy of "constructive engagement" with Mr Mugabe.

Mr Mbeki said he would meet the Zimbabwean president soon to express concern at the increasing repression.

"We continue to be concerned about the situation in Zimbabwe," he said. "Some of the things that have been happening recently are to all of us as South Africans of very serious concern: things that are affecting the judges, affecting the press, apart from earlier questions to do with the land redistribution."

webTitle: Straw's tilt at 'money-mad' lawyers provokes fury

fields.headline: Straw's tilt at 'money-mad' lawyers provokes fury
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, was last night branded a "dangerous reactionary" by the legal profession after he claimed that lawyers would soon outnumber police officers and that the only thing they could ever agree about was "taking money off clients".
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, was last night branded a "dangerous reactionary" by the legal profession after he claimed that lawyers would soon outnumber police officers and that the only thing they could ever agree about was "taking money off clients".

Mr Straw, a qualified lawyer, launched his attack, aimed at defence lawyers in particular, when he was asked about his little-used anti-social behaviour orders during a crime reduction conference in Linton, Cambridgeshire. In reply he criticised the attitude taken by some defence lawyers in opposing such anti-crime measures.

"The reason why there are so many lawyers in our society, and the numbers have quadrupled in the past 25 years, is because lawyers never agree except about taking money off clients," claimed the home secretary, who on Monday outlined plans to give the prosecution a much stronger hand in the court room.

"Very aggressive defence lawyers sometimes forget about their wider social responsibilities and their responsibilities to the court, and in trying to protect their niche markets with the local criminal fraternity act in a way which would have been unacceptable when I was practising 25 years ago," said Mr Straw.

"It will not be long before there are more lawyers in the country than there are police officers, which is a trend that I for one do not support."

Mr Straw's criticism drew an angry response from the representatives of 10,000 barristers. "He betrays a dangerous reactionary attitude towards the criminal justice system," said Roy Amlot, Bar Council chairman. "The home secretary's dark and disturbing sentiments place too much emphasis on obtaining convictions regardless of their safety."

The Law Society, which represents 83,000 practising solicitors, was apopleptic. "It is extraordinary that Jack Straw, a lawyer himself, should disparage the profession in such a way," said the president, Michael Napier. "We are astonished by the inaccurate picture he has given of the solicitor's profession. There are, in fact, only 11,300 solicitors who represent people accused of crimes, compared with 125,000 police officers."

In the past, Mr Straw has attacked "BMW-driving civil liberties lawyers from the suburbs" for opposing his anti-social behaviour orders. He further angered civil liberties groups on Monday when he proposed to disclose previous convictions to juries in a limited number of cases. Liberty decribed the scheme as "a serious erosion of a key principle of the criminal justice system".

On the numbers, Mr Straw is strictly correct that at the current rate of growth, lawyers will soon outnumber police officers in England and Wales. In 1976, there were 3,881 barristers and 31,250 practising solicitors, compared with 109,547 police officers. Latest figures show that there are now 10,132 barristers, 82,700 practising solicitors, and a further 20,000 who are qualified but are not practising, compared with 124,614 police officers.

webTitle: Geldof expected to announce sale of Deckchair.com.

fields.headline: Taking a back seat
fields.standfirst:
Geldof expected to announce sale of Deckchair.com
More net news
fields.trailText: Geldof expected to announce sale of Deckchair.com.
fields.body:
Bob Geldof's online travel firm, Deckchair.com, is understood to be on the verge of being bought by AIM-listed Online Travel Corporation, writes John Cassy .

The move comes after Deckchair was forced to cut costs and staff and underlines consolidation taking place in the competitive internet travel market.

Ian Neale, Deckchair's head of sales and development, yesterday refused to comment on the talks but confirmed that 13 people, about a third of its workforce, had been laid off.

It is thought an agreement could be announced within the next fortnight.

Deckchair was founded by Mr Geldof, pictured, and former Eidos executive James Page in April 1999. Mr Geldof invested some of the £7m he made from the sale of TV production house Planet 24 to Carlton Communications. Other shareholders include pop promoter Sir Harvey Goldsmith and Marks & Spencer founding family the Seiffs.

The company was valued at £20m but is likely to be sold for a fraction of that.

Mr Page was the driving force of Deckchair in its early days but no longer plays an active role in its day to day running.
