fields.headline: Labour's lost loves
fields.trailText: School governors deserve Blunkett's thanks too
fields.body:
 Like John O'Farrell, I too am married to the Labour party (Awful, but I like it, February 24). Lots of us are. It is a kind of political polygamy. The party is the husband, we are the wives. When the party is out of power, wives who initiate things are popular. Once in power it is the wives who simper and do not make a fuss who are most often welcomed to the marital bed.

As school governors we campaigned against schools opting for grant-maintained status, for instance; we were very successful. Party spokespersons told us what a good job we were doing, how important we were. How different now. I, along with every other chair of governors, received a letter from David Blunkett introducing the summary of the government's schools green paper. In the letter he puts on record his appreciation for the work teachers and non-teaching staff have done to turn policy proposals into reality. Quite right, they do deserve thanks, but so do governors. We get no mention in the letter. A lot of us active Labour "wives" are beginning to feel like concubines outside the gates. Maybe that is why we are not rushing forward to help with the wedding anniversary celebrations.
Anthony Stoll
London ant@stoll.greatxscape.nett

 John O'Farrell is wrong when he says "we may enter a new phase - to help re-elect a Labour government for a second full term". Wrong if the government decides for an election before April 30 2002 - which is the full term for which Tony Blair and his colleagues were elected in 1997.

The problem is the custom whereby the prime minister of the day exercises his power to call an election when he/she thinks the time is most advantageous for the government party. Most other democracies do indeed have a fixed term and this is a simple electoral reform to put in place; governments could no longer play the economy or other issues for their own advantage. The only exception for an early election would be the loss of a vote of confidence or of the government's finance bill. Given that most recent governments have chosen to go to the electorate after four years, why not fix this as the life of the parliament? Let's have less about Labour seeking a second full term and more about re-electing a Labour government which will enact electoral reform during its second term.
Tony Mayer
Strasbourg amayer@esf.org

 I read Madeleine Bunting's article (The baby vote, February 26) with great interest. Here in Ardrishaig, mid- Argyll, we constitute a deprived community. Last May our small voluntary playgroup decided to expand, to come in line with our government's policy, and become a playgroup offering pre-school education for all under fives, and after-school care for working parents.

They have just been evicted from their premises in a public hall because they could not pay the increased fee. The treasurer ploughed through a huge volume of paperwork to apply for grants promised by the government. Grants were pledged in January, but the amount was halved; there were further delays, and they will now be paid at the end of March.

Money from the local authority for childcare has not been paid since January. MPs have been contacted, but to no avail. So now the playgroup has no money to pay its professional staff at the end of this week.

Pre-school education for all? You must be joking! This is a divided society, and it begins at nursery school.
Alison Walker
Ardrishaig, Argyll

fields.headline: Shifting alliances
fields.standfirst:
Even Nato may become obsolete one day
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Even Nato may become obsolete one day.
fields.body:
The problem with being a bridge is that you risk getting trampled on at both ends. Thus Tony Blair, with a foot in two camps but especially Camp David, is criticised on the European side for giving in to George Bush over missile defences and on the American side for hoodwinking that trusting Texan over the EU's plan for a rapid reaction force. Nato chief George Robertson is another exponent of balancing acts. Speaking in Brussels yesterday during a fleeting state visit by Colin Powell, he dismissed fears of an alliance split by the RRF plan. "There can be and will be no substitute for Nato," he intoned. This is a kind of mantra for Lord Robertson, to be repeated at bedtime perhaps and twice on Sundays. Indeed, the very fact that he loses no opportunity to stress "the vital importance of the transatlantic link" in Europe's security arrangements raises suspicions that at heart he knows it is a lot less vital now than, say, a dozen years ago when the Soviet empire menaced one and all.

In reassuring the Americans that nothing has changed, Lord Robertson, like Mr Blair, risks upending the seesaw and leaving French legs (and others) dangling in mid-air. The EU is perfectly entitled to create an autonomous defence force. It could even supplant the alliance one distant day. What is less clear is whether the Nato of the two Georges will be entitled, politically speaking, to veto its future activities. "Assets and capabilities", mutters Lord Robertson, pointing up Europe's lack of them. "It's unrealistic to imagine the US is going to give assets without any say over how those assets are used." But it is also unrealistic to believe that Washington's dominant role in European security, projected via Nato, will be indefinitely upheld by privately despised, subservient allies whose own capabilities are evolving and whose legitimate interests may be diverging.

While the US is simultaneously advocating missile systems of dubious utility but certain disruptiveness, antagonising Russia (not least by Nato's enlargement), and pursuing a half-hearted approach to Balkans peacekeeping, doubts about the alliance's indispensability to Europe will only grow. The message for Mr Powell to take home is that Europe, slowly but perceptibly (and rightly), is moving towards its own ideas of collective defence. To try to impose unilateral limits on that risks burning alliance bridges, not building them. Memo to the two Georges, cc. Tony: nothing is forever, not even Nato.

fields.headline: Nemesis at the farm
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth outbreak might be bad news for agri-business, but welcome news for animal welfare.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth outbreak might be bad news for agri-business, but not necessarily so for the four-legged "produce" of this industry (Panic felt across the west country, February 27). Live exports temporarily banned; hunting postponed; even the celebrated ripping apart of hares at the Waterloo cup scuppered. All welcome news for animal welfare.

Watching hypocritical farmers bewailing their stock as if they were beloved pets destined for a long life of care and comfort at the farm is hard to swallow. It might seem that with the foot and mouth crisis Nemesis has delivered a well aimed kick to the rumps of those who have for so long lived off the back of animal exploitation and cruelty.
Carol Williams
Tunbridge Wells, Kent

 As a cattle-wagon driver who went through the 1967 outbreak, can I offer a tip to anyone who has to use disinfectant during the current outbreak now that stocks are running out?

In 1967 the ministry issued an advice notice which said that the most effective disinfectant for the foot and mouth organism was ordinary washing soda in hot water. We mixed up a concentrated solution at home and carried this with us. It was cheap, easily available and, according to the ministry, very effective. It saved us a lot of money and time.
Stanley Challenger Graham
Barnoldswick, Lancs

 I have read that animals recover from this disease. I have also read that it doesn't affect humans. Perhaps I've missed something, but why can't we just wait for the animals to get better?
Bill Edmead
London

fields.headline: A global perspective
fields.trailText: Globalisation and Bush.
fields.body:
John Gray (Goodbye to globalisation, February 27) seems obsessed with the idea that globalisation must be American led and as a semi- isolationist president is in the White House, the globalisation project is over. Well, Gordon Brown seems to disagree; in calling for increased action on tackling global child poverty the chancellor is aware that globalisation will be very much alive in the coming decades. Gray's defeatist attitude is alarming. Sam Smedley
Colchester, Essex ssmedley@essex.co.uk

 As a historian I always knew that there was far too much hype about globalisation. John Gray's belated exorcism of another "isation" will mean, however, that next semester's new module, which I've spent an inordinate amount of time tooling up for, will have to be retitled "Globaloney in historical perspective". Ron Noon
Liverpool John Moores University

 John Gray reckons George Bush's emphasis on US protectionism is incompatible with globalisation. But global market leaders always pursue protectionism at home while opposing protectionism abroad. We did it in the 19th century and the US pursues the same policy today - whoever occupies the White House. Des McConaghy
Liverpool

webTitle: Letters: He won the booby prize

fields.headline: He won the booby prize
fields.trailText: Satire died the day Kissinger was awarded the Nobel peace prize.
fields.body:
Reading Christopher Hitchens's excerpts on Henry Kissinger (A nation betrayed, February 26), I am reminded of Tom Lehrer's comment that satire died the day Kissinger was awarded the Nobel peace prize. Each time I think of it, it gets funnier, although I suspect I'm not the only one who isn't laughing.
Doug Stratton
London

 I was interested in Simon Rumble's letter (February 24) about the high price of condoms. "Quid a shag" indeed: how romantic. Presumably less than the pint of XXXX that sets the scene.
Dulcie Evans
Teddington, Middlesex

 I kept my cool when they suggested Cliff Richard was gay; lost it when they said Austria's Freedom party leader, Haider, might be a pouf. Now you describe Eminem as "gay-looking" (Letters, February 27). I am starting a new group: Gay Men Who Do Not Need To Boost Their Self-esteem By Attributing Gayness To A Bunch of Tossers Whom Nobody In Their Right Mind Would Want To Have Sex With Anyway!
Paul Patrick
Burnley, Lancs

 Giles Smith (This time it's personable, G2, February 27), writes: "I would only consider heading into Chelmsford if either I or one of my passengers was haemorrhaging." I'm glad he didn't. Chelmsford is very congested and we already have enough bleeding smartasses.
Roger Brian
Chelmsford

webTitle: We police have feelings too, you know

fields.headline: We police have feelings too, you know
fields.trailText: I must declare an interest: I am a serving police officer. I do feel though, that while kicking a police officer in the head once might be considered an unfortunate accident, twice begins to look like carelessness (Arrested development, G2, February 27). I feel that Sally Weale accepts, a little too uncritically, Frances Whitehouse's rationalisation of her treatment by the police.
fields.body:
I must declare an interest: I am a serving police officer. I do feel though, that while kicking a police officer in the head once might be considered an unfortunate accident, twice begins to look like carelessness (Arrested development, G2, February 27). I feel that Sally Weale accepts, a little too uncritically, Frances Whitehouse's rationalisation of her treatment by the police.

If you read the facts in the article it would appear that the police were faced, on several occasions, by a couple, both of whom habitually use violence against each other and others. Is it unreasonable to consider arresting someone whose partner has just fallen through a second storey window during domestic violence? Particularly when, two weeks earlier, she had been arrested for possession of an offensive weapon (oh sorry, I forgot, she was just taking it home).

It is too easy to blame the police in these situations. I and many others I know and work with welcome the progressive stance taken by Paul Whitehouse and other senior police officers. The police still have much to do to change generations of attitudes and prejudice but so do many other bodies.

I do not recognise this picture of a uniformly racist, sexist and homophobic police service and I think you do a disservice to a great number of police officers who share the Guardian's ambitions for society.
Name and address supplied

 As a serving police officer in the Met, I know that there are many areas where the police needs to improve. Factual and balanced press coverage may well help. However, to assert (Mark Lawson, G2, February 26) that "serious analysis of the police is left to dramas such as Cops", is frankly incredible.

The evidence presented in Raw Blues may not fit Mark Lawson's view of the Met, but surely he cannot be suggesting that the fantasy of a TV crime fiction is more truthful than a fly-on-the-wall documentary?

What next? Peak Practice as a serious exposé of the health service? London's Burning as a behind the scenes examination of the fire service?
Ian Wiggett
Rickmansworth, Herts

fields.headline: It's clearly a vision thing
fields.trailText: Karl Sabbagh isn't the only film-maker being drilled into stupidity (Letters, February 27).
fields.body:
Karl Sabbagh isn't the only film-maker being drilled into stupidity (Letters, February 27). Among recent edicts to come my way are requests that no more than two talking heads be joined together without "pictures" and for no single interview segment to last more than 30 seconds. As for scripts, I have been asked to remove "subversive" from a mid-evening documentary on the grounds that the word was "too difficult".

New entrants to the industry may be better placed to cope. At a post-graduate seminar two weeks ago, I witnessed a senior BBC executive extol Big Brother and Popstars as the most important factual programmes of recent times. He seemed especially pleased to have discerned that "cruelty is the new watchword" for such shows. We are obviously moving back to an earlier civilisation. Bring on the gladiators! Send home the documentary makers!
Martin Smith
Bristol starlock@btinternet.com

webTitle: Leader: Treasury mistaken on London Underground

fields.headline: Dogma down the tube
fields.standfirst:
The Treasury should speak up or shut up

Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: More than 80% of Londoners are opposed to the government's part-privatisation of the underground system. Practically anyone who is anyone is against it except for one very important man: Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
More than 80% of Londoners are opposed to the government's part-privatisation of the underground system. Even the Conservatives have abandoned their plans to privatise it in the face of unremittingly hostile public opinion. Practically anyone who is anyone is against it except for one very important man: Gordon Brown.

The chancellor - and, to be fair, his department - are implacably opposed even though they know they have lost the argument with electors. They passionately believe that their public/private partnership model would not only leave most of the tube in public hands but would, for the first time, ensure that cost overruns on public projects are met by the private sector and not the taxpayer as happened with the Jubilee extension, which doubled in cost.

If this were true it would be a formidable argument. But opponents simply don't believe that the Treasury has found a solution to the endemic problem of controlling large projects. It points to the Channel Tunnel, a private sector project that doubled in cost, and the fast rail link to the channel that the private sector wouldn't build without a Treasury guarantee. It suggests Mr Brown and his colleagues should drop their political objections to Ken Livingstone and take the TGV on a journey around France ending up with the Paris Métro to see for themselves how government money and control can produce enviable results.

Tony Blair must sort this mess out very quickly. Not because there is an election in the offing but because London's collapsing transport infrastructure demands a speedy solution. If the Treasury, which has been remarkably shy to argue its own case in public, really thinks it has right on its side then it should speak up or shut up. But its case will need to be good. In Bob Kiley, London appears to have found the right man for the right job at the right time. And time is something that suffering underground passengers do not have on their side.

webTitle: Letters: Piers Morgan on Naomi Campbell

fields.headline: Mirror shows up Naomi
fields.trailText: I would never say that newspapers have "a duty to expose" celebrity role models who take drugs (A model of private respectability, February 26).
fields.body:
I would never say that newspapers have "a duty to expose" celebrity role models who take drugs (A model of private respectability, February 26). That would be an absurdly sanctimonious thing for the editor of a modern tabloid newspaper to claim - and I didn't. What I do think is that the press has a right to report the attendance of publicity-mad stars like Naomi Campbell at Narcotics Anonymous meetings, given the illegal activities that have led them there. If I were Ms Campbell, I would be more concerned about a curious knock on the door from the drugs squad than bleating about supposed invasions of privacy.
Piers Morgan
Editor, the Mirror

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Today's news
fields.body:
Bush says sorry for sinking

A special US envoy delivered a letter from President George Bush to the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, yesterday to apologise for the sinking of a fisheries training boat by an American submarine earlier this month.

Admiral William Fallon, the vice chief of naval operations, was also expected to meet the families of the nine Japanese missing in the accident. AP, Tokyo

300 immigrants land in Italy

Police rounded up more than 300 illegal immigrants who landed near Locri on the toe of Italy in an old fishing boat yesterday.

The vessel, believed to be from Turkey, is thought to have been at sea for eight to 10 days. It carried mostly Kurds, but Senegalese, Algerians, Pakistanis and Indians were also on board. Reuters, Rome

Jailed student 'not a US spy'

A US diplomat denied Russian domestic security service (FSB) claims yesterday that an American student arrested for buying drugs in the southern city of Voronezh had links to US military intelligence.

The diplomat said that John Tobbin, who has been denied bail, was not a spy as the FSB had claimed, calling him "just out of college". Reuters Moscow

Deadly fire ants invade Brisbane

South American fire ants have invaded Brisbane, prompting fears that the potentially deadly insects could spread through Australia.

The ants possess a nasty bite - which can be fatal in cases of allergic reactions. Three sites in Brisbane have been infested so far. AP, Sydney

webTitle: New York prisoner brokers a fraudulent fortune

fields.headline: New York prisoner brokers a fraudulent fortune
fields.trailText: When employees of his two securities brokerages asked what all the racket was when he talked to them on the telephone, Ira Monas always had a perfectly plausible explanation.
fields.body:
When employees of his two securities brokerages asked what all the racket was when he talked to them on the telephone, Ira Monas always had a perfectly plausible explanation.

Sometimes he said he was in a busy restaurant. On other occasions he blamed the noise on the fact that he was speaking from the other side of the Atlantic.

The truth is that Monas, 55, was making his calls from a noisy common room in an New York jail with fellow prisoners milling around in the background, according to documents lodged with a Manhattan court.

Through the din, it is alleged, Monas got his unwitting middle-men to persuade about 200 investors to part with $8.5m (£5.9m) in return for confirmation slips and statements that were not worth the paper they were printed on.

Monas was jailed 16 months ago for larceny and forgery in a securities fraud case. Sent to the Adironack medium security prison in Ray Brook for 2-4 years he resolved to make full use of his spare time.

He called his employees, instructing them to push the sales of securities in initial public offerings (IPOs) for United Parcel Service and two internet companies. He told his staff, some of whom had been told he had gone to Europe for health reasons, that he had access to securities through special relationships with the underwriters.

"Each was reported in the media as a hot IPO, meaning that they were oversubscribed and the securities difficult to purchase," Mary Jo White, United States attorney in Manhattan, said.

The money poured into bank accounts controlled by Monas and most was used to pay off personal and business debts. "None of the investors' funds were used to purchase securities for the investors," Ms White said.

Although some of the estimated 22,000 calls made each day from New York state prisons are monitored, state correction officials say, it is difficult to catch prisoners illegally conducting business because of the high volume.

fields.headline: Hague backtracks on tube sell-off
fields.trailText:
As Hague abandons plans to
privatise the London Underground speculation is intensifying
that Michael Portillo is strengthening his
grip on party policy.
fields.body:
William Hague will abandon Conservative plans to privatise the London Underground today, intensifying speculation that Michael Portillo is strengthening his grip on party policy - and pushing towards the centre ground.

The announcement, leaked last night, prompted the Tory right to claim that Mr Hague is increasingly a prisoner of his shadow chancellor who is busily courting what remains of the party's leftwing at Westminster with a view to a post-election leadership contest.

Faced with the deepening unpopularity of privatisation in the wake of Railtrack's problems, the Tories have decided to give their support to the alternative being proposed by Bob Kiley, the transport commissioner appointed by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone.

The latest Tory u-turn comes as Tony Blair struggles to get Mr Kiley the overall manage ment control he seeks within the broad framework of John Prescott's public/private partnership for revitalising the long-neglected underground.

Mr Kiley, an American whose smooth-talking popularity the Tories acknowledge, could be asked to chair a management board on which the three private firms running the underground will sit. "We've got to give this man a fair wind," one Hague aide said last night.

Within the Conservatives, the responsibility for junking the privatisation plan originally drawn up by John Redwood lies with the shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, and his transport spokesman, Bernard Jenkin - though Mr Portillo and Mr Hague have endorsed it.

The Redwood plan would have created park-and-ride schemes, competing underground lines, user-friendly stations and - in theory - given £750m back to the Treasury. Hague advisers said last night that "events have moved on" and that practical politics dictate that Mr Kiley deserves a chance.

Mr Redwood, former Welsh secretary and a failed Tory leadership candidate, thinks it is disastrous that some colleagues continue to speculate about Mr Hague's future so close to a spring election, when 56% of voters are said to be dissatisfied with his performance as party leader. "It's stupid and deeply disloyal," one Redwood supporter said.

Talk about a post-election leadership contest infuriates the Portillo camp, which says it is powerless to prevent people claiming to be "friends of Michael" spreading stories which they say are damaging both to him and to the authority of Mr Hague, already battered by polls which show him trailing up to 20% behind Labour under Tony Blair.

"There are no outriders licensed to speak for Michael," advisers said last night. The finger of suspicion is largely directed at a wider group of supporters. But Mr Portillo's decision to address the Mainstream group of Tory moderates at next weekend's spring conference in Harrogate has also contributed to the speculation about his intentions.

Moderate MPs have been making friendlier noises about Mr Portillo since he embraced a socially inclusive agenda. That, too, has offended the right.

Ann Widdecombe is not seen as whispering against "William" and believes he will survive if he can win 40 seats and get the Conservatives back above 200 MPs. But some MPs say Iain Duncan Smith and David Davis, both on the right, are quietly positioning themselves in case Mr Hague is voted out by MPs.

Tory jitters about their party's likely fate in an election were enhanced last night by private Liberal Democrat polling among 1,200 voters in key seats. The results are said to show that 66% think Mr Hague would say anything to get elected. His personal ratings are reported to be low among voters in terms of qualities of leadership and honesty.

Moderate MPs have been making friendlier noises about Mr Portillo since he embraced a socially inclusive agenda. That, too, has offended the right. Ann Widdecombe is not seen as whispering against "William" and believes he will survive if he can win 40 seats and get the Conservatives back above 200 MPs. The results are said to show that 66% think Mr Hague would say anything to get elected. His personal ratings are reported to be low among voters in terms of qualities of leadership and honesty.

fields.headline: Microsoft judge accused of bias
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of
Microsoft
More net news
fields.trailText: A US judge who publicly discussed his opinion of Microsoft after he had ordered the software company to be broken up was criticised in the US court of appeals yesterday.
fields.body:
A US judge who publicly discussed his opinion of Microsoft after he had ordered the software company to be broken up was criticised in the US court of appeals yesterday.

Microsoft's lawyer told the second day of an appeal hearing that the interview remarks showed bias and should lead the court to nullify the verdict. A government lawyer argued that the comments of US district judge Thomas Penfield Jackson were not enough to warrant overturning the decision.

Harry Edwards, chief judge of the US court of appeals for the District of Columbia, took Mr Jackson to task, however. "The system would be a sham if all judges went around doing this," he said.

Microsoft lawyer Richard Urowsky said Judge Jackson's interviews were a reason the court of appeals should overturn the lower court's ruling.

"What the statements suggest is actual bias," Mr Urowsky argued.

Judge Jackson had compared Bill Gates to Napoleon and his company to a group of killers. Microsoft has complained that Judge Jackson was biased and conducted the lower-court trial unfairly.

Bill Kovacic, an anti-monopolies expert at George Washington University, said after the first day of oral arguments that the seven appeals court judges might separate Judge Jackson's handling of the case from his conclusions. "Part of what may happen is nothing other than an attempt to rebuke Judge Jackson for, in some sense, showing up the court," he said.

After a difficult first day of questioning, lawyers for Microsoft and the government argued yesterday about whether the software company used its dominance to try to monopolise the market for web browsers and whether the proposed break-up remedy was justified.

The tenor of the judge's questions on the first day of oral arguments cast doubt on whether the decision to break up the company would survive the appeals court.

webTitle: Spread of foot-and-mouth virus brings new chaos

fields.headline: Spread of virus brings new chaos
fields.standfirst: • Racing and rugby abandoned • Six new outbreaks confirmed
fields.trailText: Six new foot and mouth outbreaks were confirmed yesterday, affecting four counties previously free of the disease, as disruption to normal life in Britain worsened.
fields.body:
Six new foot and mouth outbreaks were confirmed yesterday, affecting four counties previously free of the disease, as disruption to normal life in Britain worsened.

All race meetings were abandoned for a week and the rugby union international between Wales and Ireland on Saturday was cancelled. Emergency orders were rushed through parliament to give councils the power to ban the use of footpaths and public rights of way.

The minister of agriculture, Nick Brown, extended the ban on the movement of animals for a further two weeks from Friday as the disease spread into Wales for the first time and hundreds more checks were made on stock across the country. The number of confirmed cases now totals 18.

But the selected movement of some cattle, pigs and sheep would be allowed direct to abattoirs from Friday, provided there was no mingling with other animals, to maintain supplies of meat in the shops and prevent welfare problems, Mr Brown said. The army, which has its own vets, has volunteered to supervise the movements.

The government also decided to give the beef, sheep and dairy industry £170m extra compensation for losses caused by the disaster, in addition to 100% payments for slaughtered animals. Pig breeders will receive £40m in payments - which will buy them out and reduce the size of the industry.

Mr Brown called the outbreak "a national tragedy".

As the air of crisis deepened, Tony Blair chaired a meeting of ministers from most Whitehall departments. In a webcast from No 10, Mr Blair admitted the gravity of the situation: "The funeral pyres of farm animals are the worst nightmare for the livestock farmers. And it is not just financial loss, massive as that is _ the heartbreak also comes from all the hard work and planning, often over many years."

Last night up to 1,000 workers in three food production plants in the north-east - at Preston, Cottingham and Carnaby - were laid off indefinitely or placed on short-time. County councils were given the power to order the closure of footpaths in their jurisdiction.

A farmer in Anglesey, where an outbreak was confirmed yesterday, was stopped by police trying to move sheep by lorry at night.

The Jockey Club, under pressure from trainers who exercise their horses on farmland, abandoned all racing for a week but plans to resume in the hope of saving the Cheltenham festival, the showpiece of the National Hunt season, due to begin in a fortnight. Ireland also suspended all horse and greyhound racing.

The decision to cancel Saturday's rugby international was taken after the Irish government expressed concern at the risk of Ireland supporters bringing the disease back with them from England and Wales.

In Brussels, the veterinary committee of the EU extended the ban on exports of all British meat and dairy products for a second week until March 7 - and said it would repeat the exercise next week if necessary.

Elsewhere in Europe, the slaughter of animals exported from Britain continued, with 20,000 sheep to be killed in France, 11,500 pigs, 2,400 sheep and 1,900 deer killed in the Netherlands and, in Germany, a further 1,600 sheep in addition to the 360 killed on Monday.

The six new outbreaks confirmed yesterday were in Anglesey, Lancashire, Northamptonshire, Devon and two in Durham.The lamb found to have the disease at the Welsh County Foods abattoir at Gaerwen, Anglesey, had been delivered from Yorkshire and vets were checking which flock it had come from.

Another new contact was at a farm at Wolsingham, Co Durham, where owner Peter Monkhouse said he had bought the infected sheep from Darlington market. Yesterday neither of these cases had links with previous centres of the disease.

The sheep that had developed foot and mouth at Ollerton farm, Withnell, Chorley, Lancashire, came from Hexham market, which was already linked to the Northumberland outbreak.

An infected lamb from Wootton market, Northamptonshire, was traced to the farm in Highampton, Devon, where more than 1,000 animals are already being slaughtered. A fifth case was confirmed last night from an abattoir at Witton le Wear, Co Durham. The day's sixth confirmed case was at an abattoir in Okehampton, Devon.

Jim Scudamore, the chief veterinary surgeon, said yesterday he was still hopeful that all the cases in Britain could be traced back to the original outbreak at Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland.

"All these sheep cases, widely spread as they are, seem to be in the early stages of the disease. It is still possible that there is another source but we are still hopeful that all the foot and mouth can be traced back to where it we think it began in Northumberland."

fields.headline: Bush's upbeat budget message
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush gave American voters and the watchful financial markets the sort of upbeat economic message they most love to hear yesterday: they were so well off that they could afford to have it all.
fields.body:
George Bush gave American voters and the watchful financial markets the sort of upbeat economic message they most love to hear yesterday: they were so well off that they could afford to have it all.

A widely trailed budget speech to the joint houses of Congress last night had him telling Americans he would spend billions more dollars on education and defence and allow them to invest parts of their state pensions in private sector funds.

To do this, he looked likely to change one article of faith previously shared by Republicans and Democrats - that the federal government debt should be eliminated as soon as possible.

Aiming to repay only part of what is owed would help give him room for his $1,600bn (£1,100bn) tax-cut giveaway during the coming decade.

Financial and political analysts will be poring over the fine print of Mr Bush's address, which he called a "blue print for new beginnings", trying to work out its likely impact in America and beyond. In particular, attention will be fixed on whether the tax bonanza will do enough, fast enough, to head off a US-led global economic downturn.

Mr Bush's $1,900bn budget for 2002 is seen by friend and foe as the most important political initiative of his first phase in the White House.

At its centre is the tax-cutting package which public opinion polls say Americans do not especially want - a Washington Post survey yesterday showed just 22% of Americans see it as a top priority - but which the Republicans believe holds the key to their election battles against the Democrats in 2002 and 2004.

The latest figures showed US consumer confidence falling to a four-year low yesterday.

Whether Mr Bush can deliver the best of all worlds to all Americans - and whether this can stave off recession in European and Asian markets - is open to question.

His budget plans depend heavily on a projected $5,600bn surplus in the federal budget in the next 10 years. Those projections will look doubtful if the US economic downturn develops - and will go up in smoke if the US slides into recession.

The most striking new aspect of Mr Bush's budget is that it backs away from the goal of eliminating the federal debt as soon as possible.

The debt stands at $3,400bn and is expected to fall to $3,200bn by the start of the next financial year in the spring of 2002. But instead of reiterating the view that it should be paid off in just over a decade, Mr Bush last night said he aimed to eliminate $2,000bn of it in that time, leaving $1,200bn outstanding.

White House officials justified this by saying that it reflected technical difficulties in debt redemption - but this is evidently the money the Bush camp sees as giving the president the wherewithal for his spending commitments and his tax cuts.

webTitle: Nato to scale back Serb buffer zone

fields.headline: Nato to scale back Serb buffer zone
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato to reduce the buffer zone preventing Serb forces from coming within three miles of Kosovo.
fields.body:
Nato agreed to a "phased" reduction in the buffer zone preventing Serb forces from coming within three miles of Kosovo as concern about the activities of extremist ethnic Albanians in the area increased yesterday.

The decision was taken at a meeting of Nato foreign ministers attended by the US secretary of state, Colin Powell. "The United States will participate in whatever action the alliance believes is necessary," he said.

He said the message to ethnic Albanian extremists was: "This is not the time to start a new conflict in Europe."

Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, said military advisers would work out how to plan a "phased and conditioned reduction of the ground safety zone".

The Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, has proposed that the demilitarised zone, from which all Serb forces except lightly armed police are banned, should be abolished.

British defence officials have suggested that EU troops and police should combine forces with Serb soldiers to control attacks by Albanian guerrillas.

Tension has increased since K-For stepped up patrols in the autumn after ethnic Albanian militiamen began trying to take over three Albanian towns in southern Serbia.

webTitle: Impatient Nick Brown unmoved by critics

fields.headline: Impatient Brown unmoved by critics
fields.standfirst:
Dismay at Tory stance key to reluctance to debate crisis

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who is leading the battle against the nationwide outbreak of foot and mouth disease, found himself fighting on a second front yesterday as senior Conservatives attacked his handling of the crisis.
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who is leading the battle against the nationwide outbreak of foot and mouth disease, found himself fighting on a second front yesterday as senior Conservatives attacked his handling of the crisis.

Some MPs found Mr Brown's tone during Monday's Commons statement unsympathetic to the farmers' plight. Although many Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs were supportive, some Tories were angry at Mr Brown's apparent reluctance to embrace the Opposition's decision to stage a three-hour debate on the foot and mouth crisis today. Mr Brown told MPs that such a debate was a waste of ministerial and official resources at a critical time. He restated his position on his return from briefing EU colleagues in Brussels yesterday.

"It's not debates in parliament that control the disease, it's hard veterinary work on the ground. We should all be working together to exterminate the disease. I deplore people turning this into a party political issue," he said.

Labour MPs admitted yesterday that Mr Brown had got this a bit wrong. "He should have said 'I'll give the house regular statements instead'," conceded one colleague. "He sounded tetchy, but he must be tired and under pressure," said another.

What most MPs seem to have forgotten is the history that lies behind the tiff. When the Phillips report on the great BSE disaster - home-grown, unlike the almost-certainly imported foot and mouth outbreak - was published last October, some Labour MPs were cross that the agriculture minister refrained from putting the party political boot in on culpable Tory ministers and their policies.

That did not incline the Tory agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo to soft pedal last week, though he pulled back in the Commons on Monday, adopting what Brown called "a welcome change of tone".

It came too late to placate officials at the Ministry of Agriculture. "Yeo was very critical of ministers, vetinerary staff and officials. It's a bit disheartening and Nick's fed up with it," explained one ally. Such is the ill-will that Mr Brown has not felt able to call in Mr Yeo, an amiable lightweight on the Tory left, to brief him. Mr Brown can point to support from fellow EU farm ministers, not always a charitable lot where Britain is concerned. Several have contrasted their own states' dithering over the slaughter of potentially-at-risk herds with Whitehall's steely determination to act fast and firmly.

Asked if he had been criticised by any of them, Mr Brown yesterday told reporters: "Absolutely not. All expressed their sympathy both in public and private. There is nothing but goodwill to Britain in our plight."

Mr Brown, 50, a former advertising executive with Procter and Gamble in Newcastle, his adopted city, came to agriculture in 1998 after being moved sideways from chief whip.

"My local NFU like him because he's pragmatic and level-headed. He doesn't pretend to be an expert," a young Essex MP said yesterday.

"Welsh farmers like him because he talks straight, tells them what he knows and what he doesn't. There's no spin," said a Welsh veteran.

fields.headline: Rural fear and loathing
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Rural people are asking whether they are the victims of biological warfare.
fields.body:
The Animal Liberation Front says it considers the houses of anyone who goes on the Countryside Alliance March for Liberty and Livelihood a "legitimate target". This week the march was cancelled to avoid risking the spread of the livestock plague, foot and mouth disease, which had burst suddenly across the countryside. Now rural people are asking whether they are the victims of biological warfare.

If it seems to you townies that when it comes to agriculture it's just one damn thing after another, imagine how it appears to farmers. In the past I've had Welsh sheep farmers ask me if I thought their misfortunes had been deliberately inflicted on them as a part of some ethnic cleansing operation, whereby the peasantry would be replaced by Tony's cronies.

But recently the agricultural depression seemed to be stabilising. Hundreds of thousands of country people and their supporters were poised to demonstrate in London that they mattered and that their traditions and heritage mattered too. Hope was in the air. But now it's disease that has killed businesses and countryside march together.

It took several days for everyone to understand how serious the outbreak of foot and mouth in Northumberland was.

Hunts had initially suspended operations for a week. Our local hunt hoped they would soon be up and running again, since they rely on an extended season that enables them to attract followers from richer hunts that close earlier in the year. However, as more and more email messages noted the locations of new cases of foot and mouth, it became clear that there would be no late season in 2001.

Bad news for my husband's hunt, but on the farm he could thank his lucky stars that he had already closed down his outdoor pig unit. With the pigs gone the farm is now entirely arable - although having to make a man redundant seems a strange thing for which to be grateful.

Half an hour's drive away my brother-in-law has spent the past few years gradually building up an organic beef herd of rare Long Horn cattle. If they catch foot and mouth and have to be put down they could never be replaced.

To try and prevent this from happening, strips of old carpet have been soaked in disinfectant and placed across farm roads and public footpaths; but, as my brother- in-law pointed out to me at the time, all this was pointless if we were all going to go to London on March 18 and tread in each others footsteps. The demonstration would have to be cancelled.

So much time, effort and money has gone into arranging the march that I wouldn't at first believe it. I had arranged for a vegetarian and her family to guard my home while I was away. I was planning on getting the police involved, too, as paranoia had come to me early.

For I had been commissioned to write a long article about the march to be published in a glossy magazine next month. There was to be a large photograph of me, the guilty author, beside the interviews with the fashionable urban people who were to have supported the march.

The portrait would be ideal for people to throw darts at, or, as I worried, to paste up on bedroom walls along with instructions on how to make pipe bombs. It seemed unfair to leave a vegetarian alone, armed with nothing more lethal than a bag of sprouts, against armed men in balaclavas out to get me.

By Monday, even Ken Livingstone had had the damn cheek to say that it would be irresponsible for the Alliance to continue with their march. That afternoon they announced a postponement. Thousands of coaches now had to be cancelled, along with trains and even ferries (not to mention my hotel and lunch reservation). The party in Battersea park will go down the plughole and I assume the fundraiser at the old Hammersmith Palais will be cancelled too.

webTitle: Family braced for loss of 1,000 sheep and three weeks at home

fields.headline: The farm - Family braced for loss of 1,000 sheep and three weeks at home
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Family braced for loss of 1,000 sheep and three weeks at home
fields.body:
The snow-covered fields surrounding Ollerton Farm in Withnell, Lancashire, were eerily quiet yesterday.

Usually the fields are home to 1,000 sheep which graze alongside the busy main road. But yesterday as foot and mouth disease was confirmed, there was no livestock in sight.

The farm, equidistant between Chorley and Blackburn, is the first in the north-west of England to have a confirmed case of foot and mouth disease.

The track to the farm was sealed off by police and only Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) officials were allowed through. Anyone who had been on the farm had their shoes or car wheels washed by a council worker, armed with a container of strong disinfectant.

Arthur Pooley, the farmer at the centre of the outbreak, said he was a virtual prisoner in his home.

He and his family expect to stay on the sheep farm, where they have lived for 18 years, for at least three weeks.

Mr Pooley first learned of a possible risk of foot and mouth last Friday when it emerged that one of his sheep was traced back to Hexham market in Northumberland. The market had been affected by foot and mouth after animals from an infected farm in Ponteland were sold there.

Over the weekend, Mr Pooley contacted a vet who carried out tests. The farmer then erected a sign at his gate warning that the farm was under observation. Disinfected straw was spread around for vehicles to drive over.

"I have over 1,000 sheep and I will lose them all," he said yesterday. "I expect I will not be able to go out for a while, but I have enough supplies to last me for three weeks. I don't think I will have spread it to any other farms."

A funeral pyre will be lit for the sheep carcasses at lunchtime today.

David Carroll, a driver and odd-job man who lives opposite the farm, said trucks full of sheep regularly arrived at the farm. "The lorries come backwards and forwards every day and they usually come from Cumbria. As far as I am aware, they don't slaughter the animals down there."

Mr Carroll said he was worried about his two horses contracting foot and mouth disease. "We have had one of them ever since it was a foal," he said. "I just hope it doesn't get it."

At a neighbouring farm, the farmer said it was a big worry having foot and mouth disease on his doorstep. "We haven't left the farm and nobody has been on to the farm," he said.

The 1967 outbreak of foot and mouth disease had badly affected many farms in the Blackburn area.

Pensioner Brenda Bodley, who lives opposite Ollerton Farm, said: "This has probably happened because farmers move animals around far too much. It is a disaster for the countryside really. A lot of people rely on agriculture and it is devastating for them."

Veronica Waller, of Lancashire NFU, urged people to stay away from the countryside. She said they already had disaster on their hands and need to prevent the consequences from being much worse.

Staff at Withnell post office, which was quiet yesterday, said farmers had been taking extra precautions since the onset of foot and mouth disease. "I used to deliver newspapers to farmers' doors," one said. "But now I have been dropping off their papers at a box at the farm gates. The only reason we have not had so many people coming in here is because of the cold."

webTitle: Frozen baby brought back to life

fields.headline: Frozen baby brought back to life
fields.standfirst: Doctors expect 'miracle' girl to make almost a full recovery
fields.trailText: She was found half frozen and without a heartbeat. But a Canadian toddler being called a miracle baby is expected to make almost a full recovery after wandering out into sub-zero temperatures wearing nothing more than a nappy.
fields.body:
She was found half frozen and without a heartbeat. But a Canadian toddler being called a miracle baby is expected to make almost a full recovery after wandering out into sub-zero temperatures wearing nothing more than a nappy.

The little girl, who recently had her first birthday, was revived in hospital in Edmonton, Alberta, despite being recorded as clinically dead when she arrived. Her heart is thought to have stopped for two hours.

"Clearly, something or someone was on this little girl's side on Friday night," said Allan De Caen, the doctor responsible for bringing the baby back to life with a special electric blanket that blew warm air over her body.

The toddler, whose name is not being released, was sleeping in bed with her mother last Friday night when she got up, opened the back door and went outside. It was -17C (1F) with a wind-chill factor that reduced the temperature to -29C (-20F).

When the mother woke up hours later and began frantically searching for the little girl, she followed her footprints in the snow. She may have been in the garden, the mother says, for anything from 30 minutes to five hours.

One of the paramedics at the scene had been involved in a similar case in Saskatchewan in 1994, where a two-year-old girl was revived after being locked out accidentally.

The child in the present case was taken to hospital and after being warmed up regained consciousness. Since then, she has been smiling and babbling with her mother. Doctors say there appears to be no serious brain damage, though it is too early to tell for sure. She may, however, lose some of her toes or even a foot to frostbite.

Police investigated but decided no one was at fault and are laying no charges.

There are reported to be at least a dozen similar "miracles" in the medical literature.

Peter Cox, an expert in the field who works at the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto, says people can survive such trauma provided their metabolic rate slows down.

As the body cools, the heart slows down and provides less oxygen to the cells. At the same time, the cells must begin to demand less energy. "If you can maintain this balance so that by the time the heart stops beating, the cells' requirement is minimal, then they can function on reserves. That is why a situation like this can come out in such a positive manner."

webTitle: Balkans teeter on brink of fresh conflict

fields.headline: Balkans teeter on brink of fresh conflict
fields.standfirst:
Clashes with ethnic Albanians could destabilise Macedonia
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Clashes between a newly formed ethnic Albanian paramilitary group and Macedonian security forces have heightened international concern that a new war zone may be emerging in the Balkans.
fields.body:
Clashes between a newly formed ethnic Albanian paramilitary group and Macedonian security forces have heightened international concern that a new war zone may be emerging in the Balkans.

While fighting between Serb police and ethnic Albanian guerrillas continues in the Presevo valley on the north-eastern border of Kosovo, the new conflict is threatening to destabilise neighbouring Macedonia on the south-eastern border. It has already claimed one life.

The guerrillas fighting the Macedonian army have warned of an "explosion" of violence in the region and one gunman assured the Guardian: "We are not afraid."

He spoke as two hours of intense fighting raged on Monday between the newly formed ethnic Albanian National Liberation Army (NLA) and Macedonian forces.

The NLA, which has the same command structure as the former Kosovo Liberation Army, emerged only six weeks ago from the village of Tanusevc, just inside the Macedonian border.

Monday's exchange of fire, which included grenade-launchers and light artillery, prompted frightened women and children to flee across the border into Kosovo; more than 300 people have left their homes here in the past week.

The situation prompted the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, to go on national television and warn that the NLA could "jeopardise Macedonia's stability".

Although diplomats fear that the fighting could easily spread across the country, in which a quarter of the population is Albanian, the guerrillas' roots are clearly inside Kosovo.

It is possible that the fighting is motivated as much by personal gain as nationalist idealism: the borders between Macedonia, Serbia and Kosovo are well-troden smuggling routes. British Royal Marines seized £1m worth of contraband cigarettes in the area late last month.

But with two ethnic Albanian guerrilla armies in southern Serbia and Macedonia, the UN-administered province is thought to be an convenient springboard for the operations of Albanian nationalists.

Furthermore, the Nato-led peacekeeping force in Kosovo, K-For, seems unable, and in some cases unwilling, to tackle the problem.

Both guerrilla groups are operating along boundaries that fall within the United States army's area of responsibility.

Although its troops are theoretically responsible for patrolling the frontier with Macedonia, it has imposed a one-mile exclusion zone to prevent them straying across the frontier. This "forced-protection" measure has effectively given the NLA the freedom to go in and out of Kosovo as it pleases.

The group's staging post is said to be Vitina, an unimpressive Kosovan town five miles north of the Macedonian border. It is there, according to K-For and UN, that the NLA has set up recruitment and fundraising centres for associated rebel groups in southern Serbia and Macedonia.

Dimitri Mandjavidze, director of the Vitina office of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), says the town is the main supply route for the Albanian guerrilla army in southern Serbia, known as the UCPMB.

Two men, Xhavit Hassani and Skender Habbibi, are alleged to be at the core of these activities.

Mr Hassani, who comes from Tanusevc, was arrested last year by the UN police and deported to Skopje, accused of shooting a policemen.

Four Macedonian border guards, taken hostage near Tanusevc at about the same time, were freed when he was released on bail.

Several Macedonian newspapers accuse Mr Hassani of being the leader of the NLA, a charge he denies.

Mr Habbibi was arrested earlier this month by US troops and is being kept in a military prison for allegedly recruiting men to "raise funds" for the Albanian guerrillas fighting in the Presevo valley.

His arrest prompted protests in Vitina on February 7 and four arson attacks on Serb properties near the UN and OSCE compounds in the town.

"This was clearly an attempt to put pressure on us, the international community, to release [Mr Habbibi], and steer clear of their activities," one official said.

The UN police claim that extortion rackets have been set up to help fund the guerrillas' activities.

The UCPMB itself admits it is receiving donations from a revived fund used before and during the war in Kosovo, called The Homeland Calling.

"They were always collecting money ... It's nothing surprising," a local shopowner, Dimitri Mandjavidze, said, admitting that he had given some money to an anonymous fund. "It is seen as being for the good of Kosovo Albanians. Where it goes is another matter."

fields.headline: Dando case ban lifted
fields.trailText: Nine months after the arrest and two days into the trial of the man accused of murdering Jill Dando, a judge yesterday ruled that photographs and drawings of Barry Michael George can be published for the first time.
fields.body:
Nine months after the arrest and two days into the trial of the man accused of murdering Jill Dando, a judge yesterday ruled that photographs and drawings of Barry Michael George can be published for the first time.

The decision by Mr Justice Gage overturned a ban brought into force at Bow Street magistrates court and upheld at the Old Bailey after Mr George was committed to stand trial in October.

Mr George has denied murdering Dando, who was shot in the back of the head on April 26 1999 outside her home in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, west London.

He was in the dock of court No 1 at the Old Bailey yesterday, clutching a New English Bible he has kept with him since his arrest, to hear the trial judge's decision that pictures and sketches could be used by the media. It followed representations from Associated Newspapers, publishers of the Daily Mail, Evening Standard and Mail on Sunday.

Details of the legal arguments which led to the ruling cannot be published until the end of the trial.

Dando's fiance, Alan Farthing, a gynaecologist, and Nick Ross, her co-presenter on the BBC programme Crimewatch UK, were in court to follow the course of legal deliberations that are not likely to be resolved until tomorrow. A jury might not be sworn in until Friday.

Mr George, 40, who changed his name by deed poll to Bulsara in tribute to his idol, the singer Freddie Mercury, lived close to Dando in Fulham. He pleaded not guilty to murdering the BBC presenter, who was 37 when she died, at an earlier hearing.

webTitle: Some cull, others watch and wait

fields.headline: Some cull, others watch and wait
fields.standfirst:
Wide variation in measures by import states
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Wide variation in measures by import states.
fields.body:
Germany

The incineration of all sheep from stocks imported from Britain in the past two months is underway. The government is also considering destroying the thousands of sheep and pigs imported in the same period. Several farms are under quarantine. A week-long ban on livestock markets also comes into force today.

Customs officials have instructions to confiscate animal products from people arriving from Britain by road, air and sea. Packed lunches could even be affected: one paper reported that a British man who arrived in Hamburg by ferry yesterday had to hand over a bottle of milk.

France

France yesterday ordered the slaughter of 20,000 sheep imported from Britain since February 1. No case of foot and mouth disease has been found but authorities say all animals imported from Britain in the past 30 days are being actively traced and will be quarantined if they have not already been slaughtered.

Farms and abattoirs that had contact with British livestock, as well as British refrigerated lorries arriving at Calais or other Channel ports, were subject to extra inspections.

Spain

Madrid yesterday ordered the slaughter of any animal imported from Britain in the past month. At least 2,000 sheep and pigs could be affected. Farmers' unions called for a temporary ban on the transport of pigs within the EU.

Belgium

The government has shut livestock markets for a week and banned the transport of sheep and goats around the country until further notice, but is not slaughtering the several thousand animals imported from Britain since February 1. It says it is watching them.

In the centre of Brussels the meat shelves in Marks & Spencer's food section are largely bare and at the large Ciney cattle market there was anger: "It was the English who pushed for abolishing Europe's foot and mouth vaccination programme and look where we are now," said one veterinary inspector, Paul Pilotte.

The Netherlands

Over 4,000 sheep, deer and other livestock imported from Britain have already been destroyed as well as any animals that may have come into contact with British livestock. But some imported animals had already been re-exported. Livestock markets have been shut down for a week.

Ireland

The Irish Republic has stepped up its ban on British livestock, meat and dairy product imports. Hundreds of policemen are at checkpoints across the country, including the Northern Ireland border where vehicles are being made to drive across disinfectant mats. Disinfection facilities are operating at ports and airports.

Livestock markets and hunting have been cancelled, and people may be asked to avoid the Cheltenham racing festival in March, if it goes ahead.

Switzerland

Meat originating in Britain is banned, including meat that travellers might bring in sandwiches, though airport checks are not planned. Switzerland has also warned travellers not to go near farms or animals while in Britain and to avoid contact with Swiss farms for a week after returning home.

Switzerland Meat originating in Britain is banned, including meat that travellers might bring in sandwiches, though airport checks are not planned. webTitle: Woman on trial for gang rape

fields.headline: Woman on trial for gang rape
fields.standfirst: 18-year-old 'admitted she hit and held down' woman beside canal
fields.trailText: A woman aged 37 was held down while her clothes were ripped off and her face punched by another female, whose friends, seconds later, "piled in" to gang rape her, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman aged 37 was held down while her clothes were ripped off and her face punched by another female, whose friends, seconds later, "piled in" to gang rape her, a court heard yesterday.

Claire Marsh, 18, admitted to police that she struck her victim to the ground and held down her arms before another gang member kicked the woman in the head.

One 14-year-old member of the group said Marsh yanked off the woman's top to expose her breasts. The victim described how a girl, believed to be Marsh, laughed throughout her ordeal and rallied the rapists - one of whom approached "with a smile on his face" - with the cry, "go on, give her some".

The extent of Marsh's alleged involvement during the savage attack in west London last summer emerged during a trial at Blackfriars crown court, central London, yesterday in which she was jointly charged, with four others, with rape.

Although it is not the first time in British legal history that a woman has been charged with rape, Marsh is believed to be the youngest charged with the offence.

Scotland Yard holds no statistics on the exceptionally rare crime of women raping women.

Marvin Edwards, 18, from Brentford, west London, and a 15-year-old, have already admitted the offence, but Marsh, together with a 16-year-old and another 15-year-old, are also being tried on the grounds that they were part of a "joint enterprise" and played some part in it.

Explaining to the jury how it was possible to prosecute a woman for rape, Richard Whittam, prosecuting, said: "Obviously, being a female, she herself couldn't commit what is defined as sexual intercourse in law, by herself, penetrating the victim. But, if she was party to a group attack and if she was actively encouraging, ready to lend a physical hand, to join in, or if she was holding down when the event was taking place, she in law would be guilty of rape, although female."

The jury, of seven women and five men, heard how the vicious rape by the gang of teenagers occurred shortly after midnight on July 22 last year after the woman was persuaded to walk along the Grand Union canal less than five minutes from where she lived, in Ladbroke Grove, west London.

The woman said she met a young woman with short dark hair - believed to be Marsh - and a black youth as she crossed the canal after an evening's drinking, fell into a conversation, and "stupidly" agreed to join them when they suggested smoking cannabis.

At first the mood seemed "jovial" and she danced along the towpath, but after eight other people, including up to three girls, joined them the atmosphere altered and she decided it would be better to return home. It was then that she was pushed into the canal.

"I felt a couple of people, one was a girl, getting in close and then I was in the canal. I didn't slip. I was pushed, elbowed, tripped. It was pretty quick."

The victim, who had admitted to being "pretty tipsy" after drinking six pints of lager, said she was "pretty freaked out" and went into "sober escape mode".

But as she went to clamber out, the court heard how Marsh punched her in the face, grabbed her wrist and asked her: "What are you playing at?" The teenager later admitted to police that she had punched the woman in the face and held her arms down because she thought her tone was "aggressive".

The court heard how the woman had heard a girl say "yeah, do her". And as she lay pinned to the ground, they began to rip her clothes off. She then described how three people pinned down her shoulders and legs while she was raped by two different people. After the second rape she saw her chance to escape.

"I was going through different emotions from afraid to anger and then I just struggled while there was a pause. I got up and I just ran for it. It was complete survival. I didn't look back," she said.

But three or four of them, including a girl, caught up with her, pushed her on to the gravel and continued to "grab my limbs like an animal - dragging me along the ground and kicking me".

Her screams eventually frightened them off, and still naked she ran home, where her boyfriend called the police.

Marsh, a bingo caller of Margate, Kent, the 16-year-old and the 15-year-old, neither of whom can be named for legal reasons, all deny rape.

The two youths also deny indecently assaulting the woman.

The case continues.

webTitle: $1m-a-day film role for Harrison Ford fuels Hollywood wage row

fields.headline: $1m-a-day film role for Harrison Ford fuels Hollywood wage row
fields.trailText: The Hollywood heartthrob Harrison Ford is to be paid more than $1m a day for his next film, producers last night confirmed, adding fuel to a furore over the "obscene" pay demands of top stars.
fields.body:
The Hollywood heartthrob Harrison Ford is to be paid more than $1m a day for his next film, producers last night confirmed, adding fuel to a furore over the "obscene" pay demands of top stars.

With Hollywood on the brink of strikes over pay by actors and writers, moves which threaten to bring all US productions to a halt, news that Ford, 58, will be paid $25m (£17.3m) for 20 days' work on K-19: The Widowmaker, will cause consternation.

The thriller is based on the true story of a Russian nuclear submarine commander who averted a reactor meltdown when his vessel ran into trouble off Shetland in 1961.

Actors further down the food chain claim their pay is being squeezed to meet the demands of the five highest earning male leads, who are now habitually commanding in excess of $20m (£14m) a film.

Such is the groundswell of anger that at last year's Cannes film festival, Nick Nolte, once a member of that gilded club, broke ranks to rage at the "obscene" amounts being paid. He said: "It's sick. I want nothing to do with it."

Ford's $2,500-an-hour rate smashes the record set by Marlon Brando, who collected $3m for four days' work on Superman in 1978.

It also dwarfs the $25m paid to Mel Gibson for the month he spent shooting The Patriot, a deal which prompted Jim Wiatt, of the powerful William Morris agency, to warn that studios would go under if wages continued to spiral.

Ford's agent claimed his payments did not take into account the time he spent researching the part, including a trip to Moscow to meet Captain Nikolai Zateyev, the hero of the incident.

The film's producer Tim Kelly, of National Geographic Films, said Ford, who made his name playing understated heroes such as Han Solo in Star Wars and Indiana Jones, was worth every penny. "We would have paid anything to get Harrison Ford on board. He guarantees a hit," he said.

Before his fee became known, Ford said he took the part because of the film's gripping plot, its parallels with the Kursk tragedy, and the opportunity to star alongside Liam Neeson. "The cash didn't tempt me. I took the part because of the plot," he said.

"The courage and sense of duty exhibited by the Russian submarine force amid the cold war struggle inspired me."

What $1m could buy

 Ann Widdecombe giving just under 700 after-dinner speeches at £1,000 a go.

 Ex Wimbledon striker John Hartson playing 46 matches under his £15,000 pay-per-play deal with Coventry

 A room in Skibo castle in Scotland for 3.5 years at £550 a night.

 A 757 private jet flying you and 48 of your closest friends wherever you like for 11 days. At £60,000 a day the price includes six crew, the finest cuisine, vintage wines and endless champagne.

($1m = £692,000)

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
As if the foot and mouth crisis wasn't enough, our diarist now has a blizzard to contend with

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: As if the foot and mouth crisis wasn't enough, our diarist now has a blizzard to contend with
fields.body:
D-day today: just as the forecast blizzard hit us at 10am, Peter set off to collect the much-needed disinfectant from the agricultural store 12 miles away. He left with the phone and a large shovel, but with no farmer available to clear the roads or pull stuck cars out of drifts, he knew it would not be an easy journey. He made it back eventually but said he would not go out again, and that 29 farmers on the list are still without disinfectant.

We had got up just after 6am, neither of us having slept very well: I don't imagine anyone in the industry does just now. Breakfast is always accompanied by the television news, but it is the same over and over again. We are constantly bombarded with new information from the fax, phone, television, radio and internet, and keeping on top of it all is becoming a full-time job.

Yesterday, we watched Peter's cousin, Michael Bell, on the news. He runs a livestock haulage business and this stoppage is really hurting him. He employs 20 staff and his six stock wagons are stationary. We are very conscious that it is not just the farmers who are hurting, that there are many others in the supply chain, from farm gate to plate, but only the livestock farmers have this gruesome fear of the destruction and burning of their animals.

We got the detailed sheep symptoms down the fax today, and were very dismayed at lunchtime to hear the further spread to Lancashire, Durham and Northants. We almost know the sheep symptoms off by heart, but since the flock is now obliterated in near white-out conditions, it's not much help.

I fear things really are going to get worse as the livestock movement ban is extended throughout the UK, and our hopes for future exports diminish hour by hour. We produce prime lambs for sale from July to November, and 25% of this country's sheep meat is exported, so I wonder what the effect will be on prices, and how many of us will not be lambing or selling sheep this year.

I talked to some of our nearest neighbours last night and they are really scared. Roly Carr's fields are next to ours and he has cows due to calve imminently. He bought six last year at Longtown Mart in Cumbria, from Willy Cleave in Devon. That is how the livestock industry works: there are trading links from one end of the country to the other. Roly says he can't settle to anything. Peter and I are just the same. Roly expressed the great sadness we all feel and said how very attached he is to some of his cattle. Some of his suckler cows are real characters, almost like friends. It makes it so hard for us all.

Our region is also besieged by the media, and there are genuine concerns about the endless camera shots of different farms and schools in the area. Is the same crew driving from scene to scene? I sincerely hope not. I expect today's snow will slow them down a little.

I am very impressed by the courage of Ian Williamson from Ponteland: he is an example to us all. He has lost all his stock and yet he told the nation Britain needs food, and he intends to continue. We all wish him and his sons good luck for the future: they deserve it.

Another farmer three miles from here, Alan Lawson, has finally agreed to be interviewed at his gate today by Granada and take a camcorder around the livestock. He breeds pedigree Suffolk rams and Charolais cattle, as well as keeping commercial livestock like ours. His wife, Anne, is a very popular and successful registered childminder, and all her tiny charges from farms are currently barred from attending, so now the industry's much-needed diversification enterprises are also being affected.

There could be an outbreak of cabin-fever soon among folk stuck on their farms. Today (Tuesday) is traditionally market day in Hexham and there will be withdrawal symptoms felt all around the area as the auction marts fulfil a social need just as much as a vital economic one, and I am sure the town's shops will feel the pinch .

Final update as the electricity flickers alarmingly. Peter has come in for a quick cuppa. We are about to gather in the sheep that should have been sold on Friday. At lunchtime we brought in some cows and their calves. They are happily chewing the cud and Peter says we are awaiting a visit from hell, because to a farmer the flaming, bovine-fuelled infernos around the UK are exactly that.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She will be writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

webTitle: Storm lashed Flood waters sink CGNU profits

fields.headline: Storm lashed Flood waters sink CGNU profits
fields.trailText: Floods and storm damage plus hefty costs from quitting the US and Lloyd's insurance markets have battered profits at CGNU, Britain's biggest insurer.
fields.body:
Floods and storm damage plus hefty costs from quitting the US and Lloyd's insurance markets have battered profits at CGNU, Britain's biggest insurer.

Losses from last autumn's floods and storms - such as those that pounded Selsey Bill, West Sussex, above - totalled £285m. On a pre-tax basis the company slumped to a loss of £1.4bn in 2000 from a profit of £1.5bn in 1999, after provisions of £1bn on the sale of its US insurance business and a £448m to exit from Lloyd's of London.

Operating profit on ongoing business, used by analysts as a clearer indication of current trading, was down by 8% to £1,407m from £1,534m.

Profits were held back by a £133m investment in norwichunion.com and, in contrast to other large companies which have scaled back internet investment, CGNU says it intends to spend £250m on the website by the end of next year.

The figures were ahead of expectations, however, and CGNU shares ended up 3.4% at £10. In the first full-year report since the merger of CGU with Norwich Union, outgoing chief executive Bob Scott said the combined company was on target to make £275m a year in savings. Worldwide sales were up 24% to £13.5bn, with UK new business ahead 21% at £7.5bn.

CGNU insures one in four vehicles in Britain and last year pushed up premiums by 14% on average. It says that drivers will face another 10-15% increase this year, largely because of spiralling personal injury claims which now make up a third of the cost of insuring a car.

Overall profit margins were maintained despite the increase in sales, but chief executive designate Richard Harvey warned that the launch of stakeholder pensions in April, which have capped charges, would eat into margins.

Legal & General, expected to be CGNU's toughest competitor in the stakeholder market, yesterday reported operating profits up 15% at £479m from £418m. L&G chief executive David Prosser said that recent deals signed with Barclays bank and Alliance & Leicester to sell stakeholder pensions would boost L&G's total sales by a third next year but added that it would cut into margins.

Since the failure of the proposed merger with NatWest in September 1999, L&G has been touted as a perennial takeover target. Yesterday, Mr Prosser said that its recent alliances effectively ruled out a deal with a British bank.

webTitle: Royal seal of approval: Portcullis House opens

fields.headline: Royal seal of approval: Portcullis House opens
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: The Queen yesterday gave a controversial new office block for MPs the royal seal of approval.
fields.body:
The Queen yesterday gave a controversial new office block for MPs the royal seal of approval.

Portcullis House, opposite Big Ben at Westminster, has been plagued by delays and a costly legal dispute. But the Queen, opening the £235m building, congratulated "all those involved in the conception and execution of the project".

Unveiling a stone plaque during a tour of the house, she said the building complemented and contrasted with the Palace of Westminster.

Portcullis House, which houses 210 MPs and their staff, was commissioned in 1992 at a cost of £165m. But after building cost inflation and delays, the price jumped to £235m. Costs included £150,000 for decorative fig trees, £2m for electric blinds and, for each MP, a reclining chair at £440.
