webTitle: Why the US economy could end up in an L

fields.headline: Why the US economy could end up in an L
fields.standfirst: Not so much light as lightning
fields.trailText: Don't panic yet about the slowdown in the US, the governor of the Bank of England told MPs yesterday.
fields.body:
Don't panic yet about the slowdown in the US, the governor of the Bank of England told MPs yesterday. Sir Eddie George and most of his colleagues on the monetary policy committee believe that the most likely scenario for the American economy is a V-shaped recovery, a steep downturn followed by an equally rapid recovery, although they acknowledge that there is a risk of things getting much worse.

As we note today (page 27), there are reasons to think that this picture is too optimistic. The pessimists also have their favourite letters of the alphabet to describe the likely path of US output, with the bears backing the letter L - a sharp fall and then stagnation.

But for the super bearish among analysts, the new symbol for the US economy is the lightning bolt. Output falls and then rebounds slightly lower as interest rates give a short-lived boost to consumer confidence, only to nose-dive once more as the full implications of structural imbalance sink in.

Gerard Lyons, chief economist at Standard Chartered Bank, thinks that American households have been spooked by all the bad economic news and the evaporation of the paper stock market wealth. He reckons Joe Six-pack will hunker down and start saving. And, with American households already heavily into debt, this implies a sharp drop in household spending.

Yesterday's economic statistics suggest that the US is well on its way down the first stroke of the lightning bolt. Consumer confidence collapsed to a four-and-half-year low, while new home sales declined by nearly 11%.

Analysts have already suggested that another Fed rate cut is a done deal. If Mr Lyons is right, the relief rally will be short-lived. Lightning doesn't stop until it hits the ground.

Power lust

One sin Ed Wallis managed to avoid during his many years at the helm of Powergen was to try to airbrush away the corporate past by adopting a daft new name for the company - as practised by Innogy, which is better known as part of the old flat-footed National Power.

But, just as Innogy was busy reinvigorating itself yesterday, buying Yorkshire Power from its bored American owners, strange rumours were circulating about Mr Wallis' final days as both chairman and chief executive at Powergen.

He was finally cajoled into giving up the chief executive's hat to his boardroom colleague Nick Baldwin last week, but Mr Wallis made it abundantly clear at the time that he wanted to maintain a heavy involvement in a business which he turned into one of the country's leading utilities groups.

Now it is being said that Mr Wallis demanded handsome compensation for splitting his roles - an outrageous request which was turned down by the other directors.

Mr Wallis has won huge plaudits for his work in the power industry over the years. His autocratic style was tolerated because he delivered results, but his insistence in retaining a dual role at the top of the company in the face of well-aired institutional opposition damaged Powergen in the eyes of the City.

In trying to grab money now for belatedly accepting something that should have happened years ago, Mr Wallis risks leaving his colleagues with sour memories at the end of a distinguished career.

Sky needs a deal

A footnote to SMG's full year results revealed that GMTV, the breakfast show in which the company has a stake, is breaking ranks with ITV and negotiating a deal to appear on the Sky Digital platform. The programme should appear on Sky in the next couple of months.

GMTV is apparently also exploring options for exploiting its brand which could include an extension of its programming beyond breakfast - Lorraine Kelly all day long.

GMTV's action is a reminder that ITV and Sky need to do a deal for the network to appear on the platform, not only for their own respective benefits but to support the roll-out of digital TV. The two sides have had a long-running row about access - ITV complains that Sky is charging too much, Sky that ITV is being intransigent.

Nearly 5m Sky homes cannot get ITV2. When ITV has developed a family of channels, its absence will be all the more conspicuous, perhaps explaining why the network is hanging on, to wring better terms from Sky.

If the government hopes to persuade the nation to go digital it will need to act. One immediate idea comes to mind which is extending the "must carry" obligation from cable to Sky, which would force it to carry ITV on economic terms - Sky should not be penalised for having invested in and built the satellite platform.

If they cannot agree terms then it is up to Oftel, which manages the spectrum, to bang their heads together.

webTitle: New ethical indices will exclude most FTSE firms

fields.headline: New ethical indices will exclude most FTSE firms
fields.trailText: The majority of London's blue chip firms will not be eligible for inclusion in a series of ethically correct stock market indices that are being developed by FTSE, the index compiler.
fields.body:
The majority of London's blue chip firms will not be eligible for inclusion in a series of ethically correct stock market indices that are being developed by FTSE, the index compiler.

Speaking at the launch of the FTSE4Good index series, Mark Makepeace, chief executive of FTSE, predicted that more than half of the companies listed on the London Stock Exchange would fail to achieve the status of a socially responsible company when the list of eligible candidates is drawn up later this year.

FTSE is developing the indices, which will allow investors to identify and track the progress of socially responsible companies, in response to demand from City institutions which are coming under increasing pressure to make ethical investments.

Last year legislation was introduced requiring pension fund trustees to disclose publicly the extent to which ethical considerations were taken into account when making an investment decision.

Mr Makepeace said he hoped the introduction of the indices would encourage companies to clean up their acts.

"What we are trying to do is to encourage companies to act in this way. We think a lot of pressure will be brought on companies to do just that."

The indices will cover Britain, Europe, north America and the developed world as a whole. They are being developed in conjunction with Ethical Investment Research Service and a committee chaired by Mervyn Pedelty, boss of the Co-operative Bank, which will responsible for the definition of a socially responsible company.

The UK and European indices will be introduced in June with the US and global versions appearing later this year. Mr Makepeace said he could not reveal which firms would be disbarred but admitted that tobacco firms and arms exporters were likely to be excluded.

webTitle: Yorkshire deal puts Innogy on top

fields.headline: Yorkshire deal puts Innogy on top
fields.trailText: Innogy will become the country's biggest electricity supplier and second-largest gas supplier as a result of its £1.8bn acquisition of Yorkshire Power announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Innogy will become the country's biggest electricity supplier and second-largest gas supplier as a result of its £1.8bn acquisition of Yorkshire Power announced yesterday.

The group has agreed to buy the Yorkshire business from the two American companies which acquired it in October 1997.

The deal, which lifts Innogy into the same bracket as Powergen and Centrica in the retail market, had a cool reception from investors. Its shares fell by more than 5% to 196p.

City analysts pointed out that the group had paid about £295 for every new customer, against industry expectations of between £200 and £250.

"They are destroying value," Andrew Wright, a utility analyst at UBS Warburg, said.

Ross Sayers, Innogy's chairman, said the deal would give the group "critical mass" in the retail electricity and gas markets. He said that when Innogy was created through the demerger of National Power last October it aimed to get 5m retail customers within five years.

The purchase of Yorkshire Power took the firm beyond that target four years ahead of schedule. "The company has done a stunning job in moving from almost no retail customers to 5.3m today."

Mr Sayers said the group would add value by selling other products to its customer base. It intends to offer building and contents insurance from April and a fixed-line telecom service from May.

The insurance scheme would be in association with Jardine Lloyd Thompson and St Andrews Insurance, part of the Bank of Scotland, while the telecom package would be a partnership with Energis and Eurocall.

He added that Innogy had approached Yorkshire Power's joint owners - American Elec tric Power and Xcel Energy - in December and the price had been struck as a result of negotiations rather than an auction.

AEP and Xcel acquired Yorkshire Power in 1997 and Xcel is to retain a 5.25% stake in the business for tax reasons until October next year. Innogy has an option to buy the outstanding shares.

Brian Count, Innogy's chief operating officer, said Yorkshire Power's services would soon be sold under the group's national brand name, npower.

The Yorkshire company's 7% stake in the BG-operated Armada gas fields in the North Sea and surplus office property - together valued at £91m - would be sold as soon as possible.

Innogy is aiming for annual savings of £30m a year on the supply side of the business by 2004-05, although it will have to spend about £20m over the next three years to achieve the merger synergies.

The acquisition of Yorkshire Power, which has 1.68m electricity customers and 360,000 gas customers, brings the group's generating capacity roughly into line with its retail demand.

 Unseasonal weather and regulatory price cuts have squeezed the profits of Lattice, the gas pipeline and telecom business which was demerged from BG Group last year.

Lattice yesterday reported that pre-tax profits fell from £614m in 1999 to £403m last year. Warm temperatures during the year kept gas demand low, while flooding increased the cost of building its broadband telecom network.

Operating profits of its Transco pipeline business fell by £181m, largely as a result of price cuts imposed by the industry regulator.

Chairman Sir John Parker said Transco was concentrating on improving its operational and capital efficiency and achieving a satisfactory outcome from its price control review.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Equitable Life | Nycomed | WPP
fields.body:
Equitable put on defensive

Equitable Life yesterday strongly defended itself against accusations by the office of fair trading that it was treating its policyholders unfairly by having "discretion" over how much to charge them to terminate their policies.

The move follows the decision by the OFT to write to the mutual life insurance group about its decision to put a 10% penalty on policyholders who left the insurer after it was forced to close to new business last year.

Equitable Life set that levy to try to reduce the impact on its fund of a deluge of policyholders leaving. The OFT is understood to not be concerned that the 10% levy in itself is unfair but more interested in the mutual's "absolute discretion" to set the fee.

Nycomed to float subsidiary

Health care group Nycomed Amersham is pressing ahead with the Nasdaq flotation of its life sciences business in a move which is likely to raise some $300m (£208m) for the group. The APBiotech operation, jointly owned with US group Pharmacia, makes sequencing machines used to unravel the human genetic code and is poised to profit from the genome revolution.

Investors had feared Nycomed could delay the flotation in light of the tough market conditions, but chief executive Sir William Castell said it was still scheduled for the spring.

Ambassador takes WPP job

WPP, the marketing services group, yesterday named the outgoing US ambassador to Britain, Philip Lader, as non-executive chairman.

Mr Ladar, 54, has been the US envoy in London since 1997 and served in the Clinton cabinet, running the small business administration. Prior to his political career he had been in charge of the US operations of the late billionaire businessman Sir James Goldsmith.

Mr Lader succeeds Hamish Maxwell, who has chaired WPP since 1996 and is looking to retire.

webTitle: Pilkington's new glass wipes out the squeegee

fields.headline: Pilkington's new glass wipes out the squeegee
fields.trailText: The end of the window cleaner is nigh - and the outlook is equally grave for makers of windscreen wipers and window washing products.
fields.body:
The end of the window cleaner is nigh - and the outlook is equally grave for makers of windscreen wipers and window washing products.

Glass manufacturer Pilkington has invented a self-cleaning glass which sounds the death-knell for sloppy window cleaners who charge a small mortgage just to move the muck around a bit - and could ultimately spell the end of the irritating whine of wiper blades on windscreens.

The new, patented Pilkington glass - called Activ - needs only daylight and water to work and is designed for uses ranging from domestic conservatories to commercial skyscrapers.

The glass uses two microscopically thin coatings - the equivalent of placing a penny on top of the Empire State Building - with "hydrophilic and photocatalytic properties".

In layman's language, the hydrophilic bit attracts water and makes it "sheet" rather than form droplets. That means any particles of dirt and dust are automatically washed away during normal rainy weather.

Meanwhile, its photocatalytic properties use normal ultraviolet radiation - free of charge in daylight hours - to oxidise dirt and organic deposits, and prevent them sticking to the glass.

Even the thickest and stickiest "organic deposits" delivered by the biggest birds should stand no chance. The only places the self-cleaning glass will not work are in the dark, in the dry and indoors.

The first Activ glass went on sale in Ireland yesterday and it will be available in Britain by the end of the year at an installed price of about 15-20% more than normal.

Pilkington - which also invented float glass - believes sales should top £300m within four years and it might transfer the technology to car windscreens.

webTitle: Shock absorber GM hopes to avoid compulsory redundancies at Luton plant

fields.headline: Shock absorber GM hopes to avoid compulsory redundancies at Luton plant
fields.trailText: General Motors hopes to avoid making any compulsory redundancies after the controversial closure of its Vauxhall car factory in Luton with the loss of 2,000 jobs, company executives said at the Geneva Motor Show yesterday.
fields.body:
General Motors hopes to avoid making any compulsory redundancies after the controversial closure of its Vauxhall car factory in Luton with the loss of 2,000 jobs, company executives said at the Geneva Motor Show yesterday.

About 1,200 workers are expected to be transferred "in the next weeks" to GM's van and off-road vehicle plant, also in Luton, which is likely to benefit from further investment.

Nick Reilly, Vauxhall's chief executive, said others should be covered by early retirement schemes. About 300 Luton workers will be given a chance to take jobs at Ellesmere Port, Cheshire.

Mr Reilly said negotiations were still under way but the company hoped to have a clear picture by early March.

"We don't expect any further industrial action, we are in communication with our unions and have made some quite significant breakthroughs in the past week."

GM denied that it might scrap the Vauxhall brand after speculation provoked when the name was omitted from a presentation of GM's future "multi-brand" strategy in Europe. "Vauxhall has strong equity in the UK, we have a 13% market share, there would be a huge cost to build up the continental Opel name in Britain," Mr Reilly said.

After a wave of closures last year, manufacturers in Britain were buoyant about their future, despite warnings from analysts that the highly competitive car market offered low margins and fragile sales.

At the launch of the Jaguar X-type, Wolfgang Reitzle, chief executive of the parent company, Ford's premier automotive group, said the new small saloon was a "make or break model" that should help quadruple Jaguar sales by 2005.

"It will take seven to eight years to build a new customer base. If the X-type is a success, we can start thinking about variants," he added. Jaguar said it had spent $450m (£300m) upgrading the Halewood plant on Merseyside which will make the car.

MG-Rover broke a cost-cutting promise not to take part in motor shows and introduced the 75 Tourer, pictured above, on a stand financed by its Swiss importer.

In a surprise move, it also unveiled an MG estate, codenamed X11, to add to three new MG sports saloon models which are expected to roll off the lines at Longbridge in June with sales starting in September.

fields.headline: Below this mud lie 118 victims of new bloodshed in Indonesia
fields.standfirst: Witnesses recall horrific events in Borneo killing field
fields.trailText: Witnesses recall horrific events in Borneo killing field.
fields.body:
When migrants from Madura gathered in the village of Parenggean in Indonesian Borneo at 7pm on Sunday night they were told that they would be evacuated to the refugee camp in Sampit, 65 miles south.

Salima, aged four, was left behind. She never saw her family again. Instead of being taken to safety, 118 of the 392 Madurese who were hoping to escape ethnic cleansing by the indigenous Dayaks were taken a quarter of a mile down the road to a school playing field. There they were forced off the trucks and hacked to death.

"It was crazy, it was so sadistic," said Hairul Saleh, who watched in horror from his front porch 20 metres away. "They had no idea what was happening to them. They clearly thought they were being taken to Sampit."

Mr Saleh's friend Marjo, who watched the carnage with him, added: "As they got down from the trucks, they were killed straight away ... There was no way they could have run away. They fell straight away as they were chopped. Some of them were slashed up to 10 times."

The gruesome drama unfolding before them was made more eerie by the steady drizzle and the fact that the slaughter was illuminated by nothing more than truck headlights and a few torches - the Dayak thugs had stormed the village electricity station beforehand, taken its staff hostage, and switched off the power.

Mr Marjo and Mr Saleh said first one truck arrived on the pitch and the passengers were forced out and killed. It drove away and a few minutes later a second truck arrived, and the Dayak executioners went through the same brutal routine. A third truck arrived and the same slaughter followed.

Just as the first occupants of the fourth truck were being murdered, about 45 minutes after the first killing took place, something akin to divine inspiration occurred, said Rukmana Priyatna, the subdistrict chief.

"Someone screamed out: 'Special forces troops are coming.' The executioners ran off, which gave the [Madurese] the opportunity to run as well."

For some reason the Dayak murderers, who came from a neighbouring area, regrouped but decided that they had sated their bloodlust, and so spared the Madurese still waiting in the village.

The 60Dayaks, who were led by a man called Ibur and a government-appointed neighbourhood chief, calmly returned to their trucks, climbed back in and drove off.

Mr Priyatna returned almost immedi ately to the killing field. "The first thing that struck me when I reached the football field was the murder of the babies, the old people and the women," he said. "They were all still there. They were all piled up together. About six of them had been beheaded."

The massacre in Parenggean is the worst single slaughter in 10 days of ethnic cleansing of Madurese migrants by the indigenous Dayaks. The official death toll is put at 428; unofficially it is several times that number.

The police say that decades of Dayak grievances against Madurese economic success came to a head with two disgruntled Dayaks paying a gang to attack a Madurese houses Sampit. Five of the Madurese died.

The Madurese retaliated, killing 15 Dayaks, and that was swiftly followed by the tidal wave of murder. It shows few signs of abating, despite Jakarta sending several thousand troops and police officers.

Since Sunday's massacre Mr Priyatna has had time to reflect on the events of a day which began well from the point of view of saving migrant lives in his district.

Fifty-two Madurese had died since the ethnic cleansing spread to Parenggean on Wednesday, four days after it began in Sampit.

To to prevent more deaths in his sub district, Mr Priyatna called a meeting of local Dayak community leaders for 8am on Sunday.

"The attitude of the Dayak community groups was that any remaining Madurese should be murdered, whereas my attitude was that they should not live here but that they should be allowed to stay alive," he said.

The compromise reached after two hours of debate was to give the government and security forces five days to evacuate the 500 or so Madurese thought to be hiding in the jungle. Officials relayed the news to the Madurese over mosque loudspeakers.

"The announcement encouraged all those refugees in the forest to come out and that the local community would help them and give them food," Mr Priyatna said.

Within four hours 392 people had come out of hiding and been picked up and taken to Parenggean.

Mr Priyatna's well-laid plans turned to tragedy when Mr Ibur and 30 men armed with machetes, spears and a few homemade shotguns arrived from a neighbouring district, Kuala Kuayan.

"They said they came, according to the head of the group, because they were invited to 'strengthen this area', " Mr Priyatna said, adding that he tried in vain to make them go away in peace.

The situation deteriorated when two more trucks of heavily armed Dayaks arrived from Sanggai to reinforce them.

The newcomers became more emotional, and more violent.

"It was as if they were in a trance, drunk, unaware of what they were doing," Mr Saleh said. Six police officers were present, all armed with M16s, but they ran off scared.

At about 5pm the gangs' patience snapped. "They grabbed a woman and her baby from the cab of one of the trucks and murdered them in front of me," Mr Priyatna said.

His forehead smeared in their blood and facing repeated threats, Mr Priyatna collapsed in shock.

"I was aware that this was a massive human rights violation but I could do nothing to stop it happening ... There were no members of the security forces."

He was eventually forced to leave, and he immediately rang for help. Riot police arrived at half past midnight, by which time the perpetrators had long-since fled.

At 9am Mr Marjo volunteered with others to help bury the 118 victims - 26 men, 64 women, 20 children and eight babies, some of whom were his friends- in a mass grave in the village graveyard.

fields.bodyText: When migrants from Madura gathered in the village of Parenggean in Indonesian Borneo at 7pm on Sunday night they were told that they would be evacuated to the refugee camp in Sampit, 65 miles south. Salima, aged four, was left behind. She never saw her family again. Instead of being taken to safety, 118 of the 392 Madurese who were hoping to escape ethnic cleansing by the indigenous Dayaks were taken a quarter of a mile down the road to a school playing field. There they were forced off the trucks and hacked to death. "It was crazy, it was so sadistic," said Hairul Saleh, who watched in horror from his front porch 20 metres away. "They had no idea what was happening to them. They clearly thought they were being taken to Sampit." Mr Saleh's friend Marjo, who watched the carnage with him, added: "As they got down from the trucks, they were killed straight away ... There was no way they could have run away. They fell straight away as they were chopped. Some of them were slashed up to 10 times." The gruesome drama unfolding before them was made more eerie by the steady drizzle and the fact that the slaughter was illuminated by nothing more than truck headlights and a few torches - the Dayak thugs had stormed the village electricity station beforehand, taken its staff hostage, and switched off the power. Mr Marjo and Mr Saleh said first one truck arrived on the pitch and the passengers were forced out and killed. It drove away and a few minutes later a second truck arrived, and the Dayak executioners went through the same brutal routine. A third truck arrived and the same slaughter followed. Just as the first occupants of the fourth truck were being murdered, about 45 minutes after the first killing took place, something akin to divine inspiration occurred, said Rukmana Priyatna, the subdistrict chief. "Someone screamed out: 'Special forces troops are coming.' The executioners ran off, which gave the [Madurese] the opportunity to run as well." For some reason the Dayak murderers, who came from a neighbouring area, regrouped but decided that they had sated their bloodlust, and so spared the Madurese still waiting in the village. The 60Dayaks, who were led by a man called Ibur and a government-appointed neighbourhood chief, calmly returned to their trucks, climbed back in and drove off. Mr Priyatna returned almost immedi ately to the killing field. "The first thing that struck me when I reached the football field was the murder of the babies, the old people and the women," he said. "They were all still there. They were all piled up together. About six of them had been beheaded." The massacre in Parenggean is the worst single slaughter in 10 days of ethnic cleansing of Madurese migrants by the indigenous Dayaks. The official death toll is put at 428; unofficially it is several times that number. The police say that decades of Dayak grievances against Madurese economic success came to a head with two disgruntled Dayaks paying a gang to attack a Madurese houses Sampit. Five of the Madurese died. The Madurese retaliated, killing 15 Dayaks, and that was swiftly followed by the tidal wave of murder. It shows few signs of abating, despite Jakarta sending several thousand troops and police officers. Since Sunday's massacre Mr Priyatna has had time to reflect on the events of a day which began well from the point of view of saving migrant lives in his district. Fifty-two Madurese had died since the ethnic cleansing spread to Parenggean on Wednesday, four days after it began in Sampit. To to prevent more deaths in his sub district, Mr Priyatna called a meeting of local Dayak community leaders for 8am on Sunday. "The attitude of the Dayak community groups was that any remaining Madurese should be murdered, whereas my attitude was that they should not live here but that they should be allowed to stay alive," he said. The compromise reached after two hours of debate was to give the government and security forces five days to evacuate the 500 or so Madurese thought to be hiding in the jungle. Officials relayed the news to the Madurese over mosque loudspeakers. "The announcement encouraged all those refugees in the forest to come out and that the local community would help them and give them food," Mr Priyatna said. Within four hours 392 people had come out of hiding and been picked up and taken to Parenggean. Mr Priyatna's well-laid plans turned to tragedy when Mr Ibur and 30 men armed with machetes, spears and a few homemade shotguns arrived from a neighbouring district, Kuala Kuayan. "They said they came, according to the head of the group, because they were invited to 'strengthen this area', " Mr Priyatna said, adding that he tried in vain to make them go away in peace. The situation deteriorated when two more trucks of heavily armed Dayaks arrived from Sanggai to reinforce them. The newcomers became more emotional, and more violent. "It was as if they were in a trance, drunk, unaware of what they were doing," Mr Saleh said. Six police officers were present, all armed with M16s, but they ran off scared. At about 5pm the gangs' patience snapped. "They grabbed a woman and her baby from the cab of one of the trucks and murdered them in front of me," Mr Priyatna said. His forehead smeared in their blood and facing repeated threats, Mr Priyatna collapsed in shock. "I was aware that this was a massive human rights violation but I could do nothing to stop it happening ... There were no members of the security forces." He was eventually forced to leave, and he immediately rang for help. Riot police arrived at half past midnight, by which time the perpetrators had long-since fled. Lieutenant General Sir Michael Willcocks, 56, currently a UK military representative to Nato HQ, was appointed Black Rod in the House of Lords. He succeeds General Sir Edward Jones, the current holder of the office - which dates back to Henry VIII.

Bad day

Baroness Jay, the leader of the House of Lords. was known to want a woman for the Black Rod post - beaten by the old boy network once again.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy predicted his party could win an astonishing 216 seats at the general election. fields.headline: Unions criticise pay gap inertia
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday criticised by trade unions after it rejected proposals to force employers to review pay by gender in an effort to close the 18% pay gap.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday criticised by trade unions after it rejected proposals to force employers to review pay by gender in an effort to close the 18% pay gap.

As a report by the equal opportunities commission confirmed that the UK has the worst record in Europe on equal pay, ministers made it clear that pay audits would remain voluntary.

The recommendation, which was a key to the study's proposals to abolish the pay gap within eight years, is fiercely resisted by business, which claims it would create an impossible administrative burden.

The CBI condemned the proposal as "ineffective and disproportionate", and insisted that women were paid less mainly because of family responsibilities and their concentration in low paid occupations rather than because of discrimination by employers.

However, the TUC said there was nothing to make bad employers review pay. Its president, Bill Morris, said: "If you have ruled out any kind of statutory mechanism, it does not seem to me that you have got too much going for you, because you have ruled out any means of compliance."

Thirty-one years after the passing of the Equal Pay Act, the gap between the hourly earnings of women working part-time and men working full-time has barely changed, standing at 39%. Up to 50% of the pay gap was caused not by occupational segregation or women's share of family responsibilities but by discrimination, the study found.

The recommendations include moves to raise awareness of the pay gap and simplifying the system of equal pay employment tribunals.

However, amid opposition from business, ministers will not impose a statutory duty on employers to conduct pay audits, insisting that a voluntary approach will work.

Employment minister Tessa Jowell said: "We don't think mandatory pay reviews are the way forward as a first step." She said the government would review employers' moves to narrow the gap annually.

webTitle: Politically motivated complaints make standards system a farce, says Clarke

fields.headline: Politically motivated complaints make standards system a farce, says Clarke
fields.trailText: The former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, launched a bitter attack yesterday on aspects of parliament's regulatory system, saying it fed "cynicism and apathy" and would drive good people out of public life.
fields.body:
The former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, launched a bitter attack yesterday on aspects of parliament's regulatory system, saying it fed "cynicism and apathy" and would drive good people out of public life.

The MP, giving evidence to the Commons standards and privileges committee, said some of the complaints against MPs were "obviously ridiculous and politically motivated" and led journalists to write up stories in a "snide and suggestive fashion".

Only "the more shameless crooks" would become MPs if it continued, he warned.

"At least half" of all complaints made to the standards and privileges committee since 1997 had been petty or malicious, Mr Clarke said. The list read like a Who's Who of British politics, proving they were made to attract damaging publicity, he told the committee.

The former minister singled out in the "absurd" category complaints about William Hague's free use of a private gym; John Prescott's use of a subsidised flat and the fees for John Major's and Ken Livingstone's lucrative speaking engagements.

He also strongly defended the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, from accusations of advocating policies to benefit his paid consultancy with a US oil company.

He said no MP or journalist believed that his consultancy with oil company Kerr McGee, "which did not own a single petrol station" benefited from Tory policies advocating cuts in petrol prices.

The committee is examining tighter rules forcing MPs to declare fees and contracts for outside speaking engagements and insisting that employment contracts are deposited in parliament revealing exactly how much money they receive.

Mr Clarke, who opposes this, told the committee: "MPs are entitled to the same level of privacy that other citizens are entitled to expect in their activities outside parliament."

He added: "We do appear to be racing towards the American position, whereby individual tax returns and health records are made freely available to the public."

Later Sir Nicholas Lyell, the attorney general in Mr Major's government, called for one aspect of the rules to be tightened up - a proposal to exempt declarations of hospitality from regional quangos and the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland governments.

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: Something new, something blue
fields.trailText: Something new, something blue
fields.body:
Poor Sarah Montague, Today's presenter, has had to contend with being touted as "the new Sue MacGregor". This is a bit puzzling for all of us on the programme, considering that a) we already have a Sue Macgregor in perfect working order and b) how could you possibly have a new one? It would be like having a new Elgin Marbles.

Sarah has also had to put up with the, by now, predictable, debate about her class origins, with some newspapers (on the left) claiming she's favoured as a long term prospect because she's "posh". Which is puzzling again, because a few weeks ago some newspapers (on the right) were suggesting that Edward Stourton was to LEAVE because he was posh.

I'm not sure about Sarah's class status. Maybe we should do what the Workers' Revolutionary Party did to suspect members in the 70s: tie her to a chair and beat her up until she confesses, tearfully, to a privileged upbringing.

To tell the truth, as far as we're concerned, Sarah's been a mite disappointing so far. Oh, she's been a brilliant presenter - sharp, clever, warm and extremely professional. But she's singularly failed to tell any member of the Today team to fuck off, and we're beginning to lose patience.

A few months ago Sarah was in all the papers for telling a Breakfast News producer to fuck off, live on air. As a result, she immediately attained hero status in the rather insular and chippy world of radio, where this is precisely the correct form of address to television producers, regardless of the nature of the inquiry.

The BBC - and, indeed, Sarah - deny the phrase was used, of course. It is authoritatively stated that she actually said: "Please incommode me with superfluous information no longer, respected colleague", or something. Which only goes to show how succinct a presenter she is, getting all that into two, taut syllables.

Most presenters I've worked with have said the same to me, which probably says more about me than them. The late Brian Redhead told me to do so pretty much on a daily basis, although his most splenetic use of the phrase was reserved for the man from the pronunciation department who demanded, somewhat pompously, that Brian must pronounce Turkey as "Tur-keeeh-yah".

I'm sure she'll get there. She'll certainly be playing a big part in the future of Today. And the good news is that there are lots of talented women presenters coming through at the moment - Sarah, Winifred Robinson, Claire Bolderson, Victoria Darbyshire and Jane Garvey on radio, Jane Hill, Sian Williams to name but two on TV. I'm sure their class backgrounds will be extensively researched.

Rod Liddle is editor of BBC Radio 4's Today programme. His column appears every Wednesday

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Thinking Allowed | Say It Loud With Isaac Hayes - The Funk Story | Flesh And Chips
fields.body:
Laurie Taylor's Thinking Allowed (Radio 4, 4pm) will have Harry Potter fans reaching for their dictionaries or pestering their parents. Prof Taylor debates whether JK Rowling's stories about Harry and his wizard chums are "phallocentric, tedious and part of the process by which we homogenise our children." If you are the one doing the explaining then you might just find the above, from Jack Zipes of the University of Minnesota yet another "tedious" attempt at playing the provocative academic. Coming to Potter's defence is Nicholas Tucker from Sussex University, who sees Potter et al democratising boarding-school fiction.

No sooner has Lionel Ritchie got to the end of a series praising the black all-round contribution to popular music, than another 70s Afro-American singer appears with his own radio show. Say It Loud With Isaac Hayes - The Funk Story (Radio 2, 9pm) looks at the rhythm of every good 70s revival night.

Flesh And Chips (Radio 4, 9pm) examines how far we have got towards creating that sci-fi fiction favourite, the Cyborg. Forget Bladerunner scenarios, instead think of Campbell Aird, a Scottish hotel manager, who uses a robotic arm that is now sophisticated enough to pour a glass of beer, while Keven Warwick, professor of cybernetics at Reading University, explains what it is like to be permanently wired to a computer system.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Charge Of The Light Brigade | International football
fields.body:
Films

Charge Of The Light Brigade (Michael Curtiz, 1936) 9.30am, TCM The one in which, as David Niven recalled, Hungarian director Curtiz famously yelled, "Bring on the empty horses!" The charge is moved from the Crimea to India, but who's quibbling? The climactic ride into the Valley of Death is so stirring you want to saddle up and go with them. Dashing Errol Flynn leads the glorious suicidal attack,and skirmishes with brother Patric Knowles over the colonel's daughter Olivia de Havilland.

They Live By Night (Nicholas Ray, 1948) 10.25am, Sky Cinema Marvellous combination of love story and crime thriller, with young innocents Farley Granger and Cathy O'Donnell forlornly trying to escape the attentions of his former convict allies, Jay C Flippen and the thoroughly menacing Howard da Silver. It's bound to end tragically, in Ray's assured debut as director.

The Front (Martin Ritt, 1976) 2.45am, Sky Cinema Ritt, his screenwriter Walter Bernstein and actor Zero Mostel all approached this re-creation of the communist witchhunts with bitter personal experience, but the result is not compelling. Part of the problem is Woody Allen, who is hard to take seriously in his first straight role as a bookie who leases his name to the work of blacklisted scriptwriters. Mostel, though, is superb as an anxiety-ridden actor ruined by accusations of a red past.

Seul Contre Tous (Gaspar Noë, 1998) 3am, FilmFour Philippe Nahon gives a mesmerising performance as the furious, misanthropic anti-hero of this brutally original drama. An unemployed butcher dumps his pregnant mistress (Frankye Pain) and trails through Paris with a loaded gun, dreaming of releasing his autistic daughter from care. It's a frantic, shocking picture of an outsider on the furthest edge of society: the astonishing thing is that Nahon's monster remains a subject of pity. Noë intended to make a radical statement with his first feature, and he succeeded.

Snake Eyes (Brian De Palma, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier The bravura opening - a 12-minute take in which we follow Nicolas Cage's hustler-cum-cop Santoro going about his dodgy business in an Atlantic City sports stadium before a big fight - is a homage to De Palma's beloved Hitchcock, and enticingly sets the scene for a gripping thriller. The champ takes a dive and despite the attentions of Santoro's security chief chum Dunne (Gary Sinise), a political bigwig is shot.

Sports

International football 7pm, Sky Sports 1 & 2 It's all very well for the FA to insist that England only play friendlies against the very best opponents, but the fans want to see the team win and perhaps the occasional encounter with the lesser footballing nations, such as Vanuatu or Wales, would not go amiss. Here Sven-Goran Eriksson faces Spain in his first match in charge of England (on Sky Sports 2). The Republic of Ireland, meanwhile, play Denmark on Sky Sports 1.

fields.headline: No strings attached
fields.standfirst: Forget the simple innocence of Sooty and Pinocchio. Today's puppets are acting in Ibsen or producing erotic entertainment.
fields.trailText: Forget the simple innocence of Sooty and Pinocchio. Today's puppets are acting in Ibsen or producing erotic entertainment.
fields.body:
When Disney brought The Lion King to London 18 months ago, it marked the arrival in Britain of puppetry as a mainstream art form. But it is last week's West End debut of Shockheaded Peter, that bastard offspring of junk puppetry and the lunatic asylum, that finally proves that puppets are hip.

Phelim McDermott, Julian Crouch and a whole new generation of theatre-makers are taking a craft often dismissed as old-fashioned, low-tech and just for kids, and making it a dramatic must-have. Puppets are popping up everywhere, from the West End to Welsh National Opera's acclaimed production of The Queen of Spades. Next month a version of Ibsen's A Doll's House arrives in London in which only Nora and Torvald are played by humans. Even Hollywood has joined in - the film Being John Malkovich featured John Cusack playing a puppeteer who dreams of elevating the genre.

Britain may still trail much of Europe in attitudes towards puppetry and willingness to fund it, but when it comes to skills we are up there with the best. The mad micro-worlds of Faulty Optic and Green Ginger are now on show in Brussels in what is being billed as the world's first erotic puppet festival, an event that conjures up the scary spectacle of puppet porn.

"There is the money and the confidence to do this kind of experiment in Europe. The word puppetry is seen as a bonus, not something to put people off," says Chris Pirie of Green Ginger, a company that until recently did not put the P-word on any of its British publicity for fear of frightening audiences away.

Alas, for the moment it seems unlikely that British audiences will get a chance to catch Green Ginger's entry for the erotic puppet festival, Coming Soon, which features a life-size puppet called Derek who sits in a booth taking money from punters at a porn cinema while a blue-movie soundtrack plays in the background. We will have to content ourselves with the company's show at the Lyric Hammersmith, which ought to win a prize for the title of the year: Bambi - The Wilderness Years. (It was with a twinge of regret that Pirie and his gang relinquished one of the piece's working titles: Death in Venison.)

Green Ginger's post-apocalyptic version of Felix Saltern's 1920 story, which relocates Bambi and his family to a car dump, is likely to upset anyone with a soft spot for the cute little creature with big watery eyes of the sentimental Disney story. What is certain is that the company's customary disrespect for classic tales (previous shows include outrageous versions of Frankenstein and Sweeney Todd) is matched by its disrespect for traditional ideas about what you can and can't do with puppets. In this sense, Green Ginger is typical of the new generation of puppeteers. In Bambi - The Wilderness Years, high-tech and low-tech solutions go hand in hand and digital video rubs shoulders with shadow play. As Pirie says: "We use whatever is the right tool for the job."

If purists are upset by this approach, they will probably have fainting fits when confronted by the Custard Factory's adaptation of A Doll's House, which takes Ibsen's great naturalistic drama and replaces many of the characters with puppets.

Director Juliet Forster admits this approach may sound perverse, but claims the device heightens the game-playing aspect of Torvald and Nora's rela tionship and the collusion that holds it together. So Nora's admirer, Dr Rank, becomes a puppet operated by Torvald, partly to amuse Nora but also to exert power over her. Nora's old friend Mrs Lindstrom is a Victorian doll from Nora's childhood, and Krogstad, to whom Nora owes money, is a huge shadow puppet who looms menacingly over the sitting room.

"You couldn't possibly shoehorn the play into this kind of presentation, but because the use of puppets springs completely from ideas present in the text, it works amazingly well. There is something very Brechtian about putting puppets in a play that is naturalistic," says Forster.

Steve Tiplady of puppet company Indefinite Articles believes puppets can do anything humans can. Like many of the new generation of puppeteers, Tiplady grew interested in his trade through object animation rather than traditional marionettes. He has worked extensively with Improbable Theatre, and his latest piece, Dust, was inspired by his experiences on tour with that company's sticky-tape-and-newspaper show, 70 Hill Lane.

Tiplady refuses to think small. Dust is an adult show of epic proportions based on The Odyssey, which creates landscapes using piles of dust and an overhead projector. Sounds wacky? It's this belief that anything is possible that is making puppetry such a potent tool in the theatre. As Tiplady says: "When I entered this profession more than 10 years ago, there was a feeling that it was a backwater, a dead-end job. Not any more. Theatre is a magpie. It thrives on pinching things and it has suddenly woken up to the fact that puppetry has so much to offer."

 Bambi - The Wilderness Years is at the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6 (020-8741 2311), until March 10. A Doll's House is at the Warehouse, Croydon (020-8680 4060) from March 16 to April 8. Dust is at BAC, London SW11 (020-7223 2223) from March 20 to April 8.
fields.bodyText: When Disney brought The Lion King to London 18 months ago, it marked the arrival in Britain of puppetry as a mainstream art form. But it is last week's West End debut of Shockheaded Peter, that bastard offspring of junk puppetry and the lunatic asylum, that finally proves that puppets are hip. Phelim McDermott, Julian Crouch and a whole new generation of theatre-makers are taking a craft often dismissed as old-fashioned, low-tech and just for kids, and making it a dramatic must-have. Puppets are popping up everywhere, from the West End to Welsh National Opera's acclaimed production of The Queen of Spades. Next month a version of Ibsen's A Doll's House arrives in London in which only Nora and Torvald are played by humans. Britain may still trail much of Europe in attitudes towards puppetry and willingness to fund it, but when it comes to skills we are up there with the best. webTitle: Master of both murder and music

fields.headline: Prince of darkness
fields.standfirst: How did we ever forget Don Carlo Gesualdo, master of both murder and music?
fields.trailText: How did we ever forget Don Carlo Gesualdo, master of both murder and music?
fields.body:
Forget the tune and the rhythm. When music starts shifting the tectonic plates of the heart, nine times out of 10 what is at work is harmony - which is why the music of Don Carlo Gesualdo, royal prince and multiple murderer, sings to us so clearly across four centuries.

Harmony is the weapon that composers use to hit us where we live, and perhaps no one has ever exploited its power with greater cunning than the Prince of Venosa, whose madrigals and motets, representing the cutting edge of music in the early years of the 17th century, will be performed at the Barbican next month along with a new film by the American painter and performance artist Joe Coleman as part of the Only Connect festival, in an evening devoted to Outsider Art.

"If Gesualdo had been taken as seriously in his own time as he is now," the Czech composer Ernst Krenek said in the 1950s, "music history would have taken a different course." Even today, listening to his music can be like cycling down a frozen path - a sudden patch of harmonic ice can whip the listener's wheels away. Composed before the modern scale became the norm, his pieces - written for five, six or seven voices - make extensive use of microtonality, turning an Easter hymn or the setting of a love poem into a wild ride, full of quarter-steps and sideslips.

Yet Gesualdo earns his status as an outsider artist not by virtue of his harmonic inventiveness but through his earthly transgressions, which included supervising the murder of his wife, their baby and his wife's lover. The contrast between the calculated gruesomeness of that deed and the celestial beauty of his music probably explains his appeal to the likes of the film directors Hans Werner Herzog, whose 1995 film biography, Death for Five Voices, featured the London-based Gesualdo Consort, and Bernardo Bertolucci, whose next feature film, Heaven and Hell, tells the composer's story.

When Alex Poots, the executive director of Only Connect, called Joe Coleman at his Brooklyn home to discuss the possibility of combining his paintings with music, Gesualdo was one of the names on his list. "I could see that he was interested in people with a very dark side to them," Poots says, referring to the murderers and freaks who populate Coleman's obsessively detailed portraits and "humanscapes". "I thought maybe this combination would bring out the darker side of Gesualdo's music, which a lot of people prefer to ignore." The artist's response could hardly have been more gratifying. "I've been wanting to do that for 10 years," said Coleman, who turned out to have an extensive collection of recordings of the composer's music.

As Krenek's words suggested, interest in Gesualdo is recent. His death in 1613 was followed by a silence lasting more than three centuries, until dedicated work by a small band of enthusiasts, among them Igor Stravinsky and the conductor Robert Craft, brought him back into the light. Craft supervised a series of recordings, while Stravinsky's deep involvement led him to write Monumentum pro Gesualdo, an orchestral recomposition of three madrigals, first performed in 1960 and later choreographed by Balanchine. Gesualdo's place in history is now assured, based on the 125 madrigals, two keyboard pieces and three books of sacred music that are all that survive of what may have been a much larger body of work. The Taverner Consort's fine recording of his Good Friday service, released last year, is the most recent evidence of Gesualdo's acceptance.

Born probably in 1560, a descendant of a king of Sicily, he showed early talent as a singer and a lutenist, cutting his teeth as a composer by producing settings for the poems of Torquato Tasso, a member of his father's court. In 1586, needing to produce an heir, he married the attractive Maria d'Avalos, his cousin. He was her third husband - the first, it is said, had died of too much sex, while the second obtained a papal divorce. Four years after their marriage in Naples, he came back from a hunting trip to dis cover her in bed with a young duke and had the two lovers stabbed to death and their corpses mutilated - although there is evidence that he had known about the affair for some time and set the whole thing up to look like a crime of passion. Harbouring doubts about his son's paternity, he also had the child murdered.

He fled to his castle in the countryside, but on his father's death in 1591 he succeeded to his title and returned to Naples. The following year he began a successful courtship of Leonora d'Este, a princess of Ferrara, and left Naples for her home town with a retinue including 300 pieces of baggage carried on 24 mules.

Asthmatic, manic depressive, a snappy dresser, addicted to masochistic practices, devoting at least seven hours a day to his music, he may not have been the easiest of partners. As the years passed Leonora grew unhappy with his waywardness, and a divorce petition was awaiting the pope's attention at the time of Gesualdo's death in 1613.

As Robert Craft wrote, Gesualdo "outstrips all contemporaries in his ability to choose correctly the intensifying step in a harmonic progression, and the next step, and the next". But there was more to it than mere logic. Audacity was the identifying characteristic of his music, and it may have been rooted, as the musicologist Eric Van Tassel suggests, in the knowledge that he had no patron to satisfy, and could write to please only himself. That sense of freedom, of impulsiveness within a context of restraint, is what speaks to us today.

 Outsider Art/Music, part of the Only Connect series and including work by Joe Coleman and Gesualdo, is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), on March 22

fields.headline: A hippy ending
fields.standfirst: In the 1970s he put a safety pin through the Queen's lip for the Sex Pistols. Today Jamie Reid produces swirling canvases and calls himself a druid.
fields.trailText: In the 1970s he put a safety pin through the Queen's lip for the Sex Pistols. Today Jamie Reid produces swirling canvases and calls himself a druid.
fields.body:
Never mind the bollocks, let's talk about the here and now. Jamie Reid, whose record designs for the Sex Pistols gave punk some of its most enduring images, doesn't put it quite as bluntly as that, but that's the message.

In his Toxteth flat, surrounded by the sunny, slightly New Agey work he now produces, he is willing to talk about those days of youthful rebellion but would rather discuss the exhibition of his work that opens in Glasgow this week - or even his plans to break into the hospitality industry. He doesn't want to be defined by his most striking image, the reworking of Cecil Beaton's portrait of Elizabeth II for the single God Save the Queen, which put a safety pin through the sovereign's lip in her silver jubilee year.

"My ambition now," he says, fiddling with his hair, "is a kind of hotel. Surrounded by a good half a mile of land on all sides, it would have a landscape based on the four elements, a recording studio, film-making facilities and a really good restaurant. I'd love to do it in Liverpool. But wher ever you do it, you hit all kinds of problems with planning consent."

It's hard to imagine Reid in the dry-as-dust world of planning consent forms and local government meetings. Even before his work with the Pistols, whose manager Malcolm McLaren was a fellow student at Croydon Art School in the late 1960s, Reid had founded Suburban Press, an anarchistic publishing house.

In the decades since punk he has worked with musicians and campaigners from the radical left in their battles against nuclear weapons, racism, the poll tax and the criminal justice bill, clause 28, the criminalisation of cannabis and global capitalism. He spent the 1990s designing and painting the interior of the Strongroom recording studios in east London, and is currently working on his third CD cover for the Afro-Celt Sound System.

During the last decade he also split from his partner of 17 years, actress Margi Clarke. With his wife Maria he is currently working on an animated film based on their frequent jaunts to the countryside in Wales, Scotland and Ireland. At the height of the Cool Britannia hype, Reid sold limited-edition prints of his punk designs to Kate Moss, Noel Gallagher and Madonna.

Reid is keen to play down the radicalism of punk, seeing it simply as part of a long struggle for social justice. "Punk was part of a story that had been going on for the whole of the century, if not longer - it was no more than an important bit of that story in Britain. I came to it through community-based anarchism and situationist theories, and they came out of surrealism and dadaism. And punk continues - at the anti-poll tax demonstrations in Trafalgar Square, 10,000 people were wearing T-shirts with the same ransom-note lettering as Never Mind the Bollocks but saying 'Bollocks to the Poll Tax.'"

Reid's more recent artwork is not quite so heavy on the expletives. While the new exhibition includes a mini-retrospective of his artwork for the Pistols, it consists mainly of the distinctly unthreatening and trippy Celtic-tinged wall hangings and large paintings that he now concentrates on. At first glance they look, well, hippyish and it's hard to reconcile them with the savage experimentalism of the 1970s.

"There have always been two sides to my work - the esoteric and the political. I think it has to do with being brought up in a family that was both deeply socialist and very druidic. I'm a druid and I've always believed that, much as you need political change, you also need spiritual change."

Cynics may see in his astrologically influenced, shamanistic designs simply another angry young man who has turned artistically soft. But Reid's family background was a combination of both activism and privilege. He embraced the one and rejected the other. His grandfather, George Watson MacGregor Reid, was head of the Druid Order and stood for parliament just before the first world war. Though his father was City editor of the Daily Sketch, Jamie Reid's childhood couldn't have been further from a training in the sharp practices of the business world.

Growing up in Shirley, near Croydon, with all the promise of postwar suburbia around him, Reid's early years were nonetheless highly politicised, with his parents "dragging" him off to CND demos and anti-apartheid marches. They sent him to the local grammar school where he flourished only at sport. "I wanted to become a footballer, but was way too dissipated by 16," he cackles between puffs on ever-present cigarettes.

"I blew all my exams too. My choices then show how much things have changed. I could just walk into the local technical college without any qualifications and receive a grant to study art. Now you'd have to have three A-levels and you'd be in debt before you started. Education has become so elitist - that's why we've got such a vibrant underground of people educating themselves."

It is his passion for this underground which indicates that Reid has retained more of the punk ethos than many of his peers. He prefers festivals and clubs to precious galleries, is more at home with collaborative, "organic" ways of working rather than commissions, and he has a deep concern for the harm global capitalism is doing. This leads to some very unpunky statements ("I spend a lot of time down at the allotment") and helpings of New Age mysticism (he calls the earth Gaia and refers to David Icke as a serious source of information). But the way he lives his life now remains close to the spirit of 1977.

"Punk was never about big master plans and it was always much more collective than Malcolm McLaren and John Lydon would ever admit. It was about finding yourself in a situation, reacting and then moving on, and that's what I do now."

As he says this, the brilliant wintry sunshine that has been flooding into the flat is suddenly replaced by huge hailstones falling from a black sky. Reid smiles, calls Maria in. "Look at that - it's Gaia saying she's had enough. She's fighting back against the damage we've done to the planet." Just heavy weather to the rest of us, but a moment of thrilling counter-cultural resistance to Jamie Reid.

Peace is Tough by Jamie Reid is at the Arches, Glasgow, from Friday until March 18 as part of this year's FuncT festival. Reid will give a talk about his work this Saturday afternoon. Festival hotline: 0901 022 0300.

webTitle: Take five: the daily news quiz

fields.headline: Take five: the daily news quiz
fields.trailText: Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

C1 What will David Jason call his daughter?

(a) Wendy

(b) Rodney

(c) Darlin'

(d) He hasn't decided

C2 Which is a line from Bob Dylan's Highway 61 Revisited?

(a) "Now the fifth daughter on the twelfth night"

(b) "My love she speaks like silence"

(c) "'Twas down in Chaynee County"

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: A walk on thin ice
fields.trailText: A walk on thin ice
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Frost is one of the great transformative energies in the landscape. In creating a shining envelope over the form of everything that stays still, it gives it sharper definition. It also defines everything that is not still, such as the sky, clouds, passing birds and the light itself. On a morning when every twig, moss, leaf and stem is crystallised, everything that moves through the frostlands has to break, crack or puncture a frozen crust of ice. Birdcall is flinty. Every footfall scrunches. Breath smokes. Just walking through the trees leaves something behind - a mark, a vapour. Despite the cold, or perhaps because of it, the newly forming tree buds make their presence felt. Ash buds stand out like black hooves. Soft, shiny nylon tufts split from sallow. Tiny buds of the palest rose edge along the blackthorn. Hazel catkins wag.

But the most potent are the pollen buds on the old, dark yew trees, clustering along the tips and brimming with explosive zeal. As the morning wanes, another hugely transformative power unrolls slowly and stealthily from the river through the plains. A giant fog smothers everything. This has the opposite effect to the frost. The fog defines itself by sucking the form out of everything and losing it. Fogs open out and dissolve all the definition which the frosts closed in. Everything is still; all the sounds are buried under it. Owl hoots ooze between invisible trees. Within the space of a few hours, this landscape is transformed several times - from night to day, dark to light, frost to fog. Then the fog rolled into night, thicker than ever and tingling with liberated shadows, freed to take any imaginative form.

fields.headline: Rovers rise up and down Town
fields.trailText: Tranmere Rovers showed that they really do care about the league last night as they overcame Huddersfield and leapfrogged above them in the table to leave Lou Macari's side bottom of the First Division.
fields.body:
Tranmere Rovers showed that they really do care about the league last night as they overcame Huddersfield and leapfrogged above them in the table to leave Lou Macari's side bottom of the First Division.

After another week of outrageous Cup fortune, Rovers' manager John Aldridge exhausted the book of cliches, insisting he would swap his side's 4-3 success over Southampton last week for league safety.

His team picked up exactly where they had left off against Southampton by scoring a goal from their first attack. Wayne Allison set them on their way to their first league win in four games when a misfired Jason Koumas shot fell in his path with the game less than a minute old.

Allison, whom Huddersfield let go last season, ensured that Tranmere did not miss last week's hero Paul Rideout, who was absent with a thigh strain, as he scored his first goal since October.

Steve Yates doubled Tranmere's lead before half-time when he headed in an Andy Parkinson cross to cause an outbreak of optimistic chants from the home crowd suggesting that they would survive their relegation battle and that Huddersfield might not.

Yet the visitors were unfortunate not to get back into the match in the second half. Although Rovers threatened constantly with their three-man attack, they were missing the influence of their club captain Sean Flynn at the back and the defence always looked vulnerable.

Ben Thornley had Huddersfield's best chances of the game. He really should have scored after 65 minutes when Kevin Gallen found him on the right with only the goalkeeper to beat, but he fired wide.

The former Manchester United midfielder had another great chance five minutes later when he again attacked down the right flank and hit the outside of the post from the edge of the area.

"I thought we murdered them in the second half," said Macari. "I can't criticise any of the players. I can't complain about the performance at all because they were great."

Tranmere Rovers (4-3-3): Achterberg; Allen, Jobson, Yates, Roberts; Hinds, Koumas (Gill, 81min), Henry; Allison, Barlow (Taylor, 74), Parkinson.

Huddersfield Town (4-4-2): Vaesen; Jenkins, Lucketti, Armstrong, Moses; Thornley, Irons, Heary, Smith; Gallen, Facey.

Referee: T Jones.

fields.headline: Predatory Pablo punishes England
fields.standfirst: Pablo 14, 21; Colsa 64, Xisco 88
fields.trailText: A watching Sven-Goran Eriksson was left hoping that this result, England's heaviest home defeat, is not a sign of what lies in wait this evening.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson will hope this was not a sign of what lies in store this evening. The England coach saw the Under-21s comprehensively outplayed by their Spanish counterparts last night and may have left feeling the future is less bright than he had imagined.

The Swede has talked enthusiastically of how an abundance of young talent helped attract him to the job, but it is Spain who can feel more content this morning. Superior in touch, technique and movement, they ripped England apart at times.

Two goals down inside 21 minutes, England could have done with a return of the fog that caused their previous match, in Italy last November, to be abandoned. "The first half was like the tide coming in," Howard Wilkinson said. Perhaps he was hoping for a flood.

This Spanish side, inspired by the Barcelona midfielder Xavi Hernandez and the striker Pablo Gonzalez, who scored twice, were hewn from the squad that won the World Under-20 Championship in Nigeria in 1999. Their understanding was plain to see in passing which belied the poor state of the pitch.

"Good game, bad performance," Wilkinson said. "There are a lot of plusses if we are prepared to learn the lessons. Spain's movement and passing was excellent, particularly in the first half. Ours was at times almost clumsy by comparison."

The five changes Wilkinson made at half-time told of his assessment, and although the lively Newcastle substitute Shola Ameobi created several openings, late Spanish goals produced a scoreline with which few could argue.

That England included several players with considerable Premiership experience made the evening all the more deflating. Gareth Barry, who has played for the senior side, and John Terry, the Chelsea centre-back, suffered a torrid first half and were both taken off at the interval.

Paul Robinson had already made two good saves before Pablo punished England. Having first knocked in a Vincente Rodriguez cross from close range, he took advantage of an embarrassing misunderstanding between Robinson and Terry on the edge of the area to guide the ball into an empty net.

England created their best chances after half-time, Ameobi hitting the keeper's legs before setting up Jonathan Greening and Mark Wilson for one-on-ones which were wasted.

Those misses proved costly when Joaquin Sanchez's fine skill and cross allowed Gonzalo Colsa to head in, and Xisco Munoz rounded off a bad night. Eriksson will hope things get better.

 A 27th-minute goal by Juventus's Zinedine Zidane gave France victory in last night's friendly against Germany in the Stade de France in Paris, stretching their unbeaten run to nine matches.

Primary school children in Islington, north London, have stopped collecting Pokémon cards and are now swapping prostitutes' calling cards.

A thief who broke into a house in Holloway, north London, and stole a mobile phone was caught when the man he tried to sell it to on the street turned out to be the owner.

Pupils at a school in Hull are being offered a £100 incentive by a local company if they achieve five or more A to C grades in their GCSE exams.

Demons be gone

The Bishop of Brentwood, Essex, has ordered that the diocesan email addresses should be changed because they contain the word "demon".

Not quick enough

Two rapid response police officers called to a shop in Stafford to pick up a CCTV video of a suspected shoplifter came out to find they had been given a parking ticket.

Dire straits

A £23m refurbishment of the Rochdale canal, Lancashire, to make it navigable for the first time since the 1940s has hit a snag because one of the bends is too narrow for some boats to get through.

Oldham Chronicle, 6.2.01 (E Fletcher, Manchester)

An agency in Manchester is putting adverts on beer mats in the city's pubs, clubs and student unions to try to attract more graduates into teaching.

Manchester Metro News, 2.2.01 (E Kime, Stockport)

Tucking in

The owners of a pet rabbit in Richmond, North Yorkshire, arranged for it to have a cosmetic tummy tuck operation because it had grown too fat to clean itself properly.

Northern Echo, 7.2.00 (K Jensen, Hartlepool)

Big sleep

A lifeless hamster handed in for cremation at a vet's in Sedgley, West Midlands, was given back to its owners when it was found that the pet was only hibernating.

Liverpool Echo, 9.2.01 (S Yates, Liverpool)

Canter lever

Engineers have fitted an electronic device to traffic lights to allow horse riders an extra seven seconds to cross a main road through Lympstone, Devon.

Sunday Independent, 11.2.01 (L Peters, Cullompton)

webTitle: The role seriously ill people should have in planning their own care

fields.headline: User friendly
fields.standfirst: Mike George on a new report that highlights the key role seriously ill people should have in planning their own care
fields.trailText: Mike George on a new report that highlights the key role seriously ill people should have in planning their own care
fields.body:
If you were very ill, would you want to be asked about how the health or social care services you receive could be improved? Or, as doctors often advise, are you likely to take things "one day at a time"?

Research released today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation shows there's enormous confusion whether those with serious and often life-threatening conditions should be asked to participate in the planning and delivery of their own care, or of the care generally available for people with their condition. For while government departments, local authorities and care agencies make much of "user involvement", it is often assumed that seriously ill people either shouldn't be asked, or are incapable, of exercising this option.

Penny Rhodes, co-author of today's report, points out that misconceptions often arise because, in the past, agencies may have asked people with terminal or serious conditions to serve on user panels, but often they didn't turn up. This could be because at the time they were not well enough to take part, or simply because not enough thought was given to providing reliable transport to and from meetings.

However, it is true that some service users may feel unable to overcome emotional or conceptional barriers to involvement. For instance, the sheer uncertainty of how they will feel day to day and week to week makes it impossible to think about their own future, never mind that of others. People may also be living with the stress of alternating hope and disappointment; others may have learnt to cope with the experience by living from day to day.

Even so, says Rhodes, health and other support agencies should not assume that barriers like these preclude user involvement. First, agencies need to understand how these practical, emotional and psychological factors frame the experience of sufferers and their carers. Second, agencies have to acknowledge that they may make many demands on a person's time and emotional energy. Third, agencies must be imaginative in how they ask sufferers to become involved in service planning and delivery, and in how they intend to make user involvement an accessible and realistic process.

The research focused on service users with multiple sclerosis, cystic fibrosis and motor neurone disease. It also highlights the ways in which people can become socially invisible and excluded, making user involvement even more unlikely. This may be due to an understandable reaction on the part of parents of a seriously ill child, for example. Their focus will inevitably rest on the child's condition and care, and on the emotional impacts this has on the family.

But there is also the uncomfortable fact that provision of health, palliative and support services, and the consequent attention paid to user involvement, is uneven, depending to a large extent on the numbers of patients with particular conditions. Rhodes stresses that while comparisons are invidious, conditions such as cancers appear to have attracted more attention than cystic fibrosis, for instance, or a host of other serious illnesses affecting small numbers, but which together involve a considerable number of service users and their families.

Perhaps the main exception to this is the very active campaign by those living with HIV/Aids, though even here, as one service user said at a recent conference: "It's been difficult to persuade clinicians that we play a meaningful part in the determination of our lives. Somehow we've got to be asked and we've got to be listened to."

Nevertheless, we have probably moved on from the time when clinicians and other professionals viewed user involvement as an idealistic but impractical idea. Ann Crossley, regional chairperson of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, points out that professionals are more aware than ever of the importance of issues such as the management of severe pain, and how to give newly-diagnosed sufferers the right information in the right way. These developments might not have occurred without user involvement, she says.

It is being increasingly recognised that real user involvement not only assists service providers and commissioners, but can mark a profound change in the way patients or clients view themselves, and are viewed by professionals. Tricia Holmes, director of care development at the Motor Neurone Disease Association, says: "People living with MND have no control over the manner in which the disease progresses, and its impact. So it is important that they have control over how they live and the quality of their life."

Another proponent of user involvement, Jean Pounceby, head of the Cystic Fibrosis Advocacy Service (CFAS), endorses the benefits to patients and services. "People with chronic illnesses are the experts on their own condition, its clinical and treatment implications and the repercussions of these for their personal and social lives," she says.

The CFAS, which employs paid advocates, all of whom have cystic fibrosis, is now about to operate on a national scale with senior NHS officers on the planning and commissioning of health services for those with the illness. She sees this as one model which the NHS, and other agencies, should investigate if they're serious about user involvement of people with serious illnesses.

Other ways of making user involvement real, rather than token, are being developed. Peter Beresford, a veteran campaigner and professor of Brunel University's social policy centre for citizen participation, cites a recent event at which the majority of participants had life-threatening conditions.

This, he says, aimed to show that people normally excluded from conventional user involvement forums were, with the right support, able to attend and contribute. Their contributions also made it clear that some relatively simple procedures could ensure that socially excluded patients could have an effective voice.

So pressure is mounting to stop professionals and clinicians making unfounded assumptions about who wants to be, and who can be, involved in planning service delivery on either an individual or a wider basis. The government's NHS plan envisages the creation of a patient and advocacy liaison service. However, the jury is still out on whether this will address the fact that different individuals and service settings may require different approaches to user involvement. Also, it is not yet known whether the National Care Standards Commission will be able to bring socially excluded patients into the process of developing minimum care standards.

But as Beresford points out: "We've found that people with a terminal illness sometimes want to contribute to changes that will be in place after they're no longer here. They see it as part of their legacy to others."

Too Ill To Talk? User Involvement and Palliative Care is available at £15.99, plus £1.50 p&p, from Routledge (tel: 01264-343071).
