First, agencies need to understand how these practical, emotional and psychological factors frame the experience of sufferers and their carers. Second, agencies have to acknowledge that they may make many demands on a person's time and emotional energy. Third, agencies must be imaginative in how they ask sufferers to become involved in service planning and delivery, and in how they intend to make user involvement an accessible and realistic process. The research focused on service users with multiple sclerosis, cystic fibrosis and motor neurone disease. It also highlights the ways in which people can become socially invisible and excluded, making user involvement even more unlikely. This may be due to an understandable reaction on the part of parents of a seriously ill child, for example. Their focus will inevitably rest on the child's condition and care, and on the emotional impacts this has on the family. But there is also the uncomfortable fact that provision of health, palliative and support services, and the consequent attention paid to user involvement, is uneven, depending to a large extent on the numbers of patients with particular conditions. Rhodes stresses that while comparisons are invidious, conditions such as cancers appear to have attracted more attention than cystic fibrosis, for instance, or a host of other serious illnesses affecting small numbers, but which together involve a considerable number of service users and their families. Perhaps the main exception to this is the very active campaign by those living with HIV/Aids, though even here, as one service user said at a recent conference: "It's been difficult to persuade clinicians that we play a meaningful part in the determination of our lives. Somehow we've got to be asked and we've got to be listened to." Nevertheless, we have probably moved on from the time when clinicians and other professionals viewed user involvement as an idealistic but impractical idea. Ann Crossley, regional chairperson of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, points out that professionals are more aware than ever of the importance of issues such as the management of severe pain, and how to give newly-diagnosed sufferers the right information in the right way. These developments might not have occurred without user involvement, she says. It is being increasingly recognised that real user involvement not only assists service providers and commissioners, but can mark a profound change in the way patients or clients view themselves, and are viewed by professionals. Tricia Holmes, director of care development at the Motor Neurone Disease Association, says: "People living with MND have no control over the manner in which the disease progresses, and its impact. So it is important that they have control over how they live and the quality of their life." Another proponent of user involvement, Jean Pounceby, head of the Cystic Fibrosis Advocacy Service (CFAS), endorses the benefits to patients and services. "People with chronic illnesses are the experts on their own condition, its clinical and treatment implications and the repercussions of these for their personal and social lives," she says. The CFAS, which employs paid advocates, all of whom have cystic fibrosis, is now about to operate on a national scale with senior NHS officers on the planning and commissioning of health services for those with the illness. She sees this as one model which the NHS, and other agencies, should investigate if they're serious about user involvement of people with serious illnesses. Other ways of making user involvement real, rather than token, are being developed. Peter Beresford, a veteran campaigner and professor of Brunel University's social policy centre for citizen participation, cites a recent event at which the majority of participants had life-threatening conditions. This, he says, aimed to show that people normally excluded from conventional user involvement forums were, with the right support, able to attend and contribute. Their contributions also made it clear that some relatively simple procedures could ensure that socially excluded patients could have an effective voice. So pressure is mounting to stop professionals and clinicians making unfounded assumptions about who wants to be, and who can be, involved in planning service delivery on either an individual or a wider basis. The government's NHS plan envisages the creation of a patient and advocacy liaison service. However, the jury is still out on whether this will address the fact that different individuals and service settings may require different approaches to user involvement. Also, it is not yet known whether the National Care Standards Commission will be able to bring socially excluded patients into the process of developing minimum care standards. But as Beresford points out: "We've found that people with a terminal illness sometimes want to contribute to changes that will be in place after they're no longer here. They see it as part of their legacy to others." Too Ill To Talk? User Involvement and Palliative Care is available at £15.99, plus £1.50 p&p, from Routledge (tel: 01264-343071).

webTitle: Community project in Glasgow helps bridge hardship gap

fields.headline: Fruitful Fare
fields.standfirst: Bob Holman on a community project in Glasgow that is helping to bridge the hardship gaps left by the social fund
fields.trailText: Bob Holman on a community project in Glasgow that is helping to bridge the hardship gaps left by the social fund
fields.body:
Who can a lone parent turn to when her purse has been stolen and the police can't help? Or a single woman urgently needing £500 because social security won't meet the full cost of her mother's funeral? Or a mum with a drug habit, her children at risk, under pressure from a dealer to pay up - by any means necessary?

In Glasgow, the answer for such desperate cases is a locally-controlled community project, Family Action in Rogerfield and Easterhouse. Fare, as it's known, was offered a hardship fund by the Charities Advisory Trust to provide a financial lifeline. I'm a member of the Fare committee, and we thought hard about accepting the offer of £6,000. In less than two years, we have helped 52 families with grants from £5 to £400.

The grants fall into three groups: 27 for emergencies - that lone mother faced four days without a penny until the hardship fund saw her through; 14 for unanticipated events, such as the shortfall in funeral costs; nine for basic domestic items, among them a washing machine for a mother of three, whose husband had committed suicide.

About 47 families we helped were dependent on income support or jobseeker's allowance; another three were on low wages. Almost three-quarters (36) received social fund loans from the benefits agency. Three had had applications rejected. Social fund loans are provided interest-free for essential items such as electric fires and furniture, but they entail automatic repayments averaging £9-10 per week. I met lone parents who, after deductions, had a weekly cash income of less than £7. The minimum income support rate, set by the government, is £84.35.

Unable to cope on their low and reduced incomes, more than half the families had taken out loans with companies charging up to 150% interest, or they had brought goods from shops which cater specially for "the poor". One firm swiftly delivers - with no deposit required - a cooker, washing machine and television. But an item priced at £739 eventually costs £1,636, with an APR of 29%, plus service charges.

Typical of our cases at Fare was a lone mother with a weekly income of £113.88. Her expenditure, including debt repayments of £28, came to £113.25. When she bought Christmas presents, she fell behind with repayments, and her bed and cooker were about to be repossessed.

These people are not wasteful. They are just living in poverty. As the family budget unit of London University has demonstrated, income support levels are far below a tolerable living standard. Families are pushed into debt, and the burden of repayments force them to scrimp on food, and cut out leisure activities.

Poverty can be eliminated only by government. A local hardship fund only occasionally has a lasting effect - such as when a long-term unemployed drug-user sought our help. A relative in London had offered him digs and an introduction to a job, so Fare covered his travel costs. In London, he found a partner and is now off drugs. Generally, however, the grants provide only temporary respite.

Yet Fare believes it brings certain advantages to the administration of a hardship fund. In contrast with the delays over applications to statutory bodies, our help is immediate - for instance, preventing the drug-user from turning to crime.

As Fare's participants are familiar with life at the hard end, those in need can turn to us as understanding friends, not distant officials. When some members knew that a low-paid couple were taking in the child of a neighbour serving a prison sentence, they suggested, in confidence, that a grant might be possible. Fare also ensures that grants can be accompanied by other forms of support.

Some we help may return the favour. The project leader noticed that one woman, with large debts, got on well with local kids. She was offered a sessional job teaching dance. This helped with her repayments and boosted her self-confidence.

Community projects could do more to enable people to fight collectively against poverty. Fare sells fruit, cheap nappies and employs a few residents. But we could expand to bulk buying, and food stalls could be stocked with a greater variety of produce. A baby co-op could be set up, and far more local people could be given work at realistic rates.

However, community projects are not deemed worthy of long-term funding from government. Until that changes, their potential for going from an individual to a collective approach will not be realised.

fields.headline: Lifers' lifeline
fields.standfirst: As prisons face up to the problem of suicide and self-harm among inmates, one jail is blazing a trail in mental health care.  Lynne Wallis  reports
fields.trailText: As prisons face up to the problem of suicide and self-harm among inmates, one jail is blazing a trail in mental health care. Lynne Wallis reports
fields.body:
It is eight years since Stanley, now 30 and a former drug addict, began a life sentence for murdering one of his prostitute girlfriend's clients in a cocaine-induced frenzy. Last month, not long after being moved in with other lifers at the high security Belmarsh prison in south London, he opened the main artery in his arm and was clinically dead before being resuscitated.

Since the suicide attempt, Stanley has been an inpatient in the prison's mental health facility, which includes a day care unit. Run jointly by the prison service and the NHS, it has won the government's "beacon" status for its work on mental health - the only project of its kind to do so.

Stanley, who says he was sexually abused as a child, is a difficult, disruptive prisoner. But now he visits the day care unit frequently and is feeling better than he has in years.

As well as self-harm and suicide attempts, Belmarsh has to be constantly alert to the risks of escape, rioting and violence. Half of all its inmates have been under the care of a psychiatrist, and up to 10% are severely disturbed. Belmarsh's mental health unit was set up after four inmates took their lives over a period of seven months in 1997.

In January 1999, the Oxleas NHS trust went into partnership with Belmarsh, and the mental health unit - named "Cass" after a deceased member of staff - was born. It services 1,000 inmates per year, half of them inpatients and half off the wing.

The year of Cass's birth saw just one suicide in Belmarsh, and only one more last year. The prison has been given £15,000 to spread the secret of its success to other prisons.

Fiona Lydon, head of clinical services, says: "We are there to help inmates who aren't coping, who may be self-harming or severely depressed. A lot of them should be in hospital, but they have personality disorders rather than mental illness, so we're stuck with them." Belmarsh's mental health service transfers just 70 inmates a year to secure hospitals.

Lydon continues: "After severe criticism from the chief inspector of prisons for the high number of deaths in custody, the governor did away with the old medical model and advertised for a head of healthcare, looking at service delivery in the community as a model. Being NHS led means inmates are more trusting of us, more likely to use the service."

Ian Cummings, an NHS psychiatrist and one of the unit's 11 staff, spends three-and-a-half days a week at the prison. He says: "We have lots of high-profile inmates here, on murder and sexual offences. Many are acutely mentally ill, with no structure to what they do in prison. We offer simple things to start with - table tennis, a relaxing atmosphere, comfy chairs - to encourage inmates to know the unit. If they're interested we can offer more, such as occupational therapy, art, music, yoga, counselling, mood management groups. We have a duty of care to the individuals beyond what they have done.

"Outside, there are lots of ways of dealing with depression. Maybe you'll talk to a friend, have a drink, or go to the gym to relax. Here, they don't have those means," Cummings says.

"A lot of these inmates have been victims themselves, and we are dealing with one of society's most disadvantaged groups. We have a chance to make a real impact."

Senior prison officer Jan Czajkowski is a former Yorkshire miner who, with occupational therapist Tania Nicholls, runs the Cass unit. His job is to persuade inmates to come to the unit. Czajkowski, who moved from the landing because he "didn't want to be a 'hard-nosed screw' for 20 years", says: "It was hard at first because the rest of the prison think if you're in the 'fluffy bunny' club you can't be secure. The cynics say we're a coffee shop for psychopaths. But what we are is an oasis in the prison desert. The work we do in our unit is like an oil tanker - tip it a bit and it could go out of control. We try to divert our inmates away from disaster."

Paul Branks, clinical manager of the unit, adds: "We are dealing with everyone from clever, astute men to the behaviourally sub-normal. Some need crisis intervention, others just need to be observed and assessed. We have to be good communicators."

Self-harm gets much worse than lacerated arms in Belmarsh. Billy, a young inmate with a string of minor offences who is described as a "poor coper", developed a habit of opening up a wound in his stomach and filling it with cutlery, food and excrement, which gave him septicemia.

Prison officer Maggie Shiret says he has "not cut up for ages" after the unit turned him around. "Billy just needed someone to offload to, but he won't have that when he goes home. He's got nothing to go home to."

Billy uses the "snooze room", a therapeutic chill-out area for inmates, designed by a nurse and funded by a charitable donation. It has pan-pipe background music and moving light patterns on the walls from a "bubble machine". There are yoga mats and aromatherapy sprays.

Among a group of men working with clay in the art room, while listening to classical music, is Anthony, who was given a seven-year sentence for manslaughter as the balance of his mind was deemed to have been disturbed at the time he beat somebody to death with a blunt instrument. He says: "I came to prison just after attempting suicide, and it's a culture shock. I come to the unit every day to release tension, by learning relaxation and doing creative writing.

"The activities can help us to address our problems and move on."

More and more prisons recognise that learning basic skills and how to do a CV just isn't enough to prepare troubled inmates for release. By 2004, every prisoner released with serious mental health problems will have a care plan and a care coordinator. Also, as part of an NHS plan to bring prison mental health in line with what is available in the community, there will be 300 more staff with specialist mental health training to augment the existing 2,000.

Derek, a muscular man who has just started a life sentence for murder, uses yoga. "It makes me calm, mentally at ease, with an inner peace I've never known before," he says. "It helps you shut out all the shouting and bickering all around you. It helps me to cope with prison, with an existence that is totally devoid of compassion."

Names of inmates have been changed.

Danger watch: the priority for prisons

Since 1996, 394 prisoners in England and Wales have committed suicide. Last year, suicides fell by 10%, from 91 to 82. This was the first fall since 1995, when 59 prisoners killed themselves. But in just the first month of 2001, seven prisoners took their lives.

In addition, since 1998, there have been 3,542 reported incidents of prisoners hanging or strangling themselves that have not resulted in death. Between 1998 and 2000, reported incidents rose by 54% - and incidents are generally under-reported.

Some 14% of male prisoners and 20% of female prisoners have borderline personality disorders, compared to 1.8% in the outside population.

In April the government will introduce a three-year strategy to reduce prisoner suicide and self-harm. In the first year, £8m will be invested to create more first-night centres for new prisoners, safe cells, crisis suites and gated cells. Inmates in 10 pilot prisons will be screened to identify mental health problems and care packages will be provided for high-risk cases.

Staff in these prisons will be supported by specialist mental health teams and dedicated drug detoxification units. Suicide prevention coordinators will be employed in high-risk local prisons, which will have more trained listeners. Frontline staff will also get more training in mental health and suicide prevention.

Martin Narey, director general of the prison service, has instructed all prison governors to make the prevention of suicide their highest priority in 2001.

Alison Benjamin

webTitle: Alternative solutions to the foot and mouth epidemic

fields.headline: Kill or cure?
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth strikes again, and as ever our only answer is slaughter. But the disease isn't so deadly,  Abigail Woods argues, so why don't we treat it sensibly?
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth strikes again, and as ever our only answer is slaughter. But the disease isn't so deadly, Abigail Woods argues, so why don't we treat it sensibly?
fields.body:
The reappearance of foot and mouth disease (FMD) in Britain has dealt a further blow to the fortunes of British farmers. And in its efforts to stamp out the disease, the Ministry of Agriculture is applying measures that have changed little in more than 100 years: all infected pigs and their contacts upon the premises must be slaughtered.

The current outbreak has revived the memories of those who lived through the 1967-68 outbreak - the most devastating in British history. Yet that was merely the latest in a long history of devastation wreaked by this disease, which was rarely absent from its first recorded appearance in Britain in 1839 until the 1970s. The rapid spread of FMD by frequently unidentifiable means and the far-reaching consequences of the government's chosen control policy meant that for years - until supplanted by BSE - FMD was widely regarded as the most dangerous animal plague known.

But FMD is not a killer disease. Most strains cause only sporadic deaths among young or sick animals; the vast majority suffer only lameness and loss of appetite, recovering in two or three weeks. Nor does FMD have many human health implications. Transfer to humans is rare and symptoms are mild. Because of this, the slaughter policy in the past has stimulated widespread opposition.

The government's justification for slaughter is older than the policy itself. It is based solely on the fact that recovered animals show a decline in meat and milk productivity. Given its extreme contagiousness, officials say that if the disease is permitted to spread freely, the economic losses inflicted would outweigh the costs of eliminating FMD.

In addition, the occurrence of even a single case of FMD leads many disease-free nations to place an immediate ban upon our valuable export trade. Disease freedom is therefore a precondition of international trade, and this could not be obtained through disease treatment or vaccination.

The agriculture ministry therefore regards FMD primarily as an economic problem, not an animal welfare or public health issue. But while the productivity and export arguments may favour FMD elimination at the present time of intensive farming and open EU trade, they do not explain the origin of this policy or its continuation throughout most of the 20th century.

It can be argued, indeed, that the slaughter policy has been self- reinforcing, giving rise to the very agricultural and economic conditions which justify its continuation.

Large-scale state control of livestock disease dates from the 1860s, by which time FMD had been prevalent for more than 20 years. Slaughter, import regulation and movement restriction were introduced to control the killer cattle plague, a new contagious disease which devastated the national herd from 1865-67.

Because of the success of such measures, there was a movement for the extension of controls to manage other prevailing contagious ailments, including FMD. Strong opposition to this was grounded in the widespread belief that FMD was an extremely mild and inconsequential disease, very unlike the cattle plague.

But this was successfully countered by a group of wealthy, influential breeders, whose stock suffered a more severe form of disease, with corresponding economic losses. In this way, FMD became subject to legislative controls while many other prevalent diseases inflicting equivalent, or greater, economic damage were ignored.

It was, therefore, the economic interests of the influential few which informed the original decision for state control of FMD. However, once these far-reaching measures were widely experienced - and failed to control the disease - they came to be identified with the disease itself. FMD occurrence began to be viewed as an economic disaster, not because it affected the milk supply but because it involved stock destruction and the prevention of marketing. As such, prevention was vital and farmers started to support the state programme for FMD elimination. This meant that when slaughter was first introduced in the 1910s - nominally to deal with initial outbreaks, rather than a widespread epidemic - there was little farming opposition.

By the time of the extensive outbreak of 1922-24, however, slaughter was applied in almost every case, resulting in more than 250,000 deaths. At this point, the ministry answered criticisms by stating that disease elimination was essential to preserve the export trade. Owing to a government policy prioritising the production and export of manufacturing, not agricultural goods, this trade largely consisted of valuable pedigree stock, whose aristocratic owners undoubtedly influenced and supported the ministry's action.

It was not until after the second world war that the export trade expanded. By this time, a new emphasis on agricultural productivity which favoured intensive farming methods gave further justification to strict FMD controls. The fact that many nations are now disease free and impose export bans upon other infected countries is in itself a direct result of British action.

Partly, this occurred in the tit-for-tat attitude that seems to inform international BSE prevention. But also, in forming the European Commission on FMD in 1954, Britain successfully encouraged other countries to adopt similar FMD controls. The existence of reciprocal export bans thereby reinforced the ministry's position on the need to eliminate the disease, rather than simply control it.

Using arguments of productivity and the export trade, the ministry has repeatedly refused to contemplate alternative FMD controls. However, this reliance upon such primitive measures - which predate the germ theory - has drawn frequent criticism, as huge scientific advances in disease control developed during the late 19th and 20th century have seemingly passed FMD by. If it never intended to diversify FMD controls, why did the government pour millions of pounds into a FMD research institute, founded at Pirbright in 1924, with the express aim of making FMD less harmful to Britain?

In 1952, FMD spread throughout Europe, where it was combated using newly developed vaccines. Maff refused to consider such a step, despite rampant disease in Britain. This caused press condemnation. How had scientists spent public money if it was not to expressly aid British agriculture? In fact, vaccine research and production did occur in Britain, but only as a result of the second world war, when the ministry feared that a limited meat supply could lead to the abandonment of slaughter.

The threat of FMD as a biological weapon was also taken extremely seriously during the 1940s and 50s and ensured ongoing prioritisation of vaccine research. However, due to a culture of secrecy (the hangover of which gave rise to the recent BSE debacle), such work was never publicised for fear that farmers would clamour for vaccine if they knew it existed. During the 1960s, when most European nations had embarked upon extensive FMD vaccination programmes, the ministry again refused to apply such measures to control the devastation in Britain.

This story of FMD explodes the myth that the biological features of a disease automatically inform its "correct" management. It also reveals the diversity of economic arguments used to support slaughter - not all of which are openly acknowledged to the public. In response to the present outbreak, the government, as in the past, will undoubtedly, explain FMD slaughter in terms of productivity and the export market, and in economic terms their arguments will probably be justified.

But these reasons have effectively been "created" over time - in part, to provide additional justification for an always-questionable policy. Time will tell how prepared the nation is to tolerate such arguments.

And in its efforts to stamp out the disease, the Ministry of Agriculture is applying measures that have changed little in more than 100 years: all infected pigs and their contacts upon the premises must be slaughtered. The current outbreak has revived the memories of those who lived through the 1967-68 outbreak - the most devastating in British history. Yet that was merely the latest in a long history of devastation wreaked by this disease, which was rarely absent from its first recorded appearance in Britain in 1839 until the 1970s. The rapid spread of FMD by frequently unidentifiable means and the far-reaching consequences of the government's chosen control policy meant that for years - until supplanted by BSE - FMD was widely regarded as the most dangerous animal plague known. But FMD is not a killer disease. Most strains cause only sporadic deaths among young or sick animals; the vast majority suffer only lameness and loss of appetite, recovering in two or three weeks. Nor does FMD have many human health implications. Transfer to humans is rare and symptoms are mild. Because of this, the slaughter policy in the past has stimulated widespread opposition. The government's justification for slaughter is older than the policy itself. It is based solely on the fact that recovered animals show a decline in meat and milk productivity. Given its extreme contagiousness, officials say that if the disease is permitted to spread freely, the economic losses inflicted would outweigh the costs of eliminating FMD. In addition, the occurrence of even a single case of FMD leads many disease-free nations to place an immediate ban upon our valuable export trade. fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Environment news
fields.body:
Culling fields

How long before Maff uses the foot and mouth episode to complete its long-desired extermination of British wildlife? The blame for the last serious outbreaks was partly laid on starlings, theoretical spreaders of the disease, and the ministry is already saying that, if vets fail to control the epidemic, it may have to "review the wildlife situation". Can we therefore expect to see a state-sanctioned massacre of any deer, hedgehogs, squirrels, foxes, birds and wild boar that remain after 30 years of intensive farming? Badgers for once may escape, if only because they are being officially massacred anyway.

With friends...

The "green movement" - FOE, WWF, CPRE, the Green Alliance, RSPB, the Wildlife Trusts and Greenpeace - meets today in conjunction with another newspaper for a pre-election discussion. On the platform responding to "pledges" the groups have tortuously managed to agree on and want the parties to adopt, will be Labour, LibDem and Tory politicos. But the Green Party has not been invited and is in a great huff. "It's nothing personal", says one of the organisers. "If we asked them, there would be no room on the platform and we'd have to ask the Scottish nationalists and Plaid." This is tosh, but out of sympathy and because the Guardian has not been invited either - on the basis, it seems, that it would offend the Tories - Eco soundings will invite the Green party to an exclusive cup of tea. Nothing personal.

Stitch up

Nike, the global cobbler, has had its problems with protesters complaining about the conditions of its workers in poor countries. So it recently offered to customise shoes, for $50, by stitching on any legal name or phrase that people submit. American Jonah Peretti duly sent the multinational $50 to put on "Sweatshop". Nike refused. Peretti tried again. Nike refused. Now an email of their correspondence has been forwarded to about 10m people - rather more than would have seen Mr Peretti's shoes had Nike just taken his money.

Crop that

The Philippines has summarily stopped all GM research because of "great objection from civil society", said President Macapagal-Arroyo. In Britain, there is also deep opposition but the government has bunged millions more into research. It's a cheap point, but we have lots of farming malaises, and the Philippines doesn't.

webTitle: Profile: Helen Carroll, pioneering midwife to the homeless

fields.headline: Birth of a notion
fields.standfirst: Helen Carroll, pioneering midwife to the homeless
fields.trailText: Profile: Helen Carroll, pioneering midwife to the homeless
fields.body:
Helen Carroll doesn't sound or look like a pioneer. Her voice is soft and she stands at just 5ft 1in. But her appearance is deceptive: Carroll has strength and determination in abundance.

Today, she collects the OBE awarded for her work as a midwife dealing specifically with homeless families in south Manchester. It's not a common job description - she knows of only one other person in the country doing anything similar.

Carroll, 45, arrived at her specialism via community midwifery, where she noticed inequalities. "Homeless families weren't accessing services properly," she says. "It was all crisis management. No one knew they were there until something bad happened."

She suggested it would be logical to have a homeless families midwife, but she was ahead of her time. "It was the late 1980s and management didn't feel it was the right thing to do. It wasn't on the political agenda then. Public health wasn't such a buzz word."

So Carroll got involved with a special interest group for homeless families and continued her work on an informal basis. It took until 1996 for her idea to be taken up officially. A new head of midwifery services agreed that a role should be developed for special needs, covering homeless families, teenage pregnancies and women with mental health problems. Carroll was given the job - and a very wide brief.

"Homeless families are my priority," she says, "but I work with women with problems such as schizophrenia, with postnatal depression and with teenagers. I also give family planning advice. It's difficult to fit everything in, but you can't tell people you won't help because it's after official hours."

There's a lot of liaison with different agencies (social services, health visitors, drug counsellors and housing departments) but Carroll says: "I'm lucky because there's no stigma attached to midwives, so I'm generally looked at in a positive way by the women who need my help. I also make a real effort to be proactive. I find out if these women are booked into hospitals for their labour, if they're linked to other agencies, if they know how to help themselves. I give them support and antenatal and postnatal care, and keep some continuity going."

The women she helps are not always the easiest to deal with, but Carroll says that's not surprising. "It's important not to be judgmental and to have some empathy. I don't want these women to be painted as down-at-heel."

She focuses mainly on three homeless family hostels and a supported accommodation unit for single young women. She has a caseload of 37, with most of the women aged between 17 and 30.

The work can be draining. Carroll recalls a girl who committed suicide a few years after having her baby. She left a letter thanking her for her help, but Carroll still wishes she had done more for the girl.

She is keen for midwifery to have the kind of city-wide team that exists for social workers and health visitors. Last year, 41% of the women Carroll looked after were fleeing domestic violence. Such women could be lost by the system, but Carroll is determined they won't be. "In the last five years, domestic violence has become something of a political football, but it's important to remember the real people it affects. You have to help the women become survivors. They need emotional support and maternity care. I just have to adapt to the circumstances." That might mean changing the hospital they go to, because the boyfriend knows where it is, or giving antenatal care at the hostel.

She too experienced aggressive behaviour. "Once I had this frightened, pregnant woman, her five-year-old twins hanging on to my legs, and an irate man screaming at all of us," she says. "The hostel had a panic button and the police soon came to take the man away, but it was a stressful experience."

Carroll's expertise has involved her with other domestic violence committees and mental health forums. She is also looking at public health and the role of the midwife for the Department of Health.

"Ten years ago you wouldn't have found midwives sitting on these kind of committees. We're progressing but there's a lot more to do. I'm nervous about my OBE because it puts the spotlight on me, but it's good for midwifery and I'm hoping it will be good for the women I treat. Something has to be done about affordable, desirable housing."

webTitle: Poet Michael Symmons Roberts on his childhood spent in fear of nuclear threat

fields.headline: Nuclear families
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot on a childhood spent under the cloud of fear that enveloped Greenham Common
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot on a childhood spent under the cloud of fear that enveloped Greenham Common
fields.body:
Poet Michael Symmons Roberts returned to Greenham Common in 1998, to see the landscape of his childhood and adolescence being demolished in a way he could never have imagined. What he had imagined, back in the late 1970s and early 1980s, was not just demolition, but nuclear annihilation. A blinding flash. Fierce heat. The end of him, his family, his friends, the rest of Newbury, the rest of Berkshire and, for all he knew, most of southern England.

All that would remain would be those huge concrete silos that housed American missiles on British soil. At least he was right about that. They were still there, covered in grass and ivy now, but impervious to assault by bulldozer or JCB. "I saw them as soon as we had gone through this business park full of computer companies and security firms," he recalls. "The road suddenly opened up and there was a vast wasteland, like a moonscape."

What was once the longest runway in Europe had been broken up. Halfway along it was an abandoned Fiat Uno, its windscreen smashed by a chunk of concrete. "The joyriders had scrawled 'F-off, Yanks' along the side," says Roberts, 37. "They'd done what we had wanted to do at their age, which was to storm in and make a claim. But it was a pyrrhic victory."

The Yanks had effed-off years ago. Even most of the women protesters who had occupied the famous Greenham Common peace camp for so long had departed. All that remained was a solitary caravan at the main gate and, inside, one or two nature wardens and the demolition workers. "When I first saw what they were doing, I had an odd reaction," Robert goes on. "I thought it a shame that something so familiar from my childhood was being swept away. Then I checked myself. What was I saying? I started to remember what it was really like to grow up here."

He's about to tell the rest of us. His third book of poems, Burning Babylon - dedicated to Greenham Common - will be published later this year. But next week, Radio 4 will broadcast Roberts's first play, Brimstone, inspired by the same subject. The main characters are a demolition man and a female nature warden. Both are locals with other reasons for coming back. The warden had once "crossed the line" to join the peace women. "It's a useful dramatic device, but I never knew anyone who did it in real life," says Roberts.

Apart from being a poet, Roberts is a Manchester-based BBC television producer and no stranger to radio. Why has he chosen now to write his first play? "Sometimes, when the subject matter is very close, you can't see it," he says. "I'd been back to see my parents on many occasions, but only when the demolition started did I take notice of the air base again."

The memories stirred up a long-hidden resentment "against the society that produced something so lunatic on our doorstep," he explains. "We were right in the nuclear triangle between Aldermaston, where they designed these weapons, Burghfield Royal Ordnance Factory, where they made them, and Greenham Common, where they were deployed. Everybody at my school was conscious of being in the firing line.

"I've begun to brood on why we should have had that blot on our childhood. My oldest boy, Joseph, is seven and imaginative, quite capable of being terrified by floods or monsters. Just imagine trying to tell him what it was like to have Greenham Common down the road."

Roberts was the same age as Joseph is now when his parents moved from Preston to Newbury, where his father became sales manager at a local company. Life was reasonably peaceful and the local air base even staged open days. Not for much longer, though. He was 12 or 13 when he became conscious that more and more US Air Force F1-11s were darkening the skies over Berkshire. "I remember one of them dropping white dust on our school playing fields. Because it looked like snow, we all picked it up. There was a rumour doing the rounds for days afterwards that the dust was radioactive."

The rumour mill began turning ever faster in 1979, when the missiles arrived. Roberts lay awake at nights, sometimes chilled with fear. What was that siren? And that plane overhead? Was the big bang coming?

Threads, Barry Hines's TV play about a nuclear strike on Sheffield, was screened on the BBC at the height of this phase of cold war tension. "It scared the hell out of us," Roberts recalls. "You could tell some kids were really nervous, but there was a lot of bravado among the boys. We'd compete to tell the most terrifying stories of what it would be like. A hot carving knife peeling off your flesh was one of the favourites."

He was with friends in Newbury when he first saw some peace women. "We knew who they were, but we were too awe-struck to go near them. They looked as though they'd come down from the mountains. Very exotic." Also exotic, in a different way, were the American airmen. "They had their own mini-town on the edge of the base, with baseball pitches and a grocery store," Roberts says. "You'd even see big Cadillacs cruising around. When we were old enough to drive, we'd go out there and gawp. At night we'd play motorised tag with the military police. We'd park somewhere on the perimeter fence and shine the headlights inside on full beam. After 10 minutes, they'd turn up, we'd move on and they'd follow. They never spoke. They just made it plain we were under observation."

Did he ever feel as though he was living under an occupying power? "There was something of that about it. Here was a place we couldn't go, but we knew it was threatening our future because we saw it regularly on the national news."

At 19, he went to Oxford to study philosophy and theology, returning after three years to join the Newbury Weekly News. "I was politically sympathetic to the peace women but put off by their manifest hostility to me as a man and as a representative of the press. They would only be interviewed by female reporters. And when I covered their cases before the local magistrates, they were always bristling with hostility towards the court system and the media.

"They were part of a movement whose intentions were entirely laudable at the beginning. But the peace movement got hijacked by another agenda - a sort of feminist-separatist policy which made them even more distanced from the local community."

Did the women have any influence on the process that saw US airmen ultimately replaced by demolition men?"It was more to do with economic changes in the former Soviet Union than anything happening in Newbury or, indeed, Whitehall," Roberts says. "This was world-stage politics played out on somebody's doorstep. It just happened to be ours."

The big band or just a rehearsal?

Sirens in the small hours:

in come the Cadillacs and Chryslers,

the families who live outside.

Yellow, to red, to black alert;

troops in masks and radiation suits usher cars through Main Gate.

Yellow Gate women stagger

from their tents and squat in the road to scupper this night exercise,

but only the Colonel knows for sure

if this is a rehearsal, or the big bang.

Either way, it must feel real.

An extract from The Sacrifice, by Michael Symmons Roberts, from the book Burning Babylon

Brimstone will be broadcast on Radio 4 at 2.15pm next Tuesday. Burning Babylon will be published, price £8, by Jonathan Cape in August.

Was the big bang coming? Threads, Barry Hines's TV play about a nuclear strike on Sheffield, was screened on the BBC at the height of this phase of cold war tension. "It scared the hell out of us," Roberts recalls. "You could tell some kids were really nervous, but there was a lot of bravado among the boys. We'd compete to tell the most terrifying stories of what it would be like. A hot carving knife peeling off your flesh was one of the favourites." He was with friends in Newbury when he first saw some peace women. "We knew who they were, but we were too awe-struck to go near them. They looked as though they'd come down from the mountains. Very exotic." Also exotic, in a different way, were the American airmen. "They had their own mini-town on the edge of the base, with baseball pitches and a grocery store," Roberts says. "You'd even see big Cadillacs cruising around. When we were old enough to drive, we'd go out there and gawp. At night we'd play motorised tag with the military police. We'd park somewhere on the perimeter fence and shine the headlights inside on full beam. After 10 minutes, they'd turn up, we'd move on and they'd follow. They never spoke. They just made it plain we were under observation." Did he ever feel as though he was living under an occupying power? "There was something of that about it. Here was a place we couldn't go, but we knew it was threatening our future because we saw it regularly on the national news." At 19, he went to Oxford to study philosophy and theology, returning after three years to join the Newbury Weekly News. "I was politically sympathetic to the peace women but put off by their manifest hostility to me as a man and as a representative of the press. They would only be interviewed by female reporters. And when I covered their cases before the local magistrates, they were always bristling with hostility towards the court system and the media. "They were part of a movement whose intentions were entirely laudable at the beginning. But the peace movement got hijacked by another agenda - a sort of feminist-separatist policy which made them even more distanced from the local community." Did the women have any influence on the process that saw US airmen ultimately replaced by demolition men?"It was more to do with economic changes in the former Soviet Union than anything happening in Newbury or, indeed, Whitehall," Roberts says. "This was world-stage politics played out on somebody's doorstep. It just happened to be ours." The big band or just a rehearsal? Sirens in the small hours: in come the Cadillacs and Chryslers, the families who live outside. Yellow, to red, to black alert; troops in masks and radiation suits usher cars through Main Gate. Yellow Gate women stagger from their tents and squat in the road to scupper this night exercise, but only the Colonel knows for sure if this is a rehearsal, or the big bang. Either way, it must feel real. An extract from The Sacrifice, by Michael Symmons Roberts, from the book Burning Babylon Brimstone will be broadcast on Radio 4 at 2.15pm next Tuesday. Burning Babylon will be published, price £8, by Jonathan Cape in August.

fields.headline: Bloom boom
fields.standfirst: Kirklees bids for wildflower crown
fields.trailText: Kirklees bids for wildflower crown
fields.body:
Claiming the title Wildflower Garden of England is audacious, but Mike O'Rourke, of Kirklees metropolitan council, has no hesitation about doing just that for his area, which is tucked in the shadow of the Pennines, on moorland dissected by valleys and ribboned with mill towns and villages.

"We have produced over 200,000 plants, all of which have been planted out by school pupils, community groups and the council," he says. "This year we will top 360,000. That's one for every man, woman and child living in Kirklees".

In the past two years, Kirklees has established almost 200 new wildflower meadows on 40 acres across the authority, from Batley to Denby Dale, Mirfield to Meltham. Yellow rattle, oxeye daisy and cowslips bloom in the spring where once only perennial rye grass flourished. School grounds and public open spaces have been left unmown and planted with peat-free compost plugs. A formal public park has been transformed. Two acres of wildflower-rich hay meadow on the outskirts of Huddersfield now lie between rose beds and manicured baize grassland.

Using urban parks was the idea of Richard Brooker, head of the council's leisure and recreation services. He reasoned that, with public involvement and ownership, some of these formal open spaces could contribute to the authority's biodiversity plans.

After complaints that the long grass was a litter trap, O'Rourke got volunteers to do weekly clean-ups. More than 1,000 people also turned out for a day of wildflower-linked events in the park last August.

The inspiration came from a Landlife project at St Helens, Lan cashire. "That and my past work with Greater Manchester council - seeing so much landscape work resulting in monocultures, green billiard tables with lollipop trees - made me think there must be a better way to manage public open spaces," says O'Rourke.

Involving a wide range of community groups was the notion of Yorkshire Water, which put in £24,000 over two years. Community affairs manager Regan Cooper says: "Success depended on engaging local communities. People came forward as a result of local newspaper coverage, making it much more than just a council-owned project. About 25,000 people of all ages took part in some way."

But Kirklees's claim may not go unchallenged. Across the Pennines in Knowsley, Landlife has been creating wildflower meadows since the 1980s, with financial support from the borough council. In 1992, an early day motion was tabled in Parliament, christening Knowsley the "Wildflower Borough".

Richard Scott, project manager for Landlife, is relaxed about O'Rourke's claim. "What is important is that we get it right," he says. "The biggest problem is soil fertility. Many public open spaces have been managed intensively. Most wildflowers prefer poor soils."

Back in Kirklees, O'Rourke enthuses about his plans for this year: "I'm targeting grass verges next - miles and miles of roadside nature reserves. We will also have three community festivals, bringing local people closer into the project. They will set the pace and come forward with new sites and plans."

Pete Bowler is a Guardian country diarist.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Racism: one step forward...

fields.headline: Racism: one step forward...
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Will the Macpherson report into the racist killing of Stephen Lawrence go the same way as the Scarman report?
fields.body:
Will the Macpherson report into the racist killing of Stephen Lawrence go the same way as the Scarman report? Twenty years ago, Scarman's report into the Brixton riots received an ecstatic welcome and an ocean of warm words, but achieved little long-term change. Macpherson's reception was more mixed, but on its second anniversary last week the momentum for reform was still being maintained.

Of course, there have been reverses. The backlash began in week one, when the Mail and the Telegraph sought to distort the report by suggesting its "institutional racist" findings against the Met, meant every officer was a racist. It meant no such thing. What it spelled out was that unintentional as well as intentional racism can cause serious harm.

There is disappointing news on the recruitment of Asian and black officers. Last Saturday's Guardian survey showed that new officers from ethnic minorities dropped this year (155) compared to a year earlier (261). This makes home secretary Jack Straw's ambitious target of 6,000 extra ethnic officers by 2009 look even more distant. Currently, there are only 2,900 in a force of 125,000.

Yet progress on other fronts continues. The 100% increase in reports of racist incidents is good news. It shows ethnic minorities are more ready to come forward - and police more ready to prosecute, with 1,500 convictions for racial violence or harassment.

In April, the Race Relations (Amendment) Act comes into force, outlawing discrimination in all public services and placing a statutory duty on public bodies to promote race equality. Institutional racism is not confined to the police. It infects all services: health, education, armed services, civil service and judiciary. As the prime minister noted in 1997, there were just two Asian and black people in Whitehall's top four grades and a mere 58 among its 3,000 senior policy-makers.

Stop and search continues - as Macpherson wanted - but pilot programmes show stops can be reduced, while the proportion of arrests increases. The ninefold increase in stops between 1986 and 1996 was absurd. It led to gross discrimination, with black people five times more likely to be stopped.

Straw can take a bow. His record on fighting racism is impressive, even if its extension to public services was belated. It's also brave. The last British Social Attitudes survey shows working class people to be much more prejudiced than professional people. Hence, William Hague's bid for these votes with his u-turn in December, condemning Macpherson. In the last election, all leaders agreed to discipline members stirring up racism. Just how Hague could do the same this time is far from clear.

webTitle: New scheme to tackle drugs problem in Cornwall

fields.headline: Alive and kicking
fields.standfirst: Behind the picture postcard images, there is a dark side to Cornwall.  Linda Jackson on a scheme to tackle a serious drugs problem
fields.trailText: Behind the picture postcard images, there is a dark side to Cornwall. Linda Jackson on a scheme to tackle a serious drugs problem
fields.body:
Teri used to boast that if it was not nailed down, she would steal it. Telephones, personal organisers and video cassettes would all go towards funding her £350-a-week drugs habit. The cash was to pay for amphetamines, which she injected up to three times a day.

That was two years ago. She has since taken part in a pioneering project that has turned her life around from an addict who would stop at nothing to get a fix into a 28-year-old with a job - and self-respect.

West Cornwall, with its picture postcard image, is an unlikely setting for a revolution in criminal justice. But this is what has happened in an area that has become known as the county's "heroin capital". It has been prompted in part by the recognition that rising drug abuse and the associated rise in crime has overwhelmed the existing system.

It is almost three years since the drug assessment and stabilisation programme (Dasp) was introduced in the Cornish council wards of Penwith and Kerrier as an alternative to other sentences, including prison.

The scheme, targeted at persistent offenders who use drugs intravenously, is based on rehabilitation. Instead of custodial sentences, offend ers are given probation orders with the condition that they participate fully in a detoxification programme, admit to their offences and help in retrieving stolen property. Drug workers liaise constantly with police and probation officers to monitor any non-compliances. Any evidence of continued use of drugs or criminal activity is dealt with harshly, with the offender brought back to court.

The success of the detoxification programme in dealing with the "hardest cases" has led to similar schemes rolling out across Britain with the introduction of drug treatment and testing orders. Under the orders, introduced last October, drug abusers with long criminal records agree to have their addiction treated, and, in return, courts can decide against jailing them or imposing large fines. Addicts are subjected to twice weekly urine tests and regular court reviews of their progress. Offenders who go back on to illegal street drugs are returned to court where they will face a traditional punishment.

Keith Hellawell, the government's anti-drugs coordinator, hopes the orders will break the cycle of drugs and crime. Announcing introduction of the orders, home secretary Jack Straw cited Home Office research showing that six in 10 criminals take drugs. Also, it is claimed that a third of all property crimes such as burglary are drug related - with an annual cost to the country of £2.5bn.

The scheme is due to be rolled out across the UK in 2003. But in west Cornwall there has already been a dramatic reduction in crime following Dasp's launch in October 1997.

Penwith, which stretches from the craggy cliffs of Land's End to the picturesque, bustling town of St Ives, has become a haven for heroin addicts. At least nine dealers are known by police to operate from Penzance. Amphetamines, rather than heroin, are the main drug in the neighbouring district of Kerrier. And both areas have a drug dependency problem comparable with some inner cities. The average hard drug problem costs £282 a week - more than £14,500 a year. The scale of drug use is such that it is estimated that 70% of crime within Kerrier and Penwith is drug-related.

Liaison at an early stage between the police and the probation service and community drugs team has been crucial. In just 12 months, house burglaries dropped by a third in Kerrier, and fell by 10% in Penwith, while non-domestic burglaries fell by a third in Penwith and 15% in Kerrier.

Bob Crossland, Cornwall drug action team coordinator, says it proved vital to start the treatment process while the addict was on bail following an arrest. Detox treatment could be offered immediately - with the defendant taking substitute prescription drugs at a community pharmacy, and being given counselling.

"We are very lucky as we have no waiting lists to enter treatment," says Crossland. "This minimises the pos sibility of any further offences being committed before a court order. Offering a place on the programme also motivates the offender to admit the offences as well as assist in the retrieval of stolen property. We can also see how motivated they are in keeping appointments with the community drugs team."

Unlike Cornwall, other areas have long waiting lists for drug treatment programmes and are struggling to give offenders the help they need quickly. They are also shackled by a shortage of community drug workers - a situation which has angered probation workers. "Recruitment problems should have been addressed before launching the scheme," says Harry Fletcher, of the National Association of Probation Officers. "Offenders can not wait six months for treatment."

The treatment on offer varies across the country. In Wakefield and Pontefract, West Yorkshire, complementary medicines have been offered alongside traditional detoxification programmes to offenders for the last three years. Addicts can receive a massage or auricular acupuncture to help treat their addiction, on top of conventional detoxification treatment. Small lapses are tolerated in the first few months, but any major lapses lead to a reappearance in a special drugs court and a possible prison sentence.

For Teri, one of Dasp's biggest success stories, the prospect of spending six months in prison was enough to persuade her to undergo treatment. She had started experimenting with drugs when she was 15, but it was not until she lost her job, at the age of 24, that her problems began. She had a live-in job at a hotel, but found herself homeless when the hotel suddenly closed down.

Teri says: "I was found somewhere to live in Truro which was full of dealers. I couldn't get a job and couldn't go back to college. I had nothing to do, so I started taking speed. After three or four months of playing about with speed, I started injecting. It was costing £500 a day so I started stealing and began shoplifting to order. If it cost more than £10 and wasn't nailed down I would take it."

She was caught several times and ended up on remand at Eastwood Park prison, Gloucester. With nine previous convictions for shoplifting and two for credit card fraud, she faced a minimum six-month jail sentence. Terrified by the prospect, she agreed to take part in the Dasp scheme as part of a two-year probation order. One of the conditions was spending the first 12 months living in a bail hostel in Camborne.

After five months on the programme, Teri was allowed to leave the hostel as she had been clear of street drugs and had committed no further crimes. Shortly afterwards, she was off drugs completely, her probation order was revoked and she was in her own flat. Two months ago, she started a new job as a waitress in a hotel.

Tough route to success

Thirty-four people in Cornwall have been placed on a Dasp order, including eight women. Others were referred to the community drugs team, but assessed as not suitable. Half have succeeded, or are continuing on the programme.

All have experienced a reduc tion in the use of street drugs; 78% no longer use them at all. Women are more likely to succeed than men; three-quarters of women succeeded.

Amphetamine users achieved better outcomes than heroin users, and those aged 25-32 were more likely to succeed.

fields.headline: Shared vision
fields.standfirst: Mencap launches 'inclusive' manifesto
fields.trailText: Mencap launches 'inclusive' manifesto
fields.body:
People with learning disabilities have for the first time shaped the general election manifesto of charity Mencap, released this week.

Responding to criticism that it has been too paternalistic and has failed to give people with learning disabilities a voice, Mencap has changed its constitution to encourage inclusiveness. Now almost half the members of its national assembly have a learning disability.

This drive has continued through consultation with focus groups, district committees and the national assembly on the charity's priorities for the next five years. The final manifesto - Choice, Opportunity and Respect - includes promises to step up Mencap's work with children, people with profound and multiple learning disabilities and ethnic minority families.

David Scott-Ralphs, who coordinated the consultation, says that story boards, magazines and audio tapes were used in the process. "We used visual symbols and more accessible methods which allowed people with learning disabilities to make decisions. I'm not saying it was a perfect process, but we sought to listen at every stage."

Simon Cramp, a Mencap trustee who has a learning disability, says service users' influence on the charity's manifesto "gives us ownership of our future".

webTitle: Woolwich scheme designed to benefit poorer tenants

fields.headline: Banking on a better deal
fields.standfirst: Woolwich scheme designed to benefit poorer tenants
fields.trailText: Woolwich scheme designed to benefit poorer tenants
fields.body:
Housing officers are to become part-time bank managers in a new project to tackle financial exclusion, being launched tomorrow by Treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson. The move is a bid initially to reach more than 20,000 housing association tenants whose poor credit rating, or level of debt, has prevented them accessing mainstream banking facilities. The idea could, ultimately, go nationwide.

Under the plan, the Woolwich bank is allowing housing officers to authorise opening of its "open plan" account. Tenants will not have to provide a passport or driving licence - though they will have to provide four other forms of identification - nor will they be credit checked.

To avoid being stigmatised as a poor person's account, the product is being marketed under the Woolwich's open plan service, which has 500,000 existing customers. The account does not come with a cheque card or cheque book, but holders may draw money from cash machines and pay for goods with a card that prevents them becoming overdrawn.

The account also allows for up to 14 separate savings "pots" to enable easier payment of bills.

Margaret Sandford, director of People for Action, the housing umbrella group which helped devise the scheme, says: "Tenants told us they didn't want to get into debt. We hope the account will build their confidence in the banking system and enable them to gain access to the cheaper utility bills offered to people who pay by direct debit or standing order."

The project is initially being piloted by six People for Action members - North British Housing in West Yorkshire, the Mercian and Family housing associations in Birmingham, Selhal in Oldham, Broomleigh in south London, and Leicester housing association, which is testing the scheme among black and minority ethnic tenants. If successful, Sandford hopes the idea will be rolled out nationally to 1.5m housing association households.

According to a recent survey by Broomleigh, about a third of social housing tenants and private renters living in Penge and Anerly, south London, found it difficult to pay fuel bills, had no banking service whatsoever and no savings. Martina Gavan, Broomleigh's community projects officer, says: "Paying for fuel bills with key meters is very expensive and tenants turn to loan sharks and get into a spiral of debt. We have been trying to gain access for our tenants to a number of high street banks, without any luck, so this project is very welcome."

The move is a bid initially to reach more than 20,000 housing association tenants whose poor credit rating, or level of debt, has prevented them accessing mainstream banking facilities. The idea could, ultimately, go nationwide. Under the plan, the Woolwich bank is allowing housing officers to authorise opening of its "open plan" account. Tenants will not have to provide a passport or driving licence - though they will have to provide four other forms of identification - nor will they be credit checked. To avoid being stigmatised as a poor person's account, the product is being marketed under the Woolwich's open plan service, which has 500,000 existing customers. The account does not come with a cheque card or cheque book, but holders may draw money from cash machines and pay for goods with a card that prevents them becoming overdrawn. webTitle: Can the much-maligned tower block be making a comeback?

fields.headline: Tall order
fields.standfirst: Can the much-maligned tower block be making a comeback? As  John Cunningham reports, some housing groups are reaching for the sky again
fields.trailText: Can the much-maligned tower block be making a comeback? As John Cunningham reports, some housing groups are reaching for the sky again
fields.body:
Tower blocks, the detested public housing blamed for aggravating the social problems they were built to combat, are set to make a popular comeback after 30 years' controversy.

Scores of uninhabitable concrete monsters have already been demolished by councils, to the joy of disgruntled former residents. And William Hague believes that many high-rise council estates are still so unpopular that he has committed the Conservatives to tear down all remaining blighted blocks.

But this block-bashing is balanced by new enthusiasm for homes in the sky. Housing minister Nick Raynsford today opens a unique scheme in Portsmouth: the conversion of a city centre office tower into 96 flats; a mix of housing association and private ownership. And in London, Peabody Trust, the housing charity, is breaking new ground with plans for three projects of up to 20 storeys.

Jeff Welling, Portsmouth's housing services director, says that a shortage of land for housing in the city was the impetus for utilising an empty office building, renamed Chandos Rise.

In London, intense demand for accommodation for key workers in inner boroughs , and for low-income tenants, plus the prohibitive cost of new sites, is steering Peabody to plan far taller buildings than it has previously constructed, says the trust's director of development, Dickon Robinson.

Peabody has its eye on sites in Hackney, North Kensington and Southwark. If the schemes go ahead, Robinson believes that flats on the upper floors should have bigger rooms than those below, to attract occupants; and that maintenance must be of a guaranteed high standard.

Horror stories - everything from design defects to drugs; from mould to muggings - began to plague high-rise living almost as soon as blocks were erected en masse in the system-built 60s.

Catastrophes, such as the gas explosion that ripped through the corner flats of the 22-storey Ronan Point in east London in 1968, killing five people, fixed the image. Yet the reality is that most councils, while they might have pulled down some scarcely habitable blocks, still have a mix of well-run and run-down high-risers - 4,000 in all, providing homes for an estimated 800,000 people.

While there has been a national campaign by disillusioned tenants to get rid of tower blocks, there's been no concerted effort to persuade professionals in the housing sector, and residents, of their merits - until now.

The pressure group formed for this purpose hasn't picked a catchy name - the National Sustainable Tower Blocks Initiative (NSTBI) - but at least the four founding partners (Community Development Foundation, Going for Green, Groundwork and Shell Better Britain) have chosen a good moment for a campaign. In the next few years there is expected to be a huge transfer of blocks by councils to housing associations, many with no experience of the specific problems of multi-storey buildings.

There is a lot of muddle about what to do with the tower block legacy. It is roughly 10 times more expensive to refurbish than to demolish them. Finance is more easily obtained for housing association new-build schemes than for renewing localauthority stock.

No wonder there are conflicting views. Put problem families or refugees in otherwise unlettable high-rise blocks on a short-term basis, says one camp; patch up the blocks and make the best of a bad job, runs another argument. What is true is that some councils have reversed decisions to condemn blocks - and the result has been a spectacular success. This confusion has at least shown the need for a new discussion.

Several of the NSTBI's founders are, or were, environmental campaigners, and it's the extension of their concerns from countryside to cities that is leading to a re-think about high-rise. Chris Church, initiative co-ordinator, stresses that they are not in favour of retaining all blocks, whatever the cost. Those that are structurally unsound, saturated with social problems, or located on badly planned estates, may be beyond any recovery programme.

But Church, who started in Greenpeace in the 1970s, insists that revitalising the blocks must be done in a wider social, environmental and economic context.

Socially, blocks often fail because they are used inappropriately, which means they are not suitable for families with young children. For a sense of community to flourish, they need residents who are happy to be there, not desperate to move out, and residents have to be given a democratic voice in running their estates.

Economically, tower blocks in or near city centres can help improve urban life if some of the accommodation is reserved for employees who keep vital services running - transport, health and welfare.

Environmentally, the initiative argues that tower blocks have the advantage of often leaving a smaller "ecological footprint" than conventional housing. They can be more energy-efficient, and sharing facilities and services - food co-ops, community cafes and growing vegetables - can reduce waste and save residents money.

Church and his colleagues have held seminars and produced reports detailing the past perils of high-rise; and have defined the essentials for well-run blocks, as a sort of good practice guide. They argue that, as the government predicts 4.4m new households will be formed by 2016, tower blocks will be ideal for small family units. They point out that the government should realise how relevant they are to Labour policies on social inclusion, local democracy and active citizenship.

The initiative makes a cogent, well-argued case. The partners have yet to bend a ministerial ear, and still have to persuade most local authorities to support their ideas. But at least they are beginning to spread the practical message that there are plenty of examples of successful tower block communities which can be copied.

Salford, in Greater Manchester, shows how it can be done - on the Pendleton estate, whose 30 towers once made it the highest density estate in Europe. Area housing manager John Oakley says Salford council has always invested heavily in maintenance, kept vandalism to a minimum with CCTV, formed a residents' management committee, and added many communal facilities, including landscaped gardens. It has also marketed the estate's good reputation when advertising vacant flats.

Star of the estate is the 16-storey Apple Tree Court. Betty Burton, a lynchpin of the community for 22 years, surveys her desirable domain from the cafe built - together with a grand conservatory - with almost £200,000 from the national lottery charities board. "It's always been a good block," she says, listing the improvements that the tenants' association has implemented. The best testament is the list of 14 prospective tenants waiting to be interviewed for a vacant flat.

There is, perhaps, a whiff of creating model communities in tower blocks in the minds of Chris Church and his colleagues. Some might sniff at it. It is easy to see why harassed housing managers and councillors, faced with "slums in the sky", see demolition as the solution to a well-meant bit of 1960s social policy gone sour. But projections show we may need high-rises for decades to come.

Setting up a national network of tower block residents' groups is one of the initiative's ideas. Even simpler is its suggestion for a national tower blocks day, to mark the joys of living aloft.

The rise and fall and rise again...

About 6,500 multi-storey blocks went up in the UK from the early 1950s to the early 1990s. The boom period lasted 20 years from the early 1950s. About 4,000 tower blocks remain, mostly council-owned, and an estimated 800,000 people live in them. In London, the first high-rise was a 10-storey residential block in Holborn, in 1949.

Most notorious block: Ronan Point, Canning Town, east London. A corner of the 22-storey structure collapsed in 1968. Five people were killed.

Most lauded block: Trellick Tower, North Kensington, London. Designed in the 1960s by Erno Goldfinger; an architectural and housing management showplace. Almost all of its 200 residents prefer to rent rather than buy.

Worst decade for high rise: The 1970s, when the backlash against faulty structures and the concentration of social problems almost halted construction of tower blocks.

Best decades: The 1960s, when system-building led to forests of blocks; the late 1990s onwards, when luxury tower blocks became fashionable in the private sector, and the public sector realised the value of well-run high-rise buildings.

Further information on the NSTBI at www.towerblocks.org.uk
