webTitle: New scheme to tackle drugs problem in Cornwall

fields.headline: Alive and kicking
fields.standfirst: Behind the picture postcard images, there is a dark side to Cornwall. Linda Jackson on a scheme to tackle a serious drugs problem
fields.trailText: Behind the picture postcard images, there is a dark side to Cornwall. Linda Jackson on a scheme to tackle a serious drugs problem.
fields.body:
Teri used to boast that if it was not nailed down, she would steal it. Telephones, personal organisers and video cassettes would all go towards funding her £350-a-week drugs habit. The cash was to pay for amphetamines, which she injected up to three times a day.

That was two years ago. She has since taken part in a pioneering project that has turned her life around from an addict who would stop at nothing to get a fix into a 28-year-old with a job - and self-respect.

West Cornwall, with its picture postcard image, is an unlikely setting for a revolution in criminal justice. But this is what has happened in an area that has become known as the county's "heroin capital". It has been prompted in part by the recognition that rising drug abuse and the associated rise in crime has overwhelmed the existing system.

It is almost three years since the drug assessment and stabilisation programme (Dasp) was introduced in the Cornish council wards of Penwith and Kerrier as an alternative to other sentences, including prison.

The scheme, targeted at persistent offenders who use drugs intravenously, is based on rehabilitation. Instead of custodial sentences, offend ers are given probation orders with the condition that they participate fully in a detoxification programme, admit to their offences and help in retrieving stolen property. Drug workers liaise constantly with police and probation officers to monitor any non-compliances. Any evidence of continued use of drugs or criminal activity is dealt with harshly, with the offender brought back to court.

The success of the detoxification programme in dealing with the "hardest cases" has led to similar schemes rolling out across Britain with the introduction of drug treatment and testing orders. Under the orders, introduced last October, drug abusers with long criminal records agree to have their addiction treated, and, in return, courts can decide against jailing them or imposing large fines. Addicts are subjected to twice weekly urine tests and regular court reviews of their progress. Offenders who go back on to illegal street drugs are returned to court where they will face a traditional punishment.

Keith Hellawell, the government's anti-drugs coordinator, hopes the orders will break the cycle of drugs and crime. Announcing introduction of the orders, home secretary Jack Straw cited Home Office research showing that six in 10 criminals take drugs. Also, it is claimed that a third of all property crimes such as burglary are drug related - with an annual cost to the country of £2.5bn.

The scheme is due to be rolled out across the UK in 2003. But in west Cornwall there has already been a dramatic reduction in crime following Dasp's launch in October 1997.

Penwith, which stretches from the craggy cliffs of Land's End to the picturesque, bustling town of St Ives, has become a haven for heroin addicts. At least nine dealers are known by police to operate from Penzance. Amphetamines, rather than heroin, are the main drug in the neighbouring district of Kerrier. And both areas have a drug dependency problem comparable with some inner cities. The average hard drug problem costs £282 a week - more than £14,500 a year. The scale of drug use is such that it is estimated that 70% of crime within Kerrier and Penwith is drug-related.

Liaison at an early stage between the police and the probation service and community drugs team has been crucial. In just 12 months, house burglaries dropped by a third in Kerrier, and fell by 10% in Penwith, while non-domestic burglaries fell by a third in Penwith and 15% in Kerrier.

Bob Crossland, Cornwall drug action team coordinator, says it proved vital to start the treatment process while the addict was on bail following an arrest. Detox treatment could be offered immediately - with the defendant taking substitute prescription drugs at a community pharmacy, and being given counselling.

"We are very lucky as we have no waiting lists to enter treatment," says Crossland. "This minimises the pos sibility of any further offences being committed before a court order. Offering a place on the programme also motivates the offender to admit the offences as well as assist in the retrieval of stolen property. We can also see how motivated they are in keeping appointments with the community drugs team."

Unlike Cornwall, other areas have long waiting lists for drug treatment programmes and are struggling to give offenders the help they need quickly. They are also shackled by a shortage of community drug workers - a situation which has angered probation workers. "Recruitment problems should have been addressed before launching the scheme," says Harry Fletcher, of the National Association of Probation Officers. "Offenders can not wait six months for treatment."

The treatment on offer varies across the country. In Wakefield and Pontefract, West Yorkshire, complementary medicines have been offered alongside traditional detoxification programmes to offenders for the last three years. Addicts can receive a massage or auricular acupuncture to help treat their addiction, on top of conventional detoxification treatment. Small lapses are tolerated in the first few months, but any major lapses lead to a reappearance in a special drugs court and a possible prison sentence.

For Teri, one of Dasp's biggest success stories, the prospect of spending six months in prison was enough to persuade her to undergo treatment. She had started experimenting with drugs when she was 15, but it was not until she lost her job, at the age of 24, that her problems began. She had a live-in job at a hotel, but found herself homeless when the hotel suddenly closed down.

Teri says: "I was found somewhere to live in Truro which was full of dealers. I couldn't get a job and couldn't go back to college. I had nothing to do, so I started taking speed. After three or four months of playing about with speed, I started injecting. It was costing £500 a day so I started stealing and began shoplifting to order. If it cost more than £10 and wasn't nailed down I would take it."

She was caught several times and ended up on remand at Eastwood Park prison, Gloucester. With nine previous convictions for shoplifting and two for credit card fraud, she faced a minimum six-month jail sentence. Terrified by the prospect, she agreed to take part in the Dasp scheme as part of a two-year probation order. One of the conditions was spending the first 12 months living in a bail hostel in Camborne.

After five months on the programme, Teri was allowed to leave the hostel as she had been clear of street drugs and had committed no further crimes. Shortly afterwards, she was off drugs completely, her probation order was revoked and she was in her own flat. Two months ago, she started a new job as a waitress in a hotel.

Tough route to success

Thirty-four people in Cornwall have been placed on a Dasp order, including eight women. Others were referred to the community drugs team, but assessed as not suitable. Half have succeeded, or are continuing on the programme.

All have experienced a reduction in the use of street drugs; 78% no longer use them at all. Women are more likely to succeed than men; three-quarters of women succeeded.

Amphetamine users achieved better outcomes than heroin users, and those aged 25-32 were more likely to succeed.

Small lapses are tolerated in the first few months, but any major lapses lead to a reappearance in a special drugs court and a possible prison sentence. For Teri, one of Dasp's biggest success stories, the prospect of spending six months in prison was enough to persuade her to undergo treatment. She had started experimenting with drugs when she was 15, but it was not until she lost her job, at the age of 24, that her problems began. She had a live-in job at a hotel, but found herself homeless when the hotel suddenly closed down. Teri says: "I was found somewhere to live in Truro which was full of dealers. I couldn't get a job and couldn't go back to college. I had nothing to do, so I started taking speed. After three or four months of playing about with speed, I started injecting. It was costing £500 a day so I started stealing and began shoplifting to order. If it cost more than £10 and wasn't nailed down I would take it." She was caught several times and ended up on remand at Eastwood Park prison, Gloucester. With nine previous convictions for shoplifting and two for credit card fraud, she faced a minimum six-month jail sentence. Terrified by the prospect, she agreed to take part in the Dasp scheme as part of a two-year probation order. One of the conditions was spending the first 12 months living in a bail hostel in Camborne. After five months on the programme, Teri was allowed to leave the hostel as she had been clear of street drugs and had committed no further crimes. Shortly afterwards, she was off drugs completely, her probation order was revoked and she was in her own flat. Two months ago, she started a new job as a waitress in a hotel. Tough route to success Thirty-four people in Cornwall have been placed on a Dasp order, including eight women. Others were referred to the community drugs team, but assessed as not suitable. Half have succeeded, or are continuing on the programme. All have experienced a reduction in the use of street drugs; 78% no longer use them at all. Women are more likely to succeed than men; three-quarters of women succeeded. Amphetamine users achieved better outcomes than heroin users, and those aged 25-32 were more likely to succeed.

webTitle: Roma pay penalty as Uefa appeal fails

fields.headline: Roma pay penalty as Uefa appeal fails
fields.trailText: Roma's appeal against their Uefa Cup elimination by Liverpool has failed, Uefa announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Roma's appeal against their Uefa Cup elimination by Liverpool has failed, Uefa announced yesterday.

The Serie A leaders had claimed the performance of Jose-Maria Garcia Aranda, the referee who awarded them a penalty at Anfield only to change his mind and give a corner, was bad enough for the game to be replayed.

"As far as we are concerned the matter is now over and the result will stand," said a Uefa spokesman. "The referee has been marked by our assessors and that will play a part in which matches he is allocated in the future."

Uefa have fined Roma £15,000 and Liverpool £2,200 for their fans' behaviour during the first leg in Italy.

Meanwhile, Neil Lennon has spoken of his distress at receiving sectarian threats before Northern Ireland's friendly against Norway today.

Lennon, who is a Catholic, has been targeted by loyalists because of his decision to join Celtic and his revelation that he would like to play for an all-Ireland team. "It's been pretty upsetting for me and my family," he said. "I can't understand it and I'm just here to play football for my country."

He may not get the chance, as blizzard conditions across Ireland have jeopardised the friendly, along with the Republic's game against Denmark in Dublin, also tonight.

Mark Delaney, Aston Villa's injury-ravaged defender, has hurt his ankle in training and will miss Wales's two World Cup qualifiers next month.

fields.headline: Rioch resigns amid managerial mayhem
fields.trailText: Three Nationwide League managers lost their jobs yesterday, chief among the casualties the former Arsenal and Bolton manager Bruce Rioch at Wigan.
fields.body:
With the attention of the football world briefly turned away from the club game for this week's internationals, three Nationwide League managers lost their jobs yesterday.

The biggest surprise came at Wigan, where the former Arsenal and Bolton manager Bruce Rioch resigned only eight months after his arrival, with his club fourth in the table and within hours of negotiating a club-record transfer.

Colin Greenall, formerly player-coach, takes over as caretaker manager, and the £1.35m bid for Motherwell's striker Lee McCulloch and defender Steve McMillan remains on the table having been accepted by the Scottish club.

The other two departures had a ring of inevitability about them. Second Division Cambridge, after four successive defeats, sacked Roy McFarland, and Lincoln, who have lost five games in a row and are one point off the foot of the Third Division, terminated the contract of Phil Stant.

It was a bad day too for Crystal Palace and Norwich, both charged by the FA after a mass brawl during their First Division match on February 17, after which two players were sent off. Both sides have been fined this season for similar offences.

Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro also faces an FA charge - of violent conduct - for stamping on the Arsenal midfielder Freddie Ljungberg. His international side, Nigeria, have announced that they will play Japan in London on October 7; no venue has been chosen.

fields.headline: England 3 - 0 Spain
fields.standfirst: David Lacey's match report
fields.trailText: England: James, Phil Neville, Powell, Butt, Ferdinand, Campbell, Beckham, Scholes, Andy Cole, Owen, Barmby. Subs: Gary Neville, Martyn, Brown, Ehiogu, Phillips, Sheringham, Fowler, Heskey, Lampard, Carragher, Wright, Ball, McCann.
fields.body:
England: James, Phil Neville, Powell, Butt, Ferdinand, Campbell, Beckham, Scholes, Andy Cole, Owen, Barmby. Subs: Gary Neville, Martyn, Brown, Ehiogu, Phillips, Sheringham, Fowler, Heskey, Lampard, Carragher, Wright, Ball, McCann.

Spain: Casillas, Manuel Pablo, Romero, Guardiola, Abelardo, Mendieta, Raul, Enrique, Urzaiz Aranda, Helguera, Unai. Subs: Sergi, Canizares, Victor, J. Etxeberria, Javi Moreno, Baraja, Paco.

Referee: Kyros Vassaras (Greece)

1 Spain kick-off perhaps the most eagerly awaited England international in many years. Barmby has an early pop from 20 yards - well wide.
4 Both teams knocking the ball about eagerly in the opening minutes as they get the measure of each other. Early runs into both penalty boxes make for an open start.
5 Owen brings the ball down 40 yards out, lays it off to Beckham on the right, but Beckham's cross is blocked and Spain clear.
8 Owen again breaks through the middle and this finds Andy Cole to his right - Spain again alert to the threat and close Cole down.
12 New boy Powell gets in on the action when he breaks down the left and crosses from the by-line to Barmby in the six-yard box. Just a shame that Barmby didn't get to it first.
14 Hardly scintillating so far, as Spain build from the back again with Abelardo after another tentative push forward by England.
15 Ferdinand tries to send Owen away down the left with a long ball from deep, but Spain cut him off at the pass.
17 Pressure from Spain as Mendieta crosses from the edge of the England area - Campbell gets his head into clear. Another cross from the same position, but hesitation by Raul enables England to clear again.
19 Helguera fires in a looping shot from 30 yards, forcing James to save off the line. Spain's midfield dominating possession at the moment.
20 Scholes finds Barmby wide on the left but Barmby's cross is cleared easily. Hardly anything going down the right with Beckham at the moment.
23 Beckham tries to play the ball over the top but Phil Neville is caught offside.
24 Nothing dangerous from the boy Owen after a lively opening few minutes, but plenty of movement and touches behind last man Cole to keep things moving.
25 First real test for Casillas in the Spain goal when Scholes shoots from distance. Worth a go, but not really going anywhere if you see what I mean.
26 Powell again down the left but he is hassled to the by-line for a goal-kick.
31 England's first corner; Beckham from the left, Butt heads to the near post from 10 yards and Casillas claims.
32 Better by England as they build rapidly from the back and Owen goes through onside from the edge of the area, but the ball gets away and Casillas again claims.
36 Spain take up residence in the England half before England can clear with a goal-kick.
37 GOAL: England 1 - 0 Spain Scholes comes close when Owen's cross from the right by-line is put to his feet by Manuel Pablo, but surprise gets the better of the England midfielder. From the clearance, Owen loops the ball over the top to Barmby running through into the area; Barmby looks up, sees Casillas charging out to meet him and squeezes a right-foot shot past the Spain keeper for the opener.
43 Cole shoots from 20 yards to force Casillas down for a save.
45 Scholes releases Barmby on the left but his crossfield pass looking for Owen is anticipated well by Casillas. Cole then tees up Owen in the Spain area, but Owen just fails to tease his shot around Casillas and into the far corner. Half-time. So-so to start with, but England plugged away and came alive towards the end of the half despite Spain's best attempts to close things down with tight control and possession.

46 Substitutions Martyn, Ehiogu, Ball, Lampard, McCann and Heskey on for James, Ferdinand, Powell, Butt, Scholes and Beckham. Paco and Moreno on for Spain. Early chance by Lampard as his right-foot shot fizzes just wide of the post.
48 Early corner for England as Spain are caught napping; comes to nothing.
49 Another corner for England taken by Lampard; again, nothing doing.
51 Helguera 'tests' Martyn with a tame cross.
55 GOAL: England 2 - 0 Spain Lampard's corner is knocked down by Ehiogu on the six-yard line for Heskey to prod home.
57 Spain free-kick from 25 yards, Unai fires high and wide. From the goal-kick Spain push up again for Moreno to fire across the goalmouth from the right.
59 England corner, Lampard takes and Spain clear off the line after a knock-on.
62 England corner, easy for Casillas.
64 Substitutions Canizares, Sergi and Victor on for Casillas, Mendieta and Enrique.
67 Lots of movement and lots of possession and lots confidence from England, but nothing really to report as the game hits a lull.
69 GOAL: England 3 - 0 Spain But then, what do you know... Ehiogu wanders onto the six-yard line completely unmarked to head Lampard's cross into the roof of the net.
75 Spain corner. Victor takes and England clear.
78 Substitution Gary Neville on for Phil Neville.
79 Penalty Harsh for Ehiogu when he is deemed to have brought down Moreno. All academic after Martyn saves.
81 Substitutions Etxeberria and Baraja on for Raul and Guardiola.
83 Barmby unlucky to be caught offside when away on goal.
84 Spain corner, cleared for Sergi to fire high into the crowd.
87 Heskey gets away on the right and opts for a wayward cross to the far post from distance when he should perhaps have pushed on with Spain short at the back.
89 Helguera releases Etxeberria to the right of the England area and his cross is cleared under pressure by Ball for a corner. Comes to nothing.
90 Early smiles for Eriksson on the bench as the final whistle approaches. Lampard peels away on the left of the Spain area as England seek to keep play in the opposition half and maintain a clean sheet. Etxeberria fires wide of the Martyn's right-hand post as the ref blows for full-time.

fields.headline: A Gainsborough for the 21st century
fields.standfirst:
Julian Opie
Lisson Gallery
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Julian Opie
Lisson Gallery
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Julian Opie is hot right now because he did the cover of The Best of Blur. The four neat portraits from the CD, posters and Top of the Pops backdrop appear in the window of the Lisson Gallery. The band's faces are mocked a little by their reduction to empty black lines and easy-match colours; they are captioned - with false workerism - Alex, bassist; Dave, drummer; Graham, guitarist; and Damon, singer.

Yet in reality, these portraits are smugly celebratory. They imply that Blur are just like us, dress like us, think like us - if we dress right and are seen at all the right places. The people in Opie's show, with their cut-out hairstyles and perfunctory noses, all belong in the same world. He imagines them nude on the beach, or driving through mountains and towns.

Wait a minute, though. This is not pop. This is the culture of the contemporary British middle class, to whom Opie has appointed himself a slickly ironic Gainsborough. The very thing about his portraits that makes them jokey - the assimilation of everyone to the same conventions - also establishes group identity. Opie has everyone in designer-casual clothes, just as Gainsborough portrayed every gentleman in a wig, and the effect is the same: to establish membership of a group, in Gainsborough's case the 18th-century gentry; in Opie's - well, people who buy The Best of Blur.

It's interesting that Opie never portrays anyone really glamorous. Wolfgang Tillmans and Gary Hume (whom you might think similar to Opie because they celebrate beautiful contemporary people) depict real icons and stars among the young clubbers and artists; the lustre of a Kate Moss has a destabilising effect and is anything but reassuring to the viewer.

Opie, by contrast, never acknowledges that anyone is more or less good-looking or socially powerful than the level playing field he allows. Anyone is welcome to his local gastro-pub so long as they don't act big. This goes for Blur too. Blur are fine with that because they are not starry or cocky. They are the boys next door.

Opie's exhibition is contemporary British art at its worst, over-friendly with its knowing audience and flattering to nationalist cultural delusions. Try saying this with a straight face: "Blur are going to be remembered as a great band, and Opie's album cover is right up there with Warhol's peel-it-and-see banana for The Velvet Underground." You wonder how long art can ride this wave of fashion before it crashes down and the good is drowned along with the mediocre.

 Until March 17. Details: 020-7724 2739.

webTitle: Theatre review: Passports to the Promised Land

fields.headline: Theatre you can sing along to
fields.standfirst:
Passports to the Promised Land
Greenwich Theatre
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Passports to the Promised Land
Greenwich Theatre
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It is 1959. Eighteen-year-old Jordan Brown, sent by his vengeful mother to look for his father, who has emigrated to England, drowns when he falls off the boat taking him from Trinidad to Britain. Instead of finding himself clutching his British passport at immigration control, Jordan finds himself facing St Peter at the pearly gates. Getting into the promised land is difficult, whichever way you look at it.

Felix Cross's musical about those who came to Britain in search of a better life spans time (from 1959 to the present day) and place (heaven and earth) to tell the story of two families - their feuds and loves and, above all, their experience of immigration. The music is always better than the drama, but the evening has such a tongue-in-cheek good humour and brings its protagonists' personal histories so vividly to life that you can't help feeling well disposed towards it.

There is a generosity of spirit about this musical and a sense of sad truth too. It always paints in bold strokes, whether dealing with the black civil servant who knows Greek and Latin but never gets promoted from filing clerk because of his skin colour, or the woman who buys a large old house nobody wants in Notting Hill in 1959 and 40 years later finds herself sitting on a gold mine that will pay for her retirement in Trinidad. There is fun to be had from the snobbish Gloria, who goes native, taking a job in the Upper Crust tea rooms in Weybridge and speaking like the Queen.

Best of all, though, is Cross's music, a wondrous, distinctive melting-pot of melodies and styles. It draws on traditional Caribbean music as well as religious requiems and chants to create a seamless piece of contemporary black music theatre that is both celebratory and reflective, populist and musically sophisticated.

The raggedness of the rather contrived storyline can sometimes grate, but the dynamic cast paper over the cracks and sing like angels as they tell how the struggle really begins once you enter the promised land.

 Until March 10. Box office: 020-8858 7755. Then touring to Manchester, Ipswich, Exeter and Sheffield.

fields.headline: Vertavo Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Royal Northern College of Music
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Northern College of Music
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Norway's Vertavo Quartet are fast establishing themselves as one of the freshest and most versatile young quartets around. Their rock and jazz collaborations suggest parallels with the Kronos Quartet, and, like them, the Vertavo have a very distinctive sound. But what impresses most is the integrity and imagination they bring to their playing.

Their programme was designed to allow each player more or less equal prominence, a democratic approach that extended to the first and second violins exchanging roles for one work. By and large, their shaken-but-not-stirred sound works extremely well, being subtly blended but not blandly homogeneous. It may be an extension of that approach that their playing seemed on the nervy side: suave sophistication is not their style. While this works for Janacek and Britten, for example, it does not sit so comfortably with Schubert.

There cannot have been many performances of Schubert's Rosamunde Quartet as unremittingly dark as this one. Even the lyrical andante was played with a choked intensity that questioned its innocence, and the trio section of the menuetto was similarly oppressed - a strong rubato dispelling any illusion of security by shifting the ground from under its own feet. The troubled spirit of this work was close to the surface in a way that could appear extreme: when warmth and lyricism are constantly negated, poignancy is also lost. Overall, though, there was much to admire, and this was a performance with real vision.

Textural refinement is at a premium in Britten's Second Quartet. Its spidery dialogues and ghostly colouring present considerable problems of balance and control, which were, in the main, overcome. While the nervous energy of the second movement seemed to play straight into the Vertavo's hands, the first movement's opening was delicately luminous, and the final chacony robust and assertive.

But it was in Janacek's First Quartet that they came into their own. Based on Tolstoy's Kreutzer Sonata, the work oscillates between irrational violence and fragile tenderness. With phenomenal expressive flexibility, the Vertavo moved from warmest sensuality to knife-edge brittleness. The real revelation came at the end, where a sudden move to the major almost suggests a final uplift. It resonated with an anguished, insane hysteria that made a shattering impact.

Their rock and jazz collaborations suggest parallels with the Kronos Quartet, and, like them, the Vertavo have a very distinctive sound. But what impresses most is the integrity and imagination they bring to their playing. Their programme was designed to allow each player more or less equal prominence, a democratic approach that extended to the first and second violins exchanging roles for one work. By and large, their shaken-but-not-stirred sound works extremely well, being subtly blended but not blandly homogeneous. It may be an extension of that approach that their playing seemed on the nervy side: suave sophistication is not their style. While this works for Janacek and Britten, for example, it does not sit so comfortably with Schubert. There cannot have been many performances of Schubert's Rosamunde Quartet as unremittingly dark as this one. Even the lyrical andante was played with a choked intensity that questioned its innocence, and the trio section of the menuetto was similarly oppressed - a strong rubato dispelling any illusion of security by shifting the ground from under its own feet. webTitle: Classical review: A Day for Gubaidulina

fields.headline: A Day for Gubaidulina
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Russian composer Sofia Gubaidulina turns 70 this year. She belongs to the post-Shostakovich generation of Alfred Schnittke and Edison Denisov, and her distinctive music uses wild, modernist gestures to create a lucid, expressive world. The Centre for Russian Music's day of concerts at the Purcell Room was London's only celebration of her birthday.

The Moscow Quartet's performance of the four string quartets revealed the physicality of her music. She demands extreme performance techniques, from violent bow-strokes to passages for the left hand alone, in which the players tap, stroke and generally abuse their fingerboards. This is a music as much about texture and timbre as it is about pitches and rhythms.

The First Quartet even requires the players to move gradually to the edge of the platform, creating a visual parallel for the fragmentation of the music. The Third Quartet is a study in contrasting sound-worlds, as an unsettled pizzicato section is followed by a sensuous, bowed passage.

But even in the conviction of these performances there was something impenetrable about the music. This is partly because the power of individual pieces was diluted by being played alongside every other work Gubaidulina has written for string quartet. After a while, every contrast, no matter how dramatic, began to sound hackneyed.

And for all the vividness of particular moments - such as the memorably obsessive emphasis on a single pitch at the opening of the Second Quartet - the effect of the structures as a whole was more confusing than coherent. There is a sense of the baroque about Gubaidulina's imagery, as if each gesture has a precisely defined spiritual or emotional reference; but it was hard to divine the symbols' meanings.

Jean-Pierre Armengaud's recital of the piano music gave glimpses of a forceful imagination in her piano writing, but he seemed ill at ease with the technical requirements.

Cellist Alexander Ivashkin performed the pithy 10 Preludes, and was joined by Elsbeth Moser in an arrangement for bayan (a Russian accordion) of In Croce, a piece originally written for cello and organ. Quaternion, for cello quartet, concluded this concert, and its conflict between two cellos tuned a quarter-tone flatter than their colleagues contains potentially fascinating music. But in the context of a day of Gubaidulina's music, it came across as indigestible.

fields.headline: Les Arts Florissants
fields.standfirst:
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Purcell's Dido and Aeneas has always been considered the greatest of all English operas, though its origins, shrouded in mystery, have become the subject of considerable speculation of late.

It was long believed that it was written for a girls' finishing school in Chelsea, but it is now widely regarded as having been composed for performance at the court of Charles II and modelled on the short operas that were popular across the Channel at the court of Louis XIV. Marc-Antoine Charpentier's Actéon has been suggested as a likely prototype.

There is no evidence for this, though the tale of the mythical Actaeon's demise - he is turned into a stag and ripped apart by his own hounds after he spied on Diana bathing - is narrated in Purcell's opera as an intimation of disaster.

William Christie and Les Arts Florissants are allowing us to make up our own minds by performing the operas together in a semi-staged production by Vincent Broussard, garbed in designer chic by Christian Lacroix. The evening doesn't solve any musicological quibbles, though it does throw Purcell's genius into sharp relief by placing Dido alongside Charpentier's less successful achievement. Purcell's tragedy progresses seamlessly by immaculately welding sound to sense in a series of brief numbers; Charpentier dawdles through a sequence of extended, closed forms, proceeding by juddery fits and starts.

Christie unearthed some beautifully pellucid textures, though the singing suffered from an absence of power. The characters of Actéon belong in the mythic-titanic tradition of classical French drama, but here they were robbed of their dignity. Sophie Daneman's Diana wasn't so much a goddess as a stroppy teenager. Paul Agnew's Actéon admirably suggested the man's fierce chastity, though you got little sense of the athletic huntsman.

Charpentier adds a twist to the myth by having the whole catastrophe engineered by the implacable Juno, who stalks the characters like some Racinian obsessive, and Stéphanie D'Oustrac stole the vocal honours with her terrifying outbursts of rage. Broussard's staging seemed to have been derived from Ionesco's Chairs and had the cast stumbling through impeding furniture, for some reason.

Dido fared better, but there were problems here too. There were moments of intense intimacy for the lovers, but the supernatural scenes lacked fire. Musicology deems the sorceress and her crew to be comic, despite the majesty of much of theirmusic. Christie and Broussard follow suit, casting counter-tenor Michel Puissant as the sorceress and having him caper round the platform like Graham Norton, which breaks the mood in a disastrous way.

D'Oustrac returns as an anguished Dido, and there's a very impressive Aeneas from Nicolas Rivenq, who suggests his passion for the queen may only be skin-deep from the off.

Done properly, Purcell's opera should leave you in bits. On this occasion, I was only intermittently moved.

webTitle: Byers forced to recognise regional divide

fields.headline: Byers forced to recognise regional divide
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Money
Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers acknowledged yesterday that there were still "unacceptably wide economic gaps" between British regions after official figures showed the north-south divide is widening.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers acknowledged yesterday that there were still "unacceptably wide economic gaps" between British regions after official figures showed the north-south divide is widening.

Average income per head in London was £16,859 in 1999, according to the office for national statistics, while in the country's poorest region, the north-east, it was £10,024.

London has increased its advantage over the rest of the country since Labour came to power, according to the ONS figures. In 1997, the wealth gap between it and the poorest region was £5,965 per head of population. By 1999 it had risen to £6,835.

Mr Byers said the figures showed why an active regional industrial strategy was essential. "Our regions were at the heart of the industrial revolution," he said. "They must now be at the centre of the knowledge-based economy of the future."

His admission that regional disparities are unsustainable marks a change of heart within the government which has in the past dismissed talk of a north-south divide as over-simplification.

With an election thought likely in the spring, Labour is aware that it needs to shore up support in its traditional manufacturing heartlands.

A senior official of the Bank of England denied that Threadneedle Street had kept interest rates unnecessarily high because it was biased towards keeping inflation down.

The Bank's deputy governor, Mervyn King, rejected suggestions from MPs on the Treasury select committee that Threadneedle Street preferred to undershoot rather than overshoot its 2.5% target for inflation. "I don't think there is any reason to suppose there is a systematic bias in the way that we approach [the target]," he said.

fields.headline: Euro-twist to Abbey saga
fields.standfirst:
Tie-up with Bank of Scotland and continental partner could fend off Lloyds bid

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Abbey National and Bank of Scotland are considering a complex plan to bring a continental European partner into their proposed merger.
fields.body:
Abbey National and Bank of Scotland are considering a complex plan to bring a continental European partner into their proposed merger.

The move is one of the strategies being explored by the two banks as they look for ways to sweeten the terms of their planned merger and see off Lloyds TSB's unwanted £19bn bid for Abbey.

Abbey and BoS are understood to feel they have been given a chance to complete their attempted merger by the government's decision to refer the Lloyds bid to the competition commission for a full investigation.

While a June 12 deadline has been set for the competition investigation, to be chaired by deputy commissioner Denise Kingsmill, it is unlikely to be published until mid-July.

Abbey and BoS have been discussing a nil-premium merger, essentially an exchange of each other's shares, since last year.

But they were effectively stalled when Lloyds TSB attempted to spoil the talks by making a bid for Abbey after its negotiations with BoS were leaked.

While shareholders in Abbey and BoS might have been prepared to accept a merger before Lloyds' intervention, they are now expected to demand a higher price for Abbey's shares after Lloyds revealed it was willing to inject some cash into its offer.

Speculation is mounting in the City that if BoS and Abbey decide to press ahead with their merger in the face of the competition investigation they will need to find a way of injecting that cash into their offer.

One way of doing this would be forging an alliance with a large European company, most likely an insurance firm. If such a partner could be found, it might be able to allow the banks to argue to their shareholders that they have a clear, long-term strategy for growth, particularly in mainland Europe where Lloyds has promised to expand but is yet to announce a deal.

It is not expected that the European partner would need to be involved in a three-way, full-scale merger. But it could involve the continental group paying cash for a stake in the combined group. This money would then be passed on to shareholders.

Industry sources said last night it was far from clear that this scenario would be the one that was ultimately chosen.

It is understood that Abbey and BoS, whose board met yesterday to discuss their options, have not yet decided whether to press ahead with their merger before the outcome of the competition investigation is known.

Among the options being considered is to present the terms of the merger to shareholders before the end of March.

This would allow the merger to be completed before mid-July when the Department of Trade and Industry will need to make its decision public.

Shareholders, for now, are indicating that they would rather wait for the verdict from the competition commission as to whether the Lloyds TSB bid for Abbey would be against the public interest.

Mrs Kingsmill, the deputy commissioner who will head the investigation, has run a number of high-profile inquiries, including the controversial study of car prices in Britain.

She resigned her non-executive board position at Norwich and Peterborough Building Society last week to help avoid any accusations of bias.
